  <page>
    <title>The Lavender Manor</title>
    <ns>0</ns>
    <id>162180</id>
    <revision>
      <id>259884</id>
      <parentid>258727</parentid>
      <timestamp>2024-04-30T17:11:13Z</timestamp>
      <contributor>
        <username>EpicGamerOlm</username>
        <id>45206575</id>
      </contributor>
      <origin>259884</origin>
      <model>wikitext</model>
      <format>text/x-wiki</format>
      <text bytes="4069" sha1="dvj3fjxvw19kbsz4uoi1y88hkdciynz" xml:space="preserve">'''''[[User:EpicGamerOlm|EpicGamerOlm]]''''' '''made this.'''  

== '''Chapter 1 Best Friends''' ==
It... used to be so great... we hung out almost every day, rain or shine, night or day, it didn't matter... Autumn, brought sunshine wherever she went... Also cheered us up when we got down... her sister Summer always made beautiful art... Joey, he was so smart he knew the solution to every problem, Luna they were the second oldest they were always "the leader" taking charge and organizing time to hang out, and... Christopher, the brown Dire wolf he was the oldest he... he was so... nice to talk to he always had the best advice... he... always knew how to make you smile, and then there's me, Jerramy, a blue fennec fox... I was... the youngest, that's all I ever was...

The day we lost Christopher was a day I will never forget, it started out normally we were hanging out at Balloosh... just exploring... But then... a scream... A terrifying scream that never ceases to play in my head... echoing... reminding me... we ran to the source of the noise at the eerie outskirts of Balloosh, and it was... Her... it was Peck... The Bunny alpha... She was unconscious, Christopher ran to get help and told us to stay here, after what felt like hours... She woke up... and... Christopher didn't come back...

Peck told us she "got in a really bad fight," and it "wasn't safe here,"

We told her about Christopher, and she told us that she and the other Alphas would look for him, but we needed to get back to Balloosh. After three days of no answers... Peck came back... and said four words that broke us...

"We couldn't find him,"

Things just weren't the same without him we hung out less and less until it just stopped, I hadn't seen them in years, which made this invitation all the more surprising. I was alone in my den like usual, when I heard knocking, I slowly walked toward the door and opened it, but nobody was there. I was about to close the door when I saw it, a strange black card with gold accents and text... I read the front and stood there frozen for a moment.

"Christopher?"

It was an invitation to a party from Christopher. I stared at the card thinking, was it some kind of sick joke, I didn't know what to do, I finally just opened the card, and it showed a map of Jamaa with a red "X" on the outskirts of Balloosh, it was the same place we lost him. I again stared at it, was I supposed to go here? I debated on what to do when I finally decided to investigate. I grabbed the card and walked back into my den.

I grabbed my sword... I wasn't going back... there... unprepared... I walked back outside and started the long trek to Balloosh...

After an hour of walking, I finally arrived in Balloosh, I was almost there... I looked back at the card to see where the "X" was and started walking in that direction. After a little more walking, I saw Luna, Joey, Summer, and Autumn they were all talking with each other, confused.

"...J... Jerramy.... it's... been so long...." Luna said,

Luna was a Tiger with white fur and purple stripes, they were wearing a Purple hoodie and a moon necklace.

Autumn walked over to me and said, "Did you get one too?"

Autumn, was a yellow coyote, she was wearing a causal orange dress and flower crown.

"This?" I say, holding out the card.

"...How... Could... who did this..." Jerramy questioned confused..

Jerramy was an orange kangaroo he was wearing a white shirt and a green jacket.

"It wasn't me..." Luna responded

"I don't think any of us could have done this..." Summer responded

Summer was an orange kangaroo, she was wearing a brown hoodie and a yellow scarf.

"The best thing we can do is to keep going..." Luna said

Everyone nodded an we starting walking yet again... and... we reached something... an eerie purple manor, it looked old but not weathered...

Before any of us could... say a word... It... the door opened... and out came... him...

"Hello Everyone, are you ready for the party?

== '''Chapter 2 I Remember You''' ==

      <text bytes="494" sha1="byyibbsv4w4aeaxjhfyszj58zxmupf2" xml:space="preserve">Sir Gilbert Tigris was a strong man. Tall. Could be deemed handsome, although his looks were definitely fading. But the factor most people talked about was his strength.

He came from a country in war, and was forced into fighting. He learnt fast, well, and was talented. He never really thought much of his world, until he received his first vision. He'd grew to never clarify as to what it was, but it changed him. He turned the tide.

  <page>
    <title>Jezalyn Helios</title>
    <ns>0</ns>
    <id>162182</id>
    <revision>
      <id>258133</id>
      <parentid>258132</parentid>
      <timestamp>2023-07-29T02:33:40Z</timestamp>
      <contributor>
        <username>Auryze</username>
        <id>43449826</id>
      </contributor>
      <comment>/* History */</comment>
      <origin>258133</origin>
      <model>wikitext</model>
      <format>text/x-wiki</format>
      <text bytes="11399" sha1="o1h9tzy77j1wv3gtt20ogkgngsrckp9" xml:space="preserve">''Made by Auryze lol''{{Character_idk|title1=Jezalyn Helios|image1=Jezalyn_-3.png|nickname=Jeza &lt;small&gt;(by everyone)&lt;/small&gt;|age=27-33|height=5'8|species=Faerie &lt;small&gt;(implied)&lt;/small&gt;|status=Deceased|job=Sorceress &lt;small&gt;(formerly)&lt;/small&gt;&lt;br&gt;Florist|residence=Emeraldine|alignment=Good|relatives=Locaster Helios &lt;small&gt;(son)&lt;/small&gt;&lt;br&gt;Yuna Hanamura &lt;small&gt;(distant niece)&lt;/small&gt;&lt;br&gt;Shay Hanamura &lt;small&gt;(distant nephew)&lt;/small&gt;|affiliation=|allies=Damion Halloreen, resistance members, Locaster Helios|enemies=Blood Moon, Loid|gender=Female|Ethnicity=Tswana 🇧🇼}}

'''Jezalyn Helios''' was a minor character in a Good vs. Evil roleplay. She was the mother of the wizard prodigy, [[Locaster Helios]] and the wife of [[Damion Halloreen]]. She was one of the main contributors in defeating the once powerful army known as the Blood Moon in order for the village of Emeraldine to have independence. 

== History ==
Not much is known about Jezalyn's personal life: As she is a minor character, she does not make much appearances within the series, but is frequently mentioned by Locaster or her husband. 

Jezalyn was born somewhere in Emeraldine during their stages of developing as a village. Jezalyn was described to be a rather bright and optimistic girl, always having a smile on her face and always wanting to learn new things, and was curious about the other kingdoms cultures and magic. She was educated mainly by her mother and multiple tutors, leading her to grow  and  be a very keen intellect when she entered her teenage years. 

Though one morning, a military army known as the Blood Moon had invaded the village after the discovery of Emeraldine having powerful magic: At first, they had stated they wanted to assist in the growth of the village, easing the people's worry and welcoming them with open arms before they had taken over the village and had the main general, Loid, as their sole dictator. Jezalyn had went into hiding along with many other individuals after the soldiers begun taking away the magic from other users to fuel their army, even taking away one of the most powerful users magic without difficulty, and were willing to target more of the magic users in her area.  

The Blood Moon started to enforced strict rules on the village and whoever had fallen out of line would be killed, or if any of them had magic it would be removed from their body system. The Blood Moon had then took away the people's will to express themselves freely, To which was a big belief in the village at the time, meaning that if they ever spoke out against them, they would die. 

As this continued for many years, a resistance had formed with Jezalyn in its center after she had formed it for the remaining magic users in the area. She had made sure every member of hers was fed and started to grow more mature and serious throughout, though she had still remained optimistic and kind. The resistance had begun scrapping the last bits of magic there was to spare from the magic tree for survival. Though, when searching for magic to store, she had found a helio gem that could trap in large amounts of magic and stores it in for a long time. After it was filled up with enough magic, she decided to place it on a book, leading to the creation of the orsella spellbook. 

When realizing the magic was able to function and work as a spellbook, Jezalyn begun practicing the spells from the book until she was fluent at maneuvering and activating the spells, before making the big decision to fight the general Loid in order to try and allow Emeraldine to gain its independence from military rule, something she was planning to do for a long time but was held back due to the risks. After months of deciding and careful planning, Jezalyn took this risk and decided to face off Loid, having the risk of ending up dead or coming back alive, but with the cost of losing her spell-book and natural magic. 

After sneaking outside and intentionally causing a distraction for the guards by dropping the book to create a loud noise, she had managed to defeat them with ease, catching the eyes of the unimpressionable, yet boastful Loid. As she begun taking down more of the guards, Loid too had joined in after she managed to get rid of the back-up to prevent any interference. 

Though, the fight began turning brutal as Jezalyn's injuries began to multiply, starting minor at first but became more severe as the fight went on due to both Loid and her having the same amount of strength and magic. As Jezalyn was nearly defeated and Loid was going to take away her spell-book, she had murmured a spell that had pierced him with multiple shadow vines, killing him. Jezalyn then used another spell to remove the guards from the area and into a far forest, then going inside the headquarters to release the magic stolen from those who had lost their own after a long time.  

After the successful defeat of the Blood Moon, Emeraldine was now independent again and began to grow as a village, never being involved in conflict whatsoever due to its already developing state. Jezalyn, after creating her spell-book, began to improve her usage of magic and started to learn more spells she would use in the future and became rather well known within the community, being known as one of the most powerful sorceresses in the village as many other beginner magic users started to come to her for advice and she started to do more heavy work for the population.     

As the community began to grow and the population began to increase, the military was in the stages of being formed, as they were in need of a form of protection that was not reliant on their magic, as many of the villagers had no experience in combat. Multiple kingdoms had taken interest in Emeraldine and sent troops to form the army, one of them being [[Damion Halloreen]], a lieutenant colonel from the [https://wildworks-writing.fandom.com/wiki/Five_Kingdoms#Elveria Elverian] navy after meeting him at the front gates of the villages, immediately becoming fascinated with him. Both of them matched in strengths, Jezalyn for her intelligence and Damion with his skills from the military.      

The two of them started speaking to each-other and even worked together well due to their similar interests and high intelligence, and the both of them had an unusually good relationship and were sometimes seen doing partner-work with one another and constantly spending time watching the sunset or the sunrise: As their bond continued to grow, they begun having a romantic relationship with one another after Damion had confessed his feelings for her while walking with her in the fields by saying he always had warm feelings for Jezalyn due to her caring for him and Damion doing the same.         

After their confession, the both of them started to work together much more frequently and started to get more intimate with one another and after many years, the two of them had gotten married and were very happy to be by each-others side. According to Damion, Jezalyn and him had many traits in common, such as her intelligence, wit and views on the world. Eventually, Damion and Jezalyn had gotten married after he proposed to her and they had a child together. During her time raising Locaster, she was both his teacher and his mother and took an interest in teaching him about magic.             

== Appearance ==
Jezalyn was a tall, slender woman with dark skin, purple eyes and beige-white hair extending to her lower back, She is sometimes seen with light blue markings around her face and arms, indicating she could have been a faerie. On her left ear, she has two golden double hooped earrings, to which she never had taken off.  

Jezalyn wore a dark purple hat with a lighter purple rimming that situated on the top of her head, slightly leaning to the left side. Around her neck is layers of purple scarves that had some gold designing on them to cover the rest of her body and a light purple coat that hanged on to her back, donning a long, purple dress with frilled sleeves and a detailed skirt, white socks and strapped brown shoes. 

During her teenager years, Jezalyn had waist-length hair with a minor scratch on her face. she wore a simple shirt and pants with a black cloak wrapped around her.
== Personality ==
Not much of Jezalyn is seen throughout the role-play despite being frequently mentioned by Locaster. Though, according to Damion, she was a very hardworking, kind yet understanding woman, listening to others who talked to her and always offered advice. Despite her kind nature, she has demonstrated to be very intelligent and serious: She usually puts her family first before anything else, including her son, [[Locaster Helios|Locaster]] and her husband whom she loves dearly. She has been seen in flashbacks as a loving and educated woman, teaching her son about magic and skills he would need to ensure his survival and worked hard alongside her husband to live comfortably in Emeraldine.

According to Damion, despite her kind demeanor, she has shown to be very determined about something she wants to achieve, either for herself or someone else in her life. She has shown to have a good bond with Locaster and enjoyed teaching him magic and other spells.  

== Abilities ==
'''Overall Abilites''': Since Jezalyn was never mentioned or seen in flashbacks frequently, it is unknown what her abilities were like: However, according to Damion, he had said that Jezalyn was an extremely powerful sorceress that was able to take on many advanced military agents and successfully get them out of Emeraldine if anyone had tried to conquer with above average physical prowess and extreme endurance when having deadly wounds by Loid and his men. 

'''Leadership Skills:''' Jezalyn, despite being young when the Blood Moon had taken over, has demonstrated to have extreme leadership skills, having the capability to lead thousands of people without difficulty by using an assertive and calm voice to sway those around her without trying to entice fear in others. She has shown to have the capability to lead a crowd of people without having to use fear or her position.      

== Magic Abilities ==
'''Orsella Spellbook:''' After creating it through a single helio gem and a large book she had in her hideout, Jezalyn was the first owner of the Orsella Spellbook, passing the spellbook onto her son, Locaster.  Jezalyn has demonstrated to have mastered most spells, being able to control large spells without much difficulty and is able to carry it without it having to drag down her body due to the amount of pages, around over fourteen million pages that contain powerful and dangerous spells alike. Even when she was younger, she had managed to use large spells without difficulty.   

== Weaknesses ==
'''Overuse:''' Despite Jezalyn not being a demon, her main weakness was overusing her spellbook, which can cause her to have fatigue-like symptoms whenever overusing her magic abilities. If she were to over use it to a certain extent, she, like a demon, can fall asleep for multiple days or weeks. 

== Relationships ==

=== [[Damion Halloreen]] ===
Damion was Jezalyn's then husband before her death. As seen in flashbacks, both of them exhibit a strong love for one another

      <text bytes="104312" sha1="j0a2wra0yr4niqothajpaab4n7a7tqd" xml:space="preserve">[[Universe - Volume I|[ Volume I ]]]

== Confluence ==
Mercury felt bad. Really bad. 

He'd always been tuned in to people's emotions. He hated when people cried- More than any other person, at least. It made him want to cry too. He practically felt it as his own emotion.

His dad worked in computer repair and in a huge accident, his brother accidentally got electrocuted. He got a mild burn and was crying. The mild burn healed faster than what Mercury thought it might heal in, but Mercury still felt the pain.

And now that his brother's closest friends had died, his spirit was down as well. He couldn't quit, though. He needed to make sure his brother didn't do something stupid and die when he wasn't looking.  

If he became a Beta, though... Would Zenith and Polaroid stay alive? It was hard to think about. He didn't want to think about it. Not since yesterday. Heck, not since Monday. 

Mercury pressed a pillow to his face, feeling his hair turn from solid to liquid, little droplets floating about. He didn't want them to die. It made him mad. Almost as mad as his brother usually got. He took some deep breathes, and the drops fell, dripping onto the pillow and the hand holding it. 

He took it off, and went up the Ètare, and minutes after was knocking at Polaroid's door. After a little bit of bonding, he kind of already knew how to get to him. 

"Polaroid? It's Mercury. Can I come in?" Mercury called. 

And that familiar face opened up. Mercury stepped inside. 

It took about three hours of talking, but Polaroid asked Mercury to come to a sleepover at one of his friends' dorm. Mercury accepted. 

They still had time to spare, anyway. 
----The night soon came, and lights began to be snuffed out. Mercury had prepared a bag filled with things he considered necessary, such as a sleeping bag and snacks.  

Mercury still didn't feel really good, but it felt a little better to know his friend cared for him. His friends had let him in, too, so maybe it was a shot to make even more friends. 

At least feeling what others feel made friendships easier. He had a smile plastered onto his face, and in the slowly approaching darkness, reached for the door.   

"Hey! I'm Vertex Zaragoza!"   

A girl with thick, curly, messy hair and pink eyes outstretched her hand for Mercury to take. And he did.    

"Mercury Mercier. Polaroid probably already told you I was coming, right?" He asked.   

"Yep! Come on in!" She said.   

In the room were three people, not including Polaroid, who did him the favor of introducing them as Damini Axelson, Cyro Zacharias Edwards, and Encelad Rossi.    

The room, as rooms often did when Mercury was there, soon lightened up. And then Vertex decided it was time to tell spooky stories.    

Mercury gave the room one last look.    

It was already creepy enough, with weird goo covering the walls, bed, stools being covered in spines, the armoire having an eye that seemed to be staring at him, but when the lights were off, it was as if he was in the Titanic, and water burst through the walls and floor, and he was covered in it.    

The water was his friend. This wasn't water.    

This was ink.    

"Ten years ago, in my country, there was a war," Vertex began.   

"In my native language, we called it Waene Ukito. It translates roughly to Duality Wave. We call it that because the neighboring country suffered an explosion of some sort, so did we. The King and Queen's chests suddenly expanded, and eyewitnesses state they exploded from the inside out, drenching the throne room." Vertex stated.   

"The current rulers are their children, whose incubators were not blown up, were kept there until they were believed to be safe. Frozen in time, the older one was thawed out a year after, while the younger one, three. However, we fear if they grow older, they may suffer the same fate as their parents." Vertex let out a little sigh.   

"So they sent a teenage girl into the outside world to find a wish. And she tried, and tried. They say she hasn't returned since. They say in the dead of night, in an empty highway, if you see tentacles approaching," The ink started to dance onto Mercury's lap, "And hear heavy breathing, feel it right next to you, right down your neck," Down his neck, "Run the hell away. Drive as fast as you can. Don't go back, because she'll sense you."    

And Mercury felt scared, because he could feel the ink, and looked down and saw it, and with a burst of boiling water, got rid of it.    

"Ow! Do you have any idea how much it hurts to have those cut off?" Vertex said, as the lights turned back on abruptly, and she rubbed her tentacles as they recoiled back into her, well, back.    

"Sorry, I didn't know what they were!" Mercury said.   

"Now ya get how it feels," Cyro muttured.   

"Babe, you and I both know you wouldn't have told that guy off," Encelad gripped Cyro's hand.   

"I know, an' I hate the fact that I didn't! It's like my feelin's suddenly froze up an' I couldn't let out anythin' but a, yeah, it's cool, sure I can handle life without proper depth perception!" Cyro ranted.   

"I know you do. I know you did. You can't change the past. Let's handle the present," Encelad told him.   

Mercury could understand both sides.     

He didn't know what to say, though.     

He felt bad. At least he knew that.     

"Hey, how about we change up the topic? Let's play, uh... Truth or Dare! Yeah. Truth or Dare. It's... I... It's the first thing I thought of. Don't look at me that way." Damini said as the rest of the room stared at her.    

"It's okay. I think it's a pretty good idea. Might help us get to know each other better. Maybe it'll get interesting. Who knows?" Mercury tried to comfort her, even though she didn't really need comforting.    

"Yeah, uh, truth or dare, Vertex?" Damini asked.    

"I don't wanna risk it- hit me with a truth," Vertex said.    

"Have you ever stolen anything?"     

"Many times, Damini. Many times," Vertex chuckled.    

"I- Wow. That's weirdly attractive to me," Damini said awkwardly.    

"Cyro, truth or dare?" Vertex looked over to her right.    

"Truth."     

"Have you ever cheated on Encelad?" Vertex asked.    

"Wh- No!"     

"Just checking. Just checking," Vertex said.    

The game continued, and most of the questions were between Vertex, Damini, and Cyro. Polaroid and Encelad got a few, but nobody seemed to want to choose dare. Mercury usually did, though. There was something rather thrilling about it. Polaroid got one or two truths, but Mercury didn't get any up until a certain point. Then, they asked him a lot, wanting to see what kind of stuff he'd do. He wasn't as bad as his brother, but he certainly had done a lot throughout games in his life.     

"Mercury, truth or dare?" Damini asked, now having become a bit more comfortable with the shark.    

"Dare."    

Vertex leaned towards Damini, and whispered something in her ear, which she nodded to. "I dare you to kiss the most attractive person in this group."          

''"Damn,"'' Mercury thought, ''"Easy choice."''          

He grabbed Polaroid by the gloved hand, and pressed his lips to the other boy's. Polaroid's eyes closed as soon as they did.           

Mercury felt nothing at first, and then it kicked in. He felt like his brain turned into cotton candy, and his eyes exploded into fireworks. Bubbles floated around him, without him meaning to make any, and he felt like his chest would pop like they did when they touched the ceiling.           

He took in a breath. It was only a few heavenly seconds between the parting of lips and the bubbles and them popping. Mercury cherished them.          

"That was, uh..." Mercury said.          

Polaroid tried to say something, but his stutter kicked in so badly, he couldn't pronounce anything intelligible, blush almost making the shadow on his eyes turn a dark pink. He took a moment, then mumbled "Fe-felt-felt good..."          

"Polaroid. Calm down for me, will you? Please?" Mercury tried to calm him down, as he released the wolf's hand. He hadn't even noticed he was still holding it until then.          

"Sor-sorry. I've... Never done that... Ever... It was... How do I-I begin to ex-explain it?" Polaroid said.          

"Maybe you should explain it some other time. I know Vertex started it, but I think she and the others are starting to get bored of this now."          

"Al-alright."          
----Mercury felt his chest rise up, and fall down again. 

He stared into Polaroid's open, narrow, purple eyes. He admired their beauty.

The quiet of the night made them all the more beautiful. The others were asleep, giving him a window of time just to enjoy them. He let his free hand touch the tips of Polaroid's ears, who moved his head up just to get more contact. Thank goodness, because Mercury's left hand was being crushed under it. Polaroid's left hand, however, was resting on Mercury's chest.

And that let Mercury to think about his own breathing. Which led to more thoughts about Polaroid.

Then he thought about Zenith. Something had definitely happened ''that night,'' the night he came over, but it was different.

Zenith was like a wine bottle, and Polaroid like a milkshake. He could enjoy both, and actively wanted them. 

But he couldn't. Because there was no way he could date two guys at the same time. Mercury knew that would be cheating. At least, he was raised to think so.

Slowly, the night changed into day again. 

Mercury did not, in fact, sleep that night.
----Morning came, and so did the dreadful realization that this time, it could be him.

Polaroid was absolutely terrified, and Mercury felt the exact same way. He loved the boy, but he understood he was easily frightened and... really, this time it was quite reasonable.

Mercury knew that this time, he might die. Friday used to feel relieving in a way, because he understood the collective tranquility and emotion over the weekend, but now even the weekend was stripped away due to the future funerals. Then Monday would come along, and the cycle would repeat again.

Mercury didn't like it. But he couldn't get himself killed. He couldn't drop out, because no matter what, Antares wouldn't. Antares would probably get himself killed.

The morning went by. Polaroid snuck kisses from Mercury, and a small interaction with Zenith in the bathroom meant they managed to get in some kissing done before class, not helping Mercury's decision in any way. 

But Mercury felt a bit numbed out. Spirits were at an all-time low in the school. Reasonably. Mercury had to do something.

So he did.

''"Do not feel afraid to reach out to me in the case of trouble, though."'' This felt like trouble to Mercury.

Mercury waited until after Physics to lightly touch Solaris' left arm as he exited the class, who turned around. 

"I really need you help. Think you can ask for some time before we get to Math or... something?" Mercury asked. 

"Obviously. What do you need?" 

They sat down at the desk at the front of the class, with a long seat.  

"I noticed everyone was feeling bad. Like, really bad. I don't think that's very productive since they're gonna be thinking almost exclusively on what's wrong. Do you think maybe we could do something like... a festival or a party?" Mercury remembered the parties he used to go to, how he'd often end up a little better, although that was usually because of the drinks or the guys he'd meet. Not that it ever led to anything, but at least he'd feel good.  

After a small silence, Solaris answered; "I have genuinely never gone to a party. However, I will see to it that something happens. I can agree that most of the school has been thinking whether they or their loved ones will die, and this may distract them, especially when evaluations come around."  

"Oh- Geez- Thank you!" Mercury grinned widely.   

"I suppose it's time for you to get to Math. I, on the other hand, have to stop someone from accidentally setting the school on fire," Solaris frowned slightly more than his regular bitter face.  

"Does his name end with an S, start with an A, and have the letters N-TARE in the middle?" Mercury's grin faded.  

"Perhaps it would be good if you helped. Maybe he'd listen more to his own brother than an authority."  

"That's Antares."  
----Antares felt as frightened as when he thought his father's killer would come to murder him, too.

Judging from the pattern of things, how Anna died to Wren and Wren died to Apollo, he was up to fight his partner. He did not want to fight his partner. 

One of them would have to die, and he didn't just want to die like that. But he didn't want that death for his partner, either.

So he let the fire elsewhere. He was planning to get outside, but it looked like his emotions got ahold of him. He was crying, and that sucked, because it made him feel a bit embarrassed, to do it in the middle of a hallway.

A burning hallway. At least it was better than having Apollo suffer an incredibly painful death.

He let out a little moan, as he felt like his very skin was burning and shriveling off, and knew his hair was definitely on fire, as he was quite mad at Liza for what she wanted. Maybe the pain was just him letting off smoke. Didn't feel like smoke. That made him notice he was breathing in pure smoke, just as if it was oxygen. 

Then the overwhelming heat turned into freezing water, and Antares swiveled around to see his enemy and his brother working together to stop him. 

He'd kind of guessed his brother would have something like his hair, but he never imagined what it was. Bubbles, floating everywhere, bursting as soon as they hit a wall or flame, which was kind of cool, but not as cool as the water pouring from Mercury's hands. A puddle had formed, and it was spreading. 

The water that was washing over Antares had small shards of ice, which told him ice came first, water came next. After going through two extreme temperatures consecutively, Antares couldn't feel much except "pain" and "cold". 

Thankfully he didn't feel like he was drowning. Gills had a purpose, after all, although it was pretty annoying to float around in water for a while.

He let out a couple coughs afterwards, as he still had human lungs and needed to breathe, then Mercury ran up to him with a towel.

"Perhaps it would be best if we sent him something so incidents like these won't happen again," Solaris told Mercury.

"Yeah, maybe. Something to, like, reduce the magic power Antares lets off when he's mad."

"Exactly. I know just who to get. Come," Solaris indicated, starting to walk away from the scene.
----Graham's Workshop was actually under the school, and could only be entered through Ètare. It led towards a giant golden cog-shaped door with many different little cogs on it, leading towards a lock, but with a few blank spaces. 

A table was next to it, with twenty or so different sized and shaped cogs and a riddle on a hanging wooden sign.

Mercury couldn't read the riddle. It was in another language entirely, to make getting towards Graham more difficult.

Solaris, however, already knew exactly which cogs were necessary, and placed them in their respective areas.

Next, there was a silver cog. On its left was a metal and silver sphynx with emerald eyes. It opened its mouth, and a recording of a woman's voice played.

"Eine person, ein rätsel, eine chance. One person, one riddle, one chance," it said.

It stretched out its paw, and Solaris touched it. 

"Ein mann geht nach einer sehr langen party-" "The man goes home in the morning, so he can see well," Solaris quickly interrupted. The door slowly opened.

"They ''are'' easy, it just takes time until you can hear the English translation. I will be waiting at the next door," Solaris said, and left through the cog. It quickly closed shut again.

Antares pressed his own hand to the sphynx, and it played that old riddle with the rooster that laid an egg. He already knew the answer.

"I'm going in there, but I'm not looking at him, or talking at him. Sound good?" Antares said.

"It's cool. Go on," Mercury gave him a thumbs-up.

Antares rushed through the door and before it even closed, turned around to look at Mercury instead of Solaris.

Then Mercury touched the sphynx.

"The bow burnt. The sea rose, and the goat and the man drowned, crushing the fish. The ram charged, but it was too late. The bull searched, and it found its fate. The crab was crushed in the struggle, the lion went missing. The maiden was eaten in its hunger, but fairness decreed it dead. Wild scorpion was crushed in the middle of chaos. Who lived?" It asked.

Mercury knew the others had gotten easy riddles, and maybe this one was experimental or just a glitch, but Mercury felt like it was pretty familiar, and so he went with "Gemini."

The door slowly opened, and Mercury felt both surprised and not at all.

He felt a chill rush through his body as soon as he entered the third room, and saw a bronze cog door. This time, it had a sign bolted onto it, German on one half, with the English translation on the second half of it reading "What would Graham do?"  

A table on the cog's left had a pair of hearts, which didn't look like human hearts, giving Mercury a sense of security he didn't know he needed.  

In the center of the room was a bronze pedestal, and above it was a laser which bounced back from the pedestal making it so the room wasn't damaged.   

Solaris grabbed a heart, examined it, and said in a low voice, "He changes them once a month. I will be reminding him."  

Then, he placed the other heart under the laser, which lowered slightly, revealing a black cube, keeping the laser in place yet letting it move within it, fixing an injury Mercury hadn't seen on it. And finally, the door moved.   

It revealed a large room with many metal tables, shelves, and otherwise areas to hold items which were of course, filled with items. Tools, blades, switches and buttons. A crank was on the wall opposite the gear, and next to it was an operation table with a screen above it. None of the parts that seemed to turn on, were on.  

The last wall had a door labelled ''"Do not enter unless with explicit permission: Private Testing Room with EXTREMELY DANGEROUS experiments. Radioactive experiments are sealed further inside. Failed experiments may be discarded here."''   

Out of that door emerged an old man with white hair, slicked back with hair gel, messy and with cogs and screws tangled in it. He had a big nose, and thin lips. Time had done a number on his body, with wrinkles changing his face as he took breath and blinked his brown eyes. These had a pair of working goggles over them, with two lime green circles around his eyes.    

Matching these was a workbelt wrapped around his lower waist, holding multiple basic tools. He wore a plaid, light blue long-sleeve, black pants, and brown boots. His back was hunched and his knees wobbled a bit, but a pair of braces over his pants he walked with the help of these, and judging from the small "G" on the left leg, were made by him.    

Finally, wrapped around his lower ribs were two pieces of metal that pressed tightly against his skin that connected to a black box with three holes on each side, adding up two fifteen, occupying much of his back.     

Antares had a grin on his face. Mercury did too, but his was much softer. He understood this was Antares' favorite teacher, but Mercury didn't care too much. It was just another teacher. Solaris would probably understand, as he did work with them. Maybe it would be cool if they talked more.    

Then again, Antares wouldn't like that. He also didn't like Zenith, reasonably, but they interacted in secret, so... Solaris didn't seem to like Antares, either. Mercury could feel it. He was just there because of his duty, not because he wanted to be.        

"Hello, Graham," Solaris said.        

Graham moved his hand as if to say "Wait," and then moved towards the crank, twisting it for a spin or two. The room lit up due to the screen and operation table turning on. He moved towards the screen, and as soon as he did, a keyboard popped out of it.         

The screen had a few dozen light green squares over a dark green background. When he clicked on one, they changed to slightly darker green, and the process repeated once more. Then a light green line appeared in the middle.        

Graham typed: "I'm very sorry. I am currently experimenting with mouth technology, and therefore cannot speak. Please excuse my silence and tell me what's wrong."        

"Ah, alright," Solaris said. "Allow me to explain the situation."        

"You stay quiet if you know what's good for you," Mercury whispered into Antares' ear.        

"Think I'm ''that'' dumb?" Antares whispered back.        

"This little nitwit-" "Hey!" Antares interrupted angrily.        

"Who lacks a sense of responsibility has been blowing up at school. In both senses of the term. Thrice did he threaten, in a non-verbal way, to burn the school without success, although the most recent attempt, a few minutes ago, came close, which is why I believe it's time to seek greater measures," Solaris explained.        

"Is this a reward?" Antares joked, recieving a lightly annoyed stared from Mercury.        

"Okay, I have an idea. Give me five minutes alone with the boy. I will need him to take his shirt off as I require access to the area," Graham typed.        

"Well," Antares said as he quickly took off his shirt, revealing the bandages covering up his gills and his back tattoo of a dragon, "I'll be seeing you."        
----When Antares woke up, he had his shirt back on. He also had a collar around his aching neck, with spikes around it.

He also had a bit of pain on his chest.

Graham had typed out a message. A long one.

"The spiked collar is called a Magic Minimizer, MagiMin for short. It helps make sure you do not go excessively on your magic. Twisting the front spike will let you use your full ability. Twisting the back spike will let you take it off."

"The pain in your neck comes from an extender. It helps to make sure it links you as a core of its energy. Without the extender, it would not work."

Antares understood, and really, had no strong opinions. Maybe he'd feel differently later. For now, he had PhysMa. And he knew he might die.
----It was a cycle, and Mercury was aware of it.

He perfectly understood Antares for being afraid, because he felt they might pit them against each other. Pick a twin, he tried to joke to himself, knowing the morbid reality of the scenario.

Mercury definitely didn't want to hurt Antares, considering how his powers would either result in a painful death or a gross death. He also didn't want to die, considering how Antares' powers guaranteed a painful death, either by suffocation or burning. Plus, since they both knew each other's strengths and weaknesses, they'd either both play dirty and kill each other or just balance each other out so well, neither of them would be able to beat each other.

The cycle was simple. They started with Anna, and got to Wren. They got to Apollo through Wren. If Antares beat Apollo, they got to Antares. Antares to Mercury.

Mercury didn't want his brother to die to Apollo, but that felt kind of like a death wish. So he tried to convince himself of a hope that maybe, just maybe, it wouldn't come to them killing each other.

"Is your neck okay?" He asked, as they ran through the castle to get to class.

"Hurts. But it wasn't cut off, so I'm good," Antares dodged a statue of a giant head of some guy, and slid into a portal, Mercury following.

A few minutes later, they finally arrived at the stadium. Sitting on some seats near the ring, Mercury sighed, knowing what time it was. He hoped like hell nothing would bring Antares inside, yet a familiar face did.

Polaroid sat next to Mercury, and whispered in his ear those words he dreaded.

"I'm really, really sorry but, um... your brother... he-he was chosen to fight a-and he needs to go down the arena because... well, I asked the professors t-to let him have a few minutes to talk with his opponent and... y'know... I don't want to be the messenger h-here so..." He stuttered.

"...Okay. Thanks for telling me." Mercury grabbed Polaroid's hand and turned towards Antares.
----The room below the arena was dark red, with a wooden floor. It had a few beds, but mostly chairs. Lots of brown metal chairs, stacked together.

He pulled one out and sat on it. His mind was blank. He should've been thinking about something, anything, but... He just couldn't, and stared absent-mindedly into the wall.

Antares didn't know who his opponent was, but his stomach dropped when his suspicions were confirmed.

His own partner.

Apollo came into the room, trembling, and sat on his lap. The look on their face said both "I'm scared," and "I'm sorry." Antares pressed his index finger to their lips, and then pulled them in for a kiss. 

Then another. They melted into each other, passion mixing in with panic and the knowledge that one of them could die only intensifying the moment further, hearts pounding like the drums in a metal song. Antares placed his hand on Apollo's back, pressing them closer to him, pulling away only for air. Antares couldn't bear to lose Apollo, and yet these kisses weren't like a promise to see each other, but a goodbye.

They only stopped when Ms. Muriel told them they were starting to become late to the games, with a somber look on her face, and Antares knew that'd be the last time he'd ever feel Apollo's lips on his. 

They went through the wooden gate and onto the field. 

The sun was brighter. The people, with grimmer looks than ever. Antares had, but hadn't expected to be in the ring so soon.  

"Uh..." He tried to fill in the silence. 

''"I love you,"'' Apollo mouthed. 

Antares smiled warmly, despite the blare of the horn, despite what he knew would happen, despite everything. 

He unfastened the front spike on his MagiMin as Apollo made themselves a katana and a shield. 

Antares' mind clouded. He dodged swing after swing, knowing Apollo was much more versatile magic-wise. He knew how to dodge a punch and how to throw one back, but Apollo was... just so strong. 

He loved his partner, and felt bad. He knew he'd probably die, and hated the thought. He probably wasn't panicking enough. He never did. 

He watched as Apollo prepared himself for flight, and felt his heart beat. 

It was beautiful. 

He had to destroy his prismatic angel. He felt like his organs were pushed into a blender, and his mind in a jar, and he was gonna stay alive because of that, and suffer because for some reason his nerves were still in the blender... It didn't make a lot of sense! He didn't want to hurt Apollo... 

The emotions were revolving around him, and he felt like he was being pushed to the limit. His hair started to smoke.  

He felt like a piece of wood, and he was lit.  

So he took out the flame. 

It landed on Apollo. 

Apollo screamed. The flames only attacked the left half of his body, non-spreading, and Antares froze. It was as if his body just shut down. He thought to himself to move, to do something, and he couldn't. Pale skin turned dark, to blackening. Pieces of skin fell of his arm. His voice rose an octave.  

Then he fainted, the flames dying, leaving his damaged skin. He wasn't bleeding, and had been screaming out of panic, but Antares finally snapped out of it, and rushed towards his frail body. 

He heard through the loudspeaker a message of congratulations, but tuned it out.  

There was something more important to him. 

Apollo was still breathing, yet Antares had won. 

== Vulnerable ==
Solaris couldn't nearly begin to describe how he felt, but his mind told him he had to, just to get a grasp over it.

He felt ''helpless.'' Helpless and inadequate. He had the ability to do some stuff, but he couldn't really speak his mind about any truly important issues, such as the games. Yet he had to do so much work. He didn't have any control over what was happening around him, and even though he was a bit of an authority figure, it definitely wasn't enough.

He'd been talking to Mercury for a bit. "Antares feels pretty distraught," he'd mentioned. "I don't know what would be good for him... can you help out?" He asked.

He said yes. Not because he was actually too concerned- Antares seemed to have taken the deaths pretty easily- But because it'd make him look good. Solaris didn't feel too bad about that. He needed to do it, and he would. 

He went towards the Merciers' dorm, and knocked twice on the door. Mercury opened it.

"Antares is taking a nap. He's been doing that a lot lately," He explained in a soft voice.

"It makes sense. Can you wake him up for me?" Solaris asked.

"Alright. Don't feel bad if he swears a lot, by the way," Mercury turned around towards the bed.

Antares woke up with a face full of water. Which sure was a method. 

"Fuuuu... what time is it?" Antares asked. 

"It's Sunday. Does it matter?" 

"...Yes?"

"Seven in the morning," Mercury took a glance at a clock on the wall next to their bed.

"So why the hell are you waking me up?" Antares groaned.

"You're a wreck. Go fix your problems," Mercury stated.

"That's rude."

"That's tough," Mercury put his hand in the shape of a gun and started to squirt a bit of water at Antares.

"Alright! Alright! I'll go!" Antares exclaimed and scrambled out of bed.

Solaris waved, although the wave was stiff.

"...Hell no," Antares quickly said.

"He's gonna take you to talk with Apollo. Like it or not, Anty, like it or not," Mercury told him.

"...Damnit, man!" Antares huffed.

Solaris got out of the way and extended his arm with an edge of chivalry.

Antares followed, extremely annoyed.

"...I don't feel ready," Antares mumbled after a few Ètares and a bit of walking. Solaris understood completely. He ''was'' in the same arena, after all, and Antares was in the front line. He practically froze with shock that day. Solaris noticed it. It'd be sadistic to dismiss it.

"You couldn't. But at the very least, they're alive, and most likely waiting," Solaris tried to calm him down. It probably wouldn't work, though.

"I feel like I'm going to be executed," Antares said.

"I know. I also know you are an idiot with anger issues and do not need insecurity on top of that. Isn't closure important to you?" Solaris asked.

"...F***, you have a point there. But I don't want to raise your ego, so let's pretend I didn't say s***," Antares smiled a little.

Solaris covered his mouth to obscure a small smile, which Antares didn't notice.

As they got closer to the hospital room, Solaris felt the air get hotter. He stopped Antares by grabbing his shoulders, which made the boy turn his head away awkwardly, and turned down his Magic Minimizer. Graham had warned him to do so.

"Sorry, man... I, uh..." Antares mumbled.

"Idiot. Be glad I was here, and remember to turn it down," Solaris scolded lightly.

"F*** you. But yeah, I am kinda glad. I'm just not used to it," Antares said.

Finally, they reached the door to the hospital. Antares let his hand rest on the knob, hesitant to turn it. He looked at Solaris, a bit expectantly, yet the worry was still plain to see. Solaris thought this was... Actually, kind of cute. He wouldn't admit it then and there, and besides, he was starting to feel a little bad. Antares acted strong, and brave, even if he was hasty and foolish, but seeing him in such a state hurt. Just a little.

So Solaris gave him a little nod, both of encouragement and of approval of the action, and Antares twisted the knob.
----Bandages covered most of Apollo's left side. The few bits that Antares could see were grisly, pasty and paler than his usual skin. Antares could see a little bit of red, and felt disgusted- Not at Apollo, because this wasn't their fault. This shouldn't have happened to them. He felt disgusted of himself, of his own magic. He wished he'd just stayed at a normal school so he wouldn't feel this way, get in trouble, maybe expelled once or twice, and finally get stuck in a dead-end job.

That would be better than this.

Apollo was sleeping, so Antares reached to cup the part of their face that was burnt, and whispered into their ear some simple words; "Babe, wake up. I gotta tell you something."

Apollo's available eye opened wide, fast. "Oh- oh god..." He mumbled, scared.

"Babe, it's me. What's wrong?" Antares asked.

The two stayed silent for a minute. Solaris didn't understand what was going on, for once. He wanted them to communicate already.

"...I, uh... Third degree burns, huh?" Apollo chuckled weakly.

"Yeah... I'm really, really sorry. I just kinda froze out there, and I couldn't control my powers, and then..."

"I can't do this anymore," Apollo sighed.

"...What?" Antares asked, trying to confirm what they just said.

"I can't do this anymore! I got f****** destroyed out there! I don't know what could happen if you lost control again and f*** it, you definitely would! I need someone who'll take care of me now, and knowing you, you're not the guy! I'll get rejected in most places because of my appearance, and knowing you, you'll probably end up not getting a job until you're twenty-six! Our lives would have been s*** anyway!" Apollo ranted.

"I know, but we could've made it! Rationed food, shared an account, whatever! I'm not as senseless as you might think!" Antares exclaimed.

"And now you put words in my mouth! I don't think I'll ever see a candle in the same way, and I'm gonna have to transfer schools after this since my parents don't want me to be here! We knew we were gonna die, and this was way worse, and I can't take it! I'll stay in the hospital for the next few days, and then I'm leaving this place... This wonderful, horrible place," Apollo's voice went a bit more quiet on that last part.

"...I love you," Antares said.

"I-I can't say the same anymore," Apollo said shakily.

"...C'mon, Solaris. Let's get out of here," Antares said, looking at the man in question.
----Antares was pretty quiet. Solaris didn't know whether to bring him back to his dorm or somewhere else, and Antares was walking aimlessly. 

Then he froze.

"What's wrong?" Solaris asked, genuinely worried.

"I just got dumped," Antares said, realizing what just happened.

"I thought you were taking it quite well," Solaris tried to reassure him. 

"I'm pretty sure you've never been in a relationship. This is... my friends got killed and my partner doesn't want me anymore... I... If this keeps happening... I need to get a grip," Antares started to walk again. Solaris followed.

"I told myself I wouldn't let you see me like this, but... I guess it just kind of happened and... ah..." Antares let his hand wipe away a pair of tears from under his eyes.

"Let it all out. I'm the person least likely to tell others in this school. I lack the desire to, despite how I may feel about you," Solaris tried to calm him down.

"F***... It's just suddenly hitting me all at- at once and... I can't take it! I just... I know I'm supposed to be the strong one but I can't... I've got no control over the situation and there's nothing I can do and I hate it! I hate it! I hate it so, so much!" Despite the MagiMin around his neck, Antares still managed to let out some sparks. There were a few tears starting to drip now. 

"The one time I can do something, I mess it up, and now I'm single again... Took a bit to get over the last guy, I-" Antares suddenly quieted down for no visible reason.

"I don't know how to help. Let me do my best effort. Come with me," Solaris said in the calmest voice he could muster.

Antares did.
----Solaris brought him to the piano room. He'd never played for another human being- Sure, his pet rat, Deimos had come up here with him once or twice, when he wasn't roaming around his cage, but apart from him... 

The room was coated in beige paint. He knew it used to be a mucky shade of brown, which he liked to think was because they'd run out of nicer colors, and he tried to choose one that fit the environment. As Solaris began to play his beginning scales, Antares looked at the many books filled with musical sheets. Solaris could have told him what any of them contained, but they both knew Antares would only bore himself if he asked.

Then, slowly, Antares moved back towards Solaris, and sat next to him on the stool. "I do not know if this will help, but-" "Anything that takes my mind of him helps," Antares interrupted, staring blankly at the wall.

"Okay," Solaris looked at the keys, and began to play. He chose Moonlight Sonata, first movement. It was overdone. It didn't matter. It felt appropriate.

Antares didn't feel anything. The chords were strong, but he couldn't feel their weight affect him. His eyes, almost forced, dragged themselves from the wall to Solaris' hands. He admired the strength yet agility within them. It was different from him and the guitar. He occasionally snuck glances of the man himself, who was in some sort of trance, concentrating fully on the song.

Damnit. Solaris wasn't being mean for once, which was cool, but it didn't really matter, because it didn't change the feelings in him. Antares thought of many things, only to find his thoughts running back to his ex-partner. It hurt. He'd only dated him for a week. A f****** ''week.'' A single incident ruined what could've gone on for months, years, or maybe even until death did them part. It might've been better if Apollo would've died, but he probably wouldn't have taken that well, either. It felt like they'd known each other for years.

He felt lost. He felt lost and he couldn't find a way to be free. He didn't like this at all. 

After a particularly quiet moment, Solaris spoke up; "What about Mercury? Has he not helped you in the slightest?" 

"I mean, it's just... I don't want him thinking any differently of me. I don't want to go see him right now, either. Apollo and I started our relationship in my dorm, and I guess it probably wasn't a good idea to stay there, knowing that. Really affected me. This all happened in a short period of time, and I haven't checked the bulletin board because I know Mercury and I are probably destined to fight someday..." Antares didn't know why he was telling Solaris all this. 

"I'll try to make sure you two do not need to fight," Solaris nodded. 

"Okay. Thanks. I don't know where to go right now, though. My friends dying and all," Antares laughed a little. The laugh wasn't genuine. 

"I'm sure Polaroid can take over my duties for the evening, so why not come to my room? Sleep there for the night, I couldn't care less. I will be studying, so as long as you don't bother me, you could just... Actually, my room is surprisingly boring for anybody other than myself. I'll try to get a television or some other electronic device to keep you entertained. I was never particularly interested in that sort of thing," Solaris offered. 

"...Yeah, I'm up for it. Is that, like, a way of saying you wanna hang with me?" Antares smirked. 

"I don't consider it hanging out if I'm going to be ignoring you. I consider it giving you refuge," Solaris rolled his eyes. 

"Fair 'nough. Take me there," Antares got up. 
----The first thing Antares noticed was the fact that this dorm was huge. He knew Solaris and Polaroid would probably receive a little special treatment, but didn't expect nearly this much. He could reach the ceiling if he jumped from his dorm's bed, but he'd need to climb onto the large structure that held Solaris' bed and then grow twice his size just to be able to reach it.

Then, he saw the windows. Or wall. Window walls. "If a hurricane happened, Liza's magic would protect us from it. Although, I am not so sure about that considering what has been going on recently," Solaris said, noticing where Antares' eyes were focused.

"That's... cool," Antares said, not really knowing how to react. Then, it clicked. He ''had'' to ask Solaris about what was going on. Maybe they'd gone to his room just for that!

Antares glanced at the coffee table with books on it and a potted plant and the large sectionary sofa around it which was like a square without one side, and then looked at his desk with books and a lamp on it. It had a black swivel chair tucked into the kneehole. The large cage on his left with the rat from a few days ago in it. 

His bed was neatly made, with white sheets and two matching pillows, and its canopy held white curtains and candle holders on the posts, which were low enough they didn't burn through the curtains but high enough Antares knew Solaris probably had to use some sort of tool to reach them, even if he was taller than him. 

"The television will appear in a few hours, at most. Liza is currently busy dealing with a previous request of mine. In the meantime, I actually do not know what you could do, as our interests are very different, and I've been busy researching on... something," Solaris said. 

The room had a door on its right wall, almost near the corner, and bookshelves where Antares had come in from. "What's in the door?" He asked, heading over there in case he told him to see for himself.

"A telescope. It's quite large. There's also more bookshelves in there and a fridge in case I get hungry. I do not actually eat much, though," Solaris' eyes were focused right on Antares, giving him the familiar feeling of them burning holes into him.  

"So what would you like to do?" Solaris asked, noticing Antares being frozen in place after a few minutes. 

"I'm curious about some stuff. I mean, we all are, but... There's nothing else to do, is there? Can I ask you about what you know?" Antares felt like he was being forced to be nice, but it wasn't that bad.  

"I understand why you'd want that, all recent events considered. Alright, come over to the sofa. Maybe if we waste a bit of time, you could get something to entertain yourself afterwards, this being a magic school and all," Solaris sat down on the right side, on its middle cushion. Antares sat down on the middle seat, middle cushion.  

"Alright, so... I guess I just wanna know anything you know. I really don't wanna admit this s***, but you're smarter than me, and way closer to the alphas. I kind of assumed you'd know... something! Anything. Goddamn, we're all just suffering with this bull and we can't do something about it? That's... f****** awful," Antares said.  

"I know. That's why I must tell you everything from my side. I only wish I knew more," Solaris sighed.  

"It's cool. Anything helps, really. F***, even if you say the most slightly... what's the word for when something's related to something?" Antares asked.  

"Relevant," Solaris replied.  

"The most slightly relevant thing, I won't give a s***. I just wanna hear it," Antares finished.  

"Alright, then. I owe it to you. First off, it came as a shock not only to myself, but to all the other alphas when Liza declared the competition. It is, in fact, the first time she's ever been so reckless. I wouldn't have expected it, such an inhuman task. She has influence over the magical world, being so powerful and a war hero, so she probably obscured it from the government, or made sure this was entirely legal without any liability over the kids' deaths. Which sucks, because the parents deserve at least that much," Solaris began.  

"Last year went by quite slowly. Boring, even. She promised she'd shake things up a little, but violence should not be considered shaking things up. More of a 'throwing rapidly across a room'. Although there is a bit of thrill to the idea of a competition and some may find the danger enticing, apart from that, the school's magic has been functioning slower and slower. I believe it is being drained. Normally, a television would have-" A small crack was heard, and a flat-screen appeared on a small table in front of Antares, filling in the square the sofa made, the remote on the coffee table, "-appeared by now."  

"But as you can tell, it took a while to come up. If this keeps coming, the school will barely be able to function. I worry about the shield coating it too. If it fails, and danger approaches... Well, it was made to withstand invasions, so I think you get the message," Solaris' hands moved as he talked, kind of filling in the blanks.  

"The school would go kaboom," Antares concluded, nodding.  

"Yes, it would crumble. Now, I believe, and this is just me theorizing as I've heard a bit and been able to ''attempt'' to piece things together, but couldn't possibly know what is actually going on, that she will not give people a chance to escape once they take on the quest to find the Cube. I do not know what the Cube is. If it was genuinely important, I do believe I should have! So it must be important to her. If the champions escape, I believe she'll try to bring in the authorities, or use her magic against them. She must be picking them off in order to see who's the strongest so she can know who'll be able to survive the quest," Something in the way he spoke told Antares that he really did just build this from what he'd heard. Antares felt slightly impressed, but didn't want to admit that.  

"I also believe she wants the winners to prove themselves. I do not know if the Cube has any properties she wants, but perhaps it is more of a McGuffin? If I'm right, then I believe the reason as to why is to make an army, or bodyguards. Something that can offer her protection."  

"I do know one thing. We cannot leave campus and escape. The forest counts, but after that, we're blocked off. It was implemented as a security measure years ago, but because of all of this, now I think of it as a jailing system. Liza must be using this fact to make sure anyone in the competition can't leave it. The trial period is over too. Even though most people left during all this, the people who remained are locked in. They're stuck into the cycle of battles now, and even I can't stop it," Solaris wrapped things up.  

"God," Antares mumbled.  

"I know," Solaris replied.  

"F***!" Antares exclaimed.  

"Calm down," Solaris said.  

"Sorry. We're just cows for the slaughter, now..." Antares looked at Solaris hoping that wasn't the case.   

"That's right. Only a god could win in combat against Liza," Solaris said grimly, confirming Antares' fear.  

"I... I'm gonna stay here the night. I don't feel safe anymore," Antares admitted.  

"It's okay. I'll be studying. Go ahead and watch whatever, I'll just wear earplugs," Solaris replied, trying to make sure Antares did feel safe.  

"Thank you," Antares said in a quiet voice, and turned on the television.   
----The second time Solaris ever played for another person came later that night. Antares had soon drifted fast asleep, and while he knew Polaroid might be able to handle taking care of the school, he also knew Polaroid could get scared quite easily, and decided to double check and see if he'd done everything properly. 

When he did resolve anything Polaroid hadn't, Solaris checked up on Antares. Seeing him sleeping calmly with the TV playing, he knew that he didn't have to look out for him at the moment. Solaris had spent most of the day studying or working, save for the few minutes he'd spent with Antares, so he thought it was a safe time to go ahead and enjoy one of the few hobbies he had. He planned on sleeping at eleven at night, so at eight he went off to play piano.

As he'd been playing with Antares earlier, things definitely seemed different. There was a feeling of worry drenched in the room, but now it felt more like the calm after the storm, when although it may have caused some destruction, everything was better now. At least, as "better" as it could be.

He didn't feel like playing anything in particular. He grabbed a blank book of sheet music, and began experimenting, trying to find a nice melody. Once he did, he began playing it, fixing anything junky or off. The final result was worth it.

He played the song over and over again, relaxed.

Then he heard footsteps.

This made him slip up a little.

"Hmm, they were doing so well," someone commented.

"I'm sorry, who are you?" Solaris asked the unknown audience.

"Oh!" A girl quickly went towards the door. "Sorry. I'm Encelad Rossi. Same grade as you. Professor Juno asked me to drop off something at his office, but I got kind of lost," She held up a pair of jars, one filled with an orange, soda-like bubbling liquid, and the other with blue beetles that ran around within, some of them eating each other. 

"It's alright. If you require my assistance, I can absolutely drop what I'm doing and help," Solaris said, as he closed his book.

"No, it's fine. I really liked the song, do you mind if I come back to hear it again?" Encelad asked.

"Of course not. I'm just not quite used to playing in front of someone," Solaris answered.

"Really? But you sound so good!" She laughed.

"I've just had a lot of practice, really. You are absolutely allowed to stop by. I do hope the teachers agree with my decision..." He smiled.

"Okay, then! I'll see you in a few," She said, and left to find Juno's office.

Solaris didn't think much of the small interaction. He didn't know how long the girl would take to find the office, and he somewhat wished he'd insisted he help her out, but before long, Encelad had returned. 

"I genuinely have no idea why I had to leave those jars, but... oh, well. It's not ''really'' my issue anyway. So, what are you playing?" She asked, as she walked into the room. 

"Welcome back. I haven't given it a name, but it's just a quick song of my own design," Solaris passed her the book. 

"I see. Judging from this, there's some pieces you could give a little more on. What kind of emotion were you going for?" Encelad smiled. 

"I actually don't believe I was going for anything. It's a tranquil moment within a time of worry, so perhaps that," He said. 

"I see..." Encelad nodded. 

The conversation went on for a while. Solaris, when acting nice, somehow had managed to click with Encelad. He recognized this. They played songs and ended up writing two extra songs to go along with Solaris' melody, and although they did not name them, Solaris knew they were good. 

He still didn't feel too good, though. He still felt helpless. Because feeling better about oneself isn't always instantaneous. Sometimes, it needs to build up over a while, and the best thing Solaris could do was act as if he didn't feel these emotions. Faking it until he made it. That was the best course of action, in his mind. 

Despite all this, he made a friend. He tied up some ends. He felt good about that part. Perhaps good and bad feelings were meant to blend together in a tango, and balance into a person's self. But he wouldn't linger on such a philosophical thought at the moment, because he wanted to enjoy this moment while he could. It was a good time to enjoy a moment. He didn't usually get to. He was still a teenager, anyway. He couldn't do as much as he might have often felt like he should, but he could do this.  

== Phenomenon ==
Zenith had experienced many strange events in his life. Some were just things that made him a bit confused. Others were things that would probably scar him for life. He remembered being a kid and watching gore tapes with his cousin. It wasn't like he knew what he was seeing, but this definitely built up his immunity to such things. Even if it could get a bit shocking at times.

Seeing them in real life was different. But it definitely helped to see them, knowing how morbid his powers were. 

He never asked for his powers to be like this. His family had always been magical, and it was simply coincidence that his powers would be of death, decay, and darkness. His parents could handle raising a child like him. It wasn't the first time nor the last his family line had and would see dark magic, as one of his cousins (whose name he forgot) withheld similar magic to his, except he could manipulate it from its original intent of harm to heal.

Zenith's weren't like that. They could be used for good, sure, but they'd always be dark. 

He also remembered the first time he'd seen something die not online, but in real life. It was a cat, which he'd fed only moments before. It ran in front of a car, and he exclaimed at the cat, but a crunching sound was heard, and although it should've darted away, Zenith didn't know he should've called for help at that moment. A few moments later, and the cat was in such suffering, that his father came out with a gun. A bang later, and it was quiet. Zenith spent a long time watching its lifeless body. 

There were many other incidents he remembered. Some he wished he didn't. There were two nights in particular he wished he could purge from his memory... He would not dare to let his mind wander to them, but sometimes, it was inevitable and his brain forced itself to, his attempts against it making on effect. He used to have nightmares over them. For a moment, he shut down, and that moment wasn't very good. Not right now. 

Zenith's fingers were heavily coated with chalk. It was late Sunday, and he'd been teaching Cressida a bit more Russian and some more Math. He was surprised when she told him she was learning on her own too, now. Cressida didn't know as many things as her classmates, but she was learning at a faster rate than what most people went through. Of course, the language would need more time, but still... Their room now had a chalkboard and a desk next to Cressida's bed, which was helpful, because now Zenith had somewhere to hold himself so he wouldn't fall over.

Cressida was a little confused when she saw how Zenith just froze up. "Hey dude, are you okay?" She asked, setting aside her notebook.

"Sorry. Uh... Let's jus' keep workin'," He shook his head, and kept trying to teach Cressida. Now that the memories had started rushing back in, though, it was hard to make them stop, like a broken dam. She nodded, and followed his hand with his eyes.

The chalk broke. Zenith stiffened.

"Uh, I think that's 'nough for today," He stated.

"Alright, then," Cressida grinned. "I'm gonna go with my friends, we have a little event," She said quickly, and left the room. 

"Fair e-" Zenith didn't get to finish his sentence because of how fast she rushed out. "M'kay..."  

He went into his own room. It was almost identical to his old room, but a bit more classy and definitely less messy. It definitely had the environment of a small apartment, but it was still neater than the apartment. He had his cupboards and stove and many tools he'd use at Kinyun Kafe. Pills for the nerves. The sheets were always done, unlike at home. His drum kit was near his bed, which in turn was near the cupboards. His drawers had the clothes he'd brought here, but it wasn't like he was planning on using them any time soon.  

Self-cleaning and body cleaning uniforms was quite the innovation for people who didn't always have the motivation to shower. He lied down, concentrating on breathing, but it wasn't easy, so he made a drink that had about the same equivalent of sugar as a package of Oreos, and drank it, not in the mood for anything bitter, and instead more of a mood of going into a coma for several weeks. 

If Zenith went into a coma, though, he'd probably end up remembering more memories than he wanted to. He didn't want to. He washed his now-empty mug slowly. His brain screamed at him not to, he didn't just feel like something bad would happen, he knew it, and the memories were fluttering in... The only thing he clearly knew was that needed to get out of this room.  

So he decided to follow Cressida and see what she was doing. 
----Zenith still couldn't get a grip over this school. He'd grown up with magic throughout his life- like many children before him, as around a third of the global population had some sort of magical ability- and he knew it as much as many of those children. However, having dark powers meant things kids with water powers, or wind, or music, or colors, or really any but his, meant strange things were bound to happen.

There were people like him. People with powers related to the occult or supernatural, death or plague. But few had powers that encapsulated most fields within them. Powers like fire, light or darkness often had many sub-powers. Zenith wasn't sure if Cressida knew what she was capable of. She was just getting her footing in this world, after all. 

Zenith didn't know the full capacity of his abilities, either. Sure, he'd experimented once or twice, but powers like his were often used for malevolent acts. He never had the urge to do that. 

So when he traversed the castle walls, he should have expected something strange to happen to him. He saw ghosts daily and occasionally met much nastier spirits, but he didn't expect to see into the heavens once again.

He did it once before, in class. Everyone else saw his eyes blacken, because his vision darkened as well. But then he saw light, and it was as if he was really in another existence. Zenith could peek into the final fate of a person.

But this was different. This was new. 

He did not see into the life of someone in heaven, nor did he peer into hell. Instead, he was in a place right down the middle, where there was heavenly light piercing upwards and the threat of flames looming below. A building with drawings of people, societies, and incomprehensible messages and art. Any normal person would not understand this, but Zenith was not normal.

This was Purgatory. Zenith had an understanding that it went on for miles, with drawings of people, and billions of rooms set just for judging individual people. Gentle rumbles on the floor every few seconds indicated another person had a room made for them. Of course, Zenith was right in the heart of the place, and although he'd never been, he had some belief of a force out there giving him the knowledge he needed- Even if that force wasn't the kindest.

Zenith hadn't much of a doubt due to what he had seen, but he did wonder who or what it or they were. Music from an unseen organ was playing throughout the main room. It was peaceful. It would be peaceful if he wasn't seeing a man he'd met not-so-long ago. When he was around thirteen, to be specific. 

Stéphane. Stéphane Mercier, Antares and Mercury's dad. A redhead with each eye like one of his sons', strong and chained to the ground, in a kneeling position, with long nails and sharp teeth. 

Their meeting was wordless. Stéphane gave Zenith a look of contempt. Zenith felt as if his mind was on fire and telling him to get out of his vision right now. Zenith knew Stéphane had some sort of powers, but not what they were exactly, so he couldn't rule out the possibility that Stéphane was actually seeing him. His heart started beating so fast, his chest felt like it'd explode.

Memories rushed in faster than he'd ever experienced them, one after the other, all while staring into the face of a man that caused so much fear into his life, despite him having once loved his son, and now loving the other one. He knew he did not have the approval, and the only way he ever momentarily got his approval was by-

Zenith flashed back into his phase of reality, hyperventilating, dizzy. He slumped down the side of the castle wall, trying to breathe, choking on his breath, trying again. He sat like that for a while. He was scared inside, but once he caught his breath, he just stared at the opposite wall. Then Kranion, who had been roaming the castle free, slithered into his lap. It took a while to calm himself down, patting the snake. 

But once he did, he remembered his goal, and went straight back to it.
----Zenith was now in the yard. It was a cloudy day, around eight in the afternoon. The air was cool. He didn't know exactly where he had to go, but to be honest, he couldn't care less. It might have been reckless, sure, but it did get his mind off the memories.

Until it didn't. Then he got nervous again. What if Cressida was in danger? What if they were trying to hurt her or kill her? Eliminating the competition... He didn't know her location. He didn't know who she was meeting with. His thoughts went back to the beginning, and he'd let Kranion try to find her using her scent, so he was completely alone.

His left hand went into its correspondent pocket and messed with the teabags inside. The grass was freshly cut. Was there staff cutting the grass? He had to ask himself questions he probably wouldn't find out the answer to in order to get his mind off the issue in hand.

Suddenly, something clicked into his brain. He could do something to find Cressida much faster, if he could find a fresh body. But there weren't any- The games. What happened to the bodies? Were they shipped home, or perhaps still in the school? He couldn't waste so much time trying to find something that might not be at school, although he had a feeling they were being contained somewhere.

Ghosts, on the other hand, had all the time they needed. If Zenith was lucky, he could get them to find both the bodies and Cressida. Cressida was the more pressing matter, but he wanted to know if the school had offered the deceased some respect. A side-plan stemmed from a plan. 
----Zenith knew Kranion was still searching, so if his plan backfired, at least he had a back-up. But he still had to hurry. He rushed in through the rooms looking for anywhere with a particularly dark aura, where he knew spirits ''had'' to reside. He knew about some locations, but in places like these, there were bound to be areas where ghosts gathered around. In his head, he was writing a quick note to make sure to try and create a spell to detect ghosts and people's locations, because this could not happen again.

He couldn't lose Cressida. She relied on him, badly, and he cared for the girl like a sister. He took her in because he knew she needed help, and he knew he appreciated the company. 

He knew he'd have to refine a spell for localizing- he often had to make his own spells- but for now, the best he could do was experiment. He bent his fingers, trying to force something out of them, and his palms faced each other. A thin, shaking, purple line appeared- magic. Now all he had to do was concentrate, warp this magic into a steady beat like an instrument, make it play the song he needed it to and-

He slammed himself into a desk. Just his luck. The string was gone, too. A shred of hope, gone. Why did he not think this further? Why did he have to panic so badly and do such irrational things? He shouldn't have tried anything. Cressida probably wasn't even in danger. He just came to assume she would be. He tried to make the string reappear, but the boost in magic he'd gotten from fear, from a strong emotion, was no longer there.
