'''Serious Note: Quack'''

=== Chapter 1- Summer School: ===
''Ahhh, the land of Jamaa, a place of great adventure and stories.''

''Well, not anymore. Since the eradication of the phantoms, it has been mostly peaceful and quiet. Not a single threat on the horizon, not a war in sight. So now, nobody remembers the history of Jamaa or the battles between the alphas and the phantoms. Everyone just thinks of it as another small town, another landmark in this big world.''

''But little did the residents know that Jamaa still had one more great adventure to be had.''

''And it all starts in a classroom, near the beginning of summer break.''

Juniper drummed her paw on the table and sighed. She hunched over the desk and put her head down, snout hanging off the desk, waiting for class to end. Standing in front of her was the teacher, who was a pink flamingo who had gleefully introduced herself as Miss Flora a couple of classes ago. Her name was quite fitting for her, since flower patterns ran across all her feathers. 

There were only five other students in the room with her. A small pink fennec fox with a blue spiked collar around her neck who sat in the desk next to her, a miffed expression on her face as she listened to the teacher speak. A white pig with black splotches that sat two desks behind Juniper, face half-hidden by a propped-up book on his desk. And a blue penguin and a snow-white polar bear that sat in the back, the polar bear sitting on the ground instead of his desk. Juniper assumed the desk was a size too small for him.

Miss Flora balanced herself on one leg, all while jabbering away about the ‘grand history of Jamaa’ or whatever. 

“...as you might have known, the animals of Jamaa used to be divided, each only worrying about themselves and their own species,” she explained. “They took each of their heartstones from the pedestals in the temple, not trusting enough of the other animals to take care of them…”

Juniper gazed at a lone clock on the wall next to the school bell and some sort of siren. It was lazily bolted there, slightly slanted, and nobody cared in the least to fix it. And she suspected it was broken, because the second hand refused to move. She looked back down and examined her paws, without a better way to pass the time. ''So this is how I spend my summer, huh?'' She asked herself. ''Locked in a classroom and turning into a history buff.'' 

She looked back up at the teacher, who had shifted her discussion from heartstones onto how the alphas came together. Juniper realized she had missed pretty much everything the flamingo had said.

''Actually, scratch the last part.''

Juniper was startled out of her thoughts when Miss Flora suddenly prompted a question for the class. “Would anyone like to name every one of the main alphas?”

Although the coyote didn’t listen to a single thing the teacher was saying, Juniper still knew the answer by heart. Everyone else in the room did too.

“Liza, Cosmo, Graham, Peck, Greely, Sir. Gilbert,” everyone said plainly at the same time, though the names in various different orders. So, all the teacher heard was a jumbled up mix of sounds and names that almost sounded like names, but not quite.

The names of the six alphas were basically drilled into the heads of every resident in Jamaa at an early age. But what did she mean by main? She wondered to herself. She had only heard of six alphas in her lifetime.

Miss Flora tried to decode what all six students said, though decided to presume they all knew what they were. “I’ll assume you all said Cosmo, Greely, Liza, Sir.Gilbert, Peck, and Graham, not in that exact order, right?” she said with a slight frown. “Then you would be correct. Partially. You’re still missing one.”

Mumbles and whispers flew across the room. These were the alphas they had known and recited all their lives, whether they liked it or not. And sure, the side alphas might have been forgettable in last year’s history class, but certainly not the main alphas. Who were they missing?

Miss Flora almost seemed to bask in the students’ confusion, pleased to finally create a thought-provoking question.

“Okay, if our grade drops because of this one stupid question then it shouldn’t be our fault.” the fennec fox hissed to the others. “Besides, these were the alphas we’ve always known. Anyone else and we’re just stepping into history nerd territory,” she accused out of frustration.

“I remember one other alpha,” Juniper said, trying to get the thinking process going. “Their name was Mica. They’re a coyote alpha. But I’ve never heard anyone other than the other coyotes talk about them, so probably not.” She shrugged

“Maybe the teacher could be wrong,” the spotted pig considered. “I mean, it’s happened before.”

Watching the three argue about whose theory was right were the penguin and polar bear duo sitting in the back. The penguin spoke up.

“Tavi. The last one’s Tavi, the dolphin alpha,” he said in a quiet voice.

The fennec fox swiveled her head around and stared at the penguin, unfazed by his knowledge. “Well of course you would know, Mellow,” she sighed. “You probably studied all this ahead of time. Meanwhile, none of the history teachers I’ve had ever teaches us about this!”

“Well that changes now,” Miss Flora responded, jumping back into the conversation. “And yes, Mellow is right.” She pointed over to the penguin, who otherwise didn’t respond and was scribbling drawings of alphas on a piece of paper. “The seventh main alpha is Tavi. Now, I don’t blame you, since she’s kind of isolated herself. The only main alpha who lives in the ocean, so no one really knows her unless they’ve had an aquatic-related issue.”

“Yeah!” Mellow chimed in. “Elmer’s grandma got lost swimming at sea once.” He pointed to the polar bear next to him, who gave an awkward wave. “Tavie sent out a pod of dolphins to search for her and they found her the very next morning she disappeared.”

Miss Flora nodded. “So, all of you will just have to remember the seventh alpha, Tavie, along with the other six.”

The fennec fox shrugged casually. “What’s the point though? In fact, what’s the point in remembering any of the alphas’ names or what they do?”

“Well, it’s mostly so that when you have a problem in Jamaa you know which alpha to get,” Miss Flora responded politely. “If you’re having trouble being creative, Peck. If you need to resolve a conflict involving more than two people, Liza or Peck. If you need a history lesson, me!” She laughed. “Or Sir.Gilbert. He can also give training and wisdom if he’s in a good mood. If your plants are dying, whether it be your own fault or something else, get Cosmo. Graham if an invention has gone wrong, of course. And Tavi for aquatic-based issues.” She paused and looked at the students darkly. “Don’t get Greely for anything. The phantoms are gone, so there’s literally nothing you can give him. Just don’t.”

All of the other students laughed. Juniper started to wonder about what Greely was doing when he wasn’t studying and spying on phantoms. Like when all the phantoms were gone.

''Find evidence to argue that he still needs to study phantoms?'' She snickered to herself. 

Suddenly, Juniper was spooked by a long, drawn-out ringing noise that was cut off as abruptly as it had started.

Miss Flora threw her feathery wings up into the air. “Oh, would you look at the time!” she exclaimed. “Seems like class is over, a bit too soon personally.” 

All six students exchanged relieved looks, glad to finally get out of the cramped classroom. Juniper, along with everyone else, quickly stood up and made their way to the front of the classroom. The coyote’s legs felt weak and wobbly after she didn’t use them for a long time.

Still standing on one foot, Miss Flora used her beak to pick up a key sitting on her desk. She turned around, now right next to the door. After fumbling around a bit trying to get the key into the keyhole, she managed to open the door, letting out all of the kids.

"Elmer?" she asked the polar bear when he started to pass through the doorway.

Elmer grunted, showing that he was listening.

"Could you maybe sit in your seat next class?" Miss Flora politely asked him.

Elmer grunted affirmatively and lowered his head, not wanting to upset the teacher. 

As Juniper walked through the doorway, a cold air flowed towards her, contrasting heavily with the warm classroom she had just left. Many other students from other classes poured out as well, until a huge mob was traveling to the exit doors. 

''Time to head home.''

= Chapter 2- The most boring chapter to ever exist to showcase our boring (probably everywoman) character =
When Juniper swung open the big exit doors for the school, she was greeted with trees all around her, which made sense since her school was in a clearing near Sarepia Forest. The forest was dimly lit, fireflies and the slightest of sun rays being the only sources of natural light. 

To compensate for that, residents of Sarepia Forest had hung up lanterns and strings of light, which were a gorgeous sight to see. Juniper, however, loved the fireflies. She loved how they seemed to be tiny stars, floating around aimlessly in the forest. The way their abdomens flickered mimicked that of a heartbeat, though more chaotic.

''The heartbeat of the forest,'' she thought to herself. It felt soothing to her, and it was a great way to pass the time. Aimlessly drifting through life, just like the fireflies, without a care in the world. A normal coyote living in just another normal part of the world. She was sad to not stay around for long.

Juniper pranced her way through the forest, trying to get to where her den would be- somewhere on the edges of Jamaa Township. On her way, she saw a pack of wolves curled up beside a campfire, laughing into the flames as they tried making up a scary story to tell. A story involving phantoms, she concluded when she heard ‘slimy cycloptic tentacled beasts’ were mentioned by one of the wolves. Phantoms. No longer a threat, now only reduced to characters in a horror story. 

It felt strange, knowing that a longtime threat now ceased to exist. Juniper was born a bit before the Final War of Jamaa, so she knew some stuff about phantoms. Not much, since other, more skilled animals were out fighting them while she and some of the less skilled ones were sitting in their dens. And… now Jamaa felt a bit empty. No more acts of heroism, no more insane battles, just… peace. 

Calm, mundane peace.

But the truth was, Juniper was hoping for something exciting- something that would never come. She was adventurous and curious. It always felt like something was missing, and staying around in this part of the world wouldn’t solve it.

She sighed and lifted her head, seeing bright rays of sunshine pour in from a clearing in the trees. A light in the tunnel, to get her out of her strange thoughts. 

The coyote walked right into the sunshine and was welcomed by the chatter and conversations of crowds of animals. Some had places they needed to get to, splitting off in multiple different directions, while others decided just to stay around and banter; maybe even trade a bit. Modern-looking wooden buildings were placed all around; they were the shops. A swirled pattern in the design of a mosaic sat in the direct center, with the different paths all converging at this singular spiral.

Jamaa Township, Juniper thought to herself. She looked at the hurrying crowds of animals and took in the noisy atmosphere. ''Pretty busy place.'' And these animals had all kinds of strange and unique designs and patterns. Juniper saw a sky blue arctic wolf with stars on her back, who was complaining to her eagle friend about how hard it was to get rich nowadays.

The eagle, sitting on top of the dome-shaped roof of the diamond shop, nodded away, yellow stripes running down his wings and feathered back.

And they weren’t the only ones- so many animals around her, each dyed with a special color or with a unique pattern. Fur, feather, and scale colors with variety that transcended the rainbow. Swirls, speckles, dots, stripes, stars, splotches, even fire-like patterns. 

Looking at her own, plain, brown fur, Juniper felt like a bit of an outsider. Did she feel jealous? ''Well,'' she reasoned. ''If everyone is special except me, then doesn’t that mean they’re not special and I am?'' 

Juniper was pleased at her smart way to reassure herself, but decided to check the clothing mart. Just in case they had something that looked good on her. She entered the store, took a deep breath, and began trying on accessories.

After an hour or so, she still couldn’t find anything that looked good. Everything article of clothing seemed too unnatural, or didn’t match with her brown fur. She shook her head. ''At least I tried.''

Juniper exited the store, ready to head on back to her den. She took the path that traveled down from the spiral, where there was the arcade, fountain, and alpha headquarters. She lost herself in her thoughts, thinking about when she would like to visit the summer carnival or what Miss Flora would teach them tomorrow. 

Suddenly, among the large hordes of animals, she felt someone bump her by the thigh. Just a slight nudge, but enough to make her whirl around and try to find the culprit.

Looking over her shoulder, Juniper could see a pitch-black arctic wolf that would’ve made them the color of night if it weren’t for the violet swirls on their fur. They wore a fedora and a black spike collar, the spikes extra long, the collars being a classic fashion trend among the wolves.  The arctic wolf had a mysterious aura around them, and when he turned around, shivers were sent down the coyote’s spine.

“Oh did I accidentally bump you,” they said in a masculine voice with a clear lack of emotion. “Sorry.” And so, he turned around and began walking in the opposite direction of Juniper, taking the path to the Temple of Zios.

She stared at the spot where the arctic wolf was moments ago, trying to process what had just happened. ''Okay, that guy was weird,'' Juniper thought to herself. She just couldn’t shake off that chilling feeling she got when looking at him. It didn’t seem natural.

After that encounter, she decided it was best if she hurried home. No need to get caught up in any other weird shenanigans. And besides, the sun was already setting. 

So, she continued on her path, eventually leaving Jamaa Township and encountering a fork in the road. No problem- that was just how they separated the many dens. Once you bought one, you had to remember the path you took to get to it. There were many, many forks in the road, and some animals simply didn’t buy a den for this reason or just kept the directions in their bag. 

But Juniper trained herself to memorize it by heart.

Okay, she thought to herself while walking. First I have to take the left path. Then the middle path. Then left again. Then right. Then middle. 

She continued to recite these directions to herself the entire time she was walking.

''Left, middle, left, right, middle.''

''Left, middle, left, right, middle.''

''Left, middle, left, right, middle.''

She yawned to herself.

''Left.''

''Middle.''

''Left.''

''Right.''

''Middle.''

When Juniper finally reached her small den, she shuffled into her house with the speed and vigor that matched that of a zombie. Without a second thought, tired and weary, she face planted into her bed of mats and pillows, quickly falling asleep.

=== Chapter 3- Introduction to Phantoms ===
Juniper perched her head on one paw, trying to keep awake. Class hadn't even started yet and her eyelids were already beginning to droop close. Like yesterday, standing in front of her was Miss Flora, who, like always, balanced herself on one leg. Today, she pinched a piece of chalk between the upper and lower portion of her beak. She drew a few scribbles onto the chalkboard and dropped the chalk in a little tray, making sure to spit a few times to get the chalk dust out of her mouth. She moved over so that the students could see the board. 

“Now class,” she said with a soothing voice. “Can anyone tell me what the thing I drew on the board is?” She pointed to her doodle on the chalkboard, which seemed to be a misshapen round creature with a singular eye and multiple tentacles.

“A phantom,” Juniper, the fennec fox, and pig groaned with little enthusiasm. The only two who didn't respond were Mellow, who was working at lightning-speed trying to sketch Miss Flora’s drawing before she erased it, and Elmer who kept trying to adjust his chair. He didn’t seem to be very comfortable sitting in such a small seat.

Miss Flora didn’t seem pleased at their lack of energy, whether it be from lack of sleep or lack of willingness to learn. “Oh, come on now students,” she encouraged them. “Just because this is summer school doesn’t mean we can’t have a little bit of fun, right?” She waited eagerly for their responses.

Juniper heard the fennec fox snort in annoyance. “I mean, I’d rather be doing actually fun stuff, like going to that annual carnival or visiting a party. But I guess I’m stuck in here, so oh well.” She shrugged dramatically.

Although she would never say it out loud, Juniper actually disagreed with the fennec fox. Sure, history class was boring, but her normal life was even more boring. Instead of walking around Jamaa and losing herself in her thoughts, maybe she could learn a thing or two here. ''Maybe the teacher was right- maybe I should show more enthusiasm,'' she thought. Miss Flora seemed nice enough, after all.

“Duchess, you are in this classroom for a reason just like everyone else,” Miss Flora told the fennec fox with a serious voice. “Everyone is here because you either did not pay attention in history class in normal school, or because you simply did not take the class. Simple as that.” She looked sympathetically at Juniper the coyote, the spotted pig, and Duchess the fennec fox. “Although, I admit that their ways of teaching history conventionally are a bit… dull. So I’m here to change that.” The flamingo changed back into her usual, cheerful demeanor. She put the chalk back in the little tray.

“Because today, class, we’ll be learning about PHANTOMS!” she exclaimed.

“Oh yes yes yes!” the penguin exclaimed alongside her. He was clearly excited to be here.

Miss Flora smiled. “Well, at least I have one fan in this room.” She took a glance at a small hand-fan near her desk and grabbed it with a claw. “Actually, two!” She laughed at her own pun, while everyone else stared at her with blank expressions. 

“Smart pun, Miss Flora, but can we get back to learning about phantoms?” the penguin said. “Me and Elmer really want to hear about them.” The polar bear next to him grunted in approval.

“Oh! Of course!” She placed the hand fan back on her desk and gestured towards the penguin with a pink wing. “But perhaps you’d like to start us off by telling us what phantoms are, Mellow?”

The penguin nodded and cleared his throat.

“Okay, so, the funny thing is that no one actually knows what they are. They just, appeared one day, and trying to explain more would just be diving into the many theories of where phantoms came from. So I’ll just tell you what they’re made of. A gelatinous substance called phantom goo, which has the power to pollute nature. And these creatures love polluting. And they’re evil, as you might have guessed. Over and over again, they’ve tried to capture Jamaa, and over and over again the alphas have stopped them.” Mellow stopped speaking, seemingly pleased with where his explanation ended.

Miss Flora clapped her wings together, making a soft thump sound. “Yes! Very good Mellow!”

''This guy sure knows his stuff,'' Juniper thought to herself. ''But why is he in summer school in the first place? He already seems to be a natural at this.'' She’d have to ask him about this later after class.

The spotted pig raised a half-hearted hand into the air. 

“Yes, Scooter?” she asked.

“That guy mentioned gelatin for what a phantom is made of,” he said with a bored voice. “Does that mean they’re edible?”

“Oh goodness no!” she exclaimed. “Gelatinous just means that they’re slimy. But glad you paid attention to his explanation, Scooter.” 

Scooter just gave a slight nod, unwilling to show any energy in class.

Juniper suddenly had a question she really wanted to ask the teacher. A question that reminded her of what she was thinking about walking in Sarepia Forest yesterday. It seemed like a kind of rude question though, so she wasn’t sure whether to ask or not. But she needed to know…

“Miss Flora?” the coyote blurted out, shooting her paw into the air. “Why are we learning about phantoms if we don’t even see them anymore?”

The last phantom attack was years ago- in the Final Jamaa War. There, all the phantoms were either slaughtered by alphas and jammers or driven off, sent back to the dimension where they came from. After that, not a single phantom was seen ever again.

The whole room went silent. The flamingo inhaled in a breath and Juniper could tell this was a hard question for her to answer. Finally, she spoke.

“That's a difficult question to answer,” she admitted. “And I’m sorry, but you cannot learn the answer until later, when you’ll understand.”

Juniper sighed and hung her head in a disappointed manner. Miss Flora noticed and tried to calm her.

“Don’t worry. It will not be long until you can learn the answer. But now is the time to learn. So, now let’s take a deep dive into the many different kinds of phantoms.” Miss Flora pointed to the phantom drawing she had made at the beginning of class. “This is the basic phantom.”

Duchess, who was sitting in the desk next to Juniper, leaned towards her to whisper into her ear. 

“Hey look, it was a good question,” she admitted. “This is boring, after all. I’d rather actually be fighting real phantoms. But we can’t, because…” 

Juniper nodded. Surely there was better stuff to do than learning about creatures that didn’t have any bearing on their lives anymore. But she thought over her daily life in her head, and… not really. Shopping wasn’t really fun, parties got boring after a while, trading was only for the hardcore traders who carried value lists in their pockets…

Miss Flora continued speaking. “These are your average phantoms. They use a spin attack and swirl their tentacles around, dealing out rapid attacks. However, their range and eyesight are quite lacking. Does anyone know how we deal with the-”

Suddenly, a blaring siren went off in the classroom, causing Juniper to jump in surprise. Miss Flora looked at the flashing red light stuck on the wall, a look of dismay on her face.

“Well students, it seems like class is dismissed early.”

=== Chapter 4- Polar bears, sirens, and small desks don’t mix well ===
“Awww man! I wanted to learn about the phantoms! Especially my favorite ones,” Mellow pouted. He crossed his flippers together. Elmer put a comforting bear paw on his back.

“I haven’t heard the alarm ring in years,” Miss Flora remarked. “Now what could be such a big deal that they had to pull it now?”

Juniper scanned the sign hanging right above the siren, which read Emergency Report From the Alphas. Reading this, her ears perked up and she wagged her tail. If it involved the alphas then it was almost alway big. The siren was installed in all the dens and buildings of Jamaa and was a call for all jammers to head to the heart of the town, Jamaa Township

Finally!” she exclaimed. “Something interesting that’s about to happen.”

“Eh, who knows. Maybe little Timmy just fell into the well,” Scooter snickered. Juniper couldn’t help but snort at his joke. That little kangaroo joey was always finding his way into sticky situations that he couldn’t get out of.

Miss Flora rolled her eyes. “Amusing. Now, hurry class, we must get to Jamaa Township!” 

The teacher opened the door with a claw. Everyone quickly got out of their seats and headed out the classroom. All except Elmer, who had stuffed himself into the seat and couldn’t get out. He wiggled and wiggled but his giant polar bear body just wouldn’t budge. 

Mellow, waiting for his buddy to get out, noticed.

“Oh no…” he groaned.

He quickly waddled over to Elmer. He wrapped his flippers around Elmer’s body and tried to pull, but didn’t have enough strength to do anything. Everyone else had already gotten out of the classroom.

“Somebody!” the penguin shouted in a panicked voice, jiggling his friend’s body like a locked doorknob. “Help!”

&lt;nowiki&gt;=======&lt;/nowiki&gt;

Juniper was at the back of the line, waltzing through the school hallway with a new bounce in her steps. This was going to be something big. Something interesting. Something… different. And she was all up for being a part of it.

Suddenly, her ears caught the sound of a muffled cry coming from the classroom they just exited. It was masked by the sounds of the siren blaring, but Juniper’s coyote ears knew that it sounded like a cry for help. That was something that couldn’t be ignored.

''Aw, but I wanted to see what all the sirens were about,'' she thought, still curious. But that wouldn’t require immediate action- the cry for help, however, did. 

And so, Juniper abandoned the rest of the group and bolted towards her classroom.

And as soon as she stopped in front of the doorway to the classroom, she knew that this was going to be a sticky situation. A situation close to Timmy the Joey level.

“...What happened here?” Juniper said out loud, even though she already knew the answer. The penguin grunted as he tried pulling a polar bear out, sweating like he was weightlifting at the Olympics. Juniper walked over to Mellow.

Mellow, hearing another person enter the room, dropped his grip on Elmer and turned to look towards Juniper. “Oh thank Mira! Finally, some help!” he said with an exhausted voice. He pointed a flipper towards Elmer. “He’s stuck! These desks are not polar-bear-friendly at all. I’ll have to talk to the teacher about that… But first, I need help!” he cried.

Juniper walked behind Elmer’s back. She inspected the polar bear’s clunky body. “Alright, where do you want me to pull?”

“...the middle of the back?” Mellow answered, seemingly unsure as well. He put his flippers on Elmer’s stomach. “I’ll push up. Elmer will try to too. Ready?”

As gently as she could, Juniper grabbed Elmer’s fur.

One, two, three, GO!”

The three pushed, tugged, wheezed, and huffed, but they still seemed to be making little to no progress.  

“It’s not working!” Mellow huffed. 

“Isn’t there something else we can do?” Juniper asked. “Like…” 

She checked out the polar bear’s beefy paws. They were lazily hanging to his sides, not being put to their full use in any way. And polar bears were known for being quite capable in strength 

”Can’t Elmer just…” Juniper gestured her paw upwards. “Put his paws under the desk and push up or something?” 

Without even a moment of consideration or hesitation, Elmer shook his head. 

“What do you mean the answer’s no?” Juniper said with a hint of annoyance targeted towards him. “You haven’t even tried anything yet!” 

“Heh, that’s Elmer for you,” Mellow interjected, a meek tone to his voice. “He doesn’t want to break the desk.” 

”But if he doesn’t do anything soon, we’ll be stuck here all day!” 

”I know, I know!” 

”And how bad could the damage be? Probably just a couple of scratches or so. To be honest, these desks are banged-up enough already.” 

”Actually, doesn’t that mean the desks are going to break more easily-“ 

”We don’t have any more options! Elmer weighs, I don’t know, a few hundred pounds or something? We can’t lift that much.” 

It wasn’t until Elmer decided to use his two front paws to push up that something major happened. 

There was a loud, sudden crack and the metal frame of the desk broke into two, one half no longer connected to the rest of the desk. Juniper winced as the metal pipes slammed into the ground, making a not so nice sound. It was the sound that told them they would have to come up with a very good explanation for this. The breaking of the desk, however, did the trick, and Elmer wobbled out of his seat.

”O-okay,” Juniper faltered. “That was… worse than I thought.”

Mellow stared at the broken desk, unable to speak. He was sweating all over, thinking of all the ways they could be punished for this. “Worse than you thought?” he spluttered.  He kicked at one of the metal pipes, making it slide across the floor until it touched the wall. “Look at these dents!” He pointed to a half-bent pipe. “Look at the rust! We can’t piece this back together!”

”Are desks really that expensive?” Juniper inquired.

“Well, no, I don’t think so, but still! The people take damaged school equipment seriously.” He fiddled with his flippers agitatedly, and Elmer had to put a paw on him to calm him down. 

The coyote agreed that this was probably serious, but didn’t think Miss Flora would be the kind of teacher to dole out heavy punishments just because the students accidentally damaged school equipment trying to help someone.

“At least the teacher now knows that Elmer needs a special desk…” Mellow mumbled, voice still quivering. “Who’s going to break the news to her?”

“We can tell her about that later,” Juniper said quickly, glancing at the siren that had stopped blaring and flashing. “We need to get to Jamaa Township fast.”

Elmer grunted and walked through the doorway to the school hallway. He got down on all fours and used an arm to point to his back, trying to signal something.

“Oh, he wants us to ride on his back,” Mellow said, decoding the polar bear’s meaning. 

Juniper narrowed her eyes at him, wondering if they were allowed to do something so… primal. “Wait, actually?”

“Yup. Don’t worry, I’ve done this a couple times with him. He doesn’t mind, especially when we’ve just helped him.”

“Okay…” Juniper responded, still a bit unsure. “Can he even carry the both of us? To be honest, I haven’t been eating healthy lately.”

Elmer stared at Juniper directly in the eyes, right through her soul. The areas around his eyes crinkled, and she just knew he was smiling. And then the polar bear gave her a nod. A single, affirmative nod. Suddenly, Juniper was relieved of all doubt after seeing this sincere polar bear reassure her. She inhaled in a breath.

“Okay, let’s get on.”

=== Chapter 3- Special Report from the Alphas ===
Juniper felt the wind ruffle and tousle her brown fur. She used all four of her paws to cling to the polar bear, who was running at top speeds towards the heart of Jamaa. When the breeze blew right by Juniper, it just gave her a new kind of calmness. It melted away stress and worry, and just let her stay in the moment. The moment where it felt like she was flying in the air when she stared at the bright blue sky above her. She threw her front paws into the air and took it all in. Just another bird soaring through the sky, without a care in the world.

“So how do you like it?” Mellow asked Juniper. “I mean, probably a good way to take your mind off the consequences we’re going to get…” He was still stressing over it. 

“It’s great!” she exclaimed. “And I’m sure we’ll be fine. Miss Flora seems nice. She’s not going to be that angry.”

Mellow nodded slowly, still having yet to be convinced. “I guess. But sometimes nice birds can be the ones with the biggest fury…” he muttered to himself.

Juniper raised an eyebrow but otherwise didn’t question it. Suddenly, she remembered the question she wanted to ask him. “Hey, Mellow?”

“Huh?”

“So, I listened to your explanation in class about phantoms,” she said, “and you seem really smart. So why do you need to retake history class in the first place?”

“What?” he asked in confusion. “Oh, no, I’m not retaking it. I’m just making it up, and so is Elmer. Because you see, we only recently moved to Jamaa.”

Juniper was shocked. “Really? Honestly, I didn’t really notice any new people. But maybe that’s just me.”

Mellow nodded. “Yup. Both of us used to live on this isolated iceberg with a few other penguin and polar bear families. But then, we learned about this cool place called Jamaa, where there were animal species of all kinds and lots of great things to do. And we thought, hey, why not move there? Because living on that iceberg was kind of boring, not going to lie.”

“Okay, great reasons, but to be honest Jamaa isn’t that interesting anymore.” Juniper shrugged. “Stuff stopped happening after the phantom wars.”

“Exactly!” Mellow exclaimed. “Another reason I wanted to move here was the history. What other place do you know that has two gods working alongside animals to fight off a foreign threat from another dimension? That’s awesome! I started studying your guys’ history way before we even decided on moving here, because it was that cool.”

“But why study the history at all?” she asked. Juniper couldn’t fathom why you had to learn about stuff that was never going to happen again. “It’s all in the past and isn’t gonna come back. Seems like a waste of time.”

Mellow tried shrugging but decided he didn’t want to loosen his grip on Elmer, and so he just responded with a mumble before speaking again. “It probably sounds cliche, but history repeats itself. I study the past so I can prepare for the future.” He paused for a moment, considering the words that just came out of his mouth. “Hey, that actually sounds like a good quote!” He smiled.

Juniper laughed at the penguin’s enthusiasm. Honestly, he could be right, with the siren alert going off for the first time in years and all of that. Nothing wrong with learning a little bit of background information. And it seemed like an interesting hobby. At least, more interesting than the hobbies the hardcore traders had. Who knew screaming loudly over and over again about trading something really rare counted as a hobby? She joked to herself.

Suddenly, without warning, the polar bear stopped his running and Juniper lunged forward because of inertia. 

“We arrived, didn’t we?” Juniper said, flailing her paws around in an attempt to regain balance.

“Yup.” Mellow hopped off Elmer.

She quickly did the same and surveyed her surroundings. To her left, she saw a banner advertising the summer carnival. ''Honestly I really want to go,'' she admitted to herself. Maybe after school. 

But in the exact center of Jamaa Township, huddling around the swirled mosaic pattern made from small pebbles, were huge crowds of animals of all sorts. And from pretty much everywhere in inner Jamaa. Arctic foxes and wolves from Mt. Shiveer. Lions and giraffes hailing from Appondale. Owls and raccoons who had arrived from Sarepia Forest. Lemurs and monkeys who lived in forests near the Temple of Zios. Even some aquatic animals who could make it onto land, like seals and otters. 

When the siren rang, everyone came.

Juniper, Mellow, and Elmer walked to the large mob of animals, desperate for a good view. “Okay, I did not realize there would be this many people,” Juniper observed. 

“I guess we were late,” Mellow said sheepishly.

Suddenly, in a matter of seconds, Juniper felt her stomach drop as she was thrusted into the air, now decently above the rest of the crowd.

“Alright what-” She looked down and saw Elmer had lifted her into the air with a single arm, just so that she could get a better view. He winked, indicating that this was thanks for caring enough to try to help him.

In Elmer’s other paw was Mellow, who was also lifted at the same altitude as Juniper.

“Great view, don’t you think?” Mellow asked her. Juniper nodded and squinted her eyes, trying to see what was going on. Now that they were above everyone else, there wasn’t anything blocking her view from seeing what everyone was crowding around.

The animals circled a single, bipedal panda who had two black ears on both sides of her head that almost looked like two neatly placed hair buns, as well as a braid that hung down to her waist. The emerald crystal earrings and emerald-green vest she wore seemed to almost foreshadow her mastery in magic. But the markings around her eyes were the most prominent trait about her.

That was mostly because those markings labeled her as an alpha.

“That’s Liza!” Juniper gasped. 

“Boy!” Mellow interjected. “This is like the first time in forever that she’s actually talking to the people here, right in the flesh.”

After the phantoms were driven off, Liza’s endless thirst for adventure was still not quenched, and so, she set off to find more animal heartstones. She only occasionally visited Jamaa now, and that was because the other alphas had begged her to at least return every year. But for her to actually once again give a speech to the jammers without anyone prompting her to?

Juniper twitched her ears and tried to use her coyote hearing to listen in to what Liza was saying.

“...and so what I’m saying here to every single one of you,” Liza said, “is that you must be alert.”

Juniper scratched her. “I guess we weren’t ''that'' late.”

A wave of mutters and confusion spread through the crowd, the full picture not yet fully being given to them. Suddenly, a feeling of dread inched closer and closer to them as Liza continued slowly explaining to them what was currently happening, in order not to overwhelm them too suddenly.

“Now, I do ask you to please stay calm and collected when I tell you this,” she said in a gentle voice, “but thanks to Mira warning us about a strange aura being around Jamaa, we can pass down the information to you too.” She inhaled in a breath and stared at the crowd with sympathetic eyes, pained at what she would have to tell them next.

“Through what is assumed to be the guise of an animal, it seems that we have a phantom living among us, right here, in Jamaa.”

For just a second, it seemed like Juniper’s world had frozen. Her stomach felt queasy and a wave of emotions flooded her. She wasn’t sure what to feel. Shocked? Worried? Scared? Intrigued? Maybe a little bit of all. Mellow, meanwhile, had his mouth wide open in what seemed to be both curiosity and shock.

Like a time bomb barely given a few seconds to go off, the crowd exploded into chaos and confusion. People who had experience with them back in those days of Jamaa screamed with fear. Other, more recent residents were confused, and desperately tried to get someone more knowledgeable to explain the commotion to them. Even more prepared to riot.

“A phantom? Here? After so many years?” a bunny whimpered, a dazed look on their face. “What do they want? Another chance at taking our lives?”

“Back again?” a monkey hollered while clutching the sides of their head. “This is bananas! We, we aren’t prepared for another battle!”

“It won’t matter much anyway,” a lynx said through gritted teeth. “We’ll check every animal here! Interrogate them! We’ll weed out that phantom in no time, before they can take even one of us!”

“Uhhh, what’s a phantom?” a young cougar asked innocently. “And why are they so bad? I thought phantom meant ghost. Ghosts don’t seem that bad.”

Liza watched all the nasty words and threats being flung around carelessly like food in a food fight. She narrowed her eyes and banged her staff onto the ground, making a low, resonating sound that brought the crowd’s attention back onto her. 

“Everyone, please calm down!” she said firmly. “We do not know what the phantom wats with us, but just because there’s a single enemy living within our home doesn’t give you a reason to start accusing everyone you see! This is how the phantoms try to break the bonds between us, remember?” Her voice softened and she relaxed her grip on her staff. 

“Do not worry. I have hurried back to Jamaa simply because of this. I will work with the other alphas to find the intruder, swiftly and safely. I have told you all this because I want each of you to look out for yourself, your friends, and your neighbors.”

“But what if our friends or neighbors are the-” Liza silenced an eagle with a gesture of her hand.

“Put your trust in your friends and neighbors. It’ll be more worth it if you do. Now, I would like all of you to be alert, aware of your surroundings, aware of what a phantom is.” She glanced at the younger animals in the crowd, who mostly seemed to be yawning and completely unfazed by this news. “Because I can tell that many of you haven’t been teaching them about them. Study up on phantoms. Please. It will help us later, for it seems like the phantoms aren’t completely gone yet.” She stared at the crowd again, with a serious but hopeful look in her eyes.

“Thank you for coming to listen. If we work together, the dangers to Jamaa may finally be put to rest. Now if you’ll excuse me, I have to alert the animals of outer Jamaa on this as well.” 

And with a swirl of lights and emerald-colored dust, she was gone.

And so, the animals started to slowly dissipate from the crowd, most of the animals still mumbling and muttering to themselves or their family members about the alert. No words were off-limits when describing the phantom spy, and some were ones that would have you thrown out of the Mt. Shiveer Hot Cocoa Hut in an instant if you dared to speak them. And the workers would be so displeased with you they would start charging you extra for each mini marshmallow you put in your hot cocoa.

Elmer, who was now rather tired from holding a coyote and a penguin, set both of them down on the ground. Mellow quickly waddled over to him and whispered a quick summary of the whole thing into his ear. 

The huge polar bear suddenly lost his balance and fell back onto his bottom. He stared at the ground, not even trying to look up and face the news. 

None of them could speak. Juniper’s eyes stared directly into Mellow’s. She felt dizzy and unstable, thinking back to last night when she bumped into that peculiar arctic wolf. Finally, she found her words again.

“Mellow?”

“Uh huh,” he said, still shaking a bit from the shock and chaos of it all.

“It looks like history class is gonna finally pay off.”

=== Chapter 4- Morning Mail ===
Juniper blinked her eyes open, hearing the ring sounds of an alarm clock that blared next to her. Her eyelids felt like they were going to close shut any moment, and her legs and muscles ached.

She groaned and flopped over on her pile of mats before slamming a paw down on the clock. It stopped ringing, and now Juniper was left with a moment of serenity and quietness to decide whether or not to get up. 

After listening to Liza speak, Juniper didn’t remember much after that. The significance of the events after the announcement paled in comparison to the speech itself, and she just couldn’t get the news out of her mind. All she knew was that she walked for a bit around Jamaa before going home and settling down, only to find that she couldn’t sleep. Too much had happened. Too much to process.

Juniper stared at the clock blankly. It still felt too early to think clearly. She looked at the hands of the clock and saw the small hand positioned on the six, and the large hand positioned somewhere between the seven and the eight.

''I guess I still have some time before I need to get ready for school'', she thought. 

And so, Juniper continued to stare at the clock, an empty look on her face. She didn’t bother trying to go back to sleep, and just tried to sort out her thoughts in her mind. She thought about her classmates; the phantom spy; the weird wolf with a weird aura; what all of this meant for Juniper herself.

Should she try to investigate the wolf further?

''He could be anywhere by now though'', she thought dejectedly to herself. 

Prepare for battle against the phantoms? 

''Not even sure if there’s gonna be a battle, plus who’s gonna train me anyway?''

Learn more about the phantoms?

''Actually, that doesn’t sound too bad.'' Miss Flora was about to teach them about phantoms after all, had it not been for the siren going off at the perfect time. And besides, that would count as some form of preparation, at least.

Okay, that was the plan. With a new flow of vigor and enthusiasm, she immediately hopped out of bed, ready to finally begin her day. She smiled.

And then the muscle aches started to kick in.

''Ouch.'' She rubbed her thigh with her snout, feeling around for the sore. She even waved one leg off the ground, flexing it a few times to determine how bad it was. ''What was I even doing last night?'' 

She then remembered her walks. ''Oh right.''

Juniper decided the aches were bearable and could probably wear off in an hour or two. So, she walked over to her fridge, grabbed the fridge handle with her jaws and opened it, and prepared to get something to eat.

There were a few slices of watermelon she had bought on… well, who knows what day… that caught her eye the quickest. Probably because the rest of her food stash were frozen lizards and frogs and she felt a bit guilty eating them when other animals were literally raising them as pets. No one would see her in her own den, but still. 

Juniper had just about set the watermelon down on the table when she heard the flapping of wings outside, and something heavy landing. A few seconds later, there was a knock on her door.

She sighed. Not even a single bite. 

The coyote walked over to the door and clamped the doorknob with her teeth. She turned her head to the left and pushed. The door didn’t budge. 

''Oh wait, wrong direction.'' Doorknobs were unnecessarily frustrating for her, especially when she didn’t have opposable thumbs. She could practically hear the invisible pandas, monkeys, lemurs, and koalas laughing at her. 

She turned her head right and pushed, hearing a small click sound as the door swung open.

Standing in front of her was a blue and red striped eagle with a satchel on his back. 

“Morning mail for you!” he said cheerfully.

Juniper tilted her head. “Mail?”

“Yup!” he chimed. “Mail! For Juniper Canyonpaw!” He slid the satchel off his back with a wing and reached in with a claw, ruffling the papers around. Finally, the eagle pulled it out of his bag, an envelope pierced by the talon. He scanned the letter’s address and gave a satisfied nod.

“This one’s coming to you all the way from Coral Canyons,” he informed her.

“Coral Canyons?” Juniper said with a look of shock on her face, before settling into the realization. “Oh wait, probably from my parents. Almost forgot about those monthly letters.”

“Mmm,” the eagle said. He slid the envelope off his talon with his beak, and leaned forward before dropping it on the ground in front of Juniper.

“There you go, dear lady!” he said gracefully.

“Oh, um.” The coyote glanced down at the punctured envelope. “Thanks?”

The eagle nodded. “No worries. Just doing my job! Oh, and speaking of which…” He spread his wings. “I still have mail to deliver! Goodbye!”

And so, with a few flaps of his wings and a convenient gust of wind, he was gone.

Juniper shrugged and carried the envelope inside with her mouth.

She pinned the envelope down to the floor with a paw and used her teeth to rip the flap open. Juniper spat the loose flap out of her mouth and looked ''at the now-opened envelope. There was a single letter inside, which had a hole near the top. Using a paw, she gently slid it out of the envelope and began reading.''

''Dear Juniper,''

''Hi! It’s been a while since you’ve moved to a den in Jamaa Township, and we know we’ve been asking you this since the first letter we’ve sent. But, like the concerned parents we are, we just want to know if you’re still doing O.K. Is school alright? Other animals treating you just fine? How about friends? Speaking of friends, Snickety and Sleek really miss you, and even admitted that their games just aren’t the same without you. So maybe come visit us again? If you have time available, that is :). We’ll write back soon, and hope to see you again!''

''Love,''

''      Mom and Dad''

''P.S. You don’t have to write back unless something’s really concerning you. We know how much fun you’re having here!''

Juniper  looked at the letter with a sad and longing look. ''Fun?'' She thought to herself, thinking about all the recent events. ''Yeah. Sort of. It only started to get interesting yesterday.'' She walked over to the dining table and started munching on her breakfast watermelon.

Honestly, she kind of wanted to go back and visit her parents. And Snickety and Sleek. Those two were fun. Maybe it would be in the plans one day, when she had multiple days free to visit Coral Canyons and see them again. Not anytime soon though, as long as the phantom threat and summer school were still around…

Juniper took the last bite of watermelon, having shaved off every bit around the rind. Small pieces of watermelon and watermelon juice littered the table and floor, as well as her face. She wiped the wet underside of her snout with a paw.

“Yuck,” she cringed when the sticky juice got on her fur. She would just have to wash it off in a pond or river, because right now…

Juniper checked the alarm clock by her bed again. The long hand had moved to between the nine and the ten.

''Still a good hour and then some to get to school,'' she thought optimistically to herself. 

Juniper got up and opened the door, still spending a minute or so fumbling with the doorknob. She pushed it open though, and followed the dirt path that led outside her house and to the rest of Jamaa.

= Chapter 5- Late? =
Turned out Juniper’s clock was lying to her. 

“What?” Juniper shouted in disbelief, looking at the clock on the Jamaa Township bulletin board. 

7:30

She brushed away some pinned papers and posters, just to make sure her eyes weren’t deceiving her.

7:30.

The coyote shook her head. ''Yeah, pretty sure I didn’t take an entire forty minutes leaving my den''. She sighed. ''Looks like the clock went rogue again.'' 

Now she only had thirty minutes to get to school. At top speeds, she bolted towards Sarepia Forest, startling some animals in the result. They glared at her with suspicious and annoyed looks.

“Hey! Stop pushing!”

“Where are you off to in such a hurry? It’s summer!”

“I’m telling you, no sane animal would be this squirrely. This has to be the phantom. Come back! I’ve got some questions for you!”

“Sarepia Forest, eh?” an elephant with pink spots had said to her when she was about to cross the bridge. “I knew the newly-released movie at the theater was good, but wow, this is a whole new level.”

“I’m not going to watch the movie,” she calmly explained. “I’m going to school!”

“Summer school? Feel bad for you. Hope it goes well though.”

Juniper nodded and continued on her way.

She trotted through Sarepia Forest, gazing at the lights and fireflies while walking; never stopping even for a second. While her eyes might have been on the sights of the forest, her mind couldn’t stop thinking about one word.

''Late. Late. Late. Late. Late. I’m gonna be so late if I keep walking like this.''

Juniper quickened her pace a little. A minute later, she quickened her pace even more. The muscle aches came back, but she ignored them. Another minute passed, and, still unsure of her walking speed, quickened her pace again. She was really kicking up the dirt below her now.

Not two minutes later, she broke into a full-on run.

Muscle aches or no muscle aches, she had to get to school on time no matter how her legs were feeling. 

The wind struck her in the face, making her want to yell out loud. Not because she was in pain or anything, but just because she felt so… alive. 

“I’M NOT GONNA BE LATE!” she screamed to no one in particular. Her throat burned after she shouted that, but whatever. She did a sharp right turn into the woods, a small path created by the cleared out trees. Juniper could just barely see the schoolhouse at the end of the path, resting in a clearing in the forest. The light that shone down on it gave it a rustic and isolated feel. A little house in the woods it would be, if it wasn’t so big. 

An orange flag with a paw design was attached to a long pole. It flapped in the wind, making sharp whipping sounds.

Juniper didn’t even stop running. She looked behind her, checking to see if anyone else was coming. Didn’t look like it.

''Either I’m really early or really late.''

Suddenly, the coyote’s shoulder slammed against someone. It was a someone, because that someone made a squealing sound upon impact.

“Oof!” Juniper grunted. Her body bounced off and she lost her balance, beginning to fall backwards. Luckily, she planted her foot back just in time, and she regained balance again. She sighed in relief.

The one she bumped into wasn’t so pleased though. “Hey! What was that for?”

Juniper looked right in front of her and saw a spotted pig rubbing his cheek with a hoof. 

“Sorry!” she said quickly. “Sorry, uh…” She thought to herself, trying to remember. What was his name again? Sergeant? Sherbet? Scooter?

“Scooter!” she said out loud.

The pig looked mildly miffed. “Yeah, that’s my name. And what’s yours anyway? Speedy McSpeedster?”

“Well it’s actually-” Juniper tried to politely correct him.

Scooter snorted. “I was kidding. I remember you, Juniper. I remember everyone’s names. But how come you were running so fast? Almost thought phantoms were after you.”

“I just didn’t want to be late for class, and how come YOU’RE patrolling around the school?” she shot back. “Isn’t the classroom supposed to be inside?”

Scooter threw back his head and scoffed, one of his ears flopping to the side. “Why, phantom lookout! What else?” He scanned the woods with narrowed eyes, even doing a 360 turn. “That phantom spy could be anywhere in Jamaa. In Jamaa Township. In the Kimbara Outback hospital. Even in your HOUSE.” He whirled around to stare Juniper dead in the eyes, somehow trying to scare her.

“O-kay,” she said, unfazed. “My house doesn’t even have anything good anyway. Just some food, pillows, and papers.” She looked around her, not seeing a single animal in sight. “Am I early or late?”

But Scooter paid no attention and continued rambling on. “But I believe they have special reason to be creeping around the school, you see. Miss Flora’s teaching us about phantoms today, right? Including ways to defeat them, right? And this spy is a phantom, right? Who doesn’t want to be defeated, right?” He put emphasis on each ‘right’, convinced that he was getting somewhere.

“Scooter, it’s summer,” Juniper huffed. “If they were planning to attack a schoolhouse, it would’ve been at least while school was still in session. I’m not even sure if phantoms have ever heard of summer school before. Pretty sure they’re not gonna be planting phantom troops around a house in the middle of the forest.”

Scooter glared at her, intent on shooting back with a witty remark or quip. But then his gaze lessened and he gave in. He sat on his back feet and shrugged. “Yeah, you’re probably right. I’m just trying to save my bacon here, alright? Gotta watch out for the phantoms to make sure they don’t get the upper hand.  If the phantoms launch another full-scale invasion then I’m pretty sure they wouldn’t hesitate to eat the delicious animals first instead of capturing them.” He pointed a hoof to himself. “I’M the delicious animal! Do you know how many pork jokes have been made at my expense?”

“...too many?” Juniper replied, unsure on how else to respond.

“Exactly!” Scooter exclaimed. “They’ll capture me, grab the ol’ Chef Goop’s Best Ways to Cook 40+ Different Species of Animals- Deliciously Nasty Edition recipe book from their non-existent library, dust it off, go to the Pig chapter, and start reading. But then they’ll rip the book apart, because who even knows if phantoms can read. They’ll just invent their own recipe and throw me in a tub of phantom goop soup! Toast me above an open fire! Cackle to themselves about the meal they’re hav-”

“Okay okay!” Juniper yelled, getting more anxious by the second. “I get it! I get it! Can we at least go inside first? I still have no idea if I’m early or late!”

Scooter mumbled a bit and headed through the great big doors of the school. Juniper followed right behind him, and together, they walked to their classroom.

They entered the classroom, Scooter shutting the door behind them, and Juniper was surprised to see the rest of their classmates already there. Duchess had a small, green pod on her desk that she rolled from one side of her desk to the other, a bored expression on her face. The pod was spiky and round, and Juniper noted that it looked identical to those fruits she saw growing in trees. Nobody ever told her what they were, though,

Mellow and Elmer were hanging around in the desks in the back, with Elmer now resorting to sitting next to his still-broken desk. The penguin, meanwhile, was fidgeting around and mumbling to himself. Maybe he was still trying to come up with a good explanation for the broken desk. 

The thing that surprised Juniper the most, however, was that the chalkboard still had the chalk phantom doodle, and everything was arranged nicely in its place, just like how Miss Flora had left it yesterday when class ended abruptly. 

Oh, and also the fact that Miss Flora wasn’t there.

Juniper stared at the empty spot where Miss Flora should have been standing. “So, if the teacher isn’t here, that means I’m not late, right?”

“Mmm,” everyone muttered with uncertainty.

    <title>Yuna Hanamura</title>
    <ns>0</ns>

      <text bytes="15611" sha1="cm72z6x3vkgn3w6mj3p92amzfhzksyb" xml:space="preserve">''This article is made by Auryze. You get the gist, don't edit it without permission ;)''

'''Thank you so much HazyFacade for the sketch! Coloring by me.''' {{Character idk|title1=Yuna Hanamura|nickname=Yu-Yu &lt;small&gt;(By Nabi)&lt;/small&gt;&lt;br&gt;Yu-chan &lt;small&gt;(By Locaster)&lt;/small&gt;|age=24|height=5'11|species=50% Shadow Demon|status=Alive|job=Professional Herbalist|residence=Syuna|affiliation=Unknown|alignment=Good|relatives=Unnamed Mother &lt;small&gt;(deceased)&lt;/small&gt;&lt;br&gt;Unnamed Father &lt;small&gt;(deceased)&lt;/small&gt;&lt;br&gt;Locaster Helios &lt;small&gt;(distant cousin)&lt;/small&gt;&lt;br&gt;Shay Hanamura &lt;small&gt;(younger brother)&lt;/small&gt;|allies=Locaster Helios, Karoshi, Vivian Lu, Hikage Ishuko, Shay Hanamura,  Soul Kawasaki, Hideko Inazuma, Shizuka Ikami &lt;small&gt;(neutral)&lt;/small&gt; Ashton Khanh &lt;small&gt;(neutral)&lt;/small&gt; Nabi Haluška, Fēng Xu|enemies=Crow Watanabe, Akuji Hasegawa, Ashton Khanh &lt;small&gt;(Formerly)&lt;/small&gt;, Cassian Packard|image1=&lt;gallery&gt;

Yuna silly.png|Animal Jam

'''Yuna Hanamura''' is a major supporting character of a Good Vs. Evil Roleplay. She the distant cousin of [[Locaster Helios|Locaster]] and is fifty percent of a shadow demon. She is [[Shay Hanamura|Shay's]] older sister and an enhanced herbalist who helps the group of shard users, including his brother and distant cousin to reunite the gems. Due to her high intelligence and efficient potion making, she is a profound potion and poison maker.  

== History ==
Yuna was born in the southern part of Leiden with her brother. In the area they lived in, crops were rich during the summer times and were easy to harvest for heavy winters that were commonly used in order to make ends meet. Despite being at a rather low status, Yuna's family was a bright one and ensured that she would have a better future and pursue education. 

During this time, her brother, Shay, was born and Yuna had begun multi-tasking with pursuing what she wanted to be and learning how to be a proper sibling in order to have a strong bond with him. When he got older, Yuna started showing affection towards him and the two started to have an unusually good sibling relationship without arguing with one another about pointless things. Due to their strong bond, Yuna and Shay often times worked together without much issues despite some minor bickering they do and some small play-fights they occasionally had. 

The both of them were described as hard workers while being the opposite personality wise, as Yuna was a more gentle and carefree child who often worked hard with little interest in adventure, while Shay was an adventurous yet quiet and determined to try anything new that comes his way, but he too also was a hard-worker, being described as a keen intellect for his age.     

At the age of twelve, Yuna started to grow an interest in potions and herbs after her mother had treated her brothers wound with a specific kind of ointment that healed his scar up in an instant. She began learning from her mother at first by studying with the books her mother had and eventually learned more about herbs and potions in schools, while her brother studied about the military due to his dreams of becoming a high-ranking individual in the army due to his infatuation with the military.       

Though, at this age, her demon abilities started to develop much earlier than expected due to female demons developing much quicker than male demons. Soon realizing her new abilities and features,  Yuna was expected to cover her claws with gloves and her horns with a cape that had a hood attached in order to not get spotted by guards due to the peak of demons being murdered solely because of their species because of the rate of homicides rising in both Leiden and Myria. Even though she was rather peeved by this new rule, she was understanding of her parents motivations to protect her so she could pursue what she longed to be, and not have her life ended so early all because of her species.         

Despite this, Shay and Yuna had a fairly good childhood without much problems or difficulty with one another or having strained relationships with either one of their parents, the both of them having high amounts of intelligence with bright minds. Unfortunately, one day Yuna and Shay were allowed to play outside for sometime, but accidentally exceeded the time limit from when they need to go back, and once they had arrived home, their parents were murdered by soldiers of Leiden, specifically the Demon Task Force division that was sent to hunt down the mysterious [[Damion Halloreen|shadow demon and spirit hybrid]] that had been killing citizens from both Myria and Leiden.          

Yuna was spotted by the guards without her gloves or hood on, and was mistaken as the hybrid the division was looking for, and quickly begun to chase her and her brother, constantly having to use her magic in order to tackle some of the guards down to move farther away from the southern district, but due to the energy required to use larger and larger spells, Yuna eventually got tired and the siblings were surrounded by many of the troops in the Demon Task Force. Before they were about to seize Yuna solely, Shay had created a loud bird squawk that resulted in the task forces ears bleeding and causing them to retreat from the area.               

Due to the squawk, Yuna only had partial ear pain for a couple of days, but unfortunately for her brother, he lost his hearing entirely in order to save her from getting caught by Leiden's guards. Yuna had started to harden herself and attempted to learn things she never initially had done before. Instead of talking to Shay normally, she had adapted into writing her responses to him in a little notebook while studying sign language and teaching it to Shay.                 

After some time, though, he had gotten more fluent with sign language and was able to read lips to anyone that was talking to him, being able to communicate with his sister while still having to adjust to new accustoms. The squawk had also damaged Shay's vocal cords and restricted his speech, meaning he can only say a couple words at a time without feeling excruciating pain. As Shay started to adjust to sign language, Yuna begun to live her life normally after the both of them had built their shelter, Syuna, which would house and keep them safe for a long time.                  

== Appearance ==

=== Gacha Club Model ===
''(NOTE: this character has two appearances: one Animal Jam model, and one Gacha Club model. The Gacha Club model is supposed to give a more accurate sense of what they would look like as a person, and not in Animal Jam. The Animal Jam Models and Gacha Club Models are used to show them both In animal jam and as an actual person.)''

Yuna is a tall woman of Tswana and Japanese descent with a lean stature, being taller than Ashton by one inch and Locaster by six inches. She has wavy, silver hair that extends to her lower back and two different colored eyes, one eye being white and one eye being a light gray tint with two black stars in the center. On top of her head is a flower crown with light blue and white roses held by thin branches that are not visible.   

Yuna wears a black cloak that covers most of her body with a light blue and white bodysuit-type shirt and a long, white skirt that covers her legs entirely. Underneath, she wears white socks that go up to her thighs and brown geta sandles.   

When she reveals her demon abilities, two horns are now present on the sides of her head and black, enlarged claws with purple outlining form on her hands. In this state, her powers enhance to a great extent.   

=== Animal Jam Model ===
Yuna's Animal Jam Model consists of a tall arctic wolf with a dark gray outer fur and lighter gray inner fur with white eyes and black patterns on her fur.   

Yuna dons wears a white flower crown, a black mysterious cloak, an epic feathered tail and black elf bracelets on her wrists.  

== Personality ==
Yuna, despite usually staying inside her home of Syuna, is described as a very gentle and carefree woman with a welcoming aura, a great usage of her own words and a bright mind. She has been described as intelligent and educated by her brother and many of the members in the group, being able to gather information in the blink of an eye and is rather descriptive with what she says. According to Shay, Yuna is very protective to those around her, especially her close companions and family, mainly [[Shay Hanamura|her brother]] and [[Locaster Helios|Locaster]], and shows a motherly love to the group.        

Even though she is a rather brave and fearless soul, she has demonstrated to have a fear for scary stories, as she had gotten frightened when Veena explained the legend of [[Shítǐ|Mr. No-Face]], or sometimes referred to as the dark entity, opposite from her younger brother, who takes a keen interest in horror stories without flinching. She is often teased for her scared demeanor, but justifies her fear after implying she has intrusive thoughts about sorts of horror stories that she heard when she was a child. According to Shay, Yuna has an odd fear of jack-o-lanterns because of their scary faces that are carved into them or anything scary for that matter.        

Yuna has demonstrated to get extremely flattered when shown chivalry by any individual, immediately being charmed at any sort of affection being shown directly to her and seemingly takes a keen interest in mannerisms from those around her. According to Shay, Yuna is a very easily smitten person and is able to get swayed with by just a few words. Though, she is sometimes described as rather quiet and often prefers to work with close friends or simply with her brother. She has shown to lack some social skills and sometimes stammers on her words out of nervousness or simply being smitten.          

Being a herbalist, Yuna has an extended knowledge about herbs and potions. She is sometimes described as Shay as being obsessed with them due to her endlessly researching new potions and herbs, causing her to stay inside and somewhat act like a recluse. Yuna mainly enjoys researching and often does so alone so no one can distract her, and as noted by [[Hideko Inazuma|Hideko]], she is somewhat of an introvert despite interacting with the group when necessary. Along with being a profound healer, she was shown to be skilled enough to remove the drug Akuji had given to Locaster during their time detained in Lyakon.              

== Abilities ==
'''Overall Abilities:''' As a healer, Yuna is both an exceptional combatant and skilled healer. Taking an interest in potions and herbs when she was younger, she often includes those skills whenever in combat due to her having the incapability of inflicting physical attacks and opts to use her magic and herb skills combined to make up for her inexperience in some forms of combat. She has also exemplified to have great navigational skills, being able to sense the Lyakonian soldiers coming from each direction in order to tell the designated members patrolling the area if they are planning on an ambush. Yuna has proven to be more of a defense and navigator than an offense fighter and is often attributed to when having to heal others.     

'''Immense Speed &amp; Reflexes:''' Like most demons, Yuna has proven to be incredible fast and agile, speeding over to Locaster after his wings were ripped off in order to asist him and dodging the Lyakonian soldier's bullets while being injured. She was also able to evade most of Lilith's attacks from when they were trying to separate both her and Arcana from their soul. She has also proven to have fast reflexes, dodging most of the Lyakonian soldiers attacks and managing to surprise attack them without much difficulty and out-pacing Crow in his steps.     

'''Immense Strength:''' Despite having weak arms, Yuna possesses inhuman-like strength. His is shown when she was able to land on the ground with ease after falling off of Shay's back due to him getting shot. She has also proven her strength when she nearly punches Akuji in the face, leaving a small dent on his cheek after. She was able to nearly take out Crow without difficulty, almost landing a severe hit that could have killed him, but missed.      

'''Immense Durability:''' Despite not being the strongest, Yuna's body has proven to be incredibly durable, withstanding fatal attacks from Cassian after she attempts to shield Shay from getting hurt further and managed to overcome a bullet wound to the leg, still having the ability to run while having a large wound.       

'''Unlimited Stamina &amp; Endurance:''' Yuna possesses an incredibly high level of both stamina and endurance, never getting tired or exhausted when in combat and manages to remain in the same physical and psychological state. She was able to outnumber waves of attacks being launched at her by Crow as if it were nothing. She showed near complete immunity to one of The Dark Entity's many attacks that would have killed her and managed to remain standing for the remainder of the battle.             

'''Tactical Intellect:''' Studying herbology and potions since she was twelve, Yuna displays to have incredible intelligence and coordination skills. He was able to use the information from many books and knowledge from her brother in order to make potions and sometimes explosives to coordinate her attacks against her opponents. Yuna was able to successfully inject a lethal poison into Shítǐ in order to weaken him and was able to correctly guess many of his next attacks when doing so. With her knowledge in herbs, she managed to make a potion that would heal up most of Locaster's wounds after Akuji had ripped his wings off.               

'''Healing:''' Like Hideko, Yuna's blood contains unique properties, where if she feeds someone a portion of her blood, she is able to heal them in an instant. Though, larger wounds tend to require larger quantities in order to heal entirely.                

== Magic Abilities ==
'''Unbrakinesis:''' Being half shadow demon, Yuna has proven to have powerful unbrakinesis. She is able to control masses of dark magic, seen when she is fighting off the Lyakonian soldiers by summoning large black vines in order to slam them down. 

'''"Berserk":''' Yuna, like Locaster, has a "berserk" form when she fully awakens her powers, growing two horns and claws. Her abilities increase immensely after she activates her "berserk" form: In this form, she gains ink-like claws, longer horns and markings on her face. She was able to knock down Crow effortlessly when using this form and nearly managed to kill him. She does not use her berserk form as much because of how much energy it requires. 

'''Demonic Entity:''' Though only displayed once, Yuna has the ability to summon a drawn-like demon entity with large horns and white scribbly eyes that was able to drain the energy out of the Lyakonian soldiers. Though, this spell requires extreme concentration and energy. The entity has the capability of making a shockwave energy blast via a large screech it can deliver, but this ability still has yet to be seen in the story. 

== Weaknesses ==
'''Overuse:''' Yuna is prone to overusing her magic without realizing, especially using larger spells that require large amounts of energy to use.

    <title>Misaya Myat</title>
