"It's a nice day today," Isaac said, smiling. 

He wasn't selling it. I was shaking all over, not even caring about what the awkward leeway would be like, just terrified of the facts, the thing he was about to say. 

I knew this wouldn't last, I knew it, but I really did love him, I loved Isaac, and I never wanted to hurt his feelings or make him feel pressured or--

And then everything just fell out. Just like that, I was completely deflated.

"Isaac, I'm so, so, sorry, I didn't want to pressure you to kiss me or-- or-- go out with me, I guess- or even go on one date with me in the first place-- I just-- I really thought that- 

"I'm sorry and I- I didn't mean to do anything to hurt you, I really didn't, and I know you hate me and you want to break up with me and you probably never even had any feelings for me but if I'm not a total bigoted creep to you then please just give me one more chance- 

"Please, at least let me just be your friend, because I'm really sorry, and I promise I won't ever do anything like this again, and that--"

I was crying. 

My eyes were blurred with tears, and it felt like the little bit of salt was stinging them, trying to numb the pain in a way, but reality was all around me, right in front of me, even the past-- my parents' voices, them arguing the night I came out, everything, everything at once...

Luka approached. She raised a paw to place on my shoulder, then hesitantly glanced at Isaac.  

She then walked away towards the turquoise polar bear, who now sat at another table in the courtyard, frowning. 

"Si," Isaac whispered. "Hey, Si. Why don't you have a seat? It sounds like we have a lot to talk about. But before we start, let me clear something up. I'm about as straight as your hair right now, okay? And there's no way in hell I'm breaking up with you." 

I... he was sugarcoating it. He didn't think it would hurt me this much, did he? Haha. 

"Si," Isaac repeated, "everything is going to be OK. Everything is going to be OK. You hear me? Repeat after me, Si: Everything is going to be OK."

"You're... you're breaking up with me. You don't have to lie. I... I get why," I said, shivering, hoping that my chills and my nerves would just go away, now that I knew what Isaac thought.

"No. No, I'm not. Simon. Simon, please. I..."

He wasn't going to say those three words.

"Simon Larring, I want to be your boyfriend."

&lt;nowiki&gt;*****&lt;/nowiki&gt;

I wasn't sure what kind of tears were sliding down my cheeks. 

I was sweaty. And nervous.

Because what was this?

Did he just say "I love you?"

Or did he ask me out?

What?

I was confused. Very confused. 

I looked up at him. He was right there, right in front of me, kind of smiling. Kind of? What was I thinking?

"Did you just break up with me then get back together with me?"

What. Did. I. Just. Say. 

Isaac laughed. He. Laughed. God, I missed his laugh...

What was I even doing? This was crazy. Crazy.

I was still crying. I was so, so happy. And sad. Why was I sad?

"Isaac, God, I..."

"You're an idiot, Simon. An adorable idiot."

"I ''am'' sorry. I ''am'' an idiot."

"Don't be hard on yourself. That's not anyone's job, especially yours."

"That's not what people usually say," I replied dryly, trying to drain out the rest of my tears.

"Hey, Si. Are you sure you're alright? I mean..."

"I'm fine," I said, throwing on a smile as quickly as possible. "Everything's great. We're going to do the interviews soon!"

"We can take a break. We can ask to film later. We can have the night to ourselves," Isaac offered, grabbing my paw. "We can just hang out."

"Just... just hang out," I repeated loopily.

"Yeah," Isaac said, "that sounds good." He smiled. Again.

There was a lot of smiling. I liked that. Isaac made me smile. I made Isaac smile.

It was kind of magic. I'd never expected it. That checks off the first box, haha. And, I mean... just... this was a dream. A literal dream. Come alive. Breathing. Heart, beating. Beautiful...

I cherished this. It was everything. 

Isaac leaned in for a kiss, a little cheekily. He held my paws, and we embraced each other. 

The birdsong became romantic, and took another turn, and soon there was an orchestra, each instrument playing softly, with peace, with gratitude, with care. The world slowed down, and soon Isaac took me into his arms, and it was like a hug, but better, because it was Isaac...

He guided me. He saw for me. He took me through a series of motion: stepping backwards, and forwards, and to the left, and to the right... a box step. A slow dance.

He smiled. I smiled. There was so much smiling. There was music filling the air. Everything was perfect. 

I pushed closer, clumsily stepping over him. Perfect, still. He slipped up as I rebalanced, but it was still perfect. 

His tender lips met mine. A rush of emotion poured through our kisses, a river of song, a river of beauty... a vast river. 

His paws gently grazed my cheeks. Cautiously, he sheathed his claws. Warmth, emitting from my body, from his...

A flame, engulfed in hope, in embarrassment, in laughter, in glee, in mischief, in satisfaction, in mistakes, in misunderstanding, in sorrows, in tears, in grief, in scolding, in mockery, in teasing, in flirting, in smiles, in jokes, in kisses...

Associated with long walks in the park that came with ice cream and hot dogs, with awkward failed attempts at flirtation, with solitary moments of the most wonderful sort of quiet, with Friday night movies and pepperoni pizza, with secret afterschool kisses, with staying up too late at sleepovers and just talking about life, with soaring hopes and childhood dreams and long-lost wishes.

Lights, everywhere.

== 2. Aeros ==
"Er, hey. I'm Aeros. One of the reporters here. I was going to be interviewing you two..." 

The turquoise polar bear from earlier stood awkwardly beside us. Isaac laughed and pushed me aside, which I found somewhat offensive. 

It still hurt, though... I really thought Isaac was going to break up with me. Guess I didn't know much about love. I deliberately thought that my boyfriend was straight.

He didn't say he loved me...

Maybe it was too soon. Maybe something else was going on. I didn't want to rush this. I wanted it to last, I wanted it to be as a beautiful a story as Isaac himself... Isaac, he really was a prince. 

"...So I thought that we could do it at different times, different days. It would make it easier for all of us, I think."

"Yeah! Sounds great. Simon and I wanted to have dinner first, since it's getting late... Oh! Maybe we could get to know each other, though, so it's not so awkward. We were planning to spend some time together, the three of us... but if you have time in your work schedule, you could join us," Isaac answered, looking to Aeros.

"What? Dinner? When?" I questioned, jumping up in confusion. 

I wasn't even paying attention. Stupid, stupid. Aeros was standing there, still looking kind of shy and unsure. 

He had been talking, definitely. What about, though? Wait... Aeros was having dinner with us? We were having dinner with some random journalist?

Was this someone who knew Mr. Johnston? Was Aeros going to twist our words? Did he really know everything we'd gone through? Did he even know us? What was going to happen with this? 

This was all me. It was all my fault. I'd been the one who started the whole thing. But no, something had to be done about Mr. Johnston. This wasn't just about me. Luka needed support. Someone had to stand up for her. 

The only people that were willing to do that in the first place were Isaac and I. This was our job, regardless of what we wanted... regardless of what I wanted.  

This went beyond my dreams. I wished that this could just be my dreams, and only my dreams. Not yet. I had to fight. This was the right thing to be doing. 

And besides, this didn't negatively affect us. Really, it would give us more nights for ourselves, where we really were ourselves...

"Alright, Simon! Aeros is going to come with us for dinner. So he can get to know us better before the interview. He said it wasn't protocol, but he felt like it would just be better if we did. We just need to figure out where we actually want to go, haha. I assumed you wanted a place with fries and milkshakes, since those are the only two things you eat," Isaac joked.

"Well, you know, I thought it would just be us, and that we could ''share'' a milkshake," I whined, though it was kind of true, because I did want to have more one-on-one time... it was selfish, though. This was for more than that.

"Come on, Si. We've got to pick a place with real food- I'm in a taco mood myself," Isaac answered cheerily, taking my paw and standing up. "Let's go get Luka! She's somewhere around here, I think."

&lt;nowiki&gt;*****&lt;/nowiki&gt; 

By the time we found Luka and realized that none of us were actually ready for the interview, we agreed to tell Aeros at dinner that we needed a few days. 

So much for all of that excitement in the morning. Isaac seemed a little disappointed now, so I was determined to select the perfect restaurant. Not that this was actually a date.

"So," I suggested, "what about Mexican food? I'm sure there's got to be a good taco place somewhere."

"Oh," Luka replied, "I don't know. Maybe. We could try tacos. I mean, I don't eat a lot of meat, but I'm sure there'd be other options."

Isaac stared at me. 

"Simon," he said warningly. "Please don't make this about me. I don't care. You know that, right? It's fine. I need more time too. Besides, this isn't a date. This is just a friend thing!"

"Well," I said, trying to be as subtle as possible, "I'm in a taco mood."

Epic failure. Least subtle lion in the world. 

Luka shifted worriedly. "I'll do whatever," she said.

Isaac glanced back at her. "Hey... are you thinking about Kara?"

"Yeah," Luka muttered. "She really likes Mexican food. But, I mean, I don't care. Tacos are good. I just... I know that the wound was bad. She's not dead though, yeah? I just kind of... it felt like she was dead. I know she isn't. I got her an ambulance. Mr. Johnston didn't say or do anything, but... she got to the hospital. She lived."

"Hey," Isaac said softly, "She's still alive. She has to be. She got to the hospital. She's better by now, then."

"I haven't seen her in so long. So long that I just assumed she was... dead. But I called them that night, they s''aid'' she would live. And I need that to be true. I just drilled it into my mind that she died. If I could see her again..."

"So," I said, "Mexican food, then?"

"Sorry. It will get better, I know it. And I do want to talk about it. It just seems hard to... talk about that night. With a stranger," Luka said, quieting her voice.

"No, no," I said, "stupid response on my part. I'm bad at this. ''I'm'' sorry. 

"And you don't have to apologize for thinking about her. But what I mean to say is, she's better now. She probably ditched school after that. I doubt any of her family would've even let her come back, if she wanted too. 

"But she misses you, too. If she stands in front of you when faced by a gun-" I faltered, feeling like maybe I was saying the wrong thing, "then she loves you."

"Thanks," Luka murmured, "for everything."

"Plus, I'm sure Aeros is a nice guy! And he seemed pretty chill about scheduling. I think it'll be good. And we don't have to go to a Mexican restaurant. I mean, we could just--"

Luka smiled. Which probably meant I was talking too fast. The fact that she, smiled, though, was a total relief. I took a deep breath and smiled back. Then, I turned to Isaac.

"Oh my God, Simon, you're the best," he gushed, blushing as he grabbed my paws. "You seriously don't have to persuade everyone to get what I want. Actually. I just appreciate what you're doing. Being here. You don't need to do anything showy."

A new voice called- I turned, suddenly facing Aeros. "I'm up for Mexican food," he said, "but it's 6 o' clock, so if we want to go, we should go now."

I nodded hurriedly, hoping that this night would turn out well. Isaac got his favorite food, which was a bonus. Yes, I admit, I'd prefer fries and a milkshake, but tacos were still good. And so what if I was weak when it came to spices? I didn't need to put hot sauce on anything. 

Alright, so I didn't really want tacos. But this was going to work. 

Isaac swept in for a kiss, his arms looping around my back, pressing onto me, lips locked in mine, blushing his cheeks off as he stepped away, staggering, beaming.

"I think that you're the best," I added, leaning in for another incredible kiss. 

He was happy. I was happy, too. And if the sacrifice was making a joke out of myself for having a taco consisting only of beans, sour cream, cheese, and rice, then it would be worth it.

&lt;nowiki&gt;*****&lt;/nowiki&gt;

This was awkward. 

"I should tell you a little bit about myself," Aeros said, "so this doesn't feel so weird."

"Um. Yeah. Sure. Go ahead," I replied, attempting to be as polite as possible. 

God. 

This was a lot. My parents were going to see this. This would be on the news, these interviews. The petitions- we weren't alone at Mr. Johnston's school, we really weren't, but so many kids were afraid to speak up because of the kids like Teddy, which there weren't actually that many of-- 

I... this was a good change. A great change! I was excited. Just nervous, was all. Nervous about what other people would think. 

Which was stupid. Because this was ''good.'' I was telling myself that a hell of a lot of times, though. 

Was I comfortable being filmed and talking about all this? As if my experiences alone were the worst of all? Since they weren't the worst. They weren't. They were awful, but they weren't the worst. Still, I'm not really comfortable, since it was something completely new.

Yet again, my train of thought halted as I realized I was supposed to be engaging in conversation.

"So, I get that this must be weird for all of you. But you have no idea how much it means. Not that it matters much or anything, but yeah, I'm a trans guy, and growing up I didn't have a ton of support, and sometimes I got treated like s*** for it. Which was never OK. 

"And your stories, I know they're personal and not that great or that happy, but... they say something about society. They can prove society is wrong. ''You'' can prove that," Aeros finished, inhaling sharply.

"Well... we already agreed to the interviews, anyway," Isaac chimed in, "so I think we're already doing them."

Awkward pause. My gaze turns to Isaac. He's breathing heavily. Something's wrong.

"If I was in your position, I would've done anything to get out of that school."

"It's more than that," I said. "We do care. We care about this. We want things to be better, ''everywhere.'' It's worse than just this one summer school. We don't want it to be like that. 

"We want to be able to love who we love and that not mean anything bad or wrong. We just want to live. That's why we're here. 

"We understand what this whole interview movement thing is about. We want to be a part of it. We want to stand up for each other, we want our community to feel safe and understood. 

"But we have a right to care for our own happiness, too. We have a right to care about ourselves. We're going to work hard on this, we're going to make sure it's seen and heard and makes an impact, but we're not going to be able to change the world in a day. 

"We're going to try. I'm going to try, but I can't say it's all going to change. And I... I don't want my whole life to be sitting and being interviewed about all the f*****-up things that happened to me. 

"I want to be able to..." I pause, then turn to Isaac, and squeeze his paw, letting myself get lost in his eyes for a moment before turning back to Aeros... "I want to be able to have a boyfriend. I want to be able to go on a real date with him. I want to be able to love him and not be afraid, not feel guilty, not feel ''ashamed.'' 

"But I'm still going to try. I'm going to try for him, for me, for Luka... for the people that were scared, too. For the people that were too scared to say anything. This ''is'' important to me. 

"But queer joy should be allowed. Our lives should not be a constant fight for- for our lives. A struggle to be treated with respect. Queer joy shouldn't be the next step, an added bonus, it should be part of this. I'm going to spend some time living my life, not just fighting."

"S***, Simon," Aeros muttered, "that was incredible."

I took a deep breath. I was standing up, and some people at other tables were literally ''staring'' at me. Some stranger in the background let out a whoop-whoop and applauded. 

Before I could say or do anything, Isaac squeezed my paw back, even tighter, and smiled- and in an instant, we were kissing.

In front of all the people in a packed restaurant. 

We weren't hiding. Some people cheered? Some people looked away? It didn't matter, though, because this what I was talking about- ''this.'' Us. Getting to live our lives without fighting for once. Just being happy. 

My boyfriend was awesome. I loved him. Was now a good time to say that? Maybe not yet. But I wasn't quite as nervous about saying it. But I was mostly focused on kissing him, and how handsome and adorable he was. 

How he saw that beauty in me. No one had really... felt like that before. Or, well, general love. I mean, sure, it's not like Isaac's my adoptive father, 'cause that would be really weird and sort of creepy, but... 

No one has ever actually, like, complimented me. No one has ever really cared.

But I'm ready for this. I want to be Isaac Malcher's boyfriend, and pretty recently, he said he wanted to be mine, too. Which meant we were boyfriends. Oh, s***, wait, I hadn't actually ''said'' that. 

I pull away from him for a semi-awkward fifty seconds. 

"Isaac Malcher, I accept your request to be my boyfriend. Will you accept mine?"

"Obviously," he laughs, kissing me again, and again, and again. 

There are two other people at our table. Which I remember, then sit back down and flash a smile at Isaac. He grins back and sits back down, too. That was incredible. 

"Okay, great," Aeros said, "but it is kind of getting late, so once we finish up our food, you guys should head back to your hotel." 

"Congratulations, you two," Luka said, "though maybe try not to make out so much when we do our interviews."

"Yeah, yeah, I get it," I replied, rolling my eyes. 

I scooped a tortilla chip into some homemade guac, took a bite out of it, then pretty much claimed the entire bowl after realizing how delicious the guac was. And graciously let Isaac steal some chips. And, out of sympathy, allowed one each to Aeros and Luka, after they refuted my argument of them having ordered actual food. 

It was a good night. Maybe not perfect, but pretty damn good, anyway.

== 3. Talk ==


We had returned to our hotel room, it was around 8:30. The sun had set already and some stars settled into the sky. I mean, you only really see seven stars through the singular window in our room. Speaking of our room, it look like it had been hit by a miniature cyclone.

I honestly had ''not'' realized how much of a hurry Isaac and I were in this morning- like. It was a complete mess. 

The sheets on my bed were pulled halfway off the bed's left side. The previously neatly-arranged pastel pillows had been flung across the area, the smallest pillow was somehow under the bed completely. What had been my shoes lined up on a rack was toppled over, my favorite pair of sneakers now glued together by a puzzling knot.

The clean wooden floor  was half-covered in sweaters, jeans, hoodies, and basketball shorts that I probably should've packed up in boxes, and the closet Isaac and I were sharing had zero organization, all of the hangers were on the floor and the a few of the drawers within it were lying open- one of them had even fallen out.

"We should clean this up," Isaac commented. "I mean, mostly your side of the room is messy, but..."

"Hey!" I snapped, gesturing to Isaac's bed. "Look who's talking! You have a bunch of clothes on your bed!"

Then I realized that those were probably just pajamas he planned on wearing. 

"Well- well you should still help. It's your room too and clearly you didn't make any effort to be tidy and organized and calming earlier this morning," I responded, attempting to sound matter-of-factly, though clearly sounding flustered.

Isaac raised an eyebrow, looking in my direction. "You expect me to clean up after you now? We never agreed on that. How about we put all this silliness aside and we just leave it the way it is? We ought to be going to bed in an hour or so anyway."

Ugh. He's smart. I didn't want to clean up, so he's giving me what I want, while also winning an argument. Good on him. But, damnit on my part. 

"Alright, alright, you win," I stopped for a moment, then adjusted to face Isaac- "Uh, I kind of wanted to talk to you, actually."

Isaac glanced at me, he seemed genuinely confused. He didn't have to ask about what, since his expression already said it. I plopped down on my mess of a bed and tried to pull the sheets up to the corners so I wasn't just sitting on hard mattress. I always get kind of fidgety when I'm nervous, so I was especially desperate in trying to fix my sheets.

Isaac continued to stare. He wasn't really glowering, but it was definitely pressuring. Isaac was telling me to spit it out, and I regretted bringing it up already. I hadn't even actually brought it up yet. God.

"Well. I mean. Tonight."

From ridiculously unsubtle to ludicrously unclear. Not much of an improvement, really.

"What do you mean, Si?" Isaac quizzed me, "Did something happen tonight? Did you get hurt? Seriously, what's wrong?"

Si. I loved it when he called me that. It was absolutely adorable. 

Okay, okay, I need to focus. This is a serious question. I want to be able to inquire something and not actually sound like a total idiot for a change.

"I... you said you wanted to be my boyfriend. I do. I want to be your boyfriend. 

"But were you actually asking that? Do you really mean it? Or did you just want me to shut the hell up? Because I actually feel that way. I... I really care about you. And I don't know, I feel like something's changed. I mean, with the whole nickname thing. 

"Like, is that an evolution of our relationship? I just... I want to know your opinion. What's the status update here? And I'm being honest, as honest as I can- I really want us to be boyfriends. 

"I want to go out with you. I... really like you. I don't mean to pressure you at all, which I know I absolutely am right now, but God, this question has been messing with me.

"I'm so sorry. It's just super unclear how you feel sometimes, and it's kind of aggravating when I want to know but you're not actually upfront about it.

" I- sorry, sorry. I'm sorry, I shouldn't have brought this up, it's so stupid, we've only been together for like a month and a half- obviously you don't feel that way. I'm rushing things, when I shouldn't be. Let's just pretend I never said any of this, yeah? That's a great idea, thanks for the input, Iz."

Isaac sat down on his bed, opposite me, looking absolutely flabbergasted. Good news? He probably hadn't heard half of what I said. Bad news? He heard at least half of what I said. 

And I'm not exactly the best at math, but I know what percentages are. Meaning, 50% chance Isaac heard the accidental nickname drop, the let's-forget-this-whole-really-dumb-move-I-made part, the are-you-serious-or-are-you-kidding-me part, like, to the point where I was basically exploding. 

No, scratch that, I exploded. I was smoke, ashes, and flaming garbage.

"You... you called me Iz," he stated shyly. 

"Um. Maybe," I answered anxiously. 

"And... and you want to be my boyfriend. And I asked you to be my boyfriend. And you think I'm not your boyfriend?" He questioned, tilting his head to the right.

"I-- well- because, since, at the time I was sort of freaking out about you breaking up with me, because you're the first person that I guess has like, liked me back, but I was super unsure and kind of have a lot of self-doubt and major, er, I honestly don't know but yeah my parents are kind of completely homophobic so have never supported me. 

I inhaled and exhaled. Breathe in, breathe out. Again. Isaac was completely silent. Absolutely baffled. Which I wasn't sure if that was a good thing or a bad thing. I really didn't want to find out, so I just let all of it out. Well, most of it, anyway.

"And well they basically made me feel like no one could ever love me so yeah I just kind of thought you know they're probably right and I've been so nervous about this whole boyfriend idea because you know all these voices in my head keep on saying you probably hate me or you're in this for a laugh or something--"

"Si. Si, stop. Please stop. I really care about you, okay? I really do," Isaac croaked, "I really like you too. Because you're awesome. And I don't care if you're not a math genius or whatever the hell it is you're so stressed about. But I do want to be your boyfriend. And I was hoping for some one-on-one time tonight, but you know, I assumed you'd get the memo based on my reaction..."

"God. Sorry for ruining your night," I uttered, tears streaking down my cheeks. I really was sorry, and I wanted him to think that I wasn't a total wrecking ball of a lion, that, you know, I was somebody worth something.

"No, no, shh. You didn't do that. We literally made out. I wouldn't call that ruining my night, Si. I ''like'' kissing you. I would initiate it every day if possible. You did not ruin my night, ''at all.'' As a matter of fact, you made it way better than my nights usually go," Isaac blurted passionately. "Simon, if we're not boyfriends in your head, then I should make sure that happens. Because I really want you to call me your boyfriend."

"All you ate tonight was chips and guacamole! No wonder you're like this. Simon, you need sustenance. Real food. Come on, we're going to go out on a real date," Isaac commanded, grabbing my quivering shoulders and pulling me up, practically dragging me out the door.

"Wh- what are you- I- I'm trying to apologize, a-and you're saying I didn't do anything? But... But I thought that..." I sniffed, wiping my eyes of tears. 

"Simon, please. We're going to get you what you want, I swear. Pull yourself together. We're gonna go to that place- Patty's or something, the fast food restaurant you were so excited about," Isaac explained, forcing me down the hallway and into the lobby. 

Out the door. Outside. There were stars, shining, piercing. The moon was up, a big, yellow sphere, kind of like a smiley face. Maybe the universe was telling me that tonight was going to stay a good night.

I guess I don't really know why I get like this sometimes. Everything was going great. I'm just ironically a massively insecure lion. I suppose I've never been a fan of stereotypes, nor do any describe me all that well.

Then, I saw a new bright thing- the classical diner-like cursive of the neon-lights Patty's sign. One of my favorite burger joints in all of Jamaa. I mean, there could've been a better one, but Patty's was my go-to hangout place. And Isaac had taken me there. 

"Here we are. The castle of deep-fried sodium and blended sugar," Isaac announced, gently grazing the tips of my claws, lacing his own through mine, slowly and carefully. "My treat," he added, "I brought some cash.'

"It's... it's almost nine," I said dazedly, "H... how?" 

"Magic, my beloved boyfriend. I'm secretly a wizard," Isaac responded teasingly. 

"Boyfriend," I whispered, "sounds good."

&lt;nowiki&gt;*****&lt;/nowiki&gt;

Isaac sat opposite from me in the bright pink-cotton candy cushioned benches of Patty's, where I leaned over the silvery square table to read the menu upside-down. I could not read things upside-down.

Upon noticing my failed attempt, Isaac grinned. "You want the menu, don't you?" He inquired flirtatiously.

"I have to choose my milkshake flavor," I replied solemnly. 

"I thought we were sharing one," he shot back with a mischievous smile.

"You remembered what I said," I murmured dazedly, "you really are a wizard."

"Do you like chocolate?" He added curiously.

"Not more than you," I muttered stupidly.

Oh, f***. 

Isaac's cheeks were tomato red. Mine were blood red, if that was even possible, and if it wasn't, then it was then. 

"Excuse me," a waitress asked politely, arriving at our table swiftly, "what will you be having tonight?"

"Um. One medium chocolate milkshake, please," I said. "And, uh, a Coke and a lemonade."

"What about food?" The waitress continued, somewhat impatiently.

I basked in an awkward silence, trying to recall the specifics of my usual. Thankfully, another voice prompted me to not seem like a complete idiot- Isaac's. He knew my favorite burger. On that note, I broke into a grin.

"Two cheeseburgers, please- one with pepper jack, pickles, onions, tomatoes, lettuce- ketchup and mustard, no mayonnaise. The other with white cheddar, bacon, pickles, onions, and mayonnaise. And a large side of fries," Isaac answered hastily. 

The waitress nodded, then hurriedly walked away to another table. I was officially in an exhausted stupor. Isaac was doing something unbelievably kind and romantic, and I was too dumb and sleepy to do anything in return. I'd known he was out of my league, but not that out of my league. 

"I hope I remembered it right," Isaac said shyly, "you weren't answering, so I just assumed it was OK for me to finish the order."

"No, it's fine," I answered quickly, "you did the right thing. Thanks for this. All of it. It's really just amazing of you."

"Oh, well, you know, I just... I just thought that I ought to show you I really care," Isaac responded softly, "you seemed really nervous earlier."

"It wasn't your fault, Isaac. We just haven't had enough time to talk things through," I replied reassuringly, but to me, that was a fact, not just something to make him feel better.

"About that, I... There's something I should tell you. It might, er, change how you feel about me. I mean, not a lot, just, when we decide we're serious about this..." Isaac answered nervously.

"It won't, Isaac. Nothing could do anything other than make us even closer and even stronger," I breathed heavily, inhaling confidence, exhaling doubt- I had never been so sure in my life.

"Well, this is different. It's about me. I- Luka already knows this, it was just- it was easier to tell her, alright?  I mean- not that I didn't think you- not that I think you would take it... badly. I just..."

Wait, what? What was so important that he skipped over me to tell someone else? Even if that someone was Luka, we were more than friends. Luka was just a friend. Luka was important, too, but not- not for Isaac. Isaac and I are supposed to be a ''we,'' an ''us,'' not separated by some stupid secret. Or was I just not important enough? 

"Isaac, what the hell? Did you just take me here to butter me up or something?" I couldn't help it. Looking back, I knew it was the sh****est reaction possible. I had let all of that insecurity and frustration and confusion come flooding back. I should've been patient, should've been kind, should've been welcoming, should've been gentle. 

When it came to the important parts, I was none of those things. 

"Okay then. I kind of actually thought you were chill with this stuff. Especially when you went to help Luka! Well, surprise-surprise, Simon, the big, horrible, f***ed-up secret is that I'm trans."

S***, I sounded like my parents. 

And f*** the fact that I was quiet after Isaac came out to me. 

And just to make sure that I had really made our entire night a complete f***ing s***show, I didn't get up out of my seat after Isaac left a check on the table and ran out of the restaurant in tears. 

S***, Isaac was crying, and I wasn't by his side. 

The worst part was that Isaac and I probably weren't a ''we'' anymore. Scratch that. The worst part was that I made my boyfriend think I don't love him because of who he is. 

S***, I had to tell Isaac I loved him.

&lt;nowiki&gt;*****&lt;/nowiki&gt;

Thank Zios I had brought my phone with me, otherwise I might've died. First, I tried to text Isaac- rookie mistake. 

''Look, Iz, I'm really sorry, that was super crappy of me. Can we please talk?'' 

Isaac's reply: ''Please leave me the hell alone.'' 

I felt horrible. I had made a scene in a restaurant at 9 P.M. and probably looked like I was on a drunken rampage. I had pushed away the jammer I was closest to, and pretty much made him think I was a raging transphobe. And holy Mira, by then he had probably told Luka all about it- so not only that, but I had pushed away my one and only friend. 

Also, my ride back to the hotel was gone. Which I damn well deserved. 

After leaving the most generous tip I could, I tried calling Luka outside. They didn't pick up. I tried to shoot Luka a text, but I wasn't sure how to put my feelings to words. I scrolled desperately through my contacts- Who else could I turn to?

Aeros. The name struck me like lightning. With haste, I typed up a message and pressed send. Not long after, Aeros replied, filling me with relief. 

''I'll be there in 15. Isaac there too?'' 

The question at the end proceeded to fill me with dread. I couldn't lie and say Isaac was there, because it would be obvious that he wasn't.

''No,'' I typed back, ''I'll explain later.'' 

I took a deep breath. Aeros' reporter's instinct would kick in, and I would be dead. Giving half the truth to a budding journalist would be like cooking bacon in front of a dog: The dog is going to want the bacon. You give the dog a crumb, it wants a whole piece.

I didn't initially recognize Aeros' car, but the blue polar bear was fairly recognizable on his own. He pulled down the window and told me to come in. Before I said anything else, I found myself blurting out a random question.

"What is it like to be trans?"

Aeros raised an eyebrow. Immediately, I bit my lip, thinking the question was a bad one. But, soon enough, Aeros provided me with a thoughtful. and quite elaborate, reply. 

"I like being trans," he said wistfully, "it's a part of me that I don't want to change. The only thing I would change is being born in the body that's right for me. There's only so much I can do with the one that I have. 

" Of course, things are different now- better than they were before. But being trans is still hard. Lots of people don't understand it, and they judge and ignore and fear what they don't understand.

"So a lot of times, my identity is overlooked. People have refused to use my name and pronouns. For example, my grandparents know me as a girl. They love me, but they only love me as a girl. And I'm not a girl. The unfortunate truth is because they can't see past my gender assigned at birth, they can't see me. 

"Every newspaper I've worked for, I made sure I was listed as a male writer. But my grandparents don't want to see any of my accomplishments as Aeros. They want me to 'embrace my womanhood.'

"My grandmother is a feminist. She believes that I'm rejecting my female body because women don't have rights. She believes that by doing this, I'm a misogynist. Which isn't true. Just like any other boy, I can still be a feminist- and I am a feminist. I'm just not a girl. 

"In my personal experience, most cis people make comments like this unintentionally- they don't have a clear concept of what being trans is, so they make it up in their heads. Obviously, that doesn't automatically mean they're transphobic, it just means they're confused.

"A lot of times people accidentally misgender me. They look at my chest and my curves and decide that I am a woman. These assumptions about gender and pronouns aren't a good habit. It takes a lot of energy to educate people about why they shouldn't assume those things, though. Almost every day, I have to explain myself. 

"Sometimes, I'm rejected. Sometimes, I'm ignored. I dislike being ignored the most. If people deny me, then at least I know not to bother with them- since I now realize that people who can't love me for who I am can't love me at all. If they accept me, it shows me that they are someone I can respect and maybe trust as a friend or something more. 

"Immediate acceptance is what validates me, what fulfills me. For most cis people, it takes them work and practice to get my pronouns right. Being around other gender-nonconforming and trans people is like magic. It's instant acceptance, instant love, instant understanding. I wish that cis people could provide that same feeling. Unfortunately, that isn't always the case.

"But it's harder for nonbinary people and people who use neopronouns. Those concepts are very new to society, no matter how long people have felt that way. To be honest, I like using the singular they/them. I'm demiboy.

"Obviously, my gender identity isn't a secret. It's just a fact, something I share about myself. I hope that one day, it can really just be a fact- I can walk up to someone, say I'm trans and demiboy, and it won't matter. I won't be shoving it down their throats or making up some silly fantasy. I'll just be me.

"Dysphoria is an issue that can't really be solved, unfortunately. I had a lot of dysphoria as I went through puberty. I hated all of the changes happening to my body. I cut my hair short and wore baggy clothes and tried out for the boys' sports teams, but all that did was make things worse. I was teased through most of middle school. There was no education about gender or pronouns or being queer in middle school.

"And I think that there should have been. The root of discrimination is I am one thing and you are this, I am one thing that these other people are and you are different, I am normal and you are weird. The truth is "normal" is different for everyone, so it really is just silly that "weirdness" exists. 

"Around 8th Grade, my older sibling came out as nonbinary. Because I had no education about gender, like my peers, I didn't know there were other options. My older sibling coming out to me opened a thousand doors for me. I started researching online about different gender identities, and the first thing I found out about sounded a lot like me.

"That's how I found out I was trans. But I didn't know what I was supposed to do after that. I remember being so excited, though, saying it over and over again in the mirror. My sibling found me and smiled, and started talking to me about things I could do- binders, puberty blockers, buying boys' clothes, even testosterone shots. 

"After coming out to my parents, who did their best to support me, I decided to start small. I brought a couple of masculine outfits and got an actual haircut. I enjoyed dressing like a boy and expressing myself as one. I wasn't playing pretend, though- this was reality. And I was happy. 

"In my freshman year of high school, I got a binder as a Hannukah present. I was overjoyed- it fit perfectly, and it felt amazing. Then, though, I started feeling more discomfort whenever I didn't have my binder on. I didn't want anyone taking pictures of me without it on. I was frustrated when I realized I couldn't wear it to sleep.

"Eventually, I got a therapist. The best part was, he was a trans man too- he knew what I was going through. He was one of the first trans adults that I met in real life. 

"He showed me I had a future, and that my transness wasn't something that would hold me back, it was something that would lift me up. After talking to him, I came up with ways to be comfortable in a binder while being safe. 

"Later, in my junior year, I realized I was bisexual. I had a crush on a girl, and she liked me back, so we made it official. It was my first relationship with a girl.

"But, she was cis, and I was trans... so it was a bit of a process to get her to understand that I didn't have traditionally male body parts. By then, I had gotten top surgery as well.  We had a few rough patches, but she apologized, she supported me, she gave me space when I needed it and most of all she gave me joy. 

"...And, well, it worked out. Now, I'm engaged to the same girl, who loves not just my transness, but me. And I love her. To me, it's not just her love, but the love that my friends give me, that my family give me, the love I feel at every pride event that lifts me up the most. My journey to transition was also my journey of learning to love myself. And I succeeded.

"It's why I'm a writer, too. There are lots of trans and gender-nonconforming people who don't have the luck or the joy that I do. And that shouldn't be the case. There are people who need to know they're not alone. And that's what my writing can do. Frankly, Simon, that's why I was so eager to tell your story, to tell Luka's story, to tell Isaac's story. Because people need to hear it."

I exhaled sharply. I hadn't realized that I'd been holding my breath the whole time. How could Aeros speak like that? My heart was beating quickly. I realized there were tears in my eyes. I had no idea how much hurt Isaac could've gone through. And how my silence hurt him, too.

How my silence hurt the world.

"Holy s***, Aeros," I whispered gratefully, "you're incredible."

"We're there, in case you were wondering," Aeros said. 

He paused. 

"And Simon? Thank you for asking. Not every cis person is willing to listen. Isaac is lucky to have you."

Isaac told Aeros he was trans because I wasn't trans, and we can't relate to each other about that topic. But I wasn't supporting Isaac to the fullest. I had to think of what I could do. 

Of course. A Hannukah present.

== 4. Sky ==
''"All we see is sky, for forever. We let the world pass by, for forever. Feels like we could be alright, for forever, this way." -''Dear Evan Hansen 

I found Isaac sitting on the balcony, alone. It was a cool night with a pleasant breeze, one of those midsummer nights that make you feel like anything is possible. Even healing scars. 

Isaac was listening to music. He had his earbuds in, and he wasn't smiling, but he was tapping his paw to the beat, singing softly. I never knew that Isaac liked singing. 

I felt uncertain, awkward. It had been the same way when I first kissed Isaac. Clumsy, scared, vulnerable. I had messed up this time, though. But Isaac didn't owe me forgiveness. He had a right to be upset. An apology seemed like the wrong thing to do, but the right thing. In elementary school, an apology was enough. 

But this was real life, and sometimes feelings were so big that you couldn't just bottle them up and put them away. Sometimes, feelings were big enough that they never went away, they would only shrink as time went on. Slowly, things would get better. 

That's when I realized there wasn't anything I could do in the moment. Isaac wanted to be alone, listening to music, soaking in the night where everything felt possible. Without me. Because people need space, and people need time. I hurt Isaac's feelings, and I can't just say that I'm sorry, I have to show that I'm sorry.

I walked back into our hotel room. I lay down in bed and played ''All I Want For Christmas Is You'' by Mariah Carey, and since I couldn't sing, I hummed the parts that I knew. I didn't have headphones or earbuds, but it didn't really matter, since Isaac did, so Isaac wouldn't hear anything. 

When the song ended, I listened to the crickets chirp and the frogs croak. But they were all just the background music, all playing along to Isaac's beautiful voice. I cried a little, then curled up in a ball on my own, and thought of when Isaac and I talked to Luka for the first time, and how that time was when Luka was having suicidal thoughts. 

Isaac didn't know what to say, and so instead, he listened to my heartbeat, leaning into my chest deeper than I thought was possible. He wasn't ready to walk into that room. He was still reliving his dysphoria, I should've been able to notice all the hints. But even then, Isaac was still by my side, holding onto me as I held onto him. 

For the rest of the night, Isaac stayed outside on the balcony, singing. I stayed inside, listening to the varying Mariah Carey songs that played on my phone. I thought of all the things Isaac had done for me, and I thought of all the things I wanted to do for him. 

There were eight stars I could see through the window that night. The brightest one was Isaac. 

&lt;nowiki&gt;*****&lt;/nowiki&gt;

Somewhere between the last blinking of stars and the first glimpse of sunlight, Isaac had come back inside. Utterly sleep-deprived, I fumbled around the room until I found the coffee pot. I grabbed a mug and let the bitter, energizing drink come out in waves. Isaac must have already heated it up. 

Isaac. A part of me was desperate to see him behind me, trapping me in a passionate hug within seconds. But he wasn't there. His bed was pushed a few feet further from mine. The balcony door was shut, and Isaac wasn't outside. He had already left the room. 

It was too early for a Hannukah present. I crossed the idea off my list of things to do to make it up to Isaac. Another sip of coffee, without a trace of cream or sugar. I focused on the taste of the liquid blackness, as if I was eating my words. 

I had stayed up all night listening to music and making the list. The Hannukah present seemed genius to me, but of course it was stupid, because at the rate I'd gone, Isaac and I wouldn't be a couple by the start of the holidays. Not to mention the fact that it was still summer.  

I made a terrible mistake, and now Isaac wanted nothing to do with me. And I wanted him so, so, badly, it was as if there was a rope attached to my chest, pulling me to him, and he was sawing it off, little by little. 

Cutting me, little by little. And each drop of blood hit the floor and made a noise like thunder. This was my fault, and I had to fix it.

Another sip of coffee. I could try to find Luka, but I had a feeling they wouldn't be willing to hear me out. Isaac would've already told Luka.  And I couldn't trouble them, not when they were already going through so much. 

And Mira, what might Isaac have gone through in his first year? I should've asked. I should've been there. I should've said something. I should've done something. 

I never stopped to think that Isaac needed something other than hugs and kisses and dates. I thought that was all there was. But love was more complex. ''Life'' was more complex. 

Memories filled my head, buzzing, stinging, bursting, screaming. I couldn't keep them down anymore. Isaac, trapped in the locker room, smudged with makeup and stuffed into a dress. He must've felt horrible. My fists clenched just at the thought of Teddy Arruga, his cold, cruel smile and hollow laugh. 

The calls of ''f****t, homo, sissy, queer, t****y,'' every single horrid word clawing at me at the same time, every single thing that was so damn wrong with the world that I hadn't done a thing about. So many people around the world were struggling, so many people needed help and support and love, and Isaac was one of those people, but I hadn't given him what he needed. 

I was in my little bubble, cis and gay and neurotypical, minding my own business. 

But I could at least believe in myself. I could at least trust myself. 

How could Isaac live when his body was his prison?

I realized I was panting, and I'd ripped the list apart. None of my ideas would matter anymore. I would have to face my problems and talk to Isaac. It was the right thing to do. 

Then again, there was always Aeros. He had been honest and kind when he didn't have to be. Maybe he would be willing to talk to me. 

I didn't know what to say to Isaac. I didn't know how to tell him I loved him, because Zios, I hadn't kissed a soul before Isaac, hadn't whispered my heart out in the dead of night or stared into someone's eyes while they stared back or danced with someone until morning came. 

I was sure that was something I had to do with a girl, so I was sure that I just hadn't found the right person yet.

I had done every one of those things with Isaac, and nothing had ever felt more right.

But I did something wrong, so what was I supposed to do to make it right again?

I took a deep breath and shot Aeros a text. I sent it, and prayed he would answer.

Me: ''Sorry to bother u, but i made a huge mistake and Isaac is mad at me. Can we talk?''

In the nick of time, Aeros responded. I was shocked that he was even up so early. I barely knew him at all, but he jumped to my side whenever I asked.  

Aeros'': This has something to do with the fact that he wasn't there last night, doesn't it?''

It wasn't what I wanted to hear, but it didn't seem reasonable for me to expect much else. Aeros was still a journalist. Aeros was doing his job. The night before, though, he told me that he needed my story, Luka's story, and Isaac's story to be heard. Not because of his job, though.

Me: ''Yeah. He came out to me and I kinda just stared at him. I wasn't sure what to say. Now he's upset and sad and he thinks I hate him. It's really bad. I messed up. He won't talk to me and won't spend time with me. I don't know how to show him I'm sorry.'' 

Aeros: ''It's barely even morning. Have you tried talking to him yet today?''

Of course. That was perfectly logical. How come I hadn't just texted him when I woke up? My text back answered the question more accurately than I would've been able to say out loud.

Me:  ''I just don't know what I would say. I don't know where he is, either. He wasn't here when I woke up, and he still isn't.''

Aeros: ''Maybe you don't need to say anything.'' 

What the hell was that supposed to mean? 

Me: ''I can't just walk up to him.'' 

Aeros: ''I meant you could write him a note. Maybe sing him a song, write him a poem, a love letter, something like that. I've always thought writing is easier than talking.'' 

I changed the subject. I didn't want to admit that I was s*** at writing ''and'' singing. 

Me: ''You sounded like you had rehearsed a scene straight from Broadway when you told me what being trans meant to you. Your writing must be great.'' 

Aeros: ''I meant like banter. I could go on and on about things I'm passionate about for hours. I can barely strike up a normal conversation. Did you completely forget the dinner we had? I was stuttering in every sentence.''

Me: ''Well, I  was mostly making out with Isaac...''

Aeros: ''I'm serious. Just write him something and put it on his bedside table, or a place you'll know he'll find it. You clearly love him.'' 

Me: ''What am I supposed to write about? There are a million things I could write about. Isaac is perfect. He's beautiful.'' 

Aeros: ''Write about the million things. If I write a love letter for you, it won't be the same. It won't be yours. Besides, I wouldn't do that.'' 

Aeros: ''The fact that you're obsessing this much at 5 AM is a good example, too.'' 

Me: ''I'm not obsessing! OK, fine, I want to tell him I love him. I've wanted to ever since we got here. Then I became the world's biggest idiot for one minute, and ruined our entire relationship. Because I was scared and stupid and slow.'' 

Aeros: ''The longer you don't say or do anything, the less likely it is that Isaac will be willing to give it another shot.'' 

Me: ''What if he thinks the note is cheesy, or stupid, or bad, or some sort of sick joke?''

Aeros: ''I don't think he will. About the time thing, though, maybe don't bother him this early.''

Me: ''He's awake. He has to be. He can't be asleep and not in our room.''

Aeros: ''Well, then, take advantage of that. Set something up in the room for when he comes back. He has to eventually.'' 

Genius. Aeros was a genius. I ended our chat with a quick thank you, and immediately got to work (also while spilling coffee all over myself). 

It was time to write the cheesiest love song in the world.

&lt;nowiki&gt;*****&lt;/nowiki&gt;

I didn't know if it was good or not. I just thought about life, and thought about Isaac, and wrote something. How I felt when I was with him. I wanted to make sure he ''knew''. Not just that I thought he was amazing (because he is), but how I ''felt.'' I ''did'' love him. And I wasn't ashamed of it. I didn't want him to be ashamed, either.

And then I realized it kind of rhymed. So maybe it was a song. 

And I couldn't sing.

But I could always try.

So I started practicing, right then and there. I croaked out the first verse. It sounded like absolute s***.

But the words sounded right.

How was I supposed to make them sound ''good,'' though?


'''''Angel Arms'' - For Isaac, From Simon'''

''Mmm, mmm''

''Mmm, mmm'' 


''I wanna fall and fly into your angel arms''

''I wanna lay beneath the night sky''

''Counting the stars''


''I wanna wake up with the sunrise''

''I wanna see eye to eye''

''I wanna greet the silver morning dew''

''With you''


''I wanna wander your dreaming gaze''

''I wanna fall into your warm embrace''

''I wanna stay in this lovestruck phase''

''I wanna have every day''

''With you''


''I wanna fall and fly into your angel arms''

''I wanna lay beneath the night sky'' 

''Counting the stars''


''I wanna hear my name'' 

''From the music of your voice''

''I wanna go through joy and pain''

''I wanna make that choice''

''If it means'' 

''I get to be with you''


''I wanna rock to sleep''

''I wanna rest my head on your shoulder''

''I wanna be a little bolder''

''And I want you to know''

''How much I love you''


''I wanna fall and fly into your angel arms''

''I wanna lay beneath the night sky''

''Counting the stars''


''I wanna wake up with the sunrise''

''I wanna see eye to eye''

''I wanna greet the silver morning dew''

''With you''


''I wanna wander your dreaming gaze''

''I wanna fall into your warm embrace''

''I wanna stay in this lovestruck phase''

''I wanna have every day''

''With you''


''I want to open my mind''

''And pour it into yours''

''And I wanna open every door''

''I want you to call me your lover''

''And I wanna do the same''

''And together, I promise, we'll soar''


''I wanna fall and fly into your angel arms''

''I wanna lay beneath the night sky''

''Counting the stars''


''Mmmm, mmmm,'' 

''Mmmm, mmmm''


''I want to open my mind''

''And pour it into yours''

''I want to open every door''

''I want you to call me your lover''

''And I wanna do the same'' 

''And together, I promise, we'll soar, soar'' 


''Hold me a little closer, love,'' 

''Your eyes are the stars,'' 

''Each other a blanket,'' 

''So hold me a little closer, love,'' 

''With your angel arms...''



And it was right. It was true. It was perfect. 

The door opened. My ears perked up. Was Isaac really back?

"F***," a voice muttered under their breath, "this was a s***** idea."

&lt;nowiki&gt;*****&lt;/nowiki&gt;

"F***!" I yelled, a shot of adrenaline spiking through my veins. "Wh- what are you doing here!?"

"Okay, I now realize I'm interrupting something," said the voice, now much more clearly, "but Isaac asked me to come up here. He's still upset, by the way. It might've helped if you actually apologized."

Luka. With a reasonable sarcastic edge to their voice. Yeah, I had messed up. But I was trying, ''really'' trying to fix it. 

"And this room is an absolute s***show. What the hell are you doing, Simon?" Luka inquired, genuinely disgusted by the mess I'd made.

I chose to ignore the insult to my cleanliness, despite its accuracy. That wasn't the real problem. 

"I know I messed up, alright? I just- I thought I could make it up to Isaac. You were right, Luka. I need to put myself out there. It's only fair. Isaac did, so I--"

"Oh, f*** that. Simon, look, it's great that you're being responsible here, but please don't be dumb. Isaac ''came out to you'', and you ''looked at him like he was crazy''. You can't sugarcoat that. As someone who's trans, that's just a crappy reaction. You need to tell him, with your words, out loud, that you accept him. And he doesn't hate ''you'', he thinks you hate ''him''."

I swallowed hard. Again, Luka was right. But I didn't want to scrap what I'd written. I wished so hard that I'd be able to sing my song to Isaac, assuming I'd managed to fix this mistake. A song wasn't the answer. I had to be direct. That was what Isaac had needed.

Because I ''do'' care about him being trans. I love him, ''every single part'' of him. That includes his being trans.

And that's where I'd really made the mistake. I didn't need to prove I was so in love with him that nothing could possibly change it. I needed to prove that I loved him for who he was, and who he was only made me love him more.

"Please," I breathed heavily, "tell me where Isaac is."

Luka narrowed their eyes once more. "He's ''your'' boyfriend. Where do ''you'' think he is?"

Damnit. Luka was really good at being right. 

If Isaac wasn't ready to be up close with me as soon as he woke up, then he'd go to wherever he could get some peace and quiet that wasn't our balcony. The courtyard.

My ah-ha moment was pretty obvious. Instantly, Luka smirked. I was relieved that they weren't permanently p***ed at me. 

But I didn't really bother with expressing that relief. Luka had probably already read my mind. I had more pressing matters at the time: a beautiful, talented, charming, and increasingly wonderful transgender prince to apologize to (and also hopefully make out with. And maybe, if I'm feeling extra bold, ask him out).

I exited the lobby in a breeze. Before scanning for Isaac officially, I took a moment to, well, take things in: how ''possible'' the open, blue sky made things feel. No wonder Isaac liked it out there. The splendid weather only made me more confident that Isaac was here.

And there he was, sitting on a stone bench, singing ''All I Want For Christmas Is You''.

&lt;nowiki&gt;***&lt;/nowiki&gt;

I took a step forward. I paused. I lost my breath for almost an entire minute: Isaac ''had'' heard me. But I hadn't shown that I'd heard him.

His voice echoed across the courtyard, unforgivingly beautiful. He effortlessly reached the song's climax, belting out "All I want for Christmass... is you!" so meaningfully that I broke into tears.

And we both started crying. And some part of him knew I was there, jaws dropped. And he turned around. And I kept sobbing. And I hugged him so, so tightly. And I whispered into his ear, ''I love you, Isaac''. ''I love every part of you.'' 

The quiet was so strong that I didn't even mind when clouds thickened and grayed, a storm brewing. I still didn't mind when rain pitter-pattered down my back. I still didn't mind when the wind started howling.

"Thank you," he murmured shyly. "I love you, too."

¨I´m glad you do,¨ I whispered honestly, ¨and I´m sorry I wasn´t there for you when I should´ve been.¨

¨Simon?¨ Isaac questioned softly. 

¨Yeah?¨ I answered breathlessly.

¨I wanted you to know that Aeros talked to me. About what you asked him. The night I came out to you. And it means a lot to me that you cared. That you understood.¨

¨I ''do'' care,¨ I smiled back. ¨I care a lot, Iz.¨

¨You called me Iz again,¨ Isaac said wistfully, ¨I kind of like it.¨

¨That´s good,¨ I replied happily.

¨This is kind of crazy. It´s been a month and a half. Not really a long time, huh?¨ Isaac asked in a low voice.

¨Yeah. But I want to keep going. I like what we´re doing. I like being your boyfriend,¨ I answered, still beaming.

¨I do too.¨

&lt;nowiki&gt;**&lt;/nowiki&gt;

And I looked up, and all I saw was infinite gray, endless sky, hopeless storm clouds.

But Isaac was the sun, shining through all the dreariness, slicing through the darkness like it was butter.

And I melted into his arms, which really did feel like an angel's, because Zios, he absolutely looked like one. 

And Isaac was the best summer ever.

And he took all my breath away and so passionately refused to give it back, and within a matter of seconds I was a boy kissing an angel, we were two boys kissing each other, and the world fell away, and the rest was light.

My paws slid into his and we sat together on the stone bench in the courtyard. His fur was moist but I didn't mind since mine was too. I leaned into him like he was as endless as the sky, I fell into the music of his heartbeat, and I kissed him again and it lasted a decade, and it was beautiful.

"I accept you, Isaac, every part of you. You are the most incredible person I have ever met. I want to spend every day of this summer with you. You're the nerdiest, cutest, most talented, and most beautiful coyote in all of existence. I'm honored that you're my boyfriend."

"You sound like such a geek," Isaac whispered, and if it was possible for the world to break apart even further, it did, and it was wonderful. 

"Your wizardry is contagious," I replied, overwhelmed with joy, so ''alive'' that I felt like I had woken up for the first time in a thousand years.

"We can be ourselves now, Simon. We can do this every day. We can help other people get to this point in their lives," Isaac gushed wholeheartedly.

"Nearly all of Jamaa is going to hear our story tomorrow. Just think of it. We won't be hidden anymore," he added dreamily, his eyes lit up with stars, entire constellations, a universe of feelings, some foreign, that all I wanted to do with was to dig into, to know, to be close to.

But...

The world came back.

I sat up straight. My paws went slack in Isaac's.

"My parents might see," I said, knowing I was ruining the moment, that I could've stayed and explored Isaac's universe as he explored mine.

"You haven't talked about them much," Isaac muttered uncertainly, "are they... not supportive?"

"No. No, not really. But... I don't think they'd love me even if I was straight. I was never good enough for them," I murmured, "I just... they made me feel like- the things they did ''still'' make me feel like a screw-up, like I'm just stupid and useless and pathetic. I guess that's why... I guess that's why I was so scared you hated me."

"Simon," Isaac said softly, leaning into my ear, staring me dead in the eye, pouring his universe into mine, "It isn't possible for me to hate you."

"I... I think something's wrong with me," I whispered, tears wetting my cheeks, "I tried to be strong, Iz. I really did. But I'm terrified of what my parents will think. What if... What if they get interviewed too? What will people think about me then?"

"They'll admire you for being an upstander. They'll consider you a role model. You'll change their lives for the better," Isaac promised, then firmly gripping my paw, filling me with confidence, with love.

"Like you changed Luka's," he added sincerely, "and like you changed mine."

"After this summer, I might never see you again. What happens then? What am I supposed to do?" I questioned shakily.

Isaac paused for a minute. I could tell he was holding back tears now.

"You'll fall," he said softly, "but you might just fall back into my arms."

"Worst comes to worst, you'll find someone else who loves you just as much, no matter how impossible I think it is," he finished tightly.

"You should love yourself, though, Simon."

And I looked back up at the sky. And it was around seven in the morning and the sun was rising.

And there was pink for our love, red for our fear, orange for our worries, yellow for our joy.

Yet the most prominent colors were pink and yellow.

And so I let the sky, the sun made by Zios, the moon made by Mira, send me a sign.

"After the interviews, I'm going to take you out. I want to make sure we have one last summer day together. Before we might have more," I concluded devotedly.

== 5. Tears ==


Isaac and I had managed to stumble back into the hotel room. I was still processing it all, how chaotic these last few days had been, wondering what Isaac thought, how he felt.

"...Simon?" Isaac murmured uncertainly, suddenly shifting away from me. 

"Yeah?" I asked back, faux-casually tilting my head, instinctively taking a step closer. 

"I, uh, I'm sorry. I should've given you more time when I... When I told you. I just... I was scared. I don't know, you just looked kind of shocked, and I didn't know how to feel, and I just..."

"No, no, I should've been clear with you. It's not your fault. You shouldn't apologize. It's ''your'' coming out, not mine," I answered insistently, hoping so strongly that Isaac wasn't mad at himself.

"I know we already talked about it, but I wanted to-- I wanted to make that clear. I've just, um, had some bad experiences in the past with... Well, um, other- other people."

"What?" I turned again, eyebrows raised- ''Other people? What other people?''

"I mean- You're not the first person I've dated. That's all."

"Oh," I responded emptily, the color draining from my face. How was I supposed to react to that? Isaac was ''my'' first. I just assumed that... That, well, he and I were both... had both not dated other people.

"Not that- I'm- I'm not in contact with my exes. They were all kind of a**holes, to be honest. I mean- one of them was literally from eighth grade, and we just like kissed a few times and held hands, and never spoke to each other again since we went to different high schools, and-"

I swallowed hard, opening my mouth a little, trying to find words-- Of course I didn't think he was cheating on me, it just... It made me feel kind of bad. Like I was inexperienced or something.

"No, uh, I- I believe you," I interjected awkwardly, "I'd actually, er, prefer not to hear any... details."

"S***, that's not what I meant. I- I swear that--"

I stopped for a moment. Clearly, Isaac was intimidated. I wished I could make myself smaller, maybe then he would be less scared of me. I kind of hated being tall. 

"Are you... Are you alright?"

"Fine," Isaac sniffed, "all good." But he obviously wasn't. He was shivering in place, and tears streaked his face. His eyes were red, and they hadn't been before, and his paws were trembling-- I didn't know what to do. I didn't know what was wrong, just that something was definitely wrong, ''very'' wrong.

I grabbed him, pulling him into my chest. I wrapped him in a tight hug and didn't let him go. I wasn't sure what else I could do other than just be there.

"Hey," I murmured softly, "you're here. You're with me right now. You're safe."

"I- I-" Isaac stammered, shaking uncontrollably then, and I still didn't know what to do to make him feel better, but I wanted to do that so, so badly. His voice broke into sobs and it was like he was choking on his tears. His breaths grew wheezy and his eyes were wide and I still didn't know what to do.

I held onto him even tighter and tried to lift him up off of the ground. I could barely even manage that, it was like he had somehow gotten heavier. Frantically, I let my eyes dart around, looking for help-- And there was Luka.

"Luka! Luka, Isaac is-- something's wrong!" I shouted desperately, scrambling to reach them.

I kept Isaac in my arms, terrified of dropping him. He was still tense, and I could feel his forehead get hotter, dripping with sweat-- I was worried. Really worried.

Luka put down their phone almost immediately, bounding towards us with a determined speed. "What's going on? Are you guys okay?"

"He- he's-- I don't know what's happening to him," I choked out, "he seemed fine, and then things got kind of awkward, he mentioned dating other people, I didn't know about it so I felt kinda weird, then- then he just started freaking out all of a sudden and I- I tried to help him, asked him if he was okay, he just-- he started crying and shaking and I--" 

"Simon. Simon, take a breath. Put him down. I- I think he's having a panic attack," Luka responded firmly, clutching our intertwined paws.

"R- right," I muttered, carefully placing an increasingly wheezy Isaac onto the ground. "I- um- what does that mean?" I whispered questioningly.

"Something probably triggered it while you were talking. He's going to be alright. We just have to make sure he doesn't hurt himself and help him calm down."

Calm. How was Luka so collected? I was already a hot mess of anxious sweat and petrified tears. 

"He, um-- he mentioned dating a few other people. Some guy in eighth grade he didn't really care about, but... I don't know what else," I stammered worriedly, eyes big as I looked up to Luka for support.

"I'm not sure either. He hasn't really talked to me about that stuff. But we can figure that out later. Right now, we just need to be here for him." Luka paused, then turned towards Isaac again, putting their hands on his face- which, if anyone else had done it, would've spiked me with jealousy- and whispered very distinctly in his ear to match their breathing.

"Inhale," Luka commanded, "five, four, three, two, one... exhale. Good. Again."

"Should I- should I try that?" I asked, still scared, starting to tremble a bit myself.

"No, I don't think so. It helps more if it's consistent." Luka's face was dead serious, and so was their tone. I felt guilty for not recognizing what was happening to Isaac. Without Luka, what would I have been able to do?

They repeated their mantra and I stayed off to the side, nervously fidgeting with my paws. How could I help? The question was more of an urge than something to be answered. I ''should'' help-- He's my boyfriend, after all! But I didn't know what to do. I didn't, and that fact pained me.

"Inhale. Five, four, three, two, one... Exhale. Good. You're doing good. One more time, Isaac. Breathe with me."

Unintentionally, I started doing the breathing exercise, subconsciously following Luka's instructions. Ironically, it helped me, too. I took another breath- out of beat- and stood up. 

I leaned down again, closer to Isaac, stroking his back like I was giving him a massage. "Hey," I mumbled wistfully, "just take a breath."

Eventually, Luka backed away, letting me take charge. After another twenty minutes or so, Isaac's breathing was back to normal. His temperature had dropped (for the better) and he was shaking a lot less.

"I..." Isaac trailed off. His eyes had been cleared of all mistiness by then. He looked like he was going to say something, but whatever it was remained unexpressed. He stayed mute for a few more minutes, then finally turned to face Luka and I.

"Thanks," he sighed, getting up slowly.

"Um, I, uh... Of course," I replied, my voice low. 

"Do you have... those... a lot?" I squeezed out, face flushed with embarrassment. I couldn't have been asking more stupid questions.

"N- no, they- they don't happen that much. It's just... it's hard to talk about him," Isaac answered shakily, but physically, he was shrugging his shoulders and waving it off. 

Him? I wondered who he was talking about. Teddy, Mr. Johnston, or someone else? I had no clue. I brushed it off, deciding that Isaac probably wouldn't want to talk about it anyways.

"Are you- are you alright? Like, lightheaded or anything? Do you need a snack, or maybe a sip of water?" I implored ambiguously.

"No," Isaac shot back, his quickness coming with a sharp undertone. "I'm fine."

Luka glanced at Isaac, suspicious (although I was too), but didn't say anything out loud- instead, they shook their head, resigned, and padded off. 

Isaac started walking away, and before I left to catch up with him, I pulled out my phone and texted Luka: ''Do you know anything about what just happened? I'm worried about Isaac. That wasn't like him at all.''

I looked up, seeing Luka's phone vibrate a little ways away-- Luka stared back at me for a moment, probably questioning why I didn't walk up to them. I sent them another text to explain.

''I don't want Iz to hear me talking about it. He seemed kind of upset.''

Luka nodded, as if to say ''Ohhh,'' then proceeded to pull up their texts and message me back.

''It was definitely some sort of panic attack. But lots of people have panic attacks- sometimes it's not even because of a specific disorder, it just happens if you bottle things up a lot.'' 

Before I had the chance to reply to their first text, Luka added more information: ''Based on the context, I think Isaac was triggered by your conversation. Not necessarily that you were asking him about his exes or whatever, but it might be one ex in particular that he had a bad relationship with. Not your fault, but just try to tread carefully around that topic next time.''

I hadn't even thought of that. Why didn't I think of any of those things? I wanted to facepalm, but Isaac was probably already dubious of my physicality, so I tried not to make any blatant or dramatic gestures.

''So,'' I inquired via text, ''I shouldn't talk about that with him anymore or he'll start breaking down?''

Again, Luka answered helpfully: ''It's not exactly breaking down completely. Panic attacks can have some physical impacts as well, like migraines, stomach pains, or even passing out. But those don't happen every single time. Basically, stress builds up, stress builds up more, stress isn't discussed or mentioned, panic attack happens.''

''It's also important to know that Isaac MIGHT have a disorder, and given a diagnosis and accommodations, then panic attacks will probably happen a lot less. Again, based on context, the only thing I can think of that he might have is PTSD. Maybe anxiety too? Nevertheless, he definitely needs someone to talk to about it.'' 

I texted back: ''So what you're saying is he needs therapy.''

For a few minutes, Luka doesn't saying anything in response, and all I can see is an ellipsis with the ''Is typing...'' pop-up.

''He might benefit from that. But, to be honest, I think that you should get therapy, too. Talking with a professional is the best solution. It won't solve everything, but it'll help a little.'' 

Me? Get therapy? I hesitated, almost laughing to myself. Luka didn't notice my reaction. After a few more moments of a lack of further conversation, Luka left the chain, and after another couple of minutes, I did, too. 

Then, I could see why Isaac didn't want to talk about his feelings. The same reasons I didn't want to talk about mine.

&lt;nowiki&gt;***&lt;/nowiki&gt;

      <text bytes="3476" sha1="tgac2mhvlxie2rder2ag18vnhsl9lrb" xml:space="preserve">It was a normal day. I was playing animal jam, and I was editing my den. After a few minutes, I realised the music had been replaced with deep blue but backwards... I thought it could've been a glitch, so I just ignored it. That was my first mistake. A horrifying screech played, followed by fire sounds. I was confused, so I checked if it was a different device. and to my horror, it wasn't. I tried to move my animal and it didn't work. The next thing I thought to do was teleport. It worked but.. I ended up in.. "firefirefirefirefirefirefirefirefirefirefirefirefirefire's den" .. what? I've never seen or heard of a player like that. I still heard the sounds.. I searched the username.. A player card.. It's active now! It's animal was unusual, it was an arctic wolf but all orange. No outlines, eyes, nose, nothing. It was on fire. Then something caught my attention. The fire sound was getting louder. I was horrified. I stared at my screen as the same exact "player" walked up to me. It stopped moving. In chat, it said "you ignored me.. so rude.. time to burn..." followed with a "😸" emote. I left the game immediately before things got gross. As I re-entered, it was. . normal..? I was loading. No fire sounds. No screeches. Nothing. I spawned into jamaa township, like usual. No players. I was bored, thinking it was normal again, so I clicked parties. My mind changed as all I saw was just "fire stole." replacing every party.. I just waited until one started. 5 minutes later, it started. I clicked it and I saw a ton of other people! But.. We were all orange. Orange silhouettes of our animals. Happy crazyclaw screamed. Everybody in that party was screaming. Everyone stopped once we saw the arctic wolf walking up to us all. It did the "😾" emote. It walked up to a fox named something like.. Sweet pouncypaws.. I can't remember. Anyways, the arctic wolf said it's name and it disappeared. It did that with other people. It then got to me. It said my username and animal name, and I got kicked. Right before though, I saw myself go up in flames. I re-entered the game but instead of any loading screens, it showed my animal. Burning. I closed the game once again, getting annoyed. I waited a few hours. Once I re-opened the game, it was actually normal. Players. Normal music. My den was back to normal. I had a jam-a-gram waiting to be seen. It was from the person. It said "player is now safe." with a get well soon card. Am I now free? I checked my buddy list, they were in it. It said " Over 30 days "..  I checked chat to see if I could do anything with someone. all it said was.. "you shouldn't have checked here." and then someone said along with it, " all players who check here never.. never.. NEVER.. get away. " and then before I read the 3rd message, I was sent to my den. all teleport buttons gone. It was.. my first accounts den.. A masterpiece was  on the wall saying "she was with us. She.. was the start of this." I then was kicked. I didn't log back in for a while and when I did, it was better. It was normal. No jam-a-grams, they weren't even my buddy. I was finally free.


==Read please!==
This story is all made up! I was just bored so I made this.  All that was real was the orange arctic wolf! This is all based off of me seeing one (mainly the tail) in my den! It was just a second and nothing happened. Thanks if you read it tho! If you include it in any videos, please do credit me. You can call me Skittle!

    <title>There’s this girl</title>
    <ns>0</ns>
    <id>162264</id>
    <revision>
      <id>257458</id>
      <parentid>257456</parentid>
      <timestamp>2023-04-19T17:00:53Z</timestamp>
      <contributor>
        <username>VenonatEnjoyer</username>
