      <comment>/* 2 - I Pass a Test by Looking Away */</comment>
      <origin>258609</origin>
      <model>wikitext</model>
      <format>text/x-wiki</format>
      <text bytes="5497" sha1="d1wqf7x6d3bxyehprzn5tire0hso4bq" xml:space="preserve">''A phantom lab-raised shapeshifting beast is sent to Jamaa to gather information about a coming plan to destroy the phantoms once and for all. Will she find out what’s going on?''

== Character List ==

* Siley (pronounced “Silly”), Unidentified shapeshifting beast, main character
* Kira - Lion, teacher of Jamaa Merit High School
* Jax - Arctic wolf, popular kid #1
* Ace - Fox, popular kid #2
* Alice - Tiger, nerd
* Lacey - Tiger, Alice’s sister
* Silver - Lemur, class clown
* Mirror - Otter, most powerful

== 1 - Who I am Makes me Proud ==
A cat with purple and green fur, pink mystic eyes, wearing antlers, a heavy coat, bowtie, furry arm cuffs, and an unusually fluffy purple tail. This is the first description you think of when you first see me. It’s not very much what’s in style right now, but rather an older look seemingly from AMD (After Mira’s Disappearing) 152. It’s AMD 203, and the 34th year of Jamaa Township’s existence being so big.

I listen to the favorite music of Jammers right now, I want to wear Leo Clockwork’s newest items, and I go to the pillow room after school each week to hang out with people. You’d expect me to be a Jammer though, even with the older look, right?

That point is the only wrong thing you’d expect of me. I wasn’t really a jammer or a phantom, rather a shapeshifting beast in between known as a Phantanimal. You listen to differing myths from heroes from AMD 82 and before, describing us as creatures with tentacles along our spines and bones adorning our tails, or the famous story which posed the idea of phantanimals as someone who could end up either so powerful that they were like gods, or generic like most expect a phantom to look.

My name is Siley, I suppose they were trying to write “Silly” due to my looks, which in my purest state looks like if an arctic wolf was severely caught in a fire. My teacher, Kira, doesn’t seem to mind. Apparently, she’s had students with worse names that got tested and came out as a jammer. 

Speaking of that, I’m a part of a secret mission to discover a plan that The Alphas have to try and defeat us. In the meanwhile, I’m also studying the world so we can copy it to start our own dimension that is an exact replica, down to the soil contents of each individual inch of land. 

To do this, I go to a school, in specific, it’s Jamaa Merit High School. It’s supposedly a top class school, and most of the time, only non-gifted individuals are allowed in unless they can prove their powers have nothing to do with knowledge. I make my eyes look mystic and deep pink with contacts, and I disguise as a cat with purple and green fur to try and hide most of my features. I also have some fixed markings that I can change the shape of, but not the color of. I make it look more like a design choice by changing the pattern to lightning. I’ll also wear outfits that came from the Frozen Era (AMD 110-160). I do this to cover the mark on my neck’s side. People just assume I like Jamaa’s history, and I play along with that.

Anyways, here’s the story of how I did the unthinkable, and passed the Jammer-Phantom test as a phantom aligned beast.

== 2 - I Accidentally Passed a Test by Looking Away ==
On July 30th of AMD 202, the phantoms gave me all the answers to the Jamaa Merit High School entry quiz. This would be a key piece to gaining information, as Jamaa Merit has many people come in from Jamaa military roles to visit, sometimes talking about plans the Alphas have. Some plan discussions are more ramble-filled than others, but still full of information.

Upon sitting down to take the test, I noticed that one of the teachers seemed vulnerable enough to be killed. Most of the questions referred to the “History” of Jamaa, a incorrect telling of a war story, plagued with the things they think you know as a fact. They think the phantoms will tell you an incorrect story, when it is the Alphas who give you just that.

Answering the questions, I expected to get at least one wrong. I looked at the board and posters to check to see if there are any answers uncovered. I didn’t find any answers, but I did see a small note that I could read on the teachers desk. It read “Reminder: Test the blood of everyone after the other tests. Purple blood is not allowed!”

I thought about it for a moment. I didn’t know a blood test would also be taken after the quiz, I put a jammer blood patch of a cat on where they draw the blood from jammers as required by law, one on each wrist. It matches perfectly with my fur due to the technology. I felt my temperature drop for the rest of the test, leading up to the blood test.

Fighting tests came up, of which I learned the basic moves needed for the quiz. I got an 87 out of 95 due to some faults in my movements.

Then came the blood test.

As they took blood, they reached deep enough in to hit the patch just right, taking the cat blood and not mine. My temperature raised back to normal when I saw the blood was that from the patch. The teachers discussed some things, like how I was quiet most of the time other than answering questions and some things while fighting, but didn’t get suspicious.

Two days later, after checking the mail, I had noticed one thing. I had passed the test that supposedly no phantom could get through.

  <page>
    <title>User blog:Downwards-Upz-Mist/motivation dump 3</title>
    <ns>500</ns>
    <id>162382</id>
    <revision>
      <id>258615</id>
      <parentid>258610</parentid>
      <timestamp>2023-09-12T23:10:48Z</timestamp>
      <contributor>
        <username>Downwards-Upz-Mist</username>
        <id>47196321</id>
      </contributor>
      <origin>258615</origin>
      <model>wikitext</model>
      <format>text/x-wiki</format>
      <text bytes="4729" sha1="tucj4ao8i0rxzasopxaph0gjqpg4p3i" xml:space="preserve">== Party ==
Pain hurt. Pain hurt like a thousand needles were stuck to your skin, and you were dragged along a highway like a badly strung sleeping bag on a camping trip. (Antares never knew what happened to that bag.)

The games were stupid, and Antares hated the fact that this guy was meant to be the opponent that would kill him. Some a**hole who kept making him confused with his teleportation, attacking him from everywhere he least expected. He knew he'd probably be pulled onto the field more often, considering he'd already ruined his relationship, but he didn't expect to lie there for a fraction of a moment with steam exiting him like a broken car, as he tried to return air to his lungs. He didn't know what this meant about his anatomy, as he'd expect himself to breathe less in this state, not more, as the smoke left him and wind entered his system. 

He looked at the sky. He'd become a bit more athletic- He was always a pretty strong, fast guy, just never smart enough to think in the moment. His instincts would take over. Training with Solaris helped him clear his mind.

Solaris' fighting style was clean, orderly, yet fast. It used as much as needed, and yet the first few times Antares sparred with him, he did feel overwhelmed. Solaris was ''really'' good, and he couldn't imagine him in the arena, in a scenario where he actively had to kill. Did he even have to kill? Apollo was still alive. Maybe he just had to injure someone enough to seem dead. Solaris would be good at that.

Antares got back up after that momentary pause, with a burst of flame that let him get back on his feet. He looked at the other guy, knowing he'd forget his dark, braided hair, dark skin, and the look in his green eyes when he saw Antares attack.

Training with Solaris taught him a lot. Solaris was kind enough to unintentionally inform him a bit on how to beat people like this. 

''"You truly do just want to end the enemy at once. But the best way to fight an enemy is by holding back a little, letting them think they have a window of opportunity, setting their guards down."''

Well, that certainly worked for Solaris, who knew how Antares fought. But it wouldn't work for the man standing in front of him. So he let a nice trick he taught himself fly. 

Antares couldn't help but think what Solaris would be thinking about this trick. He wished he could think about something else, but when the first part of his attack started, his mind inevitably turned towards that instead. The floor of the arena was covered in a small layer of fire, which the other boy had to constantly teleport above just so it wouldn't singe his shoes. 

Antares had wanted to try it on Solaris, but Solaris told him that doing this would be extremely dangerous, and terribly hard to control. Antares decided not to control the flames at all, loosening his MagiMin further with his left hand so they'd go crazy. But his brain wasn't mad. He felt like thinking of Solaris had made it cool a bit. He didn't like it, and that made it heat up again. Like a broken thermometer. 

People in the arena would only see the flames dance, grow, and change colors a bit from an aggressive red to a bright yellow. The attacker seemed to be confusing themselves, as Antares let himself be consumed by the fire. They couldn't touch him anymore.

Then, in a burst, they went straight to the top of the protective dome, with barely any room for the other person to breathe, sending them into a coughing fit. Antares let the flames die to watch them fall, and with a hard ''thunk,'' pass out. Liza seemed to assume he was dead, and that familiar noise rang in his ears. 

Antares collapsed onto the field. He couldn't do this for much, and he was exhausted. The arena's onlookers started to file out.

"You have been there for a while. Are you alright?" A familiar voice asked. Antares looked up to see Solaris. 

"I don't know, man. I'm too tired to tell," he chuckled. Solaris let out a small laugh. 

"Are you too tired for me to pull you up?" He rolled his eyes.

"Nah."

Solaris grabbed his left hand, and pulled him up. "Why are you being so nice to me?" Antares asked.

"You've been through a rough patch. I don't want our scholarly relationship to crumble because we can't respect each other. I find it quite just," Solaris looked at Antares in the eyes. Antares looked back.

"Yeah. Wanna practice?"

"If you need to."

"Need to? Nah. Wanna show you what more I've got? Totally."

"I believe that's an excuse to spend time with me, Mercier." Solaris smirked.

"Go eat a rubber band, or something. What do you eat? I've never seen you eat."

"Food. Have ''you'' ever eaten a rubber band?"

"...No comment." Antares grumbled.
[[Category:Blog posts]]</text>

    <title>Polio</title>
    <ns>0</ns>
    <id>162408</id>
    <revision>
      <id>258733</id>
      <parentid>258657</parentid>
      <timestamp>2023-10-27T12:20:44Z</timestamp>
      <contributor>
        <username>Cometspace</username>
        <id>51496569</id>
      </contributor>
      <comment>/* Chapter 1 */</comment>
      <origin>258733</origin>
      <model>wikitext</model>
      <format>text/x-wiki</format>
      <text bytes="3757" sha1="7ynl5kgx7r9sd9ki8f7sdtvf0n5khna" xml:space="preserve">


==Chapter 1==
A fox trotted across Jamaa, wearing a spiked collar, yelling out loud ''“Shops my den!”''  before a weird otter, with a ripped ear, wearing an oddly grey zombie mask with red eyes, with a ragged cloak, and chains across its tail, would crawl across the ground, crawling across the crowd. The otter would grab a sandwich that an arctic wolf held with its paw, before xerting &lt;u&gt;(swallow, or gulp fast and greedily)&lt;/u&gt; the sandwich, and running away, The Arctic wolf would begin chasing it, shouting ''“Give me my sandwich back!”'' before the otter shouted conjubilantly &lt;u&gt;(Shouting with, or in joy)&lt;/u&gt; with joy ''“Gjoo!!''”. The Arctic wolf would stop, it’s mind processing what the word the otter shouted, before chasing the otter, until the Arctic wolf bumped into a purple tree, with green cracks across it and an evil smile with purple glowing out of it, the otter was behind the tree, before crawling up to the Arctic wolf, looking at it, and backflipping into the “mouth” of the tree as soon as the Arctic wolf tried to hit it with its paw, His paw would strike the ground as a pawful of dust would fly out of the air. 

The Arctic wolf, known as Combû, or simply C, was mad, hopping into the mouth, until he began to black out,  waking up in a purple grassland with the otter covered in blood, holding a knife with its mouth, before taking off its mask, revealing a horrifyingly bloody face, with no eyes, sharp teeth covered in blood, an evil smile smothered with blood, and holding a snickersnee &lt;u&gt;(Long, sword-like knife)&lt;/u&gt; along its tail, Blood would fall between Combû’s eyes, as he looked directly at the blood, before the otter grabbed the snickersnee, and stabbing the Arctic wolf, but Combû rolled before the otter landed a hit, a loud screech was heard from a pipe, coloured violet, with magenta, glowing tracks along it. The Arctic wolf was distracted, and began running towards the pipe as soon as the otter struck again with the snickersnee. 

''“TgooOOOOooo LghAAATee!”'' the otter would screech, before Combû would enter the pipe, and start running towards the light, before jumping, as he slowly shook his fur as he would close his eyes, before feeling a touch on his paws, like he was still in the ground, opening his eyes, before looking down, then up, only to look at a nearby pond, and see 67 otters, with different-coloured masks, The one in the middle was the largest, Combû would have a ring in his mind, instantly remembering a romp  (&lt;u&gt;Group of otters)&lt;/u&gt;  of 145 otters with a large leader known as Devourling, whom wore a brown, ragged cloak, a brown zombie mask with blue eyes, and had a torn ear, the rest had differently coloured, unique zombie masks to themselves, and the members wore tan cloaks, while the otter that Combû was chased by wore a dark tan cloak, and that the otter was one of the 15 foragers and gaurds of the romp.

He slowly backed away as he looked around, the entire romp of otters circling him, before Devourling would walk behind him, and it was only till Combû felt blood drip on his head between his ears, before he looked up, let out a gasp, and ran as Devourling chased him constantly before he jumped into the mouth of a tree.

Combû then woke up, as a paw constantly shook his head, ''“Hey, Combû! Wake up!”'' He heard, looking up at his friend, Polio, before jumping, ''“DONT KILL ME!”'' Combû shouted, ''“You’ve must had a nightmare indeed..”'' Polio reacted as he screamed, ''“Yea, I did.. It felt.. real.”'' Combû said, ''“Haha, we all have those sometimes,”'' Polio laughed.

[[Category: Cometspace]]
[[Category:Horror]]
[[Category: Fantasy]]
[[Category: Gore]]
[[Category: 13+]]
[[Category: Short Story]]</text>

  <page>
    <title>The Various Phantoms of Jamaa - A document by the Starry Dawn Group</title>
    <ns>0</ns>
    <id>162434</id>
    <revision>
      <id>258690</id>
      <timestamp>2023-10-20T20:30:14Z</timestamp>
      <contributor>
        <username>Sikuli</username>
        <id>37564637</id>
      </contributor>
      <comment>Created page with "The world of Jamaa is already bursting with phantom energy at times like these, and it seems Greely wants to tap into that. Although we should be supporting his aid, we at the Starry Dawn Group are working towards other issues revolving not in our world, but one far from it, where a tragedy is said to occur in 8 days.  In a bit of a short notice, we made this guide to help others understand phantoms. A few, the most elusive or dangerous, have been left out of this guide..."</comment>
      <origin>258690</origin>
      <model>wikitext</model>
      <format>text/x-wiki</format>
      <text bytes="3920" sha1="2dvh3n2wp2t2z8wo8f8lqs9roitec9x" xml:space="preserve">The world of Jamaa is already bursting with phantom energy at times like these, and it seems Greely wants to tap into that. Although we should be supporting his aid, we at the Starry Dawn Group are working towards other issues revolving not in our world, but one far from it, where a tragedy is said to occur in 8 days.

In a bit of a short notice, we made this guide to help others understand phantoms. A few, the most elusive or dangerous, have been left out of this guide due to the little information we have gotten about them.

== Basic Types and Subtypes ==
Common Phantom - Your usual 8 legged, floating beast. Usually paintseeds can be thrown at them to do harm, although it may also harm jammers if too close to said target. Also gets trapped in basic chomper plants.

Heavy Phantom - Subtype of the common phantom, they are known for having various nubs in a line going around the face, whilst also being larger, and thus heavier than the common phantom. Paintseeds have been proven to work decent, although in recent years, heavy phantoms require more than one to be defeated if sent to Jamaa.

Spitter/Mage phantoms - Another subtype of the common phantom, they are well characterized by hiding in plants and spitting burrs at jammers. They are the weakest of the basic types, and can be defeated by a regular boomseed. As they don’t move, chomper plants don’t notice them, and thus don’t consume them. Mages are a more magical variant of the spitter, using beams of miasma rather than burrs to attack, although same methods of defeat apply to them.

== Uncommon types and variants ==
Phantanimals - A general hybrid between jammers and phantoms, that can pass as a jammer with enough clothing. Usually, they have extra limbs, or tentacles sprouting from them. Paintseeds do harm them, but with the resistance of a jammer, they only go with minor injuries. They are one the two phantoms a sword would work on, and the only one that doesn’t need anything else to be fought with one. Cures for the condition are unknown.

Guise Phantoms - A full phantom disguising as an animal. Usually, they can be seen having unnatural colored double tails (variants unable to be found in stores) or having hidden limbs. Their eyes are often white, although rarely they can be yellow or purple. They can be defeated by paintseeds. This is the only other phantom you can fight with a sword, although you’d also need paintseeds when the disguise wears off. A mecha chomper will eat them out of disguise.

Twilight Storms - A phantom distinct from the common phantom, carrying lunar powers and manipulation of electricity. Although more recently seen by the public, they are not as easily defeated. Only by stealing the star shaped gems they hold can you remove their powers, and be able to defeat them. After that, it would take a mecha chomper or more paintseeds than a non-mutated phantom, but less than a fully mutated war phantom.

== Obscure Variants ==
Golden Mavericks - You may have seen the golden phantoms in games, and they are in fact real. Usually kept by kings as hostages or demanded as petlike beasts, these phantoms rarely see war. They are also the third weakest phantom, being able to be defeated by only one paintseed, compared to the 3 it takes to defeat a modern common phantom without mutations.

Rainbow Galaxites: A recently new variant, they are prized for their rainbow flecked sludge. However, they do not live easily, and tend to die on their own. They are also pet exclusive, and killing one would be a felony.

Serenity Fires: A general firefly-like phantom, with extra limbs carrying luminescent energy. They use this to communicate, or lure in jammers. If you cut off the light, it can be used as a weapon against them, or can be defeated with paintseeds.

Feel free to add onto this document if you find out more. - Miss SpookyFriend, Head Jamaa Researcher at the Starry Dawn Group.</text>
      <sha1>2dvh3n2wp2t2z8wo8f8lqs9roitec9x</sha1>
    </revision>
  </page>

      <text bytes="276807" sha1="brytl9dynbrmh8ffprmb3daqm6mfvy1" xml:space="preserve">[[File:DOJTR.jpg|center|400px]]
[[File:DOJCHA2.jpg|center|400px]]
&lt;center&gt;
'''&lt;big&gt;This story was originally published on [https://wikipets.fandom.com Wikipets].&lt;/big&gt;'''

'''Read more pet stories [https://wikipets.fandom.com/wiki/Category:Stories here]!&lt;/center&gt;'''

==About==
''”Defenders of Jamaa: The Remake” is a story based on the original 2020 pet story “Defenders of Jamaa” by Loafie.''

''While the plot has been updated and many details changed, the remake remains a tale about a lizard named Audrey whose owner gets kidnapped by phantoms, leading her to seek out the help of a group of phantom-fighting lizards to set her owner free — and along the way, searching for the identity of a rumored spy in the group and uncovering the secrets of lizard magic.''

==Characters==
*Liza
*Peck
*Sir Gilbert
*Greely
*Graham
*Cosmo
*Julie
*Skip
*Dragon
*Halo
*[[User:Loafie|Loafie]]
*Haylee
*Kaylee
*Marlenka
*Toxic
*Cakepop
*Bella
*Big Bird
*Banana
*Vatra
*Eira
*Raimu
*Wooyoung
*Mira
*Zios
*General Lido
*The Phantom King
*Baylee
*Leach

==Prologue - Liza’s POV==
Six pairs of pawsteps flattened the waving fields in the outskirts of Sarepia Forest. Nothing but the limited safety of nighttime hid their figures against the distant trees and hanging bridges that decorated the town up ahead. Nowhere in Jamaa was safe anymore, nowhere – not even at the earliest hour of the morning, not even for animals entrusted with otherworldly power to protect the land.

The six alphas rarely traveled without the aid of tiger troopers, courageous volunteers from an army raised by Sir Gilbert the tiger alpha, but a mysterious conversation had drawn Liza out of a deep sleep and into the open land to investigate alongside her five closest allies.

Peck had heard the jumbly, high-pitched chatter moments before Liza did; though it was expected that phantoms regularly sept into Jamaa and spied on whatever resistance efforts possible when the sun was far from peeking out over the lands, they rarely ever took such a risk as to talk to one another where jammers could hear them.

With a fuzzy pink paw Peck beckoned the others out of the tent to get a closer listen. The conversation crescendoed, as much as light whispering can do so, as the phantoms passed obliviously by the tent. Liza strained her ears and listened for anything clear enough to comprehend. Something about the phantom king.

Something about an uprising.

The alphas filed out of the tent one by one with feather-light motions – the shortest a pink bunny who owed half her height to the length of her ears, and the largest a mighty tiger with a cape the color of blood flowing from his back. As Liza squinted into the inscrutable shapes hidden among the underbrush, she realized that it wasn’t phantoms she was following. It was ''one'' phantom, vaguely purple in color, accompanied by two armadillo lizards who seemed to feel confident enough in their shadowed surroundings to let their tails lash noisily through the grass and bushes as they went.

Liza’s grip quivered on the hedge branch she’d pulled away to get a better look at her targets. It had been over two decades since the phantoms conducted a raid that stole lizards from their homelands of Jamaa and displaced them in the Phantom Dimension, but some of those lizards had chosen to save their own lives by joining the phantom cause – and now their hatchlings, born in the fortress, were forced to grow up mistreated and educated in the ways of evil.

“He had the nerve to assign half my students to lower fortress defense after the ''king'' ordered me to report to him about how well the schooling progress was coming along,” the phantom spat. “Some high-and-mighty general. It’s one thing that he’s been awful at strategy for as long as he’s had the job, but it’s another that he can’t even utilize the talent of all the young phantoms I work my tentacles off to train!”

One of the lizards spoke up. His colors seemed to shift every time a beam of moonlight struck him in a gap between the tree canopies, but the malicious glow in his eyes was constant. “He’s just digging his own grave, Miss Julie,” he reassured her. “Now they have one more reason to help you supplant him. He clearly doesn’t see how valuable they are… and soon that mistake will kill him.”

“Not quite, Skip,” the phantom, Julie, replied with a mischievous grin. “''We’ll'' kill him. And ''they’ll'' be right behind me.”

Then they shuffled off behind the cover of a tree with wilting branches and their faint whispers were reduced to nothingness. Liza glanced back and forth between the alphas’ shocked faces and the spot where the phantom and lizards had disappeared as if asking them whether they had heard the same conversation she did.

Receiving nods from the others, Liza stepped forward to keep following them – and tripped on a spiny green boomseed that was half-buried in the forest floor. The woods had been as quiet as if it weren’t being patrolled by six alphas, two lizards, and a phantom, but her brief yelp of alarm seemed to her as loud as a tree crashing into the grass.

Up ahead, Julie’s agitated breaths came quicker until at last she burst through the bushes and was face to face with the leaders of the phantoms’ common enemy: the alphas.

“Dragon! Skip!” Julie shouted. The two armadillo lizards scrambled to her side and bared their teeth. Liza gripped her staff, but looking at the phantom’s henchmen made her heart break. ''They should’ve been born here, in Jamaa, in a place where they would be loved and protected. But I can’t just let them go.''

Before she could even get to her paws, however, Julie’s eye began to glow a pale shade of lavender. Without warning, a ring of purple fire erupted from the earth and surrounded the six alphas. The blazes roared and grew, threatening to singe anyone who got too close, while Julie closed her eye and circled two tentacles in the air.

“She’s summoning a phantom portal!” Liza cried out, trying to reach her staff through the flames and blast Julie while she was focused, but the lizard called Skip jumped in front of her and raced down the end of the staff like a squirrel darting across a twig. The alphas struggled for space as Skip leaped off and circled them threateningly, the ring of fire closing in on them.

The last things Liza remembered were hearing Julie shout with triumph, watching a row of phantoms pour out of the portal she had grown, and choking on the toxic purple smoke before her vision went blurry and her mind slipped into darkness.

Liza almost thought she had dreamed it all when she woke up on smooth ground, something she hadn’t done since the phantoms had declared a renewed war on Jamaa and the tiger troopers’ makeshift tents became her new place of slumber every night. But as she rubbed the morning tiredness out of her eyes and pushed herself into a sitting position, she realized that the cold purple floor was very real, and so were the metal bars that trapped her there.

She gasped, gripping the bars and glancing around the room. None of the other alphas were in sight. The phantoms had confiscated her staff, her satchel, her camera… anything that could’ve helped her escape or capture information about the phantom fortress’s interior.

But what the phantoms didn’t know was that each of the alphas had the ability to communicate with the others by speaking inside their heads. The first thing Liza did after surveying what the phantoms had stolen was send a message to her five friends. ''Are you guys alright?''

''Liza!'' That was Peck. The excited emotions packed with her response gave Liza a mild headache. ''You’re alive! But where are you?''

''The rest of us are in separate prison cells in the same room, but we can’t see'' you ''anywhere,'' explained Cosmo, the alpha of the koalas. ''We thought- well, we were worried-''

''No, I’m okay, but the phantoms took almost all of my stuff. I can’t see any of you either… maybe they wanted to separate me because I’m the chief alpha?''

''That would make sense,'' Graham put in. ''Maybe they just want to make sure that all six of us aren’t together, even if some of us have to be. Maybe there’s not enough room to separate them.'' Liza shuddered at the latter idea. The phantoms had taken so many prisoners over the last year… how would they continue to make room for new ones once they ran completely out of space?

She felt so helpless. She and her fellow alphas had been held prisoner by phantoms once or twice during raids when they were unlucky enough to be caught off guard – but never had she been closer to the phantom fortress than looking at it from a close but safe distance. Now she was trapped inside it with nothing and no one to help any of the alphas escape, and all because she tripped over a boomseed.

''How are we going to get out of here?'' Peck asked through the alphas’ telepathic link. ''It’s not like we can offer anything to let them set us free. What if we get used as hostages? What if the jammers agree to something really bad to try and get us back?''

''We can’t let them,'' Sir Gilbert growled. Liza couldn’t help but admire his courage; he was always setting an example for the other jammers when it came to facing down phantoms with every drop of bravery they could muster.

''But then what can'' we ''do?'' Cosmo asked miserably. ''I haven’t got my staff either. They took Peck’s paintbrush, too; I guess they remembered it can turn into a sword.''

''Very smart of them,'' Peck said with a begrudging tone. ''They must’ve watched some of their friends get busted by my awesomely killer strokes. Hmph! Now none of us can use our powers because these stupid cells are magic-proof.''

Liza scanned the room. There was another cell beside her own, but it was empty. The sound of rumbling phantom pipes far below the prison tower kept the quiet from buzzing in her ears. Dark purple walls surrounded the tiny circular room without so much as a single banner to decorate it.

''We can’t,'' she thought quietly. ''But someone else can.''

Waves of confusion rolled into Liza’s head from almost all of the other alphas. ''How do you mean?'' Sir Gilbert asked her.

''I don’t know how long we’ll be in here, and when or if we’ll get out.'' Liza stared into her paws. The dark-gray fingerless gloves were bruised with dirt marks from when she fell in the woods. ''But Jamaa can’t stop fighting just because we’re not there. We need to ask Mira and Zios to take away our alpha powers and give them to six new animals of their choosing, at least until we’re free again and able to keep leading and fighting, because they’re no use to us while we’re imprisoned here. But it will take some time for them to find the ones who deserve those powers… so we can’t delay.''

There was a shocked silence in Liza’s brain for a few seconds. Then Greely, the wolf alpha, spoke: ''Your idea is a very noble one, Liza. Our abilities as alphas are a mere part of the massive resistance that Jamaa has been conducting for years, but they are simply too great for the war to be fought without.''

''I agree,'' said Peck. ''There are so many brave and kind jammers out there. Surely six of them will be able to take on our magic!''

''Mira and Zios chose well when they selected each of us and gifted us with fractions of their own powers to use as our own,'' Sir Gilbert agreed proudly. ''I trust that they will choose well again.''

Cosmo had no doubts either. ''I’m on board. I bet the new alphas will do so well while we’re gone that it’ll hardly seem like we’re not there fighting alongside them!''

''Me as well,'' said Graham, ''but how are we going to get Mira and Zios to hear us? How can we be sure they’re watching?''

''We just have to have faith,'' Liza replied. ''If we all concentrate together, they might just hear us…''

And she knew in moments that she had been heard, because her power to speak to the others in her mind faded away. All she could do was hope that Jamaa would welcome and fight well alongside its new alphas, and that this wasn’t the last time she’d ever hear the voices of her friends.

==Chapter One - Strays - Audrey’s POV==
Phantoms were coming.

That was all Audrey was told before her owner, Loafie, scooped her up with her friend Halo and plopped the two of them on her back. There was no time to gather more than a blanket and a small pouch of fruit and bread. Halo, a teal on cream armadillo lizard, fired question after question at Loafie, but she couldn’t answer him.

That’s what he does whenever he’s nervous, Audrey knew. Ask a lot of questions. And she hated when Halo was nervous, because it always meant he had a good reason.

Loafie saw the eight-tentacled creatures coming first. They advanced over the hills toward Jamaa Township, not quite as organized as army ranks but just as intimidating, with a larger phantom wearing a war helmet in their lead.

“They’re just here to scare us,” Loafie said. But the way the gray-and-cream fox stared back at her small house den as she fled the approaching enemy made Audrey wonder if the attack would affect the three of them beyond just a little bit of fright.

Tucked beneath the blanket on Loafie’s back were Audrey and Halo, shivering from more than the mid-autumn chill. “Where are we going?” Halo asked. Loafie just shook her head, panting as her puffs of breath became heavier with each bound. Four paws thrummed for twelve on the dusty path in time with her pounding heartbeat.

“Don’t worry, Halo. We’ll be okay,” Audrey reassured him. “Loafie always knows what to do.”

Loafie stumbled on twigs rooted in the ground as the land gradually became wooded where Jamaa Township faded into Sarepia Forest. Most of the phantoms had broken off from the group that was chasing her at this point, but some of them clearly enjoyed watching a jammer run away from them.

Suddenly, a proto-phantom popped up out of a bush Loafie was approaching. The lizards dug their tiny claws into her back to hold on while she skidded to a halt in the grass. She had sped forward so fast that the small round phantom busted, but it slowed her down enough that the other phantoms finally caught up.

“No!” Loafie gasped. Her head whirled around looking for ways to escape, but her indecision had left her surrounded. The phantoms chattered and cackled at her, watching her dart around in panic before a pair of heavy phantoms hauled out a giant cage.

Her ice-blue gaze flitted all over the field until she finally spotted a way out: a small tunnel leading from a dirt patch down into a dark hole. It was too many paces away to see what was underneath, and it was definitely too small for a fox to fit… but it was the perfect size for a pair of lizards.

Loafie jerked forward so that Audrey and Halo tumbled onto her tail and into the grass. “Get into the pouch!” she ordered them. Halo stared at her with wide red x-eyes, not moving despite the desperation in her voice, but Audrey took him by the arm and dived in among the apples and bread while Loafie bundled it up inside the blanket.

“Halo, come on,” Audrey whispered frantically. “We have to-”

Before she could finish, the two lizards were catapulted through the air, whizzing past a number of phantoms with startled expressions and then landing in front of a hole in the ground. It was Audrey’s turn to look back at Loafie in disbelief, but when her owner screeched “''Run''”, she knew she and Halo had no choice. Audrey shoved Halo into the tunnel first and squeezed the food pouch in after him, and once he had pulled the pouch far enough into the tunnel, she followed him with the blanket wrapped around her middle.

“Forget the lizards!” she heard one of the phantoms shout to its comrades. “They’ll be back for this one.” The tunnel was too narrow for Audrey to turn around, and the blanket that blocked the entrance muffled sounds from aboveground, but she was certain she heard metal snap shut against metal.

Halo heard it too. He turned his head as much as the width of the tunnel would let him, and Audrey saw tears glittering in his eyes. “She’s alive, Halo,” Audrey told him softly. “We have to be alive too if we want to get her back.” The words struck her as silly the moment they left her mouth. The phantom army was so ''big.'' How would two tiny lizards be able to find their owner, much less help her escape from Jamaa’s most infamous enemy?

The teal-and-cream lizard didn’t respond. He just shook his head and kept dragging the pouch through an endless corridor of dirt.

As they went, Audrey noticed that the tunnels branched off in many places. No matter how she squinted at them, however, it was impossible to see anything inside them. The whole underground system seemed to have been dug so close to the surface of the earth that she could still clearly smell every flower and fallen drop of phantom goop that passed by over their heads. She was grateful for whatever had caused them to be that way; the very idea of going any deeper into the seemingly-endless dark made her queasy.

Either one of the lizards could have sworn that entire cycles of the moon had passed before a light finally illuminated their way. Halo gasped when he saw it and began lugging the fruit behind him twice as quickly as before. “Be careful it doesn’t fall out!” Audrey shouted after him, but he barely seemed to listen.

The tunnel sloped upwards at last, opening out into a clearing surrounded by a ring of pine trees and carpeted with pine needles… and populated with more armadillo lizards than Audrey could count.

Halo, whose head had popped out of the hole, saw all the unfamiliar pairs of eyes staring at him and scrambled backwards into the tunnel in a panic. “Don’t back up!” Audrey yelped as the pouch got smushed up against her face.

“It’s alright.” A pastel lizard, her scales pink on blue, emerged from the crowd. “We don’t bite.”

A second lizard, larger and with scales of red and gold, stepped forward beside her and smirked. “Unless you’re a phantom, but you only half look like one.”

Halo instinctively looked down at himself and glared at the red lizard, but he hauled himself out of the hole and pulled the bread-and-food pouch behind him with his teeth. “Do you need any help?” the first lizard asked him, but he regarded her with a look of distrust and ignored her outstretched claws.

Audrey was grateful for the help, however, and let the stranger lift her back up to ground level. Her white blanket – Loafie’s – was now soiled from rubbing up against the dirt walls of the tunnels. “I’ll wash that for you,” said the lizard who had helped her up. “I’m Haylee, by the way.”

“That’s okay, I can wash it,” Audrey said instinctively, even though she didn’t have a clue where the nearest source of clean water was. Her social personality kicked in and she continued. “I’m Audrey. And this is my friend Halo.”

She noticed that Halo frowned a bit when she called him her friend. ''Why’s he upset, I wonder? We’ve only known each other for a year since Loafie adopted him,'' Audrey thought to herself. ''I’m not sure I can go around calling him a brother or anything just yet. Although if we’re going to be out here without Loafie, maybe this will be what tests our bond as adopted siblings. Or… something like that.''

“Well, Audrey, Halo,” Haylee said with a smile. “You made it. Welcome to the Defenders of Jamaa.”

==Chapter Two - Snow - Audrey’s POV==
“The… Defenders of Jamaa?” Halo echoed Haylee’s words, puzzled.

“That’s right!” A black lizard with bright yellow-green facial scales piped up. “We’re the largest all-lizard anti-phantom resistance effort in Jamaa.” He looked down at his claws. “Not like we have much competition, but there’s still a good number of us left!” Audrey tried to survey the size of the assembled lizards with her eyes, guessing that there were at least sixty of them, each with unique colors and eye shapes.

Haylee’s ear twitched when he said the word “left.” “Thank you, Toxic,” she told him halfheartedly. “Some of the group is out gathering right now, so you’re not looking at every one of us.” She pointed her tail at a purple and green lizard who stood behind her. “My sister’s one of the gatherers. She saw the two of you in trouble and went to tell us.”

That made Halo’s shoulders tense up behind his head. “She saw us?” His tail lashed with accusation at the shape of Haylee’s sister. “Why didn’t you even try to save Loafie when it was obvious we needed help?”

“She was alone,” Haylee cut in with a stern tone, “and, according to her- what did you say again?”

“There were too many phantoms there for even ''five'' lizards to be able to fight off,” Kaylee said softly. Audrey examined the tension in her arms and how her head was lowered beside her sister’s. She doubted she’d be hearing much from this lizard, but that didn’t mean she had nothing to say.

Halo exhaled. “Okay. I’m sorry. I’m just not used to having my owner ripped away from me with zero warning, and now I don’t know what to do.”

“You’re welcome to stay with us for a while,” Haylee said with a sympathetic blink of her pale-blue eyes. “We move around a lot, but for the time being, our home is in a bunker a bit deeper into Sarepia Forest.” She swept her tail at the other members of the Defenders of Jamaa. “A lot of these guys have lost their owners, too. Right now we’re focused on giving a home to lizards who have been displaced in the phantom attacks and launching surprise attacks on phantom spy parties, but with just a little more time and training, we’ll be ready to launch a full-scale invasion on the phantom fortress and take back their owners for good.”

Many of the lizards behind Haylee cheered at her words. Some were shifting their claws and ripping up the grass, clearly eager to bust some phantoms. They all looked so different in their sizes and appearances and colors – but to Audrey, that made their united determination all the more beautiful.

Audrey glanced questioningly at Halo, and turned back to Haylee when he gave her a nod. “We’ll join you.”

The lizards shouted again with excitement. The red-and-gold lizard gave her and Halo a suspicious eye, but she stepped back when Haylee invited them to the Defenders’ barracks.

It wasn’t a long trek from the clearing to the next hole in the ground. “In five weeks’ time, all this will be covered in four inches of snow,” Toxic told Audrey, sweeping his black-and-neon tail through the pine needles.

Audrey loved the snow. She fondly remembered the couple months when it finally started getting cold, right before the Jamaalidays were in full swing, begging Loafie to stock up on Cosmo’s Famous hot cocoa mix. Every time she asked, Loafie would tell her it was too early, but on a different day each year she would come home from her trading errands with an arm full of the containers and Audrey would dance all around the living room at the sight.

When Halo was adopted, she remembered him teasing her for putting cinnamon in her drink, but one time she dared him to take a sip of her cocoa and he decided he loved it. In the years that followed, the two lizards would beg their owner not only for hot cocoa, but warm cinnamon powder as well, to continue their tradition.

Given how scrappy the lizards in the group looked, though they all seemed generally happy, Audrey guessed there wasn’t any cinnamon in their bunker. Or hot chocolate. She frowned at the earth as it passed slowly underneath her.

Halo sensed her sudden change in emotions and hurried to her side. “Don’t worry,” he told her, seeming to start accepting that he would have to live with these lizards for who knew how long. “It could be worse. We could be in the phantoms’ prison. And then there would be no one to free Loafie, because what if everyone here just wants to save their own owners? Or maybe we’d just be dead.”

His gaze dropped to the point where Audrey was staring. “Maybe a few weeks on our own will do that to us. We’ve never been on our own before.”

“Halo, always the optimist,” Audrey said sarcastically. She flicked her tail over his shoulder comfortingly. “We’re not alone. We have the Defenders now.”

She glanced at the pouch of food Loafie had packed for the two of them, which was now slung over her back. “We might not have much right now, but they want to protect us. And if we help them, maybe even make some friends…” Audrey smiled as Halo rolled his eyes at the idea. “They might just help us free Loafie. And don’t you like the idea of helping do the same for other lizards’ owners?”

Halo snorted. “I still don’t think that they would lift a claw for ''us'' had you not told them we were joining. The leader’s sister left us to fend for ourselves. She ran away while Loafie was fighting for her life!”

“Shhh, keep your voice down,” Audrey tried to calm him. Toxic had trotted ahead, but he turned his head back and smiled at them. He seemed like the kind of lizard who would welcome them and help them get Loafie back.

It was going to be difficult to tell who to trust with how suddenly she and Halo had been thrust into a world without their owner, but Audrey was determined to give the Defenders a chance. ''Maybe I’ll learn a thing or two here,'' Audrey thought. ''Maybe they know how to fight back against the phantoms or teach self-defense or throw boomseeds. Or how to make hot cocoa mix out of dirt...''

==Chapter Three - Spy - Halo’s POV==
There was nothing but a round dent in the ground to signify the entrance to another tunnel. “Just so you know, it’s a little tight in here, so make sure you go single file,” Haylee called back to Audrey and Halo. “It’s the best way to make sure phantoms can’t wander in.”

Lizards scurried into the hole in a neat line, tail-to-tail, like a row of ants on a log. Halo was about to shuffle his way in when he was stopped by a red arm with three dark-gold claws blocking his way. “You two are gonna hang back with me,” the red-and-gold lizard who had teased him earlier growled.

He narrowed his eyes at her, but stepped aside from the lizards who were entering the tunnel and Audrey sat confused beside him. The lizard Haylee had called Toxic whooped and cannonballed into the hole, much to the annoyance of those waiting behind him, but Audrey chuckled at him. Halo scowled at the black-and-neon lizard as his bright tail-tip disappeared underground.

It was impossible not to notice, as more and more lizards went by and disappeared into the hole, that the red lizard was unarguably the buffest one in the group, or that Halo had ever seen. Her nose was tilted just a little bit higher than Halo’s – maybe that was her personality, he guessed – but her arms were like redwood trunks and looked just as solid. If the shade of her scales was like blood after it had dried, her eyes resembled the color when it was fresh.

Finally, she, Halo, and Audrey were the last ones remaining who hadn’t yet dived into the hole. Audrey was simply staring at everything the stranger had to stare at until she snapped her head back to them. “Marlenka,” she introduced herself with a chilly tone. Her voice was deep, much unlike the tunnels or Halo’s respect for her or anything else in the immediate area worth the comparison.

“You two are definitely new. And I assume the scouts weren’t lying about where you came from, because both Kaylee ''and'' Raimu said they saw what happened.” She said “what happened” so stoically that Halo wanted to claw her eyes out, but he forced himself to contain his feelings, at least as long as Audrey was around. He couldn’t risk acting up in front of his crush of six months.

“There’s a spy in the group.” She said it like this discovery was something that happened every other week. Halo shifted closer to Audrey, trying to send her a silent question: ''Why are you so willing to stay in a group like this when we could be looking for Loafie?''

Audrey tilted her head at Marlenka. “Why tell us?”

“I’ve told every lizard who joined the group within the last six months or so because I need as many eyes on the situation as possible and it’s unlikely that any new recruits would be involved in it.” Marlenka glanced back at the tunnel entrance to make sure no one was lingering there. “We’ve had to move around an unimaginable amount of times this year. There’s no way it’s a coincidence; someone is definitely relaying our location to the phantoms. You see…”

Marlenka traced a claw in front of the entrance and then covered it up again with pine needles. “We have several underground bunkers all over the eight lands of Jamaa. When we get found by the phantoms, we often have to leave our stuff behind, but then there’s always a pre-made bunker waiting for us to move into. We used to be able to go a few months before they’d discover us living under there, but now it just takes a couple weeks… and the timing always feels ''too'' perfect.”

Halo sniffed. “Shouldn’t it be easy to keep track of who’s leaving the bunkers frequently and at the right time to suggest they’re telling the phantoms everything? I don’t see why you need to drag every new recruit into this.”

“You wanna keep track of that, on top of all the gatherers and messengers who are ''supposed'' to be sent out? Good luck, and thanks for the load off.” Marlenka clapped Halo on the back so hard he nearly fell over. “Dinnertime. You don’t want to miss it.”

Halo just proceeded into the tunnel without looking back at her, shaking his head as he went. Audrey was about to follow him, but Marlenka lifted her head. “You seem like the observant type,” she commented, and then she squeezed into the tunnel after Audrey, leaving the purple-and-silver lizard to follow her.

The tunnel was composed of damp dirt underneath Halo’s claws, which wasn’t the most pleasant surface to walk on, but once it opened out into an underground room most of the floor was covered in ragged red carpets. A little ways away, lizards were laughing and conversing at a long table made from natural wood with the bark shaved off.

Looking over his shoulder, Halo could see that Audrey was amazed. Halo had to begrudgingly admit – though not out loud, of course – that it was incredible how the lizards made a home like this out of so little. Back at Loafie’s den, all the furniture and decorations were gargantuan, proportioned for a fox, but in the hall everything was perfectly lizard-sized. Little wooden sconces lined the walls, lit with a tiny bit of fire, and cast circles of light on the sides of the room that inhaled and exhaled with every motion of the flame. Some of the younger lizards seemed to be playing a version of “the floor is lava” – or dirt, rather – while skipping across the carpets on the way to the dining hall.

“This place is amazing,” Audrey breathed once she had caught up to Halo. “Look how there are so many other tunnels coming out from this room.” They leaned to see into the nearest one and saw a few rows of neat leafy beds. Some of them looked as lush and green as if it were still summertime, but others were drying up and the leaves inside were crinkled like the ones on the trees up above.

Behind them, Marlenka cleared her throat. “Exsqueeze me.” She shouldered her way past Halo and Audrey as they pressed themselves up against the wall. Once she had her head into the larger room, she turned it around and looked at them. “Come on, eat. We have seven metric tons of crap you can stuff your cheeks with.”

“Do you have any… strawberries?” asked Halo.

“I don’t know,” Marlenka said flatly. “Do you guys like chocolate cake?”

==Chapter Four - Welcome - Bella’s POV==
Bella watched the two newcomers join the rest of the Defenders for dinner in the great hall. When she first saw them, she felt a kind of vicarious joy at watching them be accepted, but at the same time, how happy could she really be when only two lizards had ever greeted her with that same enthusiasm?

Her parents back in the phantom fortress would tell her to push those feelings down. Push down the happiness so that it doesn’t get in the way of your thoughts, and push down the sadness so that you can harness it later.

“I think we should tell our brand-new members about the Mt. Shiveer raid in two days,” Haylee began over the loud sounds of chewing and slurping.

“Yes, that,” Marlenka agreed. “Not sure if it needs to be a dinner discussion. Only a few of us are supposed to go. Seven or less, since the messengers said there weren’t many finished prisons yet or phantoms working on them.”

Toxic piped up. “''So'' it’ll be a nice chance for them to show their loyalty if they come along!”

A bright-yellow solid lizard suddenly sat up from his chair and sang at the top of his lungs, “''RUN AWAY FROM THE HUMDRUM!!''” Another solid-yellow lizard, this one daffodil-colored, promptly slapped him right in the face.

“Hey, no,” Haylee stopped them. “Big Bird, Banana, sit down. And I’m not going to force anyone to come on a dangerous mission if they don’t want to. Because the mission involves going to a cold place and likely interacting with phantoms, it should really be their choice if they decided to go. Nobody needs to prove anything to anyone.”

Marlenka grunted. “Speak for yourself,” she muttered under her breath. Bella’s scales seemed to turn to ice as she watched the red-and-gold lizard swing her head down into a lava cake. Haylee had always been kind to her, and stuck up for her when the other lizards looked at her sideways, but Marlenka had done nothing but the opposite.

Every time she even glanced in Bella’s direction, she felt blades of festering suspicion whizzing past her ears. At least, Bella thought to herself, she had accepted that she would never gain the red lizard’s trust. And at this point, she didn’t care to overexert herself trying to earn it.

In response to what Haylee said, Toxic glanced at the newest members of the group. “Well, I’ll be going along if either of you wanted to come,” he offered. “Cakepop?”

“Yeah!” a pink-and-tan lizard responded almost instantly. “You know I’ll be there!”

“I had asked Haylee if I could come yesterday,” said a lizard with pale purple scales named Eira. “Is that still alright with you?”

Haylee smiled. “Mhm. And I know Raimu wanted to be on the mission too. So if that makes six of us with Marlenka, since she’s basically in charge of all the scratchy clawy stuff, we probably just need one more.”

The other lizards turned to look at Audrey and Halo, who sat at the designated spot for new Defenders at the end of the table. Bella knew she wasn’t going to volunteer, even if Marlenka was going. There were only two lizards in the entire group who she bothered to get to know, and they were Haylee and Millie.

Millie never went on missions anymore, since she was older and had been a Defender for all three years of the group’s existence; Haylee, the founder and putative leader (although she rejected that title officially) considered her to have done enough of a share over the years to stop working and just live with the Defenders, but Millie insisted on helping take care of the younger lizards whenever possible. Bella saw her looking her way from across the table, but she just shook her head politely. This raid just wasn’t for her.

Halo was doing a terrible job trying to send nonverbal signals to Audrey. His head shook as noticeably as possible in her direction, making him look like he was sitting in a massage chair or experiencing an electric shock, but Audrey didn’t get the message. “Don’t worry about it,” she told Haylee. “I’d love to go with you.”

The others who would be in the raid party voiced their excitement and toasted glasses of fruit juice, stretching out like scaly elastic bands to clink rims with lizards on the other sides of the table. Bella watched Halo turn his head away with a look of frustration on his face. She couldn’t blame him; she’d feel the same way if she had to be alone in the barracks with both Millie and Haylee gone.

But up until that afternoon, Halo had had an owner. He had somebody who both loved and wanted him for at least some of his life. And he didn’t even come to the Defenders alone. Bella sunk her dark-purple claws into the chair cushion. It was ''selfish'' of him to ignore all this attention just because his friend wanted to go on a mission that he didn’t. No one was treating him like a plague because of where he came from.

She stared into the shiny green grapes on her plate, the same color as her eyes, and watched the reflection move around as she turned her head. She knew if she refused to look up at the Defenders chatting up Audrey and Halo and getting to know them with a genuine kind of eagerness, maybe her tears had a chance of staying put.

==Chapter Five - Book - Audrey’s POV==
Audrey’s stomach was more than full once dinner was over. Haylee sent out groups of lizards to scout around the area and had Toxic and some others clean up the table for the next meal. Once again it warmed her heart to see such a diverse mix of age groups working together, even if one of the extreme ends just meant hatchlings licking up bread crumbs underneath the long wooden table.

She decided to approach Haylee after she had finished receiving the previous set of scouts and gatherers from their outdoor ventures. “Yes,” Haylee said, although it barely sounded like a question and was paired with a heavy exhale.

“Is there anything I can do to help?” Audrey tilted her head at the pink-and-blue lizard.

Haylee thought for a moment. “Well, all the scouting patrols are out, and we don’t need to gather until the morning. But maybe you could poke around in the storage room and see if you can find any supplies that will help us for the mission tomorrow. Blankets or spades or something. You’d be surprised what useful things get left in the bunkers when we move burrows,” she added with a wistful smile. Audrey wondered if she was still looking for something important that she’d been forced to leave behind.

“Marlenka can go with you. ''Marlenka!''” The red and gold lizard swung her head around and lumbered forward.

“What.”

Haylee pointed with her tail toward another dark tunnel branching out from the great hall. “Could you help Audrey look for stuff for the mission in the storage room?”

“I don’t know, could I?”

The pink lizard sighed. “Marlenka, ''may'' you. Please.”

Marlenka’s mouth twitched up into a smile for a split second. “Well, thank you for asking so nicely. C’mon, Purple.” She bumped Audrey’s shoulder and squeezed into the tunnel. A short and silent walk later, during which Audrey could sense they were getting much further underground, they stopped in front of a door labeled “STORAGE” with a wooden sign hanging loosely from a peg. The rope attached to it, which seemed to be made of pure sawdust, looked thin enough that it could snap and drop the sign to the ground at any moment.

“I’m not going in there,” Marlenka said.

Audrey smirked at her. “What, are there spiders in here? Are you afraid of spiders?”

Marlenka’s nose scrunched up. “Mice are the major problem, actually. But I’m tired and big and bound to knock crap over, so why would I bother.” She shrugged and began backing out of the tight passage with a remarkable lack of claustrophobia. “Have fun digging through useless garbage. Don’t know what’s been stowed away here, but all I know is my heart spear is somewhere back in the southern Coral Canyons bunker, and I haven’t seen the ol’ redrock arch in eight months and counting.” With a huff, she finally pulled herself out of the entrance and disappeared from sight of the entrance, presumably to find a more suitable place to collapse.

Audrey wandered through the door, turning her head in such a way that it felt like her neck had rusted over. There was nothing menacing about this place except for a lack of brightness and too much to look at – the only light came from a cluster of lava lamps slumped against one another in the corner of the room. She inspected the pile and, sensing no mice in her immediate accidental-grabbing range, picked up one of the flickering lamps and carried it like a torch.

The room was much taller than the corridor that had led to it, which Audrey figured was the reason the tunnel had sloped so steeply downward into the earth. Tall shelves on wheels lined the sides of the room and filled the vast space in the middle, their lowest platforms crusted with dried dirt but the contents atop them mostly clean. She saw everything from broken plates to tools to actual torches with burnt ends on display. And near the center of the room: blankets.

Audrey let out a breath of relief and let her lava lamp’s weak blue glow guide her to the shelf. The blankets were a few levels up, but she could always climb…

Reluctantly, she set down the lava lamp on the ground and hoisted herself up onto the chilly metal pole that supported one corner of the shelf. It was no surface that made crawling up it easy, but the level she needed to reach was way too high to jump up to. Before long, Audrey had reached a point where she had climbed too high to risk looking down, and she had passed more than a few levels of the shelf containing objects that no amount of squinting could make clear in the dark.

At last, she reached a level with something fuzzy and soft hanging over the edge. Audrey grabbed onto it, expecting to be able to hoist herself up, but nearly fell all the way back down the pole when it squeaked and scurried out from under her claws. “Jeez!” she hissed under her breath. After waiting a few more seconds to see if any more blanket-resembling critters would escape, Audrey swung back on the pole to gain momentum and then vaulted onto the shelf platform where the blankets were waiting.

Just in case, she swept her tail over the blankets to chase out invisible mice, expecting at least one or two more to dart out, but hit something that was clearly hard. “What…” she muttered and turned around to see what she had knocked against. Blankets were piled on top of one another all over this level of the shelf, but one of them had a square shape vaguely visible underneath it with corners too rigid to be a folded cloth.

Audrey peered at it with curious eyes. At that point, it wouldn’t have shocked her if the four-sided shape sprouted legs and ran away, but it didn’t. When she ripped away the blanket laid on top of it, what stared back at her with several pairs of illustrated armadillo lizards’ eyes was a book titled ''The Secret Talents of the Lizards.''

==Chapter Six - Secret - Audrey’s POV==
The book seemed to glow as Audrey picked it up. When she turned open the solid cover, she realized that the contents were written with some kind of iridescent ink that put the undependable luminosity of the lava lamp to shame. And it was definitely written and not printed; the lettering was far from perfect, and Audrey found herself subconsciously avoiding touching the pages as much as possible in case the glimmering ink smeared on the paper.

It was no thick volume, but what Audrey read in the table of contents made up for any resulting disappointment. There was a section for abilities to control each of the four cardinal elements – air, water, earth, and fire – and additional chapters dedicated to other types of magic that were entirely different. “''Alpha influence on lizard magic,''” Audrey read aloud, puzzled. “I ought to take a look at that one. And what’s this one about wings?”

Soon she was curled up in a not-so-neat pile of blankets, her back legs dangling over the edge of the shelf platform, flipping through information about elements and how armadillo lizards had the unique power to harness them. “There,” she muttered once she found the part she was looking for about how alpha magic affected lizard magic.

“Though alpha magic is most likely disconnected from the elemental powers of armadillo lizards,” she read off the page, “it has been proposed that the possession of alpha powers can grant a lizard powers of a specific additional element, or heightened elemental powers if the lizard is already in possession of that element. Only one lizard, though now deceased, has ever held the title of alpha before: Baylee, Alpha of Magic, Protector of Lizards, and Visitor of Lizard Heroes.”

Suddenly intensely interested, even though she knew none of the alphas were lizards, Audrey looked through a table of alpha types and what element they corresponded to, alongside a written explanation. “Alphas are categorized by the animal species whose heartstone they possess, in addition to a unique magic type. The six alpha types are moon, sun, magic, technology, nature, and phantom. The elements they are thought to add to a lizard alpha’s existing power given their alpha type are as follows: earth to nature, fire to sun and technology, water to magic, and air to moon and phantom.” She frowned at the table. “Huh. I never knew the alphas had ''types'' before…”

She flipped forward some more until she reached the chapter that was all about wings. It caught her eye as soon as she reached it, since the pages were decorated with several detailed illustrations of wings.

Audrey kept reading quietly to herself. “In addition to elemental powers, each lizard has the ability to summon a unique pair of wings that will typically draw their coloring from the lizard’s scales. Summoning the wings takes usually up to five seconds for a lizard who has practiced the skill, and they will automatically disappear once the lizard reaches the ground after using their wings to fly.”

This book really did contain secrets about the talents of lizards, Audrey thought. All of this information was completely new to her. A lizard alpha? Elemental powers? ''Wings?'' Her excitement at the knowledge was curbed by a question: ''What do I do with this book?''

Putting it back under the blanket was hardly an option now. Who knew how old the book was, and whether the words inside of it were still true? But what if handing it over to Haylee was a wrong move somehow?

''No,'' Audrey decided. ''Giving it to Haylee means giving it to someone who would probably have a better idea of what to do with these secrets than I do. And this book was in this bunker, in this storage room. It can only be property of the Defenders.''

In the back of Audrey’s brain, she was still so wrapped up in the fantasy idea of powers and flight that she felt like jumping from the shelf to see if wings would appear and carry her to the floor, but she restrained herself and slid down the metal pole with the book and three blankets tucked over her back.

When she emerged from the tunnel, Audrey saw Haylee was the only one left in the previously bustling dinner hall. She was in the process of folding the red plaid tablecloth with claws that moved as slowly as her drooping eyelids. Hearing Audrey call her name startled her back awake.

“Sorry to wake you,” Audrey said, trotting over to Haylee’s side. “Should I come back in the morning?”

Haylee shook her head and rubbed her sky-blue eyes. “No, it’s fine. Oh, hey, you found some blankets. Thank you.”

Audrey tilted to the side so that the cargo slid off her back. “Blankets, and… this.” As gingerly as possible, she reached into the blanket pile and pulled out the book. “It was right by the shelf where I found the blankets. I figured you might have lost this sometime during a move.”

But judging by Haylee’s starry-eyed reaction, that wasn’t the case. “No, I’ve never seen this book before. ‘''The Secret Talents of the Lizards''’?”

Audrey nodded and opened the book. “It’s got a whole bunch of stuff in it. Magic and wings and-”

She was stopped by the sound of claws hitting the dirt. Audrey looked up sharply. “What was that?” she whispered.

A purple-and-green lizard with big blue eyes appeared in the tunnel. “Sorry,” she said quietly. “I can’t sleep. I tried looking in your nest, but I couldn’t find you.”

Haylee smiled at her sister. “Don’t worry, Kaylee, I’ll be there in a few minutes.” In her mind, Audrey was grateful that Kaylee didn’t even seem to glance at the book. It made her guilty, considering she trusted Haylee and this was her sister, but the book’s contents made their secrecy seem all too important to stay between only those who needed to know until Haylee decided otherwise.

“Sorry about that,” Haylee said to Audrey once Kaylee had nodded and disappeared again. “She does that often. Our owner got captured by phantoms three years ago, and, well… It really hit her hard. So I do what I can to stay by her side and make sure she knows I care about her.”

“That’s sweet of you,” Audrey replied. She stared at the floor. “I hope we can both get our owners back before…” Before when? Next year? Ever? How long would it take for the Defenders to be ready to storm the phantom fortress? Haylee had already waited for three years, and what end was there in sight?

Haylee smiled at her. “We will. No matter how long it takes.” She rose to her claws and stretched out a bit. “I’ll keep the book safe in my nest for tomorrow. Maybe you, me, and Marlenka can take a closer look at it together in the morning?”

“I’d love to,” Audrey said excitedly. “Good night.”

She realized she had never picked out a place to sleep before going into the storage room, but Haylee was already down the hall to find her own nest where Kaylee was waiting. ''Oh boy. I’m so tired…'' she thought. ''I hope we can just plop down anywhere. Should’ve chosen a nest earlier…''

That little space didn’t make such an awful place to sleep. She was right near the folded tablecloth, blocking her off from sight like a little wall, and the ground was smooth and dry. In an instant she was curled up on it and peacefully dreaming she could fly.

==Chapter Seven - Leaves - Halo’s POV==
Halo had a rough time falling asleep, and by the time he woke up he guessed he didn’t get more than four hours of shuteye. When he stretched out like he always did in the morning, his tail hit branches and leaves and grass instead of the comfy fluff lining the inside of his bed back at Loafie’s den.

Also, he was surrounded by at least a dozen other lizards in the same tunnel. One of them saw him blinking awake and came over; her scales were light shades of pink and brown, and a playful ferocity sparked in her teal eyes. “Hey, Halo!” she shouted as she bounded up to him. “You snore, dude.” A couple of the other lizards chuckled.

Halo rose to his claws and glared at her while simultaneously flexing his back legs in the last of his stretching routine. This lizard was familiar to him; Toxic had referred to her as Cakepop back at the dinner table. She was one of the ones going on the stupid mission.

''Ugh.'' Thinking about dinner made his head ache. He had been surrounded by so much food – but the amount of lizards and noise in the room had made his stomach urge him not to eat, so hungry he remained. ''And Audrey didn’t even'' look ''at me when I was trying to tell her not to volunteer for the mission!''

He realized he had been so lost in his internal frustration that he was staring at Cakepop. Hurriedly he turned his head away. “Oooo, Cakepop, somebody ''liiiikes'' you!” another lizard exclaimed.

“I’m thinking about something,” Halo growled. “I didn’t mean to keep looking at-”

“Thinking about ''meeeee?''” Cakepop giggled.

Halo snorted. “You’re what, seven? Grow up a little before you start chasing after lizards who are way too old for you.”

“I’m eleven,” Cakepop corrected him with a thoughtful tone. “Which makes me like sixty years less than you.”

She and her friends giggled and scrambled away into the dinner hall before Halo could say a word. The teal-and-cream lizard ground his lower jaw against the roof of his mouth and lumbered in after them to look for Audrey.

However, the group of hatchlings in front of him stopped so abruptly that he nearly rammed straight into its back and started a reptilian domino chain. Peering over their short, spiky heads, he saw Marlenka and Haylee crouched over Audrey, who was unmoving beside the folded tablecloth that had been on the dinner table the previous night.

Marlenka prodded Audrey’s shoulder with one arm and flatly asked her, “You okay, dude?”

Halo shouldered his way through the tide of smaller lizards, causing a couple of them to bounce off the floor and yelp. “Let me through,” he snarled at them, stopping in front of Audrey.

The purple-and-silver lizard twitched and then blinked open her eyes. Her pupils contracted the second she realized she was surrounded by a bunch of other lizards who were staring at her. “What happened?” she said groggily.

“I just didn’t expect you’d fall asleep in the dinner hall, since there’s plenty of open nests you’re welcome to use,” Haylee explained and helped her up. Halo was about to tell Audrey good morning and say that he was glad she was okay, but Haylee stopped him with a stern look. “Halo, please don’t push anyone to get from place to place. We’re all on the same team.”

“Sounds like you need a new name,” one of the hatchlings giggled behind him. Halo shook his head and stomped back to his nest while Haylee scolded them for picking on him. He hated this place and all the lizards in it. Why didn’t the hatchlings’ noble, courageous, phantom-busting parents ever teach them respect?

He curled up in the grass and tucked his nose underneath the drying gold leaves, finding them less and less comfortable every time he shifted. It was hopeless to try and fit in with the Defenders, and more so to believe they had any chance of freeing Loafie even if they wanted to.

A few hours of napping gave Halo a lot of time to clear his head. While he drifted off, he had decided that if he was going to be forced to stay here so that he could stay by Audrey’s side, he would stay here comfortably.

Lizards were chatting and eating together and playing games with pebbles and sticks in the nesting rooms and the dinner hall. Halo had to poke his head into a few tunnels and witness a few questionable acts before finding Haylee re-lighting some of the wall sconces in a darkened corridor.

“Hey,” he said awkwardly, his head bent low.

Haylee regarded him with a look as friendly as if she hadn’t scolded him earlier. “Hi, Halo. What’s up? Do you need help finding something?”

“Uh, I was wondering, could I maybe become a gatherer…? I noticed that the leaves in a few of the nests were kind of… crinkly.”

The pastel lizard sighed. “Yeah. That’s the unfortunate part about autumn; there’s less leaves to replenish the ones that dry up in the nests. But sure, you can go out looking for some, and if you decide you like scavenging for leaves and maybe a few berries along the way, you could choose to become a gatherer! I’ll send Vatra to help you out.”

Halo winced. “Is there no way I could go alone?”

“Well, you probably didn’t get all that good of a look around the place on your way here to the barracks, so she can show you good spots to find trees that haven’t gone orange yet. Are you going out right now?”

He sighed. “I guess.”

“Okay, then I’ll go find her right now!” Haylee took the twig that she’d been using to light the sconces and squashed the flame into the tunnel’s dirt floor. “Let’s go.”

==Chapter Eight - Name - Audrey's POV==
Audrey watched with a pained expression as Halo stormed off back to his nest. “Shoo,” Haylee briskly told the hatchlings, who were still staring after the teal-and-cream lizard like he was made of amethysts. They giggled at one another and scattered, dispersing through the tunnels in jumbled waves.

“Don’t go into the nesting rooms!” Haylee whisper-yelled at them a little too late. “There are lizards who are still sleeping!” She sighed as their tail-tips disappeared behind every corner in sight.

“Halo’s not mean,” Audrey reassured the other two lizards. She felt bad about basically apologizing on his behalf, but she wished he was trying harder to settle in without stirring tempers. “He’s just having a hard time getting used to this environment.”

Haylee nodded. “Oh, I know. He’ll find a way to contribute to the group if he wants to. And if he doesn’t, then we as the Defenders are happy to protect him from phantoms while he stays here; that’s our mission.”

Marlenka coughed and dragged the book out from behind the folded tablecloth where Haylee had left it. “Moody newbies aside, we oughta take a peek at this thing, no?”

The other two nodded. “I had no idea that lizards have had their own powers this whole time,” Audrey said. “We can control the elements according to this thing. And fly if we concentrate the right way, or something like that.”

Haylee winked at her. “Elemental powers are something we’ve been training with for most of the Defenders’ existence. But if this book really can tell us how to gain better control of them or even summon wings, it could be a huge help the next time we come into contact with phantoms!”

“And you’re ''sure'' we didn’t own this thing?” Marlenka raised an eyebrow and pushed ''The Secret Talents of the Lizards'' in front of Audrey and Haylee. “Because I’ve never seen it before this morning, so I sure as hell didn’t stuff it away in any of the storage rooms.”

Haylee shook her head earnestly. “I have no idea how it got there either. We’re the only ones who come down in these bunkers… phantoms are too small to fit, and the night guards would notice if any of them came through. It doesn’t make sense for an enemy to have snuck this book into the storage-”

“Well, enough about how we got it and back to what’s ''inside'' it,” Marlenka snorted. “I mean, if it doesn’t work then it doesn’t work, right? Audrey already opened it. It’s not like there’ll be a bomb inside.”

The book was surprisingly clean for how old it looked, although the edges of its cover were tattered and almost clawed away. Audrey flipped back through it until she found the ''Wings'' section. “In addition to elemental powers, each lizard has the ability to summon a unique pair of wings…” she read aloud. “Summoning the wings takes usually up to five seconds… and they will automatically disappear once the lizard reaches the ground after using their wings to fly. Lizards are best at summoning wings while focusing on thoughts that lift them up or make them happy or proud.”

“Aw, jeez,” Marlenka grunted. “What’s there for ''me'' to think?”

Haylee blinked gratefully at Audrey. “You know, it’s another busy day for me. I’ve gotta check the hall torches to make sure they’re all still lit, see to a couple of concussions, ''and'' keep preparing for the mission tomorrow… but how about you two take some of the others out and see about those wings? Audrey, maybe you could learn a thing or two from them about elemental magic. I wonder what your element is.”

Audrey nodded. “Sure thing. We can do that, right, Marlenka?”

“I don’t know,” Marlenka replied. “''Can'' we?”

To avoid starting a stampede of lizards who wanted wings, Audrey and Marlenka wanted to pick out just a few of them to go outside and test the book’s words with them. Although their first thought was to collect hatchlings to experiment, Toxic overheard what they were saying and asked if he could come along. Audrey asked Big Bird if he was interested, but the solid-yellow lizard just started singing something about butterflies and zebras and circus minds.

Then she saw another purple lizard, who looked to be around her age, sitting all alone, and invited her to come. “Great! We’re going out now,” Audrey told the lizard once she had agreed, then headed back to the dinner hall to meet back up with Marlenka. From the looks of it, Marlenka had recruited one boisterous hatchling and one who looked like he’d simply rather be wrapped up in a fuzzy blanket with a cup of Cosmo’s Famous hot cocoa.
