Marlenka turned to see who Audrey had brought, and her pupils shrank immediately. She pulled Audrey over to the side and whispered urgently, “Why is the purple one coming with us?”

Audrey just blinked in confusion. “I saw her all alone and it looked like she could use something fun to do. What’s the matter?”

The pair of ruby-red eyes glaring at her narrowed. “We can’t ''trust'' her, Audrey. She was born in the phantom fortress. And you remember what I said about a spy in the group?”

''The phantom fortress?'' Behind Marlenka, the purple lizard was waiting by an exit tunnel with the three others who wanted to go outside. Her face had mostly been dominated by a small frown, but when Audrey turned her head she could see what appeared to be Toxic telling her a joke and that serious and sad exterior cracking for just a moment. “How long has she been with the Defenders?”

Marlenka moved her massive shoulder again to block the view. “Two years. But I’ve been here for all three, and she hasn’t gotten any more trustworthy. Believe me.”

Audrey rested her claws lightly on Marlenka’s shoulder and moved it back down. “Then let’s use this as an opportunity to prove that she’s just like the other Defenders. There’s no valid reason we should be wary about trying to help her gain wings.”

She heard Marlenka grumble, “She could deliver her messages to the phantoms faster,” but she let Audrey walk past her and lead the way into the tunnel.

The purple lizard jumped when she saw Marlenka coming up behind her; her claws dug into the ground, her nose twitched rapidly, and she was clearly agitated by the red lizard’s presence. “Hi,” Audrey said to her as she climbed over the dirt floor. “I’m Audrey. What’s your name?”

The question clearly took the purple lizard by surprise, but when she answered there was the tiniest smile on her face. “I’m Bella.”

==Chapter Nine - Wings - Bella’s POV==
Despite Marlenka walking just a few paces behind her, Bella felt more at ease than usual as she climbed through the exit tunnel. Before, Haylee and Millie were the only lizards who had ever asked for her name. She hadn’t expected someone else, much less a newcomer like Audrey, to want her around. ''Maybe it won’t be so bad,'' Bella reasoned silently.

The ring of trees where the tunnel sloped out had been familiar to Bella for over a year. She had been content, in the first many months of being a Defender, with gathering food and leaves for the group, and some time later, with delivering messages from the Defenders to other parts of Jamaa. But then about six months ago, Marlenka had forced her to stop being a messenger or gatherer and relieved her of taking on any job duty whatsoever that involved leaving the barracks, and Bella never found out why.

It was wonderful to get a breath of the chilly natural air. For quite some time now, Bella could only leave the barracks when the Defenders were evacuating their current bunker in a phantom invasion, so to be able to enjoy the fragrance of the nearby plants and fallen leaves in peace was a welcome experience.

“Alright, guys,” Audrey said, setting the book down in the center of the clearing. “You all know how to do your elemental power thingies, right?”

Bella and the other lizards – Toxic, Cakepop, and a small green-and-tan hatchling – nodded. “Air!” Cakepop volunteered her element. Bella nodded to indicate she had the same one, picking up a fallen branch and using her breath to spin it in an infinite circle in the air.

“Marshmallow and I are both fire, right?” Toxic grinned at Marlenka. The red-and-gold lizard just glared at him and puffed a miniscule orange flame out of her mouth, accompanied by a visible cloud of breath, where it dissolved into the morning air.

Audrey stepped closer to the green hatchling. “What about you? Sorry, I haven’t learned your name yet.”

“This is Little Woo,” said Toxic. He patted the small lizard’s head. “He’s my bro!”

“Not literally, though,” Cakepop put in. “Toxic thinks everyone is his bro.”

“Well, yeah, but Panda adopted the three of us together; that’s gotta count for some extra bro points!”

The little hatchling stepped out from the pure-energy cloud occupied by Toxic and Cakepop. “My name is Wooyoung,” he said in a soft voice. He plucked a football-shaped leaf off the ground and held his claws above it like he was sprinkling dust ont0 its surface. Both Audrey and Marlenka appeared to be equally shocked as tiny spheres of water trickled from his palm onto the leaf and sat there, bright as crystals, like natural dew. “I’m… water ''and'' nature.”

It was silent for a few moments, but then Audrey walked up to him and said with a warm and genuine tone, “I think that’s really neat, buddy.”

Marlenka set her jaw. “I didn’t mean there’s something ''wrong'' with it. I think the opposite. It’s just that two elements are really rare… and really powerful.” She stepped closer to the hatchling with the eyes of a bird of prey, the same eyes that made Bella feel as insignificant as a fallen leaf deep in the woods every time they were in the same room, and paired it with a grin. “You’re gonna do some good things for the Defenders, dude.”

“Well, he’s a kid,” Audrey reasoned. Wooyoung smushed his cheek against her shoulder as she went on. “Maybe before he goes phantom-busting with the grown-ups and fights for his life in a battle, Mira forbid, we can start with trying to teach him how to fly?”

The red-and-gold lizard blinked at her with half-closed eyes, then heaved a sigh and opened up the book, leafing through pages until she could find the part about wings. “Think good thoughts,” Marlenka said loudly. “And be proud, and stuff.”

“Great,” said Toxic. He closed his eyes, trying to look peaceful, but Bella could still see his eyeball jelly rolling around in circles as if watching a Ferris wheel spin at warp speed. “I remember when Panda bought me my very own tank, custom-built to make eyes bleed… and when Little Woo got adopted and we went to the beach with him for the first time…”

“I remember that too,” said Wooyoung. He closed his eyes too, rising cautiously up onto his back legs and settling into a tree pose. “Finally getting adopted made me so happy. I miss Crystal Sands.”

Cakepop followed her friends’ lead. “Every time I’ve ever eaten a donut. Apple cider donuts! I would do anything to eat an apple cider donut right now. No joke, I’d even share it.”

“Do you want to try, Bella?” Audrey asked. Bella jumped. She had been so briefly immersed in the other lizards’ memories, imagining she was lucky enough to have a hatchlinghood like theirs.

“Oh, I… don’t really… know what I’d think about.” Bella was reluctant at first, but then she decided she didn’t want to look like she wasn’t trying in front of Audrey, who actually seemed to believe in her. So she closed her eyes and let her mind take her back to the phantom fortress.

''This isn’t a good place to start,'' she thought. But no better options came to her head before she was immersed in the setting. Bella dug through memories of the endless purple halls for anything that had the slightest chance of bringing her joy.

Dragon was the name of the only friend she grew up with. The two of them were hated equally by their parents for not being devious enough or outwardly willing to die for the phantom cause, which brought them together until it almost felt like they were siblings.

She remembered. It was freezing in the phantom fortress one night during the season that jammers called “the Jamaalidays.” Thinking no one was around, Bella stole a phantom banner off of the wall and took it back to Dragon to use as a blanket. While she was delivering it to him, a small clique of lizards caught her and told her parents what she had done.

They were furious. The blaze in their eyes was as glaring as those atop the torches bolted to the brick wall, and she was right in the center of it. Dragon heard all the noise and found her helpless, pinned beneath her parents’ narrowed eyes, and he told them that ''he'' had stolen the banner. The other lizards didn’t argue and say that he lied. As long as someone else was getting tortured for their wrongdoing, they were satisfied.

It was the first time that anyone ever stood up for her. And in the Defenders’ barracks, where every single day of her life was the polar opposite of that, she had never forgotten it.

When she opened her eyes, she was staring at her own shadow far below her, moving and flapping as if it had-

Wings.

==Chapter Ten - Help - Audrey’s POV==
Marlenka shook Audrey’s arm. “You seeing this?”

“They’re flying!” Audrey cried. All four of the lizards in front of her, though they now hovered at different heights, had grown a unique pair of wings and lifted off the ground as they were carried into the wind.

Cakepop had been first to rise, growing a tiny pair of ice-blue angel wings with two similar winglike fans on either side of her tail. “Those must be some really good donuts, Cakepop!” Marlenka shouted up at her. The pink-and-brown lizard just giggled in response and zipped over and under the treetops, whirling around branches and past leaf clusters like her whole life was made for nothing but flight.

Then it had been Toxic, whose wings resembled those of a dragon – black and webbed with yellow-green as neon as the tip of his tail. He twirled about in the breeze slower than his friend, but he still wasn’t afraid to chase her through the thickets. “Hey, Cakepop, wait up!”

“No!” Cakepop laughed, looking back at him. “You’re gonna tackle me-” She was cut off by a low tree branch that clopped her right in the throat. Though she collapsed into the grass in spot-on dead bird fashion, it took only seconds for the bottoms of her claws to be welcomed by nothing but empty space once again.

Wooyoung’s wings were beautiful. They didn’t quite resemble a typical wing shape, but they instead appeared as a blanket of clouds over the hatchling’s shoulders, rays of prismatic light radiating out from them and sparkling in the colors of a rainbow. Audrey couldn’t stop cheering him on as he got used to being in the air and letting the currents in it move him.

Then there was Bella. She seemed so concentrated, so deep in thought, with her claws tearing at the grass and her head pulled close to her shoulder blades – in a minute, though, surely enough, something began to appear on her back.

“I wonder what hers will look like,” Audrey whispered. She heard Marlenka sniff next to her, but in the corner of her eye the red lizard was indeed watching Bella lift off the ground with interest.

She rose up into the sky, the shapes on her back morphing as they flapped…

Audrey’s amethyst eyes widened as she continued to look up. At each of Bella’s sides there was a night-colored wing made of three long, squirming shapes that looked all too much like…

“Are those ''tentacles?''” Marlenka growled. Over her and Audrey’s heads, Bella opened her eyes and smiled wider than any of them had ever seen as she gazed down at her shadow and the grass beneath her.

“Audrey!” she yelped with excitement. “I… I have wings!”

Marlenka forced herself to stop staring and stomped over to ''The Secret Talents of the Lizards.'' “How does it feel to fly?” Audrey called up to her. She tried her hardest to ignore how much the wings resembled phantom appendages. It felt wrong to comment on it in general, much less when Bella was this high in the air and probably couldn’t see what they looked like.

The question made the purple lizard’s face become several shades brighter. “I wasn’t expecting it to feel like this… but Audrey, it feels amazing.” A tawny eagle soared just a pace above her head, and she took off after it as it spiraled back down to the trees.

Audrey went over to Marlenka, who had stopped at a certain point in the book and was reading a piece of it with intense interest. “It says here,” she said darkly, “that the wings’ appearance are determined by two factors: scale or eye color, and inner identity.”

“What does that mean?” Audrey asked. She figured “identity” couldn’t mean species, since only lizards could gain these wings… but what else could it refer to? “That doesn’t-”

“I don’t care about specifics,” Marlenka growled. “This is ''physical'' evidence that, in whatever way, phantoms are involved with her identity. No matter how long she stays here, the enemy is still a part of her.”

Audrey tried to make it all make sense in her head. “But you said she’s been a Defender for ''two'' years. She can’t be aligned with the phantoms still; she’s been fighting for the Defenders’ cause for longer than most, right?”

“Hardly. She’s not allowed to be a gatherer ever since I realized there was a spy situation going on… but I guess she’s still managed to find a way to tell the phantoms where we are somehow. I’ve tried, but I haven’t been able to pinpoint her method.”

No matter what she said, Audrey couldn’t comprehend it any easier. “If you’re so convinced she’s the spy… why is she still here?”

Marlenka checked to make sure the other lizards were still occupied with learning to use their wings. “Because ''Haylee''has to have the final say, and she thinks if we can’t catch her in the act, we can’t get rid of her.” She swiped at a patch of dirt with her claws, revealing a maze of frost tendrils woven into the frozen soil underneath. “So now we constantly have to deal with being vulnerable and never being able to stay in one space for long.”

It took Audrey by surprise when Bella landed near her side, away from Marlenka. The purple lizard’s eyes were wide and filled with horror, and she had shrunken back to the same tense, twitchy version of herself that Audrey had seen before she left her memory.

“Audrey,” Bella whispered. She stared down at her own shadow. “My wings. I- I don’t know what they-”

Audrey felt a thump on her back: Marlenka’s tail. The muscular lizard swore. “Wooyoung! Cakepop! Get back in the barracks, ''right'' now!”

In a bush above where the others were gliding around, a proto-phantom floated up and down, its single eye unblinking as it stared at the armadillo lizards. Audrey jolted when she saw it. It looked just like the one that had stopped Loafie from fleeing the phantom raid. Then what must have been a dozen more rose up from either side of it. Seeing how similar all of the proto-phantoms looked to one another made a chill creep down her spine.

“What’d you say?” shouted Cakepop, who was still doing loops in the wind. A slimy purple web shot out of the earth and reached for her tail, just barely missing her before splatting back in the grass and pushing the green blades into the dirt.

Wooyoung had heard Marlenka’s warning and landed, Toxic at his tail, behind Audrey. “Go back into the bunker and call for a code purple,” Marlenka snarled at her and Toxic. She swore again. “We haven’t even been here a month.”

If she said more, Audrey didn’t hear it. Toxic raced ahead of her with a practiced determination, zooming into the dinner hall as if he still had wings, and Audrey came up behind him as quickly as she could. “CODE PURPLE!” he yelled.

No one in the hall seemed terribly surprised, but they did begin hurrying for their hatchlings and the possessions they could carry. A group of lizards shot forward and escaped through the entrance tunnel – presumably messengers or scouts, since Audrey recognized Kaylee among the mix – as if they had been waiting for this moment.

Haylee was there in no time. “Oh no,” she muttered. “This is the worst time to have to evacuate. It’s so cold out now.” But she didn’t complain for long. She went up to Toxic and told him, “My chart says that there are four lizards out gathering and one messenger is supposed to be heading home from a phantom resistance summit.

“The scouts just left to get the gatherers-” Haylee turned to Audrey. “Halo’s with them, but don’t worry, he’s in good claws with Vatra. They should be a little ways away from here, and the scouts are going to let them know we need to leave. Eira,” she continued, stopping a pale-purple lizard who was walking by, “can you head in the direction of Mt. Shiveer? We’ll be heading for the north Jamaa Township bunker, so go there when you’ve found Misty.” Facing Audrey again, she explained, “We haven’t been to that one in about a year, and both here and there are around the same distance to the spot where we need to raid Mt. Shiveer tomorrow.”

“Do you need me for anything?” Audrey asked once Toxic followed the scouts out of the entrance tunnel. A crowd of lizards were filing out swiftly behind him. Some of their faces looked alarmed, but their claws moved in an understanding and accepting kind of way that hurt Audrey’s heart.

Haylee scribbled something on the whiteboard and shook her head without looking at Audrey. “Make sure you’re calm when you leave just in case of a panic. You’ll be okay.”

The purple-and-silver lizard shifted on her claws. “Are you sure there’s no way I can help out?”

Finally Haylee glanced at her over her shoulder before turning back. “Stay with the hatchlings and make sure they’re calm.” Audrey nodded and poked into the entrances to sleeping caverns to look for hatchlings. Before she left, she heard Haylee murmur through gritted teeth, “We don’t have time to grab the blankets…”

==Chapter Eleven - Friend - Halo’s POV==
It was awkward once Haylee sent Halo and Vatra on their way to gather leaves. The unfamiliar orange lizard smiled at him every now and then when he was glancing her way to take in the local trees’ final moments of golden beauty for the year, but she didn’t seem very talkative.

Halo decided he would be the one to start the conversation. “So… how do you find leaves that don’t go away in the winter?”

“The gatherers go to south Sarepia Forest together in the middle of fall to grab some leaves, since the leaves don’t fall as quickly there and our bunker is usually close enough,” Vatra replied. Her reminiscent expression turned wistful. “We were in the Lost Temple of Zios bunker getting a good bunch of them, and then the next day we had to move out. That’s why we don’t have a stock here.”

“I guess you’ll find their carcasses the next time you go to that bunker,” Halo joked.

Vatra chuckled awkwardly. “Haha, yeah.”

It was silent for the next few minutes. Then Vatra stopped at a clump of bushes. “Boxwood,” she said. “The leaves are small, but the branches are nice to have because the bark makes for good seasoning. And I see some wintercreepers over there that we can grab.”

While she brought some of the wintercreeper tendrils over and stuffed them in a straw sack, Halo got to work picking off the boxwood branches. Side by side, the leaves didn’t look any different from one another, except the wintercreepers were tinged with yellow at the edges.

“You sure know a lot about these,” Halo remarked.

Vatra, who still appeared mildly embarrassed, gave him a toothy smile. “I’ve been a gatherer for as long as I’ve been a Defender. It’s fun bringing back things and seeing what the cooks make with it.”

She dipped her snout into her sack, low enough that the smell of the wintercreepers flooded her nose, which just brushed the yellow-dappled leaves. “If we hurry back… maybe it won’t be too late to bring the boxwood to the cooks so they can use it in a stew for lunch!”

“What does it taste like?” Halo sniffed at the bagged-up wintercreepers, then took a whiff of his boxwood pile. Neither plant’s leaves had a particularly pungent scent, but the faint aroma of evergreens – like one of the scented candles Loafie would burn back in her den – blanketed their surface.

“Like winter on the way.”

Halo’s own pouch, which Loafie had given to him full of fruit and bread that had been emptied out by his nest before the gathering trip, was more than full by the time the lizards planned to head back. “Wow, this thing sure is itchy,” he commented.

That made Vatra laugh in a way that sounded less forced. “Boy, don’t I know it. We shouldn’t be far from the barracks, though. Ten minutes if we walk back on the same path we came.”

Halo slowly turned his head toward her. “How many minutes if we run?”

Crinkled leaves of all the warm colors flashed beneath the two lizards’ claws, rearing up like wave crests in their wake. Halo hadn’t run this fast in… well, ever. His days used to be spent lounging around in his round fluffy bed, wrestling with Audrey in the yard, and following Loafie to trading spots on occasion. He had never felt like he ''could'' run so far, so fast.

Haylee had given Halo and Vatra each a blanket to keep warm before she sent them off to gather, and both lizards had chosen to wear them to keep them within reach – regrettable move, Halo decided as he and Vatra coursed after one another through the winding woods, although there weren’t many alternatives. The white and brown fuzz flapped against their scales as they pushed on, so buffeted by the wind that they looked made of dandelion seeds, like they could just blow away and be gone at any moment.

Halo stopped first. He was too big and pampered to keep up with a lizard who’d been living in the outside world for what he assumed was a while. The roots of a tree with three red leaves just barely clinging to its branches was his place of choice to flop down. Vatra saw him submit to his empty lungs and fell over on her side a few paces away.

“Wow,” she said, almost completely out of breath. “We’re… gonna be in… oxygen debt for… the rest of our lives.” Her eyes widened like something had stabbed her and she sat back in a leaf pile, clutching her hind legs. “Geez! Lactic acid is ''not'' fun.”

Halo kept panting. “I don’t know what that is, but if I could sell it, I bet I’d make enough to afford a white bowtie.”

The orange forest, he thought, made a great place to rest. Every now and then a chilly breeze would float over his and Vatra’s heads and swipe from the trees the leaves that had been hanging on for dear life. Halo pictured taking Audrey with him to this spot so that they could gather some leaves or bush branches or something and weave a hammock between the trees. They would start working at dawn and then, when a day of work was done, lay in it side by side and watch the sun roll down through the arms of the branches.

''She wouldn’t do that anyway,'' Halo thought, glowering at nothing in particular. ''She’s all occupied with her new friends. Why would she ever want to hang out with me when all these intriguing wild lizards are falling into her claws?''

He bet she’d be hanging out with Toxic. ''He thinks he’s so funny. Cannonball into the tunnel… pshh. Find something more impressive to fail at doing.''

Someone appeared around the corner that made both Halo and Vatra jump. Halo thought at first that thinking about Toxic had magically conjured the annoying highlighter-faced lizard into the scene, but who he saw instead was Kaylee, the scout who had said she watched Loafie get captured.

But just as Halo’s brain was starting to pick at all the copious aspects of her personality he so despised, he took notice of the solemn look on her face. She answered his and Vatra’s visible confusion by saying “code purple” in as loud a voice as Halo had ever heard her use, though it wasn’t as if she often spoke within his range of hearing at all.

“Haylee wants you to know we’re going to the north Jamaa Township bunker. They’re giving chase. Rendezvous by the fallen log.” Then she spun back around and darted away through the trees.

“Code purple?” Halo echoed. “Chase? What’s going on, Vatra?”

Vatra bit her lip and pulled her brown blanket over her shoulders. “The phantoms found where we were hiding; that’s what the code purple means. And it sounds like they’re chasing us out, so… there’s probably gonna be a battle. Now we need to leave for Jamaa Township so we can get into ''those'' barracks…”

Halo was silent with shock. “We just… leave?”

“That’s what we have to do when this happens.”

“Where’s this fallen log? Are we splitting up or sticking together? The Defenders, I mean.”

“We’ll all be together, since the phantoms don’t have the mental capacity to split up, so we’d lose the numbers if we go off in groups.” Vatra swished her tail over a patch of fallen leaves to signal he should follow her. “The fallen log isn’t far from here; it’s a spot the gatherers go for moss, so I know the way.”

It didn’t look like any phantoms were coming after them yet. But the back of his eyelids always seemed to be playing the memory of Loafie’s capture, and Halo decided he’d rather be safe than sorry. As soon as Vatra finished speaking, he adjusted his snow-colored blanket, secured the pouch over his shoulder, and followed her deeper into the woods.

==Chapter Twelve - Battle - Audrey’s POV==
At least six hatchlings were sticking close to Audrey as she led the way out of the exit tunnel and into the open woods. Some of the Defenders had already gone ahead and created rows to fend off the phantoms that descended on the group.

“Will we be okay?” one of the hatchlings asked. Audrey recognized him from earlier; he was one of the lizards who had been teasing Halo. “I only joined two weeks ago… I don’t know what happens when we have to move.”

“We will,” Audrey reassured him. “Look up there. See all those phantoms getting busted? Everyone’s working so hard to protect us.”

Cakepop nodded. “They’re super good. Look!” She pointed up ahead, where Toxic hefted a boomseed in one claw, tossed it into the air, and blasted it forward with a burst of his elemental fire, causing it to explode in a row of shocked phantoms’ faces. Audrey winced as one got hit directly in its wide-open eye in the last moment of its life.

While Marlenka directed attacks on the phantoms, Haylee was guiding the others further into the forest. The array of fighting lizards made strategic shifts to keep the rest of the group covered, never letting up with the explosive action. Lizards at the tail end of the mob dug up stores of boomseeds buried under tree roots and tossed them to their comrades while the rest pressed forward.

Audrey had found the Defenders’ elemental powers astounding during the brief training session when they showed off a tiny fraction of their skills, but watching the whole group use them to work together was something else. The orange-and-gold forest was ripped with red and blue and green and all the colors of paint dripping off some of the projectile boomseeds as the Defenders fought back against the shadow-colored monsters invading their home.

The hatchlings kept ducking underneath Audrey’s claws as she tried to walk; it didn’t help that occasional splatters of phantom goop landed a little too close to them as they tried to escape. “Get on my back, Wooyoung,” she told the hatchling, who she guessed was the smallest of those who kept close to her. “Cakepop, you look like you might fit too-”

Out of nowhere, Halo burst through the woods beyond the clearing, swinging his head around wildly until he locked eyes with Audrey. “Halo!” she yelled. “Over here!”

“I’m tired,” one of the hatchlings complained.

“I’m cold,” said another.

“I’m scared!” yelped a third. “I don’t know where my mommy is.”

Audrey let her tail drag over the ground so that Cakepop could scramble up onto her back beside Wooyoung, who quivered as he clung to her purple-and-silver scales. Two small lizards alone were quite a weight for her spine to handle, but as long as they stayed there comfortably, she traversed the crowd without so much as a grumble. “Don’t worry. The phantoms are going to go away really soon, and then we can rest for a long time. How about you take turns on my back?”

“I can carry some of them,” Halo offered. He bent his head back to grab the white blanket on his shoulders between his teeth, then swung back around and flopped it on Audrey’s back. “C’mere, kids. I’ll carry you up. Woof, you’re heavy!”

On Audrey’s back, both Cakepop and Wooyoung rolled underneath the blanket before it even hit her shoulders. The fuzzy material insulated her well from the bite of impending winter that was making several Defenders up ahead shiver as they went by. “Thank you, Halo,” she said with a smile.

Halo blushed. “Uhh, yeah, well, you’re welcome.” Audrey didn’t see him awkwardly grin back before she turned to her side and guided a straying hatchling closer to her with her tail.

A few minutes later, the moving battle still raged as hard as ever. Somewhere in the distance, too far away for Audrey to see, Big Bird showed off his remarkable vocal range while he cheered on Toxic’s boomseed-bomb chucks. In the corner of her eye, Audrey saw Halo, decked out with several new hatchling back accessories, keep changing his walking speed like he was trying to avoid stepping in time with the dissonant screams of the solid-yellow lizard at all costs.

Phantom goop, purple and bubbly and super gross, now littered the path where the Defenders were traveling. Big Bird screeched an electric riff as another flaming boomseed connected with a heavy phantom. “It sure is starting to look like a poison paradise,” Audrey commented when she glanced back at the damage that had been done so far.

Some lengths away, pastel scales moved against the direction of the Defenders’ mob. Audrey watched the shape move side to side trying to get through before giving up, stepping off to the side, and waiting for Audrey to reach the giant leafless oak tree where she stood.

“How’s it going?” Haylee asked her once they had caught up to one another, once again walking with the crowd’s flow. “Is everyone good?”

Audrey turned around to look at the hatchlings. “You all doing okay?”

She was answered by a chorus of squeaks from the mini-mob of lizards that kept between her and Halo. “I’m okay,” one of them said. “Can I have a turn on your back, please?”

Wooyoung slid off Audrey’s back and tumbled onto the ground unhurt. “Oh, thanks, Woo!” Audrey said to him. “Sure, Duke. Come up by my shoulder.”

Haylee seemed amazed by how well the hatchlings were behaving. “Wow, you’re really good with them! And you too, Halo, glad you got back here safely! I hate to ask you another favor, but would you mind taking them closer to the front? There are a few more hatchlings there with their worried parents, and also fewer phantoms.”

“You don’t mind if we pick up the pace a little bit, do you, guys?” Audrey asked the hatchlings. “Haylee wants us up at the front where some of your friends and parents probably are.”

“Sprite!” Cakepop exclaimed. “We need to go find Sprite and Ace!”

As her friends whooped in support, Audrey said, “I think that means they’re cool with it.”

Haylee bobbed her head on her neck. “I’ll let you lead the way. The rest of us have got a raid to finish off.”

==Chapter Thirteen - Mira - Audrey’s POV==
“Aim for the proto-phantoms!” Marlenka shouted at the Defenders. “They’re the ones that move- ''fastest!''” From her arm, which was drawn back nearly as far as her tail’s tip, she slung a boomseed slobbered with red paint at a row of proto-phantoms that had tried to circle around to the front of the group. Several of them morphed into murky purple shapes and then disappeared in the colorful explosion that followed.

Toxic bounded up beside her. “Hey, Margarita! Wanna double your blazepower there?”

The red-and-gold lizard grimaced at him. “Eugh, fine.” She lifted her claws to the air as fire began to swirl around her wrist, and Toxic did the same. “Make sure not to hit any trees, bullseye.”

“Don’t you worry, Mar!” When Toxic opened his claws, a ray of fire shot out of both his and Marlenka’s palms and evaporated the nearest phantoms on contact.

From up in the treetops, a voice like sandpaper screamed down, “Now! Get ‘em!” Half-hidden among the leaves was the shape of a large phantom wearing a helmet that looked to be made of melted and reshaped purple clay. When he lifted his tentacle forward, a rain of dark phantom goop splattered down into the grass and landed in giant puddles.

“Look out ahead!” Haylee cried out with alarm when she saw what was happening. Over by Audrey, Cakepop had stopped moving to admire the downpour as a huge glob of it fell rapidly down towards her face. “Sparkly,” she whispered.

Without thinking to speak, Audrey whirled around on her claws and hauled the smaller lizard forward in the air to keep her scales from burning against the grass. The goop landed on a tree that Cakepop had stood in front of moments ago, smashing into it hard enough that the bark above the roots was left cracked or dented.

“You okay?” Audrey asked her shakily.

Cakepop wailed. “I’m sorry! I just wanted to look at it. It was so glittery… like… glitter…”

Before Audrey could reassure her, Halo’s scream rang out across the flattened blades of green. A higher cry of pain followed right behind his own. “Halo!” she yelped. She saw two dark-purple globs land on a flash of teal and orange, but she couldn’t be sure it was Halo. It was impossible to see where he was in the mass of lizards moving across the ground and tossing their boomseeds and elemental magic into the floating ranks of the phantoms. ''And I can’t leave these hatchlings here, in all this turmoil, just to check if he’s okay. But then who will?''

A huge round phantom burst through the lizard crowd and rolled her way, bristling with tentacles that looked to be the size of baseballs. Before it could get close enough for Audrey to smell its awful reek, a pair of orange beams melted it on the spot. She flinched and watched it jump with surprise as it got hit by the beam, its spherical tentacles rolling in circles down the pile of gray sludge that used to be its body. When it dropped to the ground, Audrey saw Marlenka and Toxic side by side with their claws outstretched. “You good, Purple?” Marlenka asked her. She blew once on her claws and a wave of thin steam hissed off them.

Audrey nodded. But she knew she couldn’t keep up all these close calls for long. The hatchlings needed real protection, not a series of lucky saves. ''Where’s Haylee?'' she wondered, but the pastel lizard was nowhere to be seen. ''Hopefully that just means she’s gotten the group further ahead.''

At last, she came up with an idea. ''There are no phantoms in the trees on'' this ''side of the path…'' “Everyone,” she said, bending her head low so that the younger lizards knew she was talking to them, “I have a plan, but it’s gonna take a lot of effort. I need you all to close your eyes and keep walking, and think happy thoughts. Think about all the things you can’t wait to do when we get to our new home. If everything goes right… then you guys will get wings, and we can fly up to the giant evergreen up there to hide, okay?”

“I can show you how!” Cakepop offered to her friends. She bumped tails with Wooyoung, who was so small it nearly knocked him on his side. “So can Little Woo. C’mon!”

Audrey dropped back behind the hatchlings to ensure they kept moving and didn’t stray away from the group while their eyes were shut. Cakepop was first again to gain her wings, ice-blue and dazzling with iridescence, and Wooyoung got his own half a minute later, followed by a few other hatchlings.

But not everybody was having luck. “It’s not working,” one of them told Audrey, opening his eyes and stomping on in frustration.

“Yeah, I’m too scared,” another one agreed. “I can’t do it.”

For a moment Audrey considered whether she should just persuade them to keep trying, but the phantoms were still holding their own, and she couldn’t risk an accident. “Alright, Cakepop, Wooyoung, lead all the lizards that can fly up to that evergreen, and once you get there, ''hide''. Can you do that?”

Wooyoung nodded again. “Sure, Audrey.” He swept his tail and shot forward with the others behind, his rainbow wings not out of place in the forest scene among the colorful mix of elemental powers being used by the older Defenders.

With the winged hatchlings gone, Audrey was left with three who still struggled to gain them. “Just stay calm and keep your eyes open,” she soothed them. “I’m going to carry you to the tree myself, okay?”

They clustered closer to her legs again, but she didn’t mind. She closed her eyes and tried to think of good times. Trips with Loafie to Crystal Sands every summer. Meeting Halo when Loafie adopted him and brought him home for the first time. Looking at the empty vial – the one that Audrey herself had hatched from – that Loafie kept on display atop the hearth in her den, because she was that proud to be Audrey’s hatcher and forever owner.

Toxic telling her about the snow coming to Sarepia Forest. Getting cheered on as she volunteered for the Mt. Shiveer mission. Watching the others get their wings for the first time.

There was no way to tell when she and Halo would get Loafie back. Audrey bit her lip to battle tears at all the possibilities of horrible conditions Loafie could be living under while captive in the phantoms’ fortress.

But even though her eyes were closed, she saw the Defenders. Blazes rushed past and made the backs of her eyelids glow for a split second. She heard the sounds of water spraying outward and plants pushing through the earth, and felt the wind as it looped around her ears. If anyone could bring back Loafie, it was them.

Something pushed out from behind Audrey’s arms and kept growing. When she opened her eyes, a feathery silver wing rested at each of her sides, immaculate and practically sparkling. There was no time to admire them before she gestured for the hatchlings to clamber onto her back and took off for the evergreen, but while she lifted into the air on birdlike wings she couldn’t help but think of Mira, the goddess of Jamaa. She looked down and gasped so deeply that she struggled to keep her balance for a moment.

Audrey would have been less surprised to see the shimmering blue heron, the Sky Mother, land in the midst of the battle if the world had suddenly gone dark and lightning struck her out of the sky.

==Chapter Fourteen - Scarf - Audrey’s POV==
The indescribable shock at watching Mira’s wings float to the forest floor was only made more heart-smacking when the heron goddess craned her neck up at the evergreen tree and stared directly at Audrey, who couldn’t stop staring at her twinkling blue figure. The lizard decided in her mind that falling out of the tree and landing on her skull would have been a better reaction to Mira’s arrival at the scene of the battle.

Phantoms scattered instantly at Mira’s landing. She hardly glanced at them as they fled in fright, some of the smaller ones spontaneously bursting at the mere sight of her. “Retreat! ''Retreat!''” ordered the helmeted phantom. He didn’t so much as look back once as he led his troops away.

The forest, despite all the lizards standing in it while frozen in a variety of fighting poses, was as still as an empty lake. Nearly a hundred pairs of Defenders’ eyes were locked on the shape of the giant bird. At her side, a golden-brown mask with teal gemstone eyes and an intricate face glimmered into existence from nothing but the air.

“Greetings, Defenders of Jamaa.” Mira’s beak didn’t move when she spoke, but when she turned again to set her eyes on the evergreen tree and arched her long neck, Audrey realized the goddess was gesturing for her to come forward.

Awkwardly, the purple-and-silver lizard hugged the top of the trunk where she had been clinging and shifted her way over the needles until she felt something pulling her off the tree. At first Audrey tried to hang on, but then she saw the hatchlings being lifted into the breeze as well, surrounded by clouds of blue, and she let the magic carry her downwards. When her claws touched down on the ground again and her wings disappeared, she was beside Marlenka and the hatchlings were with their friends or parents.

“Zios and I commend you all for your selflessness and willingness to engage in teamwork as you always have,” Mira continued. Zios just floated next to her. Audrey thought that he looked a little out-of-place there, with his smaller form and unchanging expression, while Mira’s eyes marbled a new color every half a second and were constantly filled with worry.

The heron swept her wings across the grass, and although it passed through them like an apparition’s limb, all of the phantom goop splattered across it rose up off the ground and disappeared. “The already-dire situation that you all work so hard to fight every day has reached a new level of danger. Seven days ago, the alphas were captured and imprisoned in the phantom fortress. Each of them has volunteered to give up their powers until they are free and in a state to fight once again.”

Her opalline eyes rested on a sorrowful blue. “As Zios and I are restricted from any ability to infiltrate the fortress ourselves, since our capabilities to affect the physical world now are limited, all that we can do for the time being is grant their wish. The alphas no longer possess their magic – but they have requested that six new animals take their place.”

Silence still remained. Not a soul had spoken ever since her talons touched down in the woods.

“And so we looked upon none other than the Defenders of Jamaa, protectors of the land on their own volition, and valued members of the community that continue to keep Jamaa safe in its darkest hours.” Mira’s head turned back toward Audrey and Marlenka, who were next to one another. Audrey could’ve sworn that big, tough, scary Marlenka had been leaning toward her and quivering up until she saw the goddess’s eyes on her.

“Marlenka. Long have you not only fought alongside, but ''commanded'' your fellow Defenders with a fierce vigor unmatched by even the bravest of Jamaa’s warriors. And that rings just as true today as it has for the last three years of your life. Your effect on the fighters I stand before is no less than that of the sun on the springtime forest.”

Turning to Audrey, she went on. “And Audrey. You have only recently faced more discomfort and peril than you have in the entire rest of your life combined, and yet you have faced it head-on with the energy of an adventurous mother – one who never wants to stop aiding friends in need or protecting those who cannot protect themselves.”

Mira’s bent neck straightened again and her eyes glowed brighter than before. “We grant to you two the powers and titles of sun alpha and moon alpha respectively. Use them for no more than the time permits, and no less than the defense of the land you love. I trust that you, among four other Defenders who Zios and I have yet to select for the remaining positions, will use them on behalf of the forces of good while you possess them still.”

She lifted her wings and began to rise in the air beside Zios’s floating, unchanged face. “Never give up, loyal Defenders of Jamaa. This fight is far from over yet.” And then her feathers blended back into the daylight, which had fully broken, and both she and her companion were gone.

Audrey looked at Marlenka. The white shape of a sun, which definitely hadn’t been there before, glowed on the red lizard’s forehead. “You got a little… something,” Marlenka muttered, staring intensely between Audrey’s own temples, where a crescent shape had appeared with Mira’s disappearance.

When she looked down at herself, Audrey saw that there was a scarf wrapped around her neck, waving upwards as if it were reaching toward the faded goddess. It resembled the same color as her facial scales, but it was woven with silvery threads like spider silk that twinkled with light when she moved. ''A gift from Mira. I’m… the moon alpha.''

The first thing that Audrey did after receiving her new title was faint.

==Chapter Fifteen - Mission - Dragon’s POV==
All was dark and silent in the prison. Dragon and Skip, on the orders of their boss Julie, threw rotting scraps to the imprisoned alphas and then slammed the doors behind them. Dragon hated the way the chief alpha looked at him like he was a lost puppy. He was a lizard, born in the phantom fortress, and nothing about his hard exterior made him look any less.

He stopped to glance out the tiny arched window as he was proceeding down the stairs and back to the throne room. Tiny as fireflies in the distance, a row of fire drums erupted with flame. A few seconds later, the next row lit up as well.

Skip seemed to have noticed too. The purple-and-gold lizard skittered down the stairs from a higher cell and met back up with Dragon at the window. “Ey, you see all’at??” He pointed out towards the shadowed shapes that marched toward the fortress. “The Gen’ral’s back!”

Before Dragon could take another step, Skip shoved him toward the window and took off down the rest of the stairs. It would have been too small for Dragon to have fit through anyway, but the sight of the ground so far below him still made his head spin briefly. Glaring after the other lizard’s tail, he raced down the spiral after him.

By the time Skip and Dragon reached the bottom of the stairs and entered the high-roofed, sordid throne room – qualifying as that solely because it had a throne, if even a rocky one that seemed to be carved directly from a chunk of a mountain – the phantom army ranks were almost finished filing into it. Its size was noticeably smaller, although it was still led by the same helmeted commander with seven tentacles and an eye that managed to look determined and nervous at the same time.

The shape of the king, which in the lack of light seemed completely melded with the rugged throne, leaned forward ever so slightly. He was well aware of the shrink; Dragon could see it in his huge narrowed eye. But he was waiting for the general to speak first.

“Your majesty,” said the general, bowing so low to the floor that his eye might have been laying flat on it.

There he stayed for any number of moments, face planted in the floor and uneven number of arms splayed out in a display of respect for his king. Then the king spoke, with a voice so deep yet so even that Dragon found it astounding he sat on such a craggy surface all day: “''Explain'', Lido''.''”

General Lido plucked himself up off the floor and adjusted his helmet. “Yes, my king. We found the sniveling lizards in the middle of Sarepia Forest, and they seemed to flee for northeastern Jamaa Township. The capture of their leader was unsuccessful, however we have surely managed to deplete much of their… weapon storage, and now they’re not able to replenish it, for we have behind bars the alphas who supplied them with such materials.”

The king didn’t blink. “Surely.”

“Surely,” General Lido repeated. Then his eye widened as he realized his mistake.

“Did you complete ''no'' objectives that were given to you?” The king scraped one tentacle up the arm of his throne. “This was not a weapons depletion mission. And whatever you would like to believe you ''surely'' might have depleted…”

His gaze stopped wandering across the army that stood before him and fixed, with the intensity of a knife whose blade was level as the tone of his voice, on the general. “Have they not depleted your army beyond the accomplishment of your own ends?”

The general stayed silent for a short while. Dragon winced at what he was watching. Keeping quiet was the worst choice Lido could have made… but then the phantom seemed to reach the same conclusion and spoke again.

“It was the heron, your majesty,” he continued. “She descended from the sky and turned half our forces to mush just by looking at her-”

“Oh, no, Lido. This army is ''yours.'' I did not raise them day and night for months to be so weak as to evaporate at the sight of a bird.”

General Lido looked away in embarrassment. ''How did he ever get a rank in the phantom army at all?'' Dragon wondered. “Majesty, this is the first time any of us have ever seen her in our lives,” the general went on. He turned his head toward the phantoms who floated in rows behind him like he was looking for confirmation. Not one of them said a word.

“This is a disappointment beyond all past disappointments,” growled the king. “Have you truly accomplished nothing in terms of prisoners or other goals that were asked of you?”

General Lido looked like he wished he’d just spontaneously busted at the sight of Mira hours ago. “Well, your majesty… some of the phantoms you see before you had been experimenting with a special type of goop before leaving for the quest. We had taken a prototype along with us to test it on the pathetic lizards.” He swiveled to face his army again. “What were the successes?”

It took a few beats for one heavy phantom to reluctantly reply. “We counted three confirmed hits,” it said. “Now we just need to return to the labs and check whether it… I mean, how well it’s working.”

“Oh, yes. I remember you mentioning something about a little project for the lizards. What was the purpose of this research again?” asked the phantom king.

“We think that any lizards hit by it will slowly succumb to such a state that we’re able to control their minds at any time and see into their surroundings.” The general frowned. “Not to be impertinent, my king, but we would be able to be more certain that the goop works if you had allowed us to test it on the spy who lives among the Defenders.”

The king raised his tentacle. “You may not use our spy for any assessment reasons whatsoever. She offered her services to us of her own free will, and I refuse to let your ill-tested experiments affect that if it should go awry. It was because of ''her'' information that you were able to go on your mission at all… so another disservice to her is not necessary.”

“Of course, sir; we have no need for her in that way anymore. Now that we’ve landed the goop on at least a few of the lizards, we will be able to monitor how well their minds let us in over the next few weeks.”

Although the king had no mouth, Dragon could swear he smiled at these words. “Yes, indeed you will. Evidently you are not structured for the battlefield, so I encourage you to find your true use in the labs and ensure that your prototype works.”

General Lido twitched with shock. “Your majesty? The labs? But- but I’ve led the last four raids on the lizards’ camps. Who else can be- can be trusted with the duty to continue hunting them down?”

“Why, Julie seems very eager to prove her skills. Don’t you, Julie?”

A purple phantom emerged from the shadows on the wall. Dragon kept himself from flinching; he hadn’t even known she was there. She stood out among the ranks of the army for being lighter in color than almost all of them – instead of being white with a black pupil like the others, Julie’s eye was a dazzling light purple. All of the phantoms’ stares were fixed on her as she smirked and floated up to the side of the king’s throne.

“You called, your majesty.” She said it like a statement, looking at him through a half-closed eye.

The king’s eye remained fixed on General Lido. “I understand that you have worked very hard training your students.”

“Very true.” She blinked her single eye at Lido in such a way that it looked like she was winking. He narrowed his eye at her with annoyance, but then remembered that the king was watching him and quit looking her way. “They’re the hardest-working young phantoms in the fortress. Some would even say their skills outdo those of some of our ''army'' fighters.”

Dragon watched Lido as his tentacles quivered with silent rage. Julie hated him more than anything, especially because he was the king’s right hand (tentacle?) instead of her. She saw him as completely useless and never missed an opportunity to stomp on his failings in front of the king.

Personally, Dragon found it difficult to spit on his name that hard, since he just seemed to be trying his hardest and acting with the phantoms’ best interests at heart, and Julie making him constantly compete for the king’s praise and attention couldn’t have made any of that easier. But he would never say that to her. The last thing he wanted was to be on the wrong side of her aspirations to supplant Lido and exterminate his supporters.

“I’d be no less than honored to capture the lizards’ leader and any other sorry reptiles who stumble into my path.” Julie signaled toward the wall she had emerged from, and Skip, followed by Dragon, scampered up to her. “All I need beside me are my trusty scalebound wingmen.”

The king’s pupil moved in her direction. “It would be a very impressive feat if the three of you alone could bring the lizard leader back here. You would earn no small reward for serving the phantom cause in such a way, and I am willing to guarantee you a major role in her torture. But if you fail as Lido did…”

Julie gave him a dark grin. “Oh, you don’t even need to worry about that.” She patted Skip and Dragon’s heads once with her tentacle. “I can’t wait to surprise you at how much easier it is for ''lizards'' to make a more effective accompaniment than an entire army.” She cast a wicked smile in the direction of the glaring Lido. “You won’t see us return until I’ve got the leader’s neck in my grasp.”

==Chapter Sixteen - Awake - Audrey’s POV==
When Audrey came to her senses and the darkness cleared from her eyes she was wrapped up like a baby in the white blanket that Halo had been wearing. Halo himself was there too, a short distance away, alongside Marlenka – who still had, although it wasn’t glowing, the white sun mark on her forehead. ''So I'' didn’t ''imagine all that.''

“Wakey wakey, chocolate shakey.” Marlenka walked up to her and prodded her shoulder. “Woo, it’s been like three days of walking and stopping and walking and stopping and urghhhh. Now that you’re not on the verge of death, someone else could probably use that blanket. Did you know we only were able to bring like seven of them for almost a hundred lizards?”

Audrey rolled out of the blanket and instantly winced at how hard the temperature bit down on her scales. There were much fewer trees now to shield anyone from the cold, and not very far was a stretch of buildings followed by arctic land that seemed to be the northern edge of Jamaa Township. It looked like the others were having plenty of their own trouble, too; not too far away they had formed a few reptilian cuddle piles as they tried to keep shelter under the leafless trees.

“Here you go,” said Audrey, handing over the blanket, unable to hide the chattering of her teeth. She rubbed the spot on her forehead where her moon-shaped alpha mark had appeared, but it didn’t even feel like anything was there. “Geez, how’d I even get here?”

Marlenka took it from her and tossed it to Halo, who then gave it to one of the huddling lizards. “I mean, you passed out, so ''obviously-''” she clicked and curled her tail over her back. “-someone had to carry you there. Like a big strong donkey, I was.”

The other lizard just blinked at her. “Big strong donkey.”

“Yeah, you get it. We’ll probably only be allowed to take one blanket for the Mt. Shiveer mission next week because there’s not many of us going, which will suck, so maybe you can repay the favor and give me a little piggyback action, huh, huh?”

“Oh, shoot, the mission.” Audrey stretched out and surveyed the land around her. The shapes of buildings were faintly visible in the distance; she guessed that Haylee had had them break the journey to the Jamaa Township bunker into two parts. She was just glad it wasn’t more. ''Once we’re on the move again I’ll probably warm up a bit,'' she figured.

Halo came back and sniffed her head. “You okay? Your… thingy’s still there.”

“Oh, good,” Marlenka put in. She gathered her weight and began walking over toward Haylee, who was across the way. “I was afraid it fell off while I made my daring escapade.”

It felt no different for Audrey now that she had the mark on her forehead. ''Should it feel different?'' she wondered. If Mira had really transferred the moon alpha power to her… what was it supposed to mean? Was there supposed to be magic coursing through her bloodstream or something? Would the moon explode if she ever whipped out a primal battle yell?

But something disturbed her even more than not knowing what she was supposed to do, now that she maybe had extra abilities that she still wasn’t aware of. Back in the Sarepia Forest bunker, all the way down in the storage room, she had flipped through ''Secret Talents of the Lizards'' and recalled finding a table in the chapter about magic types. Up until now, Liza had been the moon alpha.

Liza, the ''chief'' of the alphas.

“Do you need me to get you anything?” Halo asked. “You look a little feverish.”

Audrey felt her own head, but it wasn’t warm. It was freezing, actually. She drew back her claws almost the second they made contact with her face. “I’m good. But… thank you. Could you do me one favor, though?”

“Uh, yeah, anything,” Halo replied, his cheeks a little rosy.

“Could you ask Haylee if she could get her book? Make sure she’s not busy, though. I still feel a little dizzy when I try to walk, so I’ll be sitting by that tree for a while. It looks pretty sheltered.” She knew that Marlenka took the book with her when the Defenders left the barracks, since it had already been outside when the lizards trained, but she also knew Marlenka had had a lot of commanding to do in the moments that followed, and Haylee didn’t have it when she checked in on Audrey and the hatchlings, so the book could have been passed off to anyone.

Halo tilted his head at her. “What book? They had books in there?”

''Whoops.'' Audrey hadn’t even thought about Halo questioning the book. She still didn’t know whether she was supposed to even mention it yet to anyone except the lizards who had already gotten their wings. “Haylee will know what to do if you ask her, don’t worry.”

Her response made Halo’s red x-eyes squint a little bit with hurt. “Is it a secret or something?”

Audrey rested her claws over his own. “Not really, Halo, it’s just something we were trying to look over together. In fact, I bet you’ll get to see it really soon. I’ll ask Haylee, okay?”

Still looking dejected, Halo lowered his head and slunk off toward the trees. “Yeah, okay. ‘Really soon.’” Audrey winced at her own poor forethought and reaction to Halo’s confusion. ''There’s no reason he shouldn’t know, especially since a battle just happened… but I really need to check with Haylee first. She probably still thinks I’m asleep.''

She stumbled past the huddling Defenders until she found Haylee talking with Toxic, saying something about wings. She waited from a distance until they had finished their conversation, after which Toxic noticed her. “Hey, Audrey! Are you good? You kept waking up for two seconds and, like, blinking super fast, and then you’d conk right back out. Ever since the battle.”

“I mean, I ''feel'' fine,” Audrey said. “Thanks. Is that Jamaa Township up there?”

“Yup!” Haylee grinned at her. “Glad to hear you’re doing well, Audrey. It’s been a few days of getting here since you’ve been out, but we’ll be able to reach the new bunker by the afternoon. Obviously we’ve had to rearrange some things with the Mt. Shiveer mission… Marlenka and I agreed on having it go out a week from now, since we weren’t sure when you were going to wake up, but it was clear you were still fighting to.

“Also, the scouts didn’t think the ice prisons had anyone in them yet, so there’s no urgency in the sense that we had to head over the second you woke up. We figured that it’d be best to spend the time, if you were awake, teaching the others how to get wings and setting things up in our new home.” Haylee’s excited look faded. “We’ve been lucky in the sense that we’ve never had to move in the last two months of the year before, when it’s extra chilly out. There wasn’t enough time to prepare ''and'' there’s barely enough blankets and supplies for everyone.”

Audrey tried to remember having dreams or struggles about breaking free from whatever prolonged sleep she had been in that Marlenka apparently hadn’t. There was nothing – the last thing in her mental timeline that came before waking up was being given the scarf by Mira. Subconsciously she touched it with her claws. It had a texture like tinsel, and the silvery fabric seemed just as thin, but at the same time wherever it was wrapped around her felt as warm as if the scarf were made of faux fur.

“Okay, I’ll be good. I just came over here to check in, and also ask about the book. What are you planning on doing with it? Will you officially be training ''all'' the other Defenders to get their wings?”

Haylee nodded. “That’s one of the first things we plan to do when we stop at the bunker and unload our stuff. Toxic left the book with Raimu, since he saw it being tossed around during the move and wanted to take a closer look at it. It’s safe with him, don’t worry.”

“I can’t wait to see what everyone’s wings are going to look like!” exclaimed Toxic. “I’ve been ''dying'' to use mine again. We’re supposed to be covert about it for now so that we don’t start a stampede, but the land here is just so open. Perfect for catching some breeze.”

“Me too!” Audrey agreed, grinning. She looked over to see if she could spot Halo amidst all the other Defenders piled on top of each other, but he wasn’t in plain sight. ''I wish I didn’t scramble like that. Now it really looks like I’m keeping a secret from him.''

Despite the temperature, hatchlings and adult lizards alike rolled around on the ground and chatted with one another as if they were living perfectly normal lives, not threatened by phantoms for an instant. ''It won’t be long, though. In just a little while I’ll get to show him how it’s done, and then we can all watch him fly.''

==Chapter Seventeen - Blank - Halo’s POV==
Head beneath his shoulders, Halo skulked off toward the trees until he was sure he was out of Audrey’s eyesight. Then, feeling safe enough that he wouldn’t embarrass himself, he stopped. ''That was stupid,'' he scolded himself. ''Why did I just leave? Where did I think I was going?''

He glanced over his shoulder and, not seeing Audrey, turned back around to return to the Defenders’ general area. However, someone ''had'' been watching him. Halo reared back in surprise when bright orange scales entered his vision out of nowhere.

“Hey, where’d you come from?” Vatra asked him. She looked down at his empty claws. “You bring anything back?”

“No,” Halo muttered, but he knew he had no real reason to be grumpy with her when his problem was with Audrey. What was so special about this random book that her cool new De-friend-ers only wanted to share with ''her?''

Vatra tilted her head, and Halo went on. “Sorry. I’m just not really in a good mood. I guess I was… going for a walk, or something.”

“I can come with you. Uh, if you want, that is,” Vatra offered.

Halo didn’t feel like turning it down. Having someone else around would probably keep him from sulking too much, he reasoned. “Okay, let’s go.”

“Haylee!” Vatra called back. “Halo and I are going on a walk, okay?”

The orange lizard turned back around once she received acknowledgement from Haylee and let Halo lead the way through the forest. Just like their first trip together to gather leaves, it was pretty silent at the beginning except for the crunching of pebbles and twigs on the ground as they went. Vatra appeared to be deep in thought, but then she surprised him with a question. “Is this the furthest you’ve ever been from home?”

Halo tried to think of the places he had been outside Loafie’s den in Sarepia Forest. “Well… I’ve visited Crystal Sands a bunch. I don’t know how much further that is, though. My owner used to take us every year when it was warmest out,” he added.

“Who’s us?”

“Oh. Me and Audrey.”

Vatra put on a look like she was running algebraic calculations in her head. ''That’s basically her resting face, though,'' Halo thought. “Oh, yeah. I haven’t seen a lot of her since the battle. She seems cool, though. I mean, she must be if Mira was willing to give her alpha powers.”

She shook her head, impressed. “Only one other lizard besides Audrey and Marlenka has ''ever'' been an alpha, and that was Baylee. The one who guides and protects the lizards in fairytales.”

Halo frowned. He ran through a list of subjects he could change their conversation to in his head, but a bright green shape to Vatra’s right caught his eye. Warily, he blocked the way with his teal-and-cream tail. “Wait. What’s that?”

She squinted at what he saw, then brightened. “Don’t worry. It’s just Raimu.” Halo reluctantly followed her as she went to say hello to the other lizard. He was tempted to ask what he was doing so far from the other Defenders, just lying there, but then he saw the open book at the lizard’s claws. ''Is that'' ‘the’ ''book?''

Raimu’s green facial scales sparkled like an emerald, but the rest of him had a more rugged and weathered look. An orange baseball cap, turned backwards, dangled from one ear, while around his neck a red bowtie rested, covered in one or two dirt stains that looked considerably old. He didn’t seem shocked at all when Halo and Vatra came up to him, just blinking at the two of them with friendly eyes.

“Hi,” said Raimu. “Do you need anything?” Halo glanced down at the book. It was currently flipped open to a chapter titled ''Alpha Influence On Lizard Magic''.

“Just wanted to say hi.”

Raimu noticed Halo trying to read the book upside down. “It’s about how the elemental powers we lizards have get affected by alpha magic.”

The teal lizard winced. ''Geez, can I stop embarrassing myself?'' “Sorry. I was just curious.”

“It’s no problem. Haylee figured that this kind of knowledge would be relevant to the current happenings, so I’m studying it.” Raimu’s eyes became thoughtful. “Although… I’ve had to go back and read it a few times. I ''know'' I read and understood this same chapter two days ago… but I can only remember small bits of it. Like my memory keeps blanking out.”

In the corner of Halo’s eye, Vatra flinched. He felt a strange feeling at the other lizard’s words as well. ''Memory… blanking out.'' Yesterday Halo was so confused. He tried to think of what had first caused the Defenders to leave before the battle with the phantoms, but when he tried to find the answer, there was just nothing. His memories of the Defenders seemed to be divided into just two parts: ''before'' following Kaylee and Vatra to the battle, and ''after'' Mira’s visit. Everything else was blurry and white when he attempted to conjure it up in his brain.

“Me too,” Vatra began slowly. “It’s weird. I remember looking for leaves with Halo, but not anything else from that morning, or how long I was out there… There was something else, too, but I forgot. None of this happened before the battle.”

“Did you hit your head on something while you were fleeing?” asked Raimu.

Both Halo and Vatra shook their heads. “Yeah, I was lucky not to get hurt, but some of that weird phantom goop ''did'' land on us,” replied Halo. “It didn’t hurt, though. I just brushed it right off.”

Raimu’s eyes were filled with concern. “I was hit too. On the nose, literally.”

He closed the book’s front cover with a ''clap'' that spat millions of dusty particles into the sky, then hefted it onto his back. “I oughta tell Haylee that something might be going on. Maybe we can ask her whether any other lizards have been hit as well.”

“No,” Halo blurted. The other lizard stopped so suddenly that the heavy book nearly slid off his back. “Well… isn’t everything so frazzled right now? What’s the point of worrying Haylee when she’s been so busy organizing the gatherers and all that? It’s only been a few days, and at least for me, there’ve only been one or two… fuzzy patches… in my memory.”

When he said it, Halo expected to get shot down immediately by one of the Defenders – or both of them – asking him why he would hide things from Haylee like that. But they didn’t. Vatra nodded slowly and gave him a small smile of agreement while Raimu’s shoulders relaxed. “It’s kind of you to be thinking of her,” remarked Raimu. “I suppose it should be fine for now if we don’t rile anyone up. But let’s try and check in with one another if those blank-outs keep happening, ‘kay?”

The lizards needed to say no more; with that agreement, they were ready to return to the Defenders. Halo had planned on just taking a nap when he got back, but when they were about halfway there, Raimu stopped and asked him and Vatra: “Haylee was planning to use this book to teach us something once I brought it back. You guys wanna be the first to see what she’s got in store?”

==Chapter Eighteen - Inside - Bella’s POV==
Haylee had gathered a meeting of all the Defenders on a hill where the new bunker’s entrance was within sight. At the top of the grassy mount she stood beside Audrey, Marlenka, and Wooyoung, who were all staring down at the same ragged book.

Bella sat down with Millie near the front. “I wonder what’s going on?” said the gray lizard. “It’s been a good long while since Haylee called all of us together for a reason other than fleeing…”

“Beats me,” Bella shrugged. “I think I’ve only been to one of these before… looks like it might be about that book up there.”

Her friend squinted at it. “Oh, it’s hard to read the spine from a distance…”

“Alright, everyone,” said Haylee at last. “Some of you have been staring at this big ol’ book for a good while, but now it’s time to finally get to what’s inside. The night before we had to leave, Audrey-” She lightly bumped tails with the purple lizard beside her. “-found it in our storage room. We don’t know how it got there yet; did it belong to any of you?”

No one responded. Lizards glanced around, but all they saw were shrugs and head shakes. Haylee looked slightly puzzled that no one claimed the book, but it didn’t stop her from going on. “Okay. Well, this book is called ''Secret Talents of the Lizards.'' Most of you probably already know how to use your elemental powers. But there’s something else this book teaches how to do.”

Audrey whispered something to Wooyoung, who was quivering violently beside her. The little hatchling stopped shaking as much, smiled, and closed his eyes. When Bella blinked again, rainbows radiated from Wooyoung’s back and he was zipping around in the air as freely as a hummingbird in the air.

“Oh my!” Millie exclaimed. “Look at him go! He’s so fast up there.”

Most everyone who was watching was audibly shocked. Some of the Defenders just watched in awe while others cheered and whisted for Wooyoung until he landed again in front of Audrey’s claws. He glanced up at her with a gaping grin and she bumped noses with him joyously while the others chanted for him.

“Wings,” Haylee continued, unable to hide her excitement on her face. “All of you are gonna learn how to get some.”

From there, work was nearly nonstop. Half of the Defenders, led by Haylee, worked on moving the things they’d brought from Sarepia Forest into the new bunker while also exploring the things that had been left behind last. Although there were only a few more blankets to find in these barracks, the lizards were happy to discover plentiful boomseed stores waiting for them in one of the underground corridors.

While that portion of the group was busy, the others trained with Marlenka and Audrey to gain their wings, focusing on ramping up the speed of the summoning process and playing games to see who could get them the fastest and fly the highest. Then they rotated the next day, over and over, until a week had passed.

Everyone was gaining progress more quickly than expected. Skill with the wings proved to have no age restrictions – Millie was learning as fast as Wooyoung and the other hatchlings had, and she was among the quickest to summon her wings. Bella wondered what fond memories her friend was looking back on while she tried to gain them.

Bella still struggled herself. Her fastest time was half a minute, and now that her first flight back in Sarepia Forest had passed, she could barely reach the same heights. Once again she fell into the gray space in her mind where she couldn’t be truly happy for anyone else because of her own difficulties.

''And my wings,'' she kept thinking. ''My wings look just like phantom tentacles. Everybody sees it, and everybody knows it.''

Millie was no stranger to when she was in that sort of place. “You’re hardly ever training anymore,” she said with concern. Bella had volunteered to help clean and prepare the new bunker all day for the last two days, exempting herself from the rotation where she would get to practice with her wings. “Do you want to talk about it?”

“Um…” Bella hesitated. “There’s not much to tell. I just don’t feel into it right now. No use training when it requires positive energy and all, right?”

Millie sat down next to her. “Well, let me know if I can do anything to help. Haylee’s been appreciating all your work with the nests, I bet you.”

“Yeah, she talked to me earlier,” sighed Bella. “I wonder if I should’ve waited, though. I mean, most of the setting up is probably done now that it’s been days, but Haylee ''and'' Audrey are leaving for her mission tomorrow morning and I’ll… almost be all alone. And then Marlenka will be back soon enough, and she’ll want me to keep training regardless of what I want to do.”

Just a couple of the Defenders knew about Bella’s issues with Marlenka. Bella suspected that Haylee and Audrey were aware by observation, but Millie was the only one she felt she could talk about it with. Haylee was too convinced, in Bella’s opinion, that she could change Marlenka’s mind about her. She was lucky to have someone like Millie to be able to vent to without unrealistic reassurances thrown in.

“Maybe Audrey will be willing to spend some one-on-one time helping you with your wings when she’s back,” suggested Millie.

That idea didn’t work for Bella, though. “She works too hard. It wouldn’t be right to take a good teacher away from everyone else just because ''I'' can’t do it.”

Millie let her claws rest on the younger lizard’s shoulder. “You ''can'' fly,” she said. “You’re just trying to do it with a roof above your head.”

The sun went down and Bella still lay outside with her friend, watching the Defenders march into the bunker until she was sure every one of them was tucked away into the fresh-made nests.

==Chapter Nineteen - Ice - Audrey’s POV==
The Defenders who were going on the mission the next morning were wished well by a sizable crowd of lizards who Audrey was surprised to find already awake. The journey to Mt. Shiveer would take almost the whole day, hence why the party planned to leave so early, but she didn’t doubt that they’d accomplish the objective they had set out to, and all in good time.

“Be safe,” Bella told Haylee and Audrey shyly. Her friend Millie, an older gray and pastel-green lizard, brought them a fuzzy blanket on her back. Audrey recognized it as the blanket Halo had been wearing, and as soon as she did, Halo himself appeared among the mass.

“Bye,” he said, his cheeks still a little pink.

Another lizard saw Halo talking and came up to his side. “Goodbye and good luck, Haylee! And Audrey too,” she said.

“See you, Vatra,” Haylee replied. “Thanks for the blanket, you guys. Don’t forget to keep warm.”

Vatra scoffed. “We’ll try to keep that in mind.”

“I know I’m coming with you, but I feel the need to say it. Don’t die, Purple,” Marlenka advised Audrey earnestly from her other side. “Mira would probably find it really inconvenient to have to pick a new moon alpha for the second time in a week.”

“Yeah, I’ll do my best.” Audrey chuckled.

Big Bird scrambled over to Haylee, tossing up leaves with his claws as he went, as if he had a wildly important message to deliver before she went on her way. When he finally reached her, gasping for air, he started singing. “Na na na na… na na na na… hey hey hey… good-”

No sooner could he finish his line before Banana, his bright-yellow acquaintance, caught up to him and gave him a smack to remember.

A few hours after the group of seven set off for the mountains, a solid layer of snow began to appear under their claws. “Is it like this all year?” asked Cakepop.

“I believe so,” Raimu answered her. “At least, based on the almanacs I’ve read, it’s always cold enough in Mt. Shiveer to maintain a year-round temperature that lets the snow sit.”

Cakepop bent her head and licked it. “Yuck,” she muttered. “I thought it would be like powdered sugar… but yikes, it ''tastes'' as wet as it feels.”

Audrey walked with Haylee, who had given the blanket to Cakepop and Toxic to share behind them, in the front of the group while Marlenka kept watch from the back. They were clustered together, mostly for security, but also for warmth; the closer they got to the mountains, the more powerful the breeze, which meant even more snow in the air.

“The rumors are that the phantoms are running out of prison space,” Haylee was telling her grimly. “Apparently, they lost a lot of it because they’re trying to keep the alphas separated and as powerless as possible.”

She fixed a determined smile on the whiteness ahead of her. “I bet they don’t know a thing about the alphas not having their power anymore. They should have no clue that their plan to keep alpha magic out of this war was far from successful.”

“Are they doing anything about it?” asked Audrey.

Haylee went on. “The rumors also say that they’re ''making'' more prisons in the lands of Jamaa, so that they don’t have to carry the jammers they trap all the way back to the phantom fortress every time and also to conserve the room that’s left. So we think based on scout news that there are ice cells being set up near the mountains. Just the building part for now; no prisoners yet, although we can expect to meet some enemies while we’re there.”

Once again Audrey became curious of her own alpha powers. What would they be able to do to destroy the ice prisons? Would she just know what to do when the time came?

Another gust of wind zoomed over the group. Toxic audibly shuddered; Cakepop was clinging to his back, the white blanket draped over both of them, but still the cold managed to ridge itself between their scales. Also in that row were Eira, who had been mostly silent for the duration of the trip, and Raimu, on whose shoulder she now leaned.

Haylee shivered as well. Audrey was surprised the pink-and-blue lizard’s teeth weren’t chattering already. She looked down at the iridescent scarf around her own neck. “Do you want to wear this?” Audrey offered, watching the fringed ends of the scarf as they fluttered past her face.

“Oh, no, no,” Haylee said. She tucked her tail around her back leg. “If I were you, I wouldn’t take off a gift from Mira like that, just in case. We don’t want the fabric of the world to come undone or anything.”

“You and Audrey can take a turn with this blanket, Haylee,” suggested Toxic from where he trotted at her tail. Faintly, Audrey could hear Cakepop squeak in protest.

“Or we can cuddle,” Marlenka added flatly.

Haylee shook her head gratefully. “Ah, thanks, you guys. But we won’t be here for too long. See how we’ve traveled a lot farther since we haven’t taken rest stops?”

“I hate traveling in a huge group for that exact reason,” spat Cakepop. “Sure, the Defenders are great for protection… but wow, they oughta work on their speed.”

Toxic snickered. “Where have you been going that ''wasn’t'' in a ‘huge group’ recently, Popcorn?”

“You gotta stop with the nicknames,” Marlenka said.

“I’m kind of amazed how quickly you come up with them, though,” remarked Audrey.

The red-and-gold lizard stared at her with such mock shock that it looked like the white sun mark on her head was glowing. “Wow. Okay then, I rescind my cuddle offer.”
