“I thought I was the one being given that offer,” Haylee put in.

“Nuh-uh. You’re letting all this slide.”

“Springs,” Raimu blurted out of nowhere.

The seven-lizard party stopped in the snow. If Audrey squinted, she could see a pool of teal and blue water swirling together, surrounded by rock formations that puffed steam as surely as chimneys… and beside them, a pale cylinder with bars of ice.

==Chapter Twenty - Hunt - Dragon’s POV==
“It’s cold,” Skip whined.

Julie ignored him. Dragon didn’t usually agree with Skip, and he never felt obligated to because the other lizard was always shoving him around… but he couldn’t help but feel a little bit of resentment that Julie didn’t care about keeping either of them warm at all.

''What can I expect, I guess,'' Dragon told himself. But it still made the snow under his claws feel a little colder watching Julie simply float above it as phantoms could do.

Already the mountains were coming into view amid the blizzard-like sheen over the land up ahead. Worker phantoms had reported to the king that two lizards were seen near an area where ice prisons were being built – presumably Defenders, since they weren’t with owners – and so Julie and her two lizards were sent to hunt them down.

Dragon had nothing to keep himself warm, so he just let his fuzzy brain guide four numb legs over the snow layer. At one point, Skip was so fed up with the temperature that he jumped onto one of Julie’s tentacles and clung there, but the purple phantom just shook him off into a snowbank in the distance. He came scrambling back moments later and never tried that again.

“How are we going to know where to look for them?” asked Dragon.

Julie glared at him. “Why don’t you keep your jaws shut before they freeze together,” she snapped at him, but then she proceeded to answer his question anyway. “They’re not going to go all the way in here because they wouldn’t realistically be prepared enough for the temperature. But they went west, or so the idiot scouts were saying, so they’re either in Jamaa Township or Appondale.”

She quit her calculating monologue and half closed her eye at her lizard sidekicks. “How well do you think a hundred lizards are gonna be able to hide themselves in a place with barely any cover?”

“No one ‘kin hide from ''us'', Miss Julie!” Skip grinned.

A small number of phantoms were milling around the area once Julie, Dragon, and Skip reached the springs. A few ice prisons had successfully been set up, although their proportions were strange and they didn’t look exceptionally sturdy.

''I knew phantoms were never too great at construction, considering the fortress was mostly built by forced labor of their prisoners… but this lot might get yelled at.'' Dragon bit his lip, bracing himself as he saw Julie float faster toward the other phantoms.

“Get outta here,” she ordered them. “We don’t need you getting in the way. Tell the phantom king we’re on the lizards’ trail.”

Without question, they abandoned their work – or wandering – and sped off in the direction of the phantom fortress. “I really hope they’re here,” Dragon said nervously, referring to the Defenders.

“They are.” Julie exhaled. “I can smell them.”

A group of moving dots of color froze in the distance. The rocky formations by the nearest blue-and-teal pool whistled as more steam shot through them.

“Do they see us?” Dragon whispered.

Skip’s head appeared in the corner of his eye. “They see their demise,” he growled.

Without turning toward either of them, Julie quickly extended a tentacle in their direction as if she were about to splat some good old-fashioned goop on their face. It was a common gesture among the phantoms that translated most simply to ''shut up or I’ll shut'' you ''up.''

The shapes in the distance began moving again. “You know what to do,” Julie muttered at her two lizards. And they did.

==Chapter Twenty-One - Fire - Audrey’s POV==
“Well, they’re really here,” said Haylee. She paused, whispering to herself and nodding like she was counting the number of ice cells in sight. “I’m not sure whether that’s more a good thing or a bad thing, but now we can do something about it.”

“Can you?” said a voice. Before anyone could question it, a phantom – a lighter, more vibrant shade of purple than Audrey had ever seen one be – revealed itself from behind one of the prison structures.

From either side of her, two lizards stepped into view. One was snarling at the Defenders as fiercely as if it were a feral creature, while the other just scowled at them with a more withdrawn stance.

Cakepop rubbed her eyes. “Am I dreaming, or did a weird ''light purple'' phantom just choose a dramatic villain entrance over, I don’t know, stealth?”

“Oh, purple doesn’t really hide itself too well against the snow,” the amused phantom replied. Her gaze fixed mockingly on Audrey. “Although I suppose that’s a lesson you’ve yet to learn, huh?”

Audrey narrowed her eyes at the strangely colored creature, although she guessed she didn’t look nearly as threatening. “How many friends you got with you, phantom?” Toxic asked her aggressively. “Just show them already. I wanna see how many eyes we’re about to take out with this little scuffle.”

The phantom raised her tentacle to stop him. “No, please, call me Julie.” The purple-and-gold lizard at her side looked up at her with wicked excitement as if expecting her to introduce him next, but his expression dropped when she just kept going. “You’re lookin’ right at all the ''friends'' who hunted your quivering little pack all the way to the mountains.” She grinned at them with her eye. “You wanna make the first move or should I?”

Audrey was still confused. There was no way this was all they’d be fighting against… it was just one phantom up against seven Defenders.

But she was so engulfed in that puzzlement that she forgot about the two lizards accompanying Julie. The purple-and-gold one moved fast as a dart and barreled straight into Audrey, clawing at her face and pulling away on Mira’s scarf like he was trying to rip it off her neck.

She kicked him in the side, but it wasn’t until a second later that Marlenka dived forward and hauled him off her by the back of his head. The muscle-bound lizard picked him right back up off the snow where he’d landed and tossed him even further into the distance with just one arm, but once he landed it was like he’d never even hit the ground. He raced back toward them and went for Cakepop and Toxic instead, occupying both of them while the second lizard finally made a move and went up against Eira and Raimu.

“Haylee!” Raimu exclaimed. “Do you think you and Audrey can take care of this one? I have a plan to handle the prisons… but it needs time, and also someone who can keep those rats off our backs while Eira and I work on it.”

Haylee bobbed her head firmly and signaled to Audrey to follow her. The second lizard, this one with green and yellow scales, chased after Eira and Raimu as expected as they bolted for the hot springs, but the two Defenders were right on his tail until he whirled around suddenly, sprayed snow in their faces with a 90-degree kick, and kept haring after his targets.

At first the sudden snowy blast left Haylee and Audrey sputtering, but Haylee shook out her head and pointed upwards after just a few moments. “Fly!” she ordered Audrey. In just three seconds, Haylee had summoned her own wings – glowing green spirals of light that swirled over her back in the shape of a butterfly – and Audrey didn’t take much longer.

It was colder up in the sky, but the evil lizard they chased had no idea they were there. He paused his pursuit of Eira and Raimu very briefly, looking backwards with confusion at no longer seeing the Defenders coming after him, and Haylee chose that moment to drop down on him from the sky. She delivered a midair punt that sent him sprawling face-first onto the ground, which cleared the way for Audrey to land on his back and pin him there.

Silver wings flared out, Audrey’s image was almost as fearsome as Julie’s. The power she felt inside of her commanded her to widen her eyes like an instinct, and when she did, all the light had sucked itself out of the vision of the lizard underneath her so that it was concentrated completely in her eyes. Confident that he wouldn’t be able to move, she looked back to the hot springs to see what Eira and Raimu were up to.

Eira was busy hollowing out a piece of rock – which was starting to look more like a bowl – while Raimu dipped an already-hollowed piece into the springs and seemed to filter the water with his claws. Once it was almost full, with the water inside of it looking clouded white, he ran it to the nearest ice prison and dumped the water on top of it, heading back immediately.

It took a short while for anything to happen, but then Audrey saw what he had done; the ice of the bars and roof became thinner and thinner until it melted entirely. ''The salt from the spring water is making it go away faster,'' Audrey realized. ''Raimu’s a genius!''

Even though one of Julie’s lizards was pinned, the first one was still as energetic as ever. Toxic was half buried in a snowbank, panting like crazy with a couple of nasty-looking scratches drawn across his face. Cakepop appeared to be trying to dig him out while simultaneously holding off the enemy lizard’s rapid attacks, and Marlenka was trying to claw Julie, who just spun in circles around her and cackled every time she missed.

Finally Julie noticed that only one of her lizards was still available to fight and glanced over at Audrey, whose wings folded and then disappeared, to see him squirming but otherwise immobile underneath her. Raimu splashed yet another cell with spring water, and the first one was now completely eaten away by the salt. Julie rose up into the air, just out of Marlenka’s jumping reach, and glowered at Audrey. “Oh, that won’t do,” she muttered darkly.

Marlenka seemed to be contemplating whether to summon her wings and keep chasing after Julie, but instead she went over to help drag the purple-and-gold lizard away from Toxic. Julie hardly even looked at her, clapping two tentacles together with alarming volume.

At once, both of her lizards turned in her direction; the attacking one abandoned his struggle with Toxic and returned to Julie, still growling at the Defenders. The lizard Audrey had pinned extended his legs from his sides and pushed himself up off the ground forcefully, knocking Audrey into the snow, but rather than continuing to try and fight her he raced up to Julie’s other side.

“What’s going on?” Cakepop squeaked. Before Raimu could return to the springs, a purple flame rose up out of the ground and spread until it was like a wall, nearly encircling him. He yelped and fell back, burnt on his nose and forearms, and the fire wall pushed him over to where Cakepop, Toxic, and Audrey were. The fire then reshaped itself and surrounded them in a ring, slowly closing in on them as Julie floated above tauntingly.

Audrey’s teeth chattered. At first she thought it was just the cold seeping into her scales, but then she realized her vision had gotten lighter and she could feel her own eyes glowing as she zoomed forward at supersonic speed and rammed into Julie with her wings as wide and powerful as three heavy phantoms.

''This is what my alpha powers are for.''

==Chapter Twenty-Two - Marks - Audrey’s POV==
The sheen of shimmering whiteness cleared from Audrey’s eyes. She didn’t feel tired or worn out – just cold, the temperature of the mountains sinking back into her scales as if it had been momentarily pushed out by a wave of heat. Julie and her lizards were nowhere to be seen.

“That was ''awesome'', Audrey!” Toxic said at once. “Those must have been the perk thingies you got when Mira made you an alpha. Coooool.”

Audrey glanced at her claws. They seemed to be glittering when she first saw them, but then the sparkles disappeared. “I guess so. But what happened to… ''them?''”

Marlenka curled her tail in the direction of a snowbank some lengths past where the group was huddled. “Last we saw, you punched ‘em real good into that little sugar pile. The stupid tentacled one probably busted on contact, and I imagine the lizards aren’t conscious, so we should be clear to skedaddle.”

Audrey gasped and drew her head closer to her shoulders. “Wait. You mean you want to leave them here? To freeze? We know Julie’s a phantom and all, but the lizards are just misguided…”

A narrow-eyed look from Marlenka’s ruby eyes cut her off. “Those lizards are the enemy, Audrey. They work with the phantoms by choice. I’m not dragging them out of the snow and saving their sorry lives just because they look like us.”

The purple lizard wished she could argue, but she didn’t have a clue what to say. She just waited for Haylee to speak instead, eyes averted. “Alright, let’s go,” Haylee said to break the awkward silence. “Good job with your powers, Audrey. And also-”

In the center of the group, a blue sphere of pure light emerged from the snow beneath their claws, humming with energy and swirling over their heads until it burst in the air. White and blue sparks sliced across the sky like petals from a flower grown by Mira herself. With the explosion came a blast of light that momentarily blinded all the lizards and sent them stumbling on their tails – but when Audrey blinked again, Raimu, Eira, and Haylee were all levitating in the air without their wings.

The dissipated shards of light moved back towards the center where they had coursed out from, slowly at first and then rapidly enough that another blink would have caused Audrey to miss it. The reformed ball of light split into three smaller orbs, one drifting into the hearts of each floating lizard. Toxic shook Audrey’s shoulder excitedly as he watched a white mark appear on Haylee, Eira, and Raimu’s foreheads. At last the lizards were lowered back onto the snow, the sky bleak and white as if nothing had happened.

“Are you guys alphas now?” Toxic blurted as soon as the shine of wonder faded from their eyes. His wide grin took up the larger half of his face.

Haylee blinked at the others who had been lifted into the air alongside her. “Eira- you have this star on your forehead…the chart from ''Secret Talents of the Lizards'' indicated that that means you’re the alpha of magic, like Peck was. And Raimu, you have a gear…”

Raimu nodded. The shape was only half visible beneath the brim of his orange baseball cap. “That I remember. I suppose this means I’ve been granted powers as the tech alpha, or Graham’s proxy. Yours has a leaf, Haylee. The nature alpha.”

Beside Toxic, Cakepop’s eyes were sparkling. “Woooooah!! Did we just get all of the remaining alphas at once, then?!”

Still in a state of shock, Haylee made a face like she was doing the math in her head; Audrey noticed that instead of solid sky blue, her eyes had a tinge of pastel green at the tops. “No,” she said uncertainly. “There were six alphas to replace. Liza, Peck, Graham, Sir Gilbert, Cosmo, and Greely. And… six types… moon, magic, tech, sun, nature, and… phantom. So there’s one left to be named.”

Cakepop tilted her head. “Wait, there’s a phantom alpha? Why?”

“Greely was the former one,” Raimu explained to her. “I found some insightful notes in one particular chapter of the book. Its writer theorized that Greely was the first to establish the position of a phantom alpha because he was the first to try – and succeed – at learning and comprehending phantom tactics as a means to defeat them. He lives by the warning to know your enemy.”

All of a sudden, Marlenka’s concerned look returned. “Wait. ‘Know your enemy?’ Look, look, I don’t wanna question the decisions made by Mira and Zios, since from the looks of it, they already have an idea of who they want to pick and just wait for the opportunity of catching that lizard in their best moment to grant them powers then. But… what if Mira and Zios are being misled?”

Toxic tilted his head. “What do you mean?”

Marlenka looked at Audrey, and then at Haylee. “There’s a spy in the Defenders. I ''know'' it. Some kind of double agent is telling the phantoms where to find us while appearing to help the Defenders at the same time. What if Mira and Zios think that this mole is being loyal to both sides to try and ‘know our enemy’ for the good of the Defenders or whatever?”

Audrey felt the need to step in. “I’m not sure about that. Can’t Mira and Zios see into our hearts and know what we really want? Even if there was a double agent, they would be able to tell what side they were ''really'' working for.”

“There ''is'' a double agent, Audrey.” Marlenka’s face and voice was dripping with exasperation. “We just need to catch them in the act.”

“Marlenka,” Haylee said rigidly. “Please do your best to trust in your fellow Defenders. We have lizards on watch at all times; they would be able to catch anyone who’s slipping off to the phantoms without permission.”

The red-and-gold lizard didn’t argue, but she held Haylee’s stare for as long as their eyes were locked. Then Haylee swept her tail across the snow, Toxic at her side with Cakepop on his back, and led the way back to Jamaa Township.

==Chapter Twenty-Three - Memory - Dragon’s POV==
Dragon groaned, the snow that completely surrounded his body starting to hurt more than it made him just feel cold. “Quiet,” Julie hissed at him. “They aren’t gone yet.”

A few more minutes passed. By now almost every part of Dragon had gone numb, his brain included, but at last Julie dragged him and Skip out of the snow.

“Well, they’ve left now,” Julie growled. “Breaking a fall is one thing the two of you don’t do so badly. Move, we need to follow them before the stupid blizzard or whatever this is hides them from us.”

“But ''Julieeeee!''” Skip exclaimed with protest. Once again he jumped up with his sole bit of strength and gripped Julie’s tentacle. “I can’t feel my anything!”

Julie gave him a bitter look. “You’re walking. Or should I punt you there instead?”

The purple-and-gold lizard nodded his head so violently Dragon wondered if a particularly strong gust of wind could carry it away. “Yes pleeeeease!”

Grunting with annoyance, Julie flared her light-purple eye and extended a purple flame from the tentacle that Skip was clinging to, setting the lizard on fire. Dragon watched her toss him in front of her and then kick him into the unforeseeable distance while he screamed and then vanished into the thick sky.

“Get a move on, scale-face,” Julie snapped at Dragon. She clopped him with another tentacle while she floated off to see where Skip landed. Teal eyes narrowed against the snow, which was blowing off the ground and through the air right at his face, he forced his limp legs to move after her.

“What do we do now?” Dragon asked her cautiously while the phantom dug a frantic Skip up.

Finally Julie succeeded at hauling him out. “And walk on your claws from now on or it’ll happen again.” The threat was spared no vocal venom. “Now we have to lure them somewhere. Into a trap, so that we can get Haylee alone and return her to the king.”

She rubbed two tentacles together eagerly at the thought. “Haylee was all we promised, and all we were asked for… but boy, I can just ''picture'' the look on Lido’s face when all the rest of the Defenders come after us, searching for their leader, and ''I'' did it single-tentacledly without a need for half-trained armies trained by a half-wit excuse for a general.”

“What about us?” Skip complained.

“''You'' will come with me and chase them someplace. Don’t kill them, though; the more Defenders we can take back to the fortress, the more impressive he’ll find us. Ideally that ‘someplace’ is the first tree we see once we’re officially off this loathsome snow. That’s the place where ''Dragon''-” She patted the green-and-yellow lizard on the head again. He hated when she did that. As if he was a pet, like those meek little Defenders.

“-will have the trap made and ready. Dragon, dig out a wide space in front of the tree and pace around it. Make sure to talk about the phantoms a lot, so they’ll want to attack you.”

''Great,'' Dragon thought to himself, but he could never even mumble it as long as Julie was within a mile of him. “Yes, Miss Julie.”

“We split up now so that they can’t get any farther ahead. Don’t screw this up, Dragon. Skip, show me those fangs. Wider!”

And then Dragon was alone in the snow. Far from the phantom fortress, and soon when he began to hobble in the opposite direction, far from Julie and Skip, the phantom proponents he always seemed to be stuck with.

He wondered what Bella’s life was like. He hadn’t seen her in two full years. ''And even after that much time, I still don’t know how to feel about it.''

The scene was still clear and colorful in his mind – as colorful as the phantom fortress could be with its dark-purple walls and black turrets built brick by brick by prisoners of the phantoms themselves. The energy of their labor was carried over into the appearance of the bastion itself; just looking at it incited a deep feeling of interminable hopelessness. Yet the unmoving walls were the scene of a terrifying battle. Sir Gilbert and his wretched tiger troopers were as close to infiltrating the fortress as they had ever been, and Dragon and Bella – named Phantom at the time – were smack dab in the heart of it.

Bella got her birth name from a nickname that she was called by the other lizards when she was a very young hatchling for having dark-purple scales just like many of their tentacled keepers. However, she perhaps, or so Dragon and the others had thought, was the least like the phantoms of all of those raised in the fortress. She never roamed the halls looking to pick a fight. She never stole comfort from the other lizards. And she ''never'' stuck up for herself when they picked on her for how little of a “real lizard” she was.

When she was caught peeling one of many banners off the wall so that she could keep the both of them warm that night, Dragon saw no other choice but to step in and claim responsibility for it. He was both frustrated that she was the other lizards’ clawing bag ''and'' frustrated that she never tried to fight back – but he didn’t regret a moment of his punishment as long as it meant she would be okay.

Julie saw how diligent he was and wanted him to come work with her to advance her “''great plans''” for Jamaa and the phantom kingdom. His decision to accept was the only thing he and Bella ever disagreed on.

So as their friendship continued to grow for their entire hatchlinghoods leading into the young adult stage of their life, Bella staying mostly the same while Dragon learned to protect himself when necessary and striving to teach her to do the same thing, she repaid him by leaving.

“Phantom, you’re going to get caught,” Dragon remembered trying to convince her in the battle’s midst. She had told him she planned to leave the phantom fortress, find a new life for herself by seeking out those “Defenders” the phantoms were always complaining about. But he didn’t think to take those words seriously until she ascended the fortress’s lookout wall so that she could escape through the surrounding woods. “You’ll be killed!”

Bella shook her head. “I won’t be killed.” But she didn’t sound certain until she went on: “If Julie and the king get what they want, ''everything'' will be destroyed.”

“Phantom- ''Phantom!''” He chased after her as she broke away from him and raced for the woods, dodging past phantom soldiers and tiger troopers alike. He tackled her to the ground as she gasped, pinning her there under his claws and the fierce teal gaze he’d only ever used on other lizards who dared bother him. The expression that Julie alone had helped him master. “If you run away,” he snarled, “You’ll be on the wrong side of the phantoms’ wrath. You. ''Won’t.'' Survive.”

Bella kicked him in the chest and sliced her claws across his face. He was so dumbfounded at what she did that he basically let her do it. Her shadow fell over his face. “I’m Bella now,” she told him. The tone of her voice was as freezing as the chill that drove her to steal the banner years before. “No longer a pet ward for the phantoms. My ''name'' is no longer Phantom.”

It was the one brave thing she ever did in her life, as far into her life as Dragon had ever gotten to see. He didn’t even know if she was still alive.

As the tops of the trees ahead finally came into view, Dragon wondered if he would ever find the same courage as she did, for that one moment, enough to never be found by the phantoms again. He knew it was treasonous to let the thought even cross his mind, but that fact didn’t stop his dazed brain from fantasizing about it.

==Chapter Twenty-Four - Progression - Halo’s POV==
Sundown was fast approaching when Haylee’s party of seven arrived back to their new bunker on the fringe of Jamaa Township. It didn’t take long for any of the Defenders to notice that three of their comrades were returning with a unique white symbol on their foreheads.

“Mira and Zios have chosen three more Defenders as replacement alphas,” said Haylee, her voice clear enough that all the lizards above ground could hear her.

As her voice reverberated through the grass, more heads popped up out of the tunnel to the barracks to listen. “I have been given powers as the nature alpha, Raimu the tech alpha, and Eira the magic alpha. It was a brave fight up in Mt. Shiveer, and we did encounter a phantom… but the ice prisons, or at least the ones that existed, are no longer, and we’ve successfully offset the phantoms’ plans for some time.” The way Haylee paused after saying “a phantom” made Halo think there was something else to say, but she didn’t go back to it if there was.

“All three of us are proud to continue defending Jamaa with the abilities we have been granted alongside Audrey and Marlenka.” The three new alphas bowed their heads to the watching Defenders, who cheered and tossed their blankets around. “We’ve also decided that with all the stress and intensity of the past week, it would be a good idea to take a group of Defenders into town to just relax, buy some blankets and food and all that. All of us-” she swept her tail to indicate the group that had gone on the mission- “except for Marlenka and Cakepop will be coming, so if you’re interested, feel free to join. We leave in ten minutes.”

Halo had decided to be a part of the trip into town after Vatra expressed interest. It didn’t feel like an obligation to him that he had to go because she was going – wanting to come along just felt natural, like they’d get to do something fun together out of… friendship? The word felt strange for him to use about anyone other than Audrey.

Vatra wanted to spend time with him, though, even when he didn’t want to be spoken to – or if Audrey didn’t want to speak to him. It seemed like she was hardly ever talking to him anymore.

He didn’t want to focus on that, though. The starlight made it hard to discern details, but Jam Mart Clothing had undergone a significant refurbishment as the phantom war gradually worsened, and now it was a place where hot drinks were made and sold in the back. Many of the clothes had become pawmade instead of manufactured. Blankets covered jagged holes in the wooden walls of the castle-like structure where heavy phantoms had once smashed through.

Immediately, Halo saw Audrey head for the drink station, Toxic beside her. When she ordered her hot chocolate he was near certain she asked if they had any cinnamon to go with it.

Closer to the door were Vatra and Halo, enjoying the heating system. He hadn’t felt generated warmth like this since living in Loafie’s den, but there was no telling when or if Vatra had experienced anything similar. “How are you enjoying the heat for once?” he asked her.

Vatra blinked up at the dim lights. “''So'' good, Halo. If only I could stay here for a while and study whatever’s keeping this building so warm, build some kind of portable heat device that can bring that to the Defenders. Like… a bonfire you can wear.”

“That description fits the old white blanket well,” Halo grumbled good-naturedly. “Whoever’s using it now better be enjoying it, because ''both'' of us are freezing our tails off now.”

The other lizard chuckled, but it was soon cut off when she saw Raimu and an elegant-looking purple lizard heading their way. “Very sorry to interrupt you,” Raimu told them earnestly. He tilted his head toward the lizard next to him. “I wanted to let you know that I told Eira about the blank-outs. Mine seem to be getting worse… but Eira hasn’t had any at all.”

“Perhaps I just don’t feel it when they happen,” Eira suggested.

But Raimu shook his head. “I fear that if you have them, you ''can'' sense it. Strongly. Right, you two?” Halo and Vatra nodded.

“Eira didn’t get hit by the special phantom goop during that battle,” Vatra mused aloud. “So maybe it ''is'' connected. We really should ask more of the Defenders just to be sure, since I think the three of us were the only ones who came into contact with it…”

“We can’t cause a panic either, though,” Halo put in. He figured that Raimu had told Eira about the blank-outs because he trusted her closely enough to handle the knowledge in a responsible way. Then he wondered why he himself had never told Audrey.

Raimu sighed. “So once again it stays with us. Do either of you have anyone you would want to ask who you know wouldn’t react explosively?”

Neither Vatra nor Halo nodded at the question.

“I can’t remember anything at all from today past the point when Audrey and everyone left,” Halo said. “Or… Marlenka’s training sessions. If you took me outside right now and asked me to summon my wings, I don’t know if I could do that quickly.”

The green-and-cream lizard in front of him and Vatra exchanged looks with Eira. “Apologies again for pausing your conversation,” said Eira. She lowered her head slightly, and the white star on it seemed to glow. “All we needed was to check in so that I could write it down in his notes.”

“His notes?” Halo cocked his head.

Eira nodded with a solemn expression. “Raimu can’t always remember the information he’s learned anymore. I must write it for him so that none of his findings are touched by his condition.”

Vatra and Halo said goodbye to them and then the two lizards walked off to an unknown spot in the store. “This is bad,” Vatra murmured.

“Maybe.” Halo stood up. “We’ll get through it. Besides, Raimu’s an alpha now; his new magic has ''got'' to overpower whatever’s affecting his memory.” When the orange lizard still didn’t look convinced, he put his claws on her shoulder comfortingly. “C’mon. We don’t need to think about it right now; we came here to be warm and have a little fun in the midst of the war.”

It took a second, but the corner of Vatra’s mouth lifted and she got to her claws too. “Okay… you’re right. Where should we go first?” She glanced at the drink station, in the corner of the building where the overhead light was weakest. “Are you maybe… thirsty?”

==Chapter Twenty-Five - Out - Bella’s POV==
Bella was feeling just fine when Haylee and the other Defenders went into the town. She was too tired to come along and guessed that Haylee and Audrey, probably the only ones she’d have talked with since Millie stayed in the barracks whenever possible, would just be discussing alpha stuff. They had more important things to attend to than her.

It made her anxious at first that Marlenka was one of the only ones from the mission who had opted to stay behind, but most of her nerves were eased when the red-and-gold lizard made her way underground without a word and shut herself away in her nest.

As long as she left Bella alone, Bella was just fine with that, although she had to wonder what had gotten Marlenka so worked up when everyone else from the mission seemed just relieved to be home.

But the peace didn’t last long. Bella only slept for about an hour before she was shaken awake by a lizard she didn’t know. Frantically she blinked up at the dirt roof of the underground bunker above her head, glad to still be lying where she had fallen asleep, but several other Defenders were standing in the nesting room with uneasy looks.

“Something’s chasing them” was all the lizard said, and then they went off to wake someone else up.

Like instinct Bella went to find Millie and ask her what was going on, but with everyone clustered and unmoving she was impossible to find, not to mention the trail of Defenders spilled up through the passage leading back to the aboveground. Bella shifted awkwardly through the mass until dark blades of grass struggled beneath her claws. She still couldn’t see Millie no matter how far around she turned-

Then she saw it. In the distance, a line of purple followed a small group of multicolored dots. Several other Defenders watched with her, squinting at the shapes and trying to make out what was following the dots, which appeared to be lizard-shaped. Dead silence occupied the land, no leaf daring to rustle.

The purple line was glowing.

''They’re getting chased by fire.''

Someone shouted it out before Bella could articulate her realization. Defenders raced both towards and away their comrades while she debated with herself which way to run. The flames were growing crisper now in her vision. Some of them licked at the trees themselves, leaving blackness and absence of life wherever they coursed. The fire was like a wall, pushing steadily toward Haylee’s group and moving them toward the barracks.

“Get everyone out of the bunker,” Bella heard Haylee shout. “No possessions, just ''get out.'' I don’t want her sending the fire through the only exit, they’ll be trapped in there!”

“What about the book?” someone else screeched. No one answered them.

''Her?'' It took Bella a few seconds to register what had just been said. But as the purple blaze grew closer and more lizards rushed past, no more time had passed than Bella received her answer.

Floating behind the fire, lavender eye glowing like a torch, waving her tentacles in the air as she manipulated its direction, was the one creature Bella feared more than Marlenka: Julie the phantom. The monster her old friend Dragon had worked with and learned from no matter how many times Bella warned him of how devious she was. To that day she still blamed Julie for turning Dragon into the mindless underling she couldn’t force herself to say she recognized.

There was no time to think. Bella ran with the outskirts of the moving Defenders, glancing back every now and then to ensure that the fire hadn’t traveled into the bunker entrance. Strangely, it hadn’t. It almost seemed like Julie was maneuvering the fire in such a way that it would leave them alone – but that didn’t heed the panic in the eyes of the escaping lizards, or in Bella’s own rapidly-moving legs.

Trees came and went as the Defenders fled like a herd of sheep. They moved with no destination in mind, only the will to not burn alive. Bella had been sprinting for long past her lung capacity, fear eating away at her senses, before she remembered Millie. She glanced back, but the hole that led to the barracks was too far away to see now. ''Where is she? Should I look for her?''

But it was a hopeless thought. It had made her subconsciously slow down, and now Defenders of all sizes and colors rushed past her without a second thought. There was no way she’d be able to find her friend when the flames were still chasing them away. All she could do was keep running and hope for the best, because any other option would lead her to a scorching end.

Then something else caught her eye. Another lizard circling beneath the vast branches of a tree at the very edge of the clump of woods, far in the distance. Julie’s fire was pushing the Defenders straight toward them, but still they moved free of alarm until they saw the Defenders right behind them.

The shape dashed off into the surrounding trees. All of the Defenders – now led by Haylee, although they had been too caught off guard to organize themselves at first – proceeded, heading for the tree, as if they hadn’t even seen it. But Bella had. It was definitely a lizard, and though the shadows beneath the empty trees’ outstretched branches made it hard to tell, its form was occasionally dappled by claws of moonlight like tiger stripes, revealing scales that were gold… and green.

Bella stopped short, nearly tripping over herself. Defenders who had been running at the tail end of the group now passed her, their waving tails thumping into her back, but she hardly noticed. The lizard peeked over his shoulder to check if he was being followed, and that was the moment Bella’s green eyes met his own.

A teal gaze struck with horror, exactly what she expected, and yet the last thing she thought she would see on a night that seemed like it would have ended like any other. But she wasn’t curled up in her flat nest underground, head filled with dreams about living any life but her own. She was standing still, in the middle of a forest, with a smoldering purple blaze steps away from consuming her whole, staring at the lizard who she had last seen standing over her and demanding that she stay in the fortress, stay loyal to the phantoms.

And then, without a pause to so much as think about it, she was pelting after him.

==Chapter Twenty-Six - Visit - Bella’s POV==
The burning of the grass grew further and further behind Bella as she veered off her path to follow Dragon. The green-and-gold lizard didn’t move. He just stared at her.

Bella stopped just short of kicking him in the eye with her flailing claws. “Dragon,” she panted. Her mind felt blank; she had no idea what to say. She couldn’t ask if he was okay, because she had no idea what he would answer. She couldn’t say she missed him, because… well, she didn’t even know how to feel about that. She couldn’t ask what he was doing here, because clearly if Julie was around, then he was probably busy being a pawn in one of her conniving plans.

''Wait.''

“Dragon…” Bella’s hoarse voice cracked.

Without waiting another second, Dragon spun on his tail and darted deeper into the woods, weaving past tree trunks and over bramble-laced hedges while Bella followed him again, her face battered by branches and thorns.

There wasn’t enough air in Bella’s lungs to try talking to him again. Maybe, she thought as the tall grass sliced at her sides, that had been the case ever since she fled the fortress.

She didn’t need to, though. Dragon stopped short, having reached a stream too big to jump across, and Bella sped right into his back, sending both of them tumbling back a few paces. When Dragon tried to back up, his yellow tail-tip hit a solid mass of oak wood and, breathless, he gave up trying to leave and just sat there while Bella pushed herself up off the ground.

The sight made her eyes burn with momentary annoyance. Not because he wasn’t helping her up, but because he didn’t keep running out of thinking she wouldn’t – or couldn’t – hurt him. ''I could,'' she thought darkly. ''He’s got nowhere to run. I wonder how painful that assumption would be if I slammed him into the tree or held him under the water.''

But she knew in her heart what she wanted wasn’t really to hurt him. With her current state of mind, she didn’t think she could even summon her wings if she wanted to. ''My phantom tentacle wings. Would he laugh if he saw me with them anyway? Would he say the world’s trying to tell me that the phantoms will always haunt me no matter how far I run?''

“Please,” she managed. “Don’t go away.”

Dragon was silent for a few beats. “I can’t talk to you, Bella.”

“Why?”

“Because you’re ''one of them.''”

She didn’t know what to say to that. Ever since she gained her wings in front of Audrey and Marlenka, watching the others soar about the treetops without a care in the world while it was like her nightmares were attached to her back, she had never felt ''less'' like one of the Defenders.

“I can’t talk to you right now,” said Dragon. This was the most conflicted she’d ever seen him, Bella thought. “You… I have to go. I need to be somewhere else. Go back to the Defenders.”

He was about to turn back around and run over to where he’d been before, but then he paused. “And… please avoid the tree with the hole in the center of the trunk. There’s a trap.” Dragon dashed off through the leaves and was gone.

Bella stared after him for some time. Then his words hit her: ''There’s a trap.''

Instantly she started forward again, trying to remember where she had come from so that she could find the Defenders. They were still clustered together and not very hard to find, with Julie and her screen of fire burning ever brighter and chasing them still. Up ahead was just the tree Dragon had warned her about: a big yawning hole, too large to be a squirrel nest, was dented into its trunk over the height of the lizards’ heads. And the ground at its roots was leafier than most other spots in the forest.

Bella waited for the Defenders to start turning towards it, herded that way by the blaze at their tails, and then she rushed up to Haylee, who was in the lead with Marlenka and Audrey close behind her. The white leaf mark on her forehead was gleaming in distress.

“Haylee,” Bella gasped. “You have to stop running. There’s a trap in front of that tree. Tell the Defenders to scatter so that they don’t get trapped between it and the fire."

Haylee glanced between the leaf pile and the purple lizard uncertainly. “It’s really not a good idea to spread out right now,” she replied. “Some of us are going to get lost, and then we’re even easier targets if we’re separated-”

“''Please!''” yelped Bella. “Don’t go into that trap!”

Haylee opened her mouth, but it was too late. Her claws got caught on a twig and she was pulled down, gaping, into the leaves, which Bella realized had been covering a pit. Audrey nearly tumbled down right after her, but Marlenka grabbed her by the scarf and blocked the way with her large body to keep anyone else from falling in.

At last, Julie’s fire burned out behind the Defenders. The oddly-colored phantom soared over their heads, a purple-and-gold lizard sneering down at them atop her head, and tugged at a vine cluster by the trap. Haylee, entangled in a net composed of even more vines, was dragged up out of it; Bella saw she was trying to use her alpha powers to control the vines and escape, but every time she focused her magic on them, they just grew thicker and thornier.

“I’ll see you all at the phantom fortress,” Julie addressed the Defenders, her infuriatingly triumphant voice leveled out like the blade of a knife, “if you want to ''witness'' your great leader get ripped to pieces.”

Deeper in the woods, a flash of emerald green and golden-yellow became hidden behind a clump of berry bushes. Julie and the lizard on her head snickered at the shocked lizards and then carried their netted prize out of sight where they were hidden fast in the night.

==Chapter Twenty-Seven - Never - Bella’s POV==
The only time Bella had seen the lizards as silent and still as they were when they stood behind her, fresh off the sight of a trapped Haylee getting lifted into the sky, was when Audrey and Marlenka had first received their alpha powers.

A shadow swallowed Bella’s figure.

“You want to tell us how you knew that trap was going to be there?” growled Marlenka, her voice lower than the unmoving grass.

Bella turned around slowly. She thought she would just edit the truth, explain that she saw Dragon and cornered him, at which point he let that secret slip out, but the second she saw Marlenka’s bright red eyes boring into her own and the white sun that embellished her forehead blazing as bright as Julie’s fire, all her words and all her thoughts were swallowed in an instant.

She realized Marlenka’s huge arms were shaking with fury. “Get out,” Marlenka snarled. When Bella still didn’t move, pinned to the earth by that ruby gaze of disgust mixed with mistrust, the red-and-gold lizard swung her forearm at Bella with full force and sent the purple lizard sprawling against the tree’s trunk. When she hit the wood, splinters of it peeling off as she dropped to the earth, it hurt like she’d been thrown against the wall of the phantom fortress itself.

“Get ''out!''” Marlenka roared at her. “You’re no Defender, you sorry excuse for a spy. You had better go sniveling back to the phantoms and tell them all about how we’re coming to break their ulnas or else we’re doing it ourselves. ''Never'' come back or I swear I’ll break your skull.”

Bella felt like she couldn’t move. If Marlenka had bounded up to her and followed through with her threat right there, she wouldn’t even have rolled out of the way. When she looked up at Audrey, the purple-and-silver lizard was staring down at her with tears in her eyes. No wind was present to blow the ends of Mira’s scarf into the air.

At last Bella stood up. She heard Marlenka’s claws crunch in the grass like she was about to spring forward, but Audrey held her back with a light grip on the bigger lizard’s shoulder.

It wasn’t until she’d been walking through the oak-laden path for several minutes, her brain devoid of all senses, that Bella began to cry.

She hardly even registered when Dragon leapt out from an overhead branch and began walking beside her. Everything that had happened to her that night felt like it could only have occurred in a fitful nightmare.

Some more time passed and nothing seemed to change with Bella’s mental state. She was now vaguely aware of Dragon next to her. He was saying something to her, but she couldn’t wrap her mind around what until she saw the round, tentacled shape of Julie hovering just above the nearest tree. The sight of the purple-eyed phantom nearly made Bella have a full-on blackout right then and there.

“...You’ll join us, right?” Bella heard Dragon say. It sounded like someone had turned right the knob that controlled his voice’s volume, and at last she could hear him clearly, though her sense of understanding was still out of her grasp.

Hanging from Julie’s lower tentacles was a net made of chunky vines; there wasn’t much space between them, but in those thin spots where the other side of the net was visible, there was no mistaking the pastel blue and pink of Haylee’s scales.

“Brought a friend, did you?” Julie narrowed her eye down at Bella. The lizard couldn’t remember a time they had ever crossed paths back at the phantom fortress, but her true fear of the phantom was entirely fueled by listening to Dragon tell her how he, Julie, and another lizard named Skip spent their days after the partnership, wondering what kind of fiend could have made him believe he was doing the right thing.

“This is Bella,” said Dragon. “She was a Defender, but she… she was trying to sabotage them, but one of their leaders found out and now she’s all on her own. She’s completely dedicated to the phantom cause.” He tried to nudge Bella’s shoulder blade – make her look more dignified or conscious at a minimum – but the other lizard’s eyes were as vacant as they had been before, and pointed at the ground.

Julie’s grin grew. “That’s no saboteur. Oh, Dragon, I’ve seen – and ''overseen'' – far too many spies to be fooled by a fake one. This scrap of scales and claws can hardly stand up; no true phantom ally would be so weak after just running for a while.”

“Wait,” Dragon blurted, his voice panicked. “She ''is'' a spy. She’s just… she’s just…”

“How about this.” Julie floated closer to the ground. The viny net in her grasp hit the grass hard, but the lizard inside it didn’t make a sound. Her expression was just as smug as it had been when she captured the Defenders’ leader. “Why don’t we just ''keep her safe'' in the fortress prison, and then we can question her later to figure out if she’s really a spy.”

Once again she lifted into the air. On the top of her head, Skip squealed with glee at her speed. “Wouldn’t want her to get beaten up if the others were to find her all alone.”

It was the last thing Bella heard before the trees turned into giant shadows in her vision, blotting out the starlight and diving straight for her wide-open eyes.

==Chapter Twenty-Eight - Spirit - Audrey’s POV==
Audrey couldn’t catch a wink of sleep. In Haylee’s absence, Marlenka had led the Defenders back to the bunker, determining Julie no longer an immediate threat to the safety of the group. She was answered by any number of groans, tired faces, and uncertain looks, but after what she’d just done to Bella, no one was in the mood to question her.

The harrowing sound of Bella hitting the tree kept Audrey wide awake every time she tried to close her eyes. She was surprised the purple lizard had been able to get up after less than a minute, much less at all.

But Marlenka had been right all along. Hadn’t she? Audrey had willed Bella with her eyes to say something, anything, that would excuse the fact she somehow knew about the trap. She hadn’t, and now Audrey didn’t know if they’d ever see each other again.

''I wanted so badly to believe in her. To believe Marlenka was wrong.'' Audrey lifted her head to check on Marlenka. The red-and-gold lizard lay with her back to the sky, face hidden between her massive claws, with her eyes closed and her sides rattling heavily, but she didn’t look any more asleep than Audrey felt.

''It was a mistake to act like I knew better than her. She’s been one of the heads of the Defenders for three years, for Mira’s sake.''

If she couldn’t sleep, Audrey decided she would at least shut her eyes and pretend. Her brain kept the boredom of the silent night away by imagining places where Bella could be in that moment and thinking up a dozen different reasons Bella could have known about the trap. She was convinced by none of them.


The rustling of leaves – and the soft yet unmistakable noise of a jingle bell – led Audrey to open her eyes again. All the Defenders remained asleep, but unlike when she had lay down, everywhere as far as her eyes could see was blanketed in a foot of snow, and more flecks of it still swirled down from the silver sky.

Everywhere except for the patch of grass directly underneath Audrey. She stood up and held back a gasp upon being face to face with a giant teal and dark-gold lizard. The large creature, the edges of its appearance flecked with snow and appearing slightly transparent against the trees, laughed heartily at Audrey’s reaction; the sound of it boomed into the open air, but no Defender stirred.

“Have- have we met?” Audrey asked the other lizard, not knowing what one was ideally supposed to say when faced with such a situation.

“Well, I would wager that I know more of your life than you mine,” the giant lizard said, wiping at one eye with a massive grin on her face. “My… ''years'' of spectating experience have shown me that scrolls don’t necessarily keep track of the little details so well.”

Audrey squinted up at her. Was this someone she could recognize? At first she had missed the light-teal Jamaaliday hat the lizard was wearing, since it nearly blended in with both her scales and the sky, but once she saw it there was no mistaking who she was speaking to. “You’re Baylee,” Audrey realized aloud. “The… the protector of lizards from the fairytales.”

“''And'' visitor of lizard heroes,” Baylee added boredly, waving her claws around in the air. “Although you seem like the modest type, I could see why you wouldn’t have mentioned such a title for yourself aloud. Glad you haven’t been having any trouble mixing me up with any of the other ‘aylee’s around this camp, though. We are ''very'' different.”

Audrey blinked. “You’re, uh… not quite what I would’ve expected for the first lizard alpha ever. The benevolent spirit of the Jamaalidays, I think some of them call you.”

Baylee puffed out her chest and the golden bell at the end of her hat swung like a pendulum. “Well, I sure hope you’re not expecting an apology. The Jamaalidays are a time about spirit, and you know I’m a spirit that’s all about the Jamaalidays.”

“You only visit lizard heroes, though?” Subconsciously, Audrey reached up for the moon alpha mark on her forehead, even though it wasn’t something she could feel apart from her scales. Her mind went to the fairytale lizards that Baylee was said to have visited: great warriors with spears strapped to their backs and a glint of adventure in their eyes. “Except for that minor skirmish in Mt. Shiveer, I haven’t done any fighting. I haven’t even been able to puzzle out where a book from the Defenders’ storage came from. A ''book''.”

“Ohhh, you mean this little thing.” Baylee tilted her palm up to the sky and ''Secret Talents of the Lizards'' floated into it, not big enough to take up the entire surface. “I see you’ve all been ''very'' curious over the last couple weeks. If that’s still so, I was the one who put it there. Dang, that dusty ol’ shelf was just too perfect a place to keep it hidden.”

Audrey gaped at her. “''You'' left it there? How? Why? Did you write it? Why didn’t you say anything before?”

“Hey, hey, hold on a minute. Yes, I put it there. Slipped right into the camp no problem; long as there’s an opening, spirits can get in just fine, y’know.” Baylee tilted her head. “I did not write it. A friend of mine did – well, a friend who was alive back before I was-”

The snow whisked itself off the ground and whirled around her claws and head in fierce tempestuous rings, blowing the point of her hat in all the directions at once like a flag in a windstorm. “-''the Protector of Lizards!''” Baylee, eyes glowing white, let Audrey stare in awe for a short while before letting the snow settle back down on the ground and leave it as perfectly even as it had been before.

“Anyways. So he’s long gone, but he died before his research on lizard magic could get out into the world, so I did him a little posthumous favor once I foresaw that there would be lizard alphas once again.”

“So why didn’t you say anything before?” Audrey asked.

“I’ve got this little spirit contract, you see. I guess that’s what I’d call it.” Baylee arched her long light-teal and dark-gold neck down toward Audrey, close enough that the smaller lizard could see the voids that were her white eyes. “Before I could get a message through to you, you had to ''become'' a hero.”

Audrey glanced back at the Defenders. Remarkably, nothing had changed about the scene since the spirit first appeared – nobody was awake to be watching, a hundred chests falling and rising alongside one another just as before. “I’ll be honest, Baylee. I don’t really know if I ''am'' a hero. I couldn’t have been more confused when Mira told me I was supposed to be the new moon alpha. And when I was fighting those lizards in Mt. Shiveer, it just felt like… she made the wrong choice. Are you planning to visit Marlenka too? Because she’s been doing such an amazing job teaching everyone how to fight and battling off the phantoms while I’m at the edge of the group hiding with the hatchlings.”

At those words, Baylee snorted. “Oh, young lizard, Mira never makes the wrong choice. She likes Marlenka because of how much she cares about teaching the others how to defend themselves regardless of their age, and also how deeply she believes in the Defenders’ cause in general and has a good heart that wants to protect them. But I’m not here to visit her.”

Snow blew itself off the icy surface of the land again. Audrey watched, mesmerized, as it formed a breeze that split itself – one half drifted over to Baylee’s back, and the other half to Audrey’s, both of them forming an amorphous pair of wings that changed shape with every chilly breath of the world. “Above all things, cheesy and stale as it sounds, I’m here to remind you to believe in yourself. You’ve spent so much time wondering what it means to be the moon alpha that you haven’t been able to realize why Mira chose you in the first place.”

Audrey’s amethyst eyes sparkled with the light of dawn as she looked upon the spectral lizard. Gradually her light-teal body became a moving blur of snow just like the wing shapes on her back, and the golden-brown of the scales on her face blurred with the pale sky. “You don’t need to be busting phantoms left and right to measure up as an alpha,” Baylee continued. Then she winked, the image of her claws fading into the earth “After all, not all heroes are fighters. Some of them are defenders.”

Then the shape of both pairs of wings collapsed, dusting the ground where they had once hovered, and Baylee was gone.

==Chapter Twenty-Nine - Faith - Audrey’s POV==
Audrey heard when the gatherers began to stir. Opening one eye, she realized she had gotten sleep after all – or at least she felt like it, her legs free of the ache they had hosted the previous night. ''I can’t believe I was just visited by the first-ever lizard alpha.'' All the things Baylee had said still rang through her mind. ''I hope she was real.''

When Audrey lifted her head she saw Kaylee, expression blank. ''I admire how well she’s able to handle Haylee being captured,'' Audrey thought. ''Plus they’re sisters, too. Bella was just a friend I thought I made and yet I can’t move my thoughts anywhere else from where she might be.''

Kaylee glanced around the camp, then slipped away with her gatherer’s satchel swung over her shoulder. Now Marlenka really did appear to be catching some z’s; a snore rattled through the nostril she wasn’t covering with her claws. Audrey had reluctantly accepted that she’d need to prod the bigger lizard to wake her up, but then Marlenka got up on her own as if Audrey just standing there had shaken her from her sleep.

“What,” Marlenka grumbled.

“Can we go deeper in the woods to talk?” Audrey angled her tail towards a ring of trees a short ways past where the Defenders were sleeping.

Marlenka turned her head and surveyed the camp. Her eyes were narrowed – whether from the early morning sunlight or annoyance, Audrey couldn’t tell. “Are the gatherers out yet?”

“Kaylee left, but I haven’t seen anyone else go yet.”

“Hrng. Okay. I’ll grab Eira and have her keep watch.”

Over under a bending oak, so silent that Audrey hadn’t even noticed he was up until then, Raimu was studying ''Secret Talents of the Lizards'', most of its pages flipped to the left side. “Why not Raimu? He’s already awake, it looks like.”

Marlenka didn’t turn around. “He’s been acting weird. Like, half-awake weird all the time. Just take my word for it, okay? Good.”

Once Eira had been set to keep watch over the camp in the two alphas’ absences, they found a pebbly forest path that led to somewhere out of the Defenders’ earshot, somewhere near the burned-away grasses that had been decimated by Julie’s fire the previous night. “Looks like it’ll snow,” Marlenka commented awkwardly, glancing momentarily up at the sky without moving her head.

“I need us to lead the Defenders in a rescue mission together,” Audrey stated.

“Fine by me. How many are we sending to look for Haylee while the others handle the guards and all that stuff?”

Audrey lifted her head. “Haylee ''and'' Bella. This isn’t an attempt to get only one of them back.”

Marlenka lashed her tail in the grass. “Why don’t you ''trust'' me ever? Haylee wasn’t there, so I ''had'' to take matters into my own claws. I don’t care what Haylee ever thought about that one, I ''knew'' Bella was the spy, and I eliminated a huge threat to us by throwing her out. If she goes back to the phantoms and tells them we’re coming, good. If she dies trying, fine.”

“How can you talk like that about someone?” Audrey couldn’t help but louden her voice. This didn’t feel like her at all – just a few weeks ago she was hiding under a blanket on Loafie’s back so that she wouldn’t even need to catch a glimpse of the phantoms swarming overhead – but someone needed to stand up to Marlenka. “You hardly even let her speak before you threw her against that tree. She was ''scared.'' And don’t forget that by telling us there was a trap there, she was trying to save us! Without her warning, I don’t know how many more would’ve been captured.”

Marlenka pushed out her lip thoughtfully. “Audrey, look. I’ve been in the Defenders for as long as Bella has and longer. I have seen ''everything'' – the way she clings to that old healer Millie, the way she takes advantage of Haylee’s excessive ‘kindness’ and reluctance to admit that, yeah, there are evil lizards out there. Which is ''mildly'' important to know when you manage a group of them that has risen to become the fortress’s public enemy number one. But you know what you and I ''both'' saw? Her wings. Tell me you don’t forget the moment she got her wings.”

It was hard for Audrey’s mind to deny that Marlenka made a good point. Even she herself was still confounded at how closely Bella’s wings seemed to resemble phantom tentacles, which was a question that had mostly been pushed out of her brain. ''We’re not talking about that, though. This is about the trap and her exile.''

Audrey couldn’t let herself look away. Marlenka wasn’t a phantom feeding off of her fear as sustenance. She was a lizard, with a heart and a mind and the ability to respond to reason. “If Bella was really a traitor, she’d have said nothing when Haylee was about to fall into the trap. You were listening too. She was desperate for someone to listen to her; it was Haylee who dismissed the warning and got herself into the trap. Which is no fault of hers, but it isn’t Bella’s fault either.”

She remembered how Marlenka had instantly leapt forward and used her body like a wall against any other Defenders who might not have been able to slow down in time. A headache still radiated outwards from the moon on her forehead from when she thudded into Marlenka’s side. It was painful, but not more than it would have been if she’d tumbled into the net and got carried off ''with'' Haylee.

“Um… thanks for blocking off the pit so none of us would fall in it, by the way,” said Audrey.

Marlenka nodded curtly. “Look, I do what I can to protect the Defenders.”

“I know you do,” Audrey reassured her. “So please. We’re going to be there looking to bail Haylee out anyway-”

“And the alphas,” Marlenka cut in.

Audrey shuddered. “And my- and our owners.” For a moment she was just silent, praying to Mira that Loafie and Panda were still alive. She’d never seen Panda, Toxic and Cakepop’s owner, but the way both of them talked about him he was just as beloved by them. “We have to look for Bella just in case. There’s no real way to help us know whether she’s a spy or not right now, not before we can sit her down and ask her how she knew that trap was there. And she has to be alive and well for that to happen.”

Marlenka blinked. It was completely quiet for an uncomfortable number of seconds before she spoke again. “Fine. But we wake them up now, because the rest of the Defenders have had hours to sleep and we can’t leave Haylee to marinate in the phantom prison.”

“And Bella,” Audrey reminded her. “If she’s there. I hope she’s not, no matter the reason, but still.”

The red-and-gold lizard snorted, but she wasn’t frowning. “And Bella.”

==Chapter Thirty - Fading - Halo’s POV==
Just like the last night, Halo was shaken awake. “Up you come,” Marlenka said in his face. Her eyes met those of several other Defenders who were blinking their slumber away. “We’re going on an expedition.” She came over to the side of the grassy bank and rolled Big Bird over onto his back with her huge claws. “All of us together. Wake up, little soldier boy.”

“Thought he could soar,” Big Bird mumbled in protest, but he heaved himself to his claws and then shook himself out like a wet dog.

“We’ve got just one detour to make, and then we’re headed straight for the phantom fortress.” Halo was surprised to see Audrey making the announcement, her head high and alpha mark pulsing between her temples. “First we go back to the bunker and uncover our boomseed stores and blankets, as many as we can carry. There’s a party leaving right now of Defenders who want to retrieve them, so if you want to hop along, go ahead.”

''Blankets?'' Halo realized no one had any blankets with them, but he couldn’t recall why. ''Wait… why aren’t we sleeping in the bunker? What’s going on?''

“I’ll go,” Halo offered, raising his cream-and-teal tail in the air, although he still didn’t understand why the things he needed to bring back weren’t already here.

Audrey smiled when she saw him and nodded. “Thanks, Halo. See you when you get back.” Halo’s state of mind was too capricious to respond as he turned around and followed the group of Defenders back to the Jamaa Township barracks.

Several boomseed stores had been left covered in the earth, but looking between the shoulders of the crowd of lizards he was surrounded by as he returned to camp, Halo was surprised there were that many to get. He trotted along, looking for Vatra so that they could be side by side when it was time to advance on the phantoms, with a white blanket on his back; it felt familiar, but his brain couldn’t tell him why.

Marlenka and Audrey were sharing uncertain glances as they prepared the Defenders to march. Not many lizards were talking, but the ones who were sounded sleep-deprived and sad. “I hope we’ll be able to free Haylee,” murmured one to their friend. “I haven’t been able to free my owner Happy in the time that we’ve been here.” The friend was quick to agree.

Given the look on Marlenka’s face, she had heard the comment. She commanded the Defenders to silence themselves and remain still in the pre-march position they were currently in. “Everyone,” she began, pacing slowly up and down the line. “I get that it’s been a while since we last raided the phantom fortress… uh, yeah, it’s been two years, I’d say that’s a while. But the reason we haven’t been able to return yet is because we weren’t able to make up the power that was lost after that first attack, since a good portion of them resigned or just ran away.

“The fortress can be scary, alright? They’re always making changes and assigning guards in all these places so that no one can get in. But remember what you’re fighting for.” Marlenka stopped at the head of the line. “We’re not just besieging the castle for Haylee alone. It’s for her ''and'' the alphas ''and'' your owners, for those of you that had them. We’re launching an attack because we finally possess enough alpha power to have a realistic chance at getting inside those most closely guarded prisons.”

She looked at Audrey, and the purple lizard stepped forward. “And on top of that, more than having most of the alphas with us, we have ''you''. You care about freeing the real alphas so that Jamaa can have its most trusted leaders again, and you care about helping your owners get out of the clutches of the phantoms, who have been doing who knows what with them. You have passion and a want for a better world, and those are drives that no phantom can ever match!”

The Defenders cheered. Beside Halo, Vatra was silent and expressionless. Halo himself only registered the cheers with a clouded sense of hearing, stumbling as the row of lizards behind him moved forward and bumped into him. “Sorry,” he muttered absentmindedly, then moved his legs robotically forward in time with his comrades.

Vaguely he could hear some of them singing or chatting with one another as they went. Halo’s vision seemed to fluctuate; it felt like he was looking at where he was going from very far away, his perspective clouded with thick inky blots. At some point a migraine took hold of his head and burrowed deep roots into all reaches of his brain, so far down it felt like the pain bit the nerves in his claws and tail, too.

The landscape only darkened as the Defenders continued to march. The bright scales on Halo’s back already felt numb while white fell softly on the land. Ahead, Marlenka and Audrey still marched as lively as ever; on Audrey’s back was Wooyoung, who looked to be practicing his dual-elemental magic on anything he could pluck out of the snow on the ground.

Toxic was up near the front, too – there was no mistaking his black and highlighter-colored scales. Halo couldn’t remember anything else about him, though. Was he supposed to feel something about this lizard? As quickly as he’d spotted Toxic, though, the other Defender sped out of his brain as his headache pulsed like a strobe light.

By the time the Defenders stopped, Halo couldn’t even look at anything but the snow directly underneath him, its whiteness toned down by his own shadow. Anything else was too bright, including the rectangular flash of purple he managed to sneak a split-second glance at. It felt like someone had covered his ears with cotton balls and was driving a rough diamond through his head at the same time, but he did everything possible to keep standing.

Then the Defenders went on again with their march and the snow underfoot melted into patchy grass beside a path made of unsmoothed purple bricks, and Halo gave in to his fleeting ability to remain balanced before letting his vision be devoured by the pressing darkness.

==Chapter Thirty-One - Treason - Dragon’s POV==
Haylee didn’t say one word when Julie threw her into the prison cell. “And I’ll have some of my guards put on ''you'', leaf-face,” the phantom snickered, then slammed the barred door back into place. “Don’t try anything. We need you not dead so that you can partake in the most highly-anticipated fight in the entire fortress.”

She chuckled to herself and began to float away. Skip still rode along on her head and Dragon was about to follow behind them, but then Haylee did speak: “Will you at least tell me how I’m going to die?”

Julie squinted back at the pastel lizard. “Hmmmm, nah. But I ''will'' tell you that originally the general was going to have you fight your cute, fluffy little owner Kenzie, but the king liked the idea that ''I'' had in store much better. You’ll see when you see, ‘Defender.’”

Off again she went down the nearest spiral staircase, muttering about all the things she wished she could do to General Lido while Skip tittered his support. Dragon pulled his leg back from the doorway to the stairs. “I’m getting the guards off their shift, okay?” he shouted after Julie. She gave him no response, only a descending cackle that echoed up to the room with Haylee’s cell.

Haylee looked at Dragon curiously, but he wasn’t here for her. He raced up a separate staircase on the other end of the room, growling at a few phantom guards on his way to assure them he wasn’t a soft Defender. The fortress was a complicated labyrinth of prisons and empty rooms with craggy indigo walls, but there was a special set of cells reserved specifically for traitors, and he knew Julie would make the cruel joke of throwing Bella in there even though she knew he was lying.

Most of the cells were empty, the doors pushed aside or sealed off entirely. In one of the vacant ones there was an illustration of a phantom made on tattered yellow paper taped to the back – drawn in scrawl, yet given the helmet on its head, clearly the image of General Lido gripping the bars. Dragon guessed he never came down here to realize Julie was making a fool of him in every place possible.

“Bella,” he called out, and saw her at the end of the hallway. Her back was folded against the corner of the wall and a spider ran over her shoulder, but her bloodshot green eyes never so much as glanced its way. Her once-white sclera looked like they had been spit on by a container of strawberry jam.

“I’m sorry I lied to Julie,” he told her with all the honesty he could express. “I was trying to keep you safe.”

Bella lifted her head. “From what?” she whispered.

“Julie, the Defenders, I don’t know. I thought if I could convince her you were definitely on our side-”

“Why would you do that?”

“Because I don’t want to see you get hurt, Bella. I still wish you didn’t just leave on a whim like that.”

With some effort, Bella stood up, revealing the bruises on her elbows. “And ''I'' still wish you had nothing to do with Julie in the first place. You had that choice, and…”

“I see the mistake I made now,” Dragon said quietly. “But I don’t know how I’m going to fix that right this second. What matters most to me is that you don’t have to suffer with the Defenders.”

“I ''wanted'' to join them.” Bella’s voice cracked and she blinked away tears. “The phantoms can’t take Jamaa for their own under any circumstances. When I saw the Defenders at that battle… I know they lost, but they were so close to ''not'' losing. Why wouldn’t I have waited so long for the right moment to get out of this night terror of a home when all the gossip up until that point was about an all-lizard army whose power posed a real threat to the phantoms’ hold?”

Dragon stared at her, not knowing what to say. The two years that had passed since Bella’s escape felt too long and too short at the same time, but the hurt he had felt after she left had only exponentially worsened nonetheless.

“But it was all for nothing,” Bella went on, curling up into a ball again. Dragon suppressed a gasp at the much larger bruise on her back that was revealed. “They threw me out. I have nowhere that I can go.”

Dragon tilted his head. “They all threw you out? How did you stay there for two years if you had nobody?”

“Just one of the leaders. I didn’t have ''nobody'', I had… I had a friend who was a healer, and the leader who got captured was trying to protect me from- from the one who hurt me. And the moon alpha spent a lot of time training with me and making sure I was-”

“Moon alpha?”

Bella stared at him with shrunken pupils. “I… you didn’t hear that.”

“Oh, I did!” The light in the doorway was blotted out by the floating shape of Julie, a growling Skip clinging to her head. “Now, I don’t know what a moon alpha is, but I ''do'' know what an alpha is. And the ones ''we’re'' keeping have been very quiet and limited in their escape attempts. I figured there was something going on.”

The phantom shook her head at Dragon. “Well, I’m pretty disappointed in you. Good thing we’re already in the traitor prison, though, that’s a neat little convenience! Shame you’ll have to be locked up for the big battle… looks like those Defenders wanted to watch their scrawny little queen get shredded up after all.”

Dragon looked frantically at Bella. She stayed still and silent, mouthing to him: ''let them.'' With almost no time and fewer options, the green-and-gold lizard let Julie kick him into the nearest stall and snap the doors shut in his face.

“Got places to be,” she called behind herself as she headed back for the doorway. “Be good while I’m away.”

Both lizards were silent for almost a minute after she left, but Julie didn’t return. “They won’t send guards to watch you right now,” Bella said. “If the Defenders are really here, then the newest prisoners are bound to be the least of their concerns.”

Dragon grinned even though he knew she couldn’t see it from her own cell. “I like where you’re heading.”

“Thank Mira that phantom locks are unique. I still remember how to open one… you do too, right?”

He did. Phantom locks were one of the most common toys for fortress-born lizards, since they weren’t allowed to leave the fortress unless commanded to accompany a phantom party – and there was nothing else for them to play with. No one had ever bothered to stop lizards who spent their time solving them because it was just assumed they’d stay loyal to their tentacled keepers and never be on the wrong side of the bars. ''Well, I guess they were wrong. Maybe Bella can teach me more ways to prove it.''

Both of them were out of their cells in moments. “Where to now?” Dragon asked. He wasn’t used to taking the lead, having been conditioned to follow Julie’s orders at all times, but more than that, Bella looked to have a gleam of newfound confidence in her reddened eyes.

“I think that’s obvious,” she said. “We go meet the Defenders.”

==Chapter Thirty-Two - Fallen - Bella’s POV==
The two lizards raced down the stairs, the sound of exploding boomseeds spiking up the walls. “You tell me where to go and I’ll… I’ll do my best with the Defenders,” said Bella.

Dragon always hated how often he had been confined to the prisons, making sure nobody tried squeezing their way out as if there weren’t an entire command of half-asleep guards doing that already. But now thanks to that experience, he told her, he already knew every twist and turn it took to return to the throne of the phantom king.

Lizards and phantom guards were everywhere. The millisecond that Bella and Dragon had descended far enough down the stairs to get a clear view of what was going on, Bella had to yank Dragon back before an air-sailing boomseed could strike him in the eye. “They’re here all right,” he gasped.

“Stay here while I find Marlenka,” she ordered him with an authority rivaled only by the night she fled the fortress two years before. Her voice still quavered a bit, and her head remained down between her shoulders, but she saw trust in his nod and didn’t hesitate to leap off of the stairwell the second Dragon was out of sight again.

''Come on. Stand here any longer and you’ll be a pile of Bella dust.'' The purple lizard shifted her claws on the stair, her chest pushed forward like she was about to leap off. But her wings weren’t coming. ''Come on, come on, come on. It would be just my luck that my phantom wings fail me in the most important room of the phantom fortress, wouldn’t it?''

She thought of the moment she broke free of the lock. ''I thought I’d forget how to do it, but I didn’t. Julie underestimated me. And now it’s about to bite her where it hurts.'' Wings spread out from her back. Not to her surprise, they still carried the resemblance of phantom tentacles, but she refused to whine over that. There was a more crucial task she had to invest her focus in.

Bella dived down and landed in front of Marlenka, who jumped at her sudden and unannounced appearance. “Send at least two Defenders up the stairs right there,” Bella ordered, pointing to the same stairwell where she hoped Dragon was still hiding. “There’s no time to explain, but my friend is waiting up there and he knows the way to Haylee’s prison and how to get her out. He needs backup in case there are guards protecting her. As soon as you can!”

She took off again so as to avoid questioning from the red-and-gold lizard, and she noticed Marlenka glaring after her with uncertainty as she circled near the throne room ceiling – however, she had clearly learned to take Bella’s urgency seriously and soon yelled for Toxic and Cakepop to go to the stairs. Bella’s heart thumped in her chest. ''It’s working!''

The Defenders still held their own with as much power as before, but the phantoms seemed to be losing energy. In one corner of the room, Banana and Big Bird were fighting back to back against a ring of proto-phantoms that closed in on them. “Do the air thing, Biggie!” shouted Banana.

The brighter yellow lizard reared up on his claws and sucked in a huge breath of air before spitting it out in screaming song horrible enough to blast away their enemies. “Bang bang, SEAT OF MY CAAAAAR!!!!!!” No one dared challenge Big Bird after that.

Audrey was initially a struggle to find amid the capricious colorful chaos, but Bella found her at the very entrance arch from the outside of the fortress into the king’s own throne room where the battle took place.
