      <comment>/* Part II - Found */</comment>
      <origin>259897</origin>
      <model>wikitext</model>
      <format>text/x-wiki</format>
      <text bytes="43991" sha1="8pparldlgnns3ujilt3cmanme54twjq" xml:space="preserve">== Lost - A Tragedy Story by puppygrl ==

== '''''&lt;u&gt;&lt;big&gt;WARNING - not appropriate for anyone below 13&lt;/big&gt;&lt;/u&gt;''''' ==
'''This story contains the following potential triggers: Child abuse, character death, depression, drug use, attempted suicide, gore, gun violence, alcohol abuse, child neglection, homophobia, and bullying.'''

&lt;big&gt;Please take care of yourself and do not read this if you think any of the items above will trigger you. Additionally, this story may not be appropriate for 13-year-olds as well. Read at your own risk. This story is an intended tragedy.&lt;/big&gt;

&lt;big&gt;The mentioned homophobia is very brief. No slurs or foul language of any kind are used in this story. However, it still contains quite a bit of darker, heavier content.&lt;/big&gt;
 
'''A Note'''

''You never know when someone you love will pass away. And you may never get the chance to say goodbye.''

''And you may not be sure how to feel.''

''Know that it's okay to cry.'' 

''And love unconditionally.'' 

=== Part I - Frost ===



''"P- please, Mrs. Brooke. W- we haven't had anything to eat in w- weeks. We n-need food,"'' stammered a sickly fox.

''"You do not know what is wrong and what is right, child! I am the one who gives the orders around here!"'' snapped Mrs. Brooke, a heartless wolf.

''"Please... just one loaf of bread... We promise we won't bother you again... We're so hungry..."''  the fox implored, eyes overflowing with hope, with love. 

He truly believed that a being so far past redemption could feel empathy.

''"You are pathetic. You are useless. You have no right to ask me of anything!"''

A thin, wheezy rabbit murmured something softly into the ear of the youthful fox. The two exchanged a brief moment of peace, of hope. Mrs. Brooke was quick to interrupt them, her face having broken into a nearly psychotic grin.

''"You think you can fool me with your parlor tricks and your petty acting? You think your friendship will save you? Well, it won't! The world will take everything you have. Everything!''

''"And you cannot ask for anything back. You will only be neglected. Begging will only outcast you further, making you inferior.''

''"And once you have reached rock bottom, you will only fall more. Deeper into despair, into yearning, into hopelessness, into pain, into fury, into misery, into hatred.''

''"And that is what will destroy you in the end. Your love. Your desire.'' 

''"Everything that makes you human will make you a monster."''

Mrs. Brooke's voice cracked. A single tear trickled down her jaw.

Yet it was not enough for her to feel regret.

She towered over the shivering young fox, the very same pup that had dared to speak out. He pleaded and sobbed, desperate for mercy. The wolf arched her back, her eyes glittering with triumph.

Yet she was not satisfied: she unsheathed her claws, a greedy glint forming within her expression. She cackled maliciously as she scratched the child, again and again, yelling at him to count each time, to beg for her to stop, to swear he would never act out again. 

And through the night she scratched and scratched and scratched, cackling and cackling and cackling, as the innocent kit begged and begged and begged.

The light of the gibbous moon was not enough to acknowledge and balance the wolf's cruelty. Every morning, she rose again, only to scold and beat each child within her home of hopelessness. Every night, she terrorized the same pup and his rabbit friend.

Each child had no name, but in secret, they looked towards each other for support, for love.

And each of them had been awarded their own name.

Even in the face of violence and hate, they still believed that each and every one of them mattered, that each and every one of them should be protected and validated.

The first one to be named was the rabbit, and his name was Frost.

&lt;nowiki&gt;*****&lt;/nowiki&gt;

''"It's alright, I don't need to sit by the fire,''" the rabbit offered shyly.

''"If Mrs. Brooke catches us..."'' whimpered an anxious otter.

''"We're going to be OK. Just get some rest, all of you. I'll be on lookout,"'' the rabbit answered reassuringly.

''"But you'll be cold! I don't want you to get sick!"'' protested the little fox. 

''"Don't worry. I'm used to the winter time,"'' the rabbit smiled wistfully. ''"I've been here the longest, but I can handle it. I'll keep you safe. You should be more worried about yourself than me."''

''"That's not fair. You can't tell me to stop worrying. You're my best friend,"'' the fox sniffed, doing his best to look brave and strong.

The rabbit shook his head. ''"I want to do this. I want to protect you. Like I said, the cold can't hurt me."''

''"But she will,"'' the fox whispered meakly.

''"Please,"'' he added, ''"don't do this."''

''"I'm sorry. I don't want anyone else taking the blame,"'' the rabbit replied stiffly, his gaze then drifting towards the motionless body of a tiger gone limp. ''"Not again."''

The brave rabbit turned away from his friend, and faced the steel bars of the dungeon they were forced to call home.

''"It wasn't your fault,"'' the fox murmured.

''"I won't let it happen again. I'm going to face the cold,"'' the rabbit insisted boldly.

He rose, straightening his posture. ''"I'm not afraid of it anymore."''

The fox was taken aback. He loved his friend dearly, and wished him nothing but safety and comfort. And yet, the world does not always work that way. 

And so, the fox did all he could. He gave the rabbit the world: a name. 

An identity. 

''"I believe in you, Frost."''

&lt;nowiki&gt;*****&lt;/nowiki&gt;

Violet Brooke was not always cruel. Yet by the time Frost had been named, she had lost herself. In her own words, she had fallen past rock bottom, deeper into despair, into yearning, into hopelessness, into pain, into fury, into misery, into hatred.

She started her life plenty fortunate. Her family was not particularly wealthy, but they were at the very least happy. 

For a brief time. In the old days when Jake was still himself, carefree and humorous. When Sunny's smile lit up every room. When her parents were still together.

Her father was a clerk at Jam Mart Furniture. Her mother worked as one of several tailors in a small business. She had a younger sibling named Sunny, and an older brother named Jake. 

Jake was a senior in high school, and he made the first crack in the mirror.

On one side, you could see joy and laughter, excitement and passion, kindness and love. 

On the other, there was a void filled with pain. 

Jake had tested his parents many times. His father grew more and more impatient with him. His mother cried when she thought no one else was there.

His mother was crying because of Jake.

Jake snuck out of the house. Jake skipped school. Jake was failing all of his classes. Jake never asked for permission. Jake rarely showed up for dinner. Jake's best friend moved away. Jake wouldn't talk about his feelings. Jake trash-talked his parents and his teachers. Jake stopped playing with Sunny. Jake quit the football team.

Ever since third grade, he had wanted to play football. As an eight grader, he came to high school tryouts, and made varsity. 

He hadn't come out, but during his senior year, there were rumors that Jake had kissed a boy.

And the varsity football team was all boys.

And all of the boys didn't want a gay boy on their team.

So whenever he walked by, they shouted at him, whispered words in his ears, threw pencils and trash and food at him.

The captain of the team, Cameron, who had always been willing to do one-on-one practices with Jake, began to send him threats.

It started with texts telling him to keep his head down. Then notes in his lockers. Then the rumors.

Then Cameron got his other friends together and started chasing him. Every day, they chased him until he couldn't keep up, and they left him with a bloody nose and a hefty bruise.

So Jake got the message and quit football.

And soon enough, Jake quit everything else.

Then he started doing drugs.

And then one night, Jake came home for dinner. He had a bottle of beer and a knife.

He downed the whole thing in 10 minutes. He vomited all over the floor and laughed it off. Then he took the knife and thrust it down his chest.

Sunny was there the whole time, and she was terrified. But she grabbed the knife before it touched Jake and called for Violet.

Sunny was six years old.

That night, the mirror had cracked the first time.

And that night, everyone in the family was crying. 

But Sunny, Violet, and Jake had nowhere else to turn.

A week later, their mother was diagnosed with depression, and she had lost her job.

Their father stopped coming home for dinner, too. He had to work full shifts.

And every night, he came back more stressed, more exhausted, more annoyed.

Until one night, when he yelled and wouldn't stop yelling.

And Sunny heard it all.

But Sunny still smiled. Sunny still played. Sunny still dreamed. Sunny still tried.

So Violet lived for Sunny, because Sunny was the only person left in her family who still tried to live.

And Violet's father kept yelling. He yelled at his wife when she wouldn't get out of bed. 

But he wasn't encouraging her. He was destroying her.

He pushed her away.

When she was in a better position, she decided to move out. She founded her own business as a fashion designer and made a living by herself. A few months later, she filed for an official divorce. 

Her husband was devastated. He wrote mountains of letters and sent them all to her, begging for her to come back, apologizing for all his wrongdoings.

She never sent back.

She was happier without him.

Since he discovered this, he was determined to make things right for his children. 

He wanted to give them the happiness they deserved.

And so he got an office job. He worked long hours in the city and got more money for it. He spent thousands of diamonds on his children.

More toys for Sunny. Therapy and rehab for Jake. A garden and a book nook for Violet. 

And eventually, Jake got a little better. He quit drugs and spent more time with his sisters. 

But he still wouldn't touch a football, and he still got chased and bruised and called names. 

Jake's father thought he could buy each and every one of them happiness. So he worked for longer and longer, for more and more money.

But Jake got more and more stressed. He felt responsible for fixing his family. He felt terrible for what he put Violet and Sunny through. 

And each day, he struggled to not end his life, to give in to the voices that taunted him.

He kept talking to his therapist. His therapist said he needed other people to support him. He needed to keep pushing through. He needed to know he wasn't alone. He needed to make new friends and eat at family dinners.

Jake replied with the fact that his father stopped coming to family dinners.

And it was a problem Jake couldn't solve.

And so Violet tried to solve it. But she couldn't, either.

The only thing that held them together was Sunny.

Until one afternoon when Sunny didn't come home from school.

By then she was nine years old. She was still a phoenix, bright as ever, always energetic, always faithful, always optimistic, always passionate. 

She had a flame that never burned out.

Until her father received an email that there had been a school shooting.

Thirteen students had been killed.

He scrolled down the list.

''Austin Meyers. Leo Sanchez. Benji Takahashi. Claire Evans. Esperanza Basurto. Ruby Halls. Mack Taylor. Elias Fischer. Avery Campbell. Ailani Hale. Sam Lynch. Charlie Hansen. Sunny Brooke.''

He told Violet and Jake that Sunny was at a friend's house.

Violet and Jake found out in the morning when Sunny still wasn't back.

Violet yelled. Violet sobbed. 

Jake didn't know what to say.

Everyone was cracking.

Everyone was broken.

Then their father got laid off.

He told them it was a good thing. He'd make it one. 

Finally, they could spend time together. As a family.

But they ran out of money in a month. Jake and Violet didn't have jobs yet. 

Their father told them to stay inside. There, they would have shelter and meager insulation. They still had beds and furniture for comfort. He would try to find food for them.

When he came to the streets, he was denied. He held up a cardboard sign labelled ''please donate. anything helps.''

But no one helped.

He sat through the pounding rain and the booming thunder. 

He sat through the howling winds and the humid mists.

He sat through the beating sun and the flashing lightning.

He sat through the layers of frost withering him away.

Minutes turned to hours. Hours turned to days. Days turned to weeks. Weeks to turned to a month.

Still, no one helped.

He had lost his way home.

He starved to death shortly after.

Eventually, his grave was moved besides Sunny's.

At first, Violet visited them every day. 

Then Jake tried to start a new life. He moved away and applied to college. He got a job and got accepted as a student at Mira's Academy.

Violet was alone.

She never went to college. She never found a job. She didn't have any friends.

Instead, she stayed in her den and pretended she did.

She played with Sunny's toys.

She ran around with Jake's football.

She became the village psychopath.

One day, she decided to make the rumor true.

And that was the day she began working on her Orphanage.

And her Orphanage became a home of hopelessness.

It became a prison.

It became a torture chamber.

But she wouldn't stop, because she couldn't.

She had lost herself.

&lt;nowiki&gt;*****&lt;/nowiki&gt;

Frost stood in front of the fire, as he promised he would. He kept guard and was wary of each and every sound: the crackle of the campfire, each restless movement of the other  children, every single pawstep, even the sound of his own  breathing.

He did not breathe steadily. He knew his friend was right: If Mrs. Brooke caught him, he would be punished.

He was already hurt, though. And he knew it would hurt him more to see so many others in pain.

And he knew that if anything, he deserved it. He was not innocent.

Even if he may not have directly been responsible for the death of the tiger, he had at the very least contributed to it.

He remembered the day  as clearly as the sun shining in a cloudless sky.

A glimmer of hope. Tangible. Pink, green, blue, red, orange. Gems.

Gems meant food. Gems meant clothes. 

And that meant survival.

He scooped up the lot of them, a measly twenty-seven, the spare change of a single purchase. 

But those twenty-seven gems could be worth gold.

He told the tiger that he would get every single one for himself if he took the beating.

And the tiger accepted.

And the tiger took the beating.

And the tiger bled.

And the tiger pleaded.

And the tiger screamed.

''Help me, please.'' 

And Frost did not help.

But now, he would do what the tiger had done. 

He would not need gems, because now he knew that gems were meaningless.

The fox had given him so much more, and it was time to give back.

Frost had a plan to defeat Mrs. Brooke.

But Frost would, under no condition, ever be responsible for hurting another soul again.

Even one far past redemption.

If that meant he would suffer for it, so be it.

&lt;nowiki&gt;***&lt;/nowiki&gt;

Pawsteps echoed across the darkened stone floor. The twisted pathways within the Orphanage were all overgrown, torn apart by weeds and eroded by time and neglection.

The only living thing in the entire den was Mrs. Brooke´s garden.

Frost thought it must have been peaceful to sit there. He would have a pen and tell his story among lilies and daffodils, perhaps in verse. He would paint landscape upon landscape, each vaster and more filled with possibility than the next. He would dream while he was awake, and study while he was asleep.

He closed his eyes as the pawsteps drew nearer. He steadied himself, and focused on his breathing. 

He was blowing up balloons for the fox´s birthday.

The first one was shiny and red, and it would be in the shape of a dog, a pet that the fox had always wanted.

The beautiful vision dissipated, and Mrs. Brooke came to deliver the horrendous reality.

''¨What are you doing, you little rat?! That light is keeping me awake!¨'' She yelled, forehead scrunched up and eyes set ablaze, anger illuminating from every cell of her body.

''¨I´m sorry, ma´am. I was cold. I thought that the light could warm me up,¨'' Frost replied solemnly.

¨''How did you start a fire in the first place?¨'' She snapped back, bewildered and very clearly deprived of sleep.

''¨There´s wood, ma´am, and coal and stone,¨'' Frost answered cautiously.

She paused, looking through the dingy metal bars and into the rabbit´s eyes. Deep within them was Sunny, and even deeper was a younger version of herself, listening to Sunny´s make-believe stories.

''¨Oh. Yes. Very well then,¨'' she whispered, ''¨Go on.¨''

Frost hesitated. He was confused, surprised even. Had Mrs. Brooke so suddenly had a change of heart?

''¨Tell me a story, little rabbit. The longer it is, the better,¨'' Mrs. Brooke added thoughtfully.

''¨A... a story?¨'' Frost questioned, sure he had misheard her.

He decided he would. If he did, he might just live through the night.

''¨I... Well. Alright, then. I´ll tell you a story of my own.¨'' 

And so, Frost did. He told the story of his life.

It started with a foolish urchin, who ran around and made merry through mischief.

Then, the little boy threw a stone at a woman´s window, and the woman threw the stone back. 

And it hit the boy, hard. And the woman came running out, and said sorry immediately. But for many months after, she hurt him, again and again. 

And sometimes, the woman apologized. Sometimes, she did not.

Mrs. Brooke seemed to know, subconsciously, that she herself was being described. She did not seem to mind, either.

Then Frost told her of his first friend in the bleak and dreary world he had grown up in.

The fox.

And then Frost continued on, until he reached the present, and told her of his name.

''¨Frost,¨'' she whispered.

Her eyes flashed. She began to cry. 

''¨It was an unforgiving winter that killed my father.¨''

Her tears turned to frustration. To rage.

''¨It was you. A monster in disguise. Sneaking out for your revenge. You came, and you made me this. You weakened my defenses. You destroyed everything. YOU DESTROYED EVERYTHING!¨''

Frost had no time to react. Mrs. Brooke lunged at him, grabbing him, forcing him against the wall. She slammed his throat, again and again, onto the cold, hard brick. 

She snarled at the rabbit, swiping and slamming and slashing, bursting and burning on the inside, destroying herself as she killed the creature who had never truly killed her father, only reminded her of the inevitable truth: She was a monster.

She had made herself a monster.

She had watched herself become a monster.

She was made into a monster by a monster.

Yet that monster was not the boy named Frost.

It was the world.

&lt;nowiki&gt;***&lt;/nowiki&gt;

The fox woke up to hear screams. He had heard them before, from the innocent tiger. 

But they came from the rabbit.

They came from his friend.

They came from Frost.

The fox screamed, too. The fox pleaded, too. But it was no use.

When Mrs. Brooke was done, so was Frost´s life.

And she padded away in tears, murmuring to herself that one day, she would find betterment.

And the fox was alone.

And the next day, Mrs. Brooke brought all she had left: thousands of gems, given to the fox.

She had sold every last piece of the home she once had.

The fox never saw Mrs. Brooke again.

But he and the children were free.

Frost was meant to be free with them, though. 

But Frost was nowhere to be found.

== Part II - Found ==
''One Month Later''

The fox curled into a ball, lying half-asleep on a dusty orange mat. He had earned a day's rest, after his valiant effort to lead the other children to a new home. He had watched every one of them be welcomed by a loving family, no matter how weak or timid they were.

Except for himself.

So, he rested alone in the Pillow Room, trying not to get too caught up in his thoughts. Frost would've known how to comfort him. Yet Frost was no longer able to.

He couldn't help but wonder why he had not been adopted. Was it his appearance? Did his tattered old blanket and moth-bitten slippers deter joy from him? Was it the fact that he was caked in mud, as he had no soap, fur brush, or shampoo? 

Or was it his personality? Did he talk too much, or not enough? Did he constantly look upset or irritated? 

He fretted on and on, finding more and more problems with himself as day turned to night. Tears wet his eyes and cheeks as they slipped beneath his threadbare cloak. He was unable to make them stop, unable to find any positives within his life. 

He sat alone in the Pillow Room, wishing on stars he could not see. He knew his wishes were already lost, yet he could not bear to give up all hope so soon. And yet, he felt ready to.

''***''

''"Mama?"'' A soft, small pup whispered curiously.

''"Don't worry, honey. Mama's here. She'll keep you safe,"''  a female voice replied warmly.

''"I'll do my best,"'' laughed an arctic wolf. 

''"Thank you, Ember. This means the world to me,"'' the artic wolf added joyously, gazing dreamily into the eyes of a bright orange fox.

''"Mama?"'' repeated the baby, who reached out with an eager paw that met the older fox's.

''"We're both here,"'' Ember, the older fox, answered gently.

''"Two mamas... Yay!"'' the kit squealed happily, throwing its paws into the air as it fell into a world of dreams.

&lt;nowiki&gt;***&lt;/nowiki&gt;

The fox's eyes fluttered open. He found himself belly up, grinning and giggling. Yet his fit of glee was brief: for he soon realized it had just been a dream. There was no fox or arctic wolf greeting him.

But then: A shadow! A beautiful arctic wolf walked into the Pillow Room. She wore a dark purple flower crown, just like the one in his dream! 

Only, when she noticed him, she did not seem as excited as he was. In fact, she turned away within a split second, not even bothering to say hello. 

His lips curled into a frown once more. He wished she would return and wrap her arms around him, crying tears of happiness and jumping for joy, telling him how much she missed him and how much she loved him.

And there would a reason as to why she had left him. It would not be out of her own will. No, she was forced to.

And so, the little fox concocted a story.

"Forced to abandon her brave, strong, little boy, by none other than her own brother, who was secretly a spy for a dark and evil force... the Basilisks! 

"The Basilisks stole magic from innocent, gifted children. They were greedy, and wanted all the power for themselves! They were merciless, even draining life from the phantoms! They were considered unstoppable.

"Even the Alphas did not dare to touch the Basilisks! They feared that it would put their lives at risk, leading to the downfall of every creature in Jamaa! 

"But this little boy, a clever and persistent fox, was still determined to stop them. His mothers, a charming arctic wolf with dark purple and pale yellow fur, and a passionate neon orange fox with a dark gray underbelly, always warned him to be careful.

"They knew of his magic, and had no doubt that he was very powerful, and not only this, but he could easily control his powers. They did not want to discourage him, so they did all they could to give him a happy, wonderful childhood.

"And what a childhood he had! He made many merry memories over the years. And yet, on one fateful day, he heard a terrible BOOM from the floor below him, in his own home!

"Even though he was very brave, he was still afraid. He worried for his parents' well-being. And so he rushed downstairs, and immediately recognized his uncle, a rather introverted black-and-white wolf. 

"But, his uncle quickly turned into something else... 

"A monstrous entity, with leathery, pitch-black wings, a shining silver beak as sharp as a dagger, and from that beak of his came out tentacles... Dozens of them, like a squid's, spitting and hissing! And oh, the horrid thing's fangs- bloody and crooked they were, horrifying on their own!

"And rather than talons, it had claws like a panther's, and a barbed tail dripping venom! And then, with no warning, spikes burst from its chest, which lit up with a flame, and soon it was breathing fire, screeching, howling, destroying everything in its path!

"The fox was trembling with fear, but he could not let his mothers be killed by this horrendous beast! Shockingly, his mothers were fighting back- they hurled bursts of brightness at the gruesome monstrosity, coming in every hue! 

"He called out to his mothers, overwhelmed with anxiety. They promised him that they would do their best to keep him safe, that they would never let him go if they had a choice!

"But alas, they could not rid themselves of the Basilisk. He was far too powerful, absorbing each and every spell they cast. Yet along with this, the fox realized that he too could use magic!

"In the end, he remembered his mothers' warnings. ''Save your strength, Cinder.'' And so he did: He gave in. He told the Basilisk that he would follow suit, so long as his mothers were not hurt.

"His mothers were in tears. The Basilisk had been in the process of draining them. They were too weak to even get up. They swore that they would come back for their sunshine, their all.

"But at the time, they were helpless. The young fox was taken away, and the Basilisk brought no harm to him. However, he was quite foolish: He bragged on and on about how strong he was, and how he had been promoted to a general!

"In doing so, he gave the fox a very detailed description of his new chambers in all their glory, including the prison he was to be placed in. The fox did his best to not smile, to not give a single hint that he had taken note of every little detail.

"And so, when the fox was thrown into what seemed a hopeless jail cell, he quickly formulated an escape plan. There was a fifteen-minute period in which all guards reported to a certain area, far from the exit.

"He eyed the clock in the general's room. It was surprisingly easy not to be caught eavesdropping, as the general spent most of his time bragging to guards, hence unknowingly distracting them, or dozing off in his cushioned, curtained bed.

"First, the fox tested to see how easily the general was woken up. He kicked a pebble across his cell, and not a peep was heard from the general other than yet another loud snore of his own. 

"The fox nearly squealed in excitement. He was free of fear, and quite pleased with himself too. He slipped through the widely-spaced bars of his cell and padded across the cobblestone floor.

"Once he had reached the doors, he was still safe. The general didn't notice a thing! Afterwards, he burst out of the building, overjoyed.

"But he had been gone for much longer than he thought. Years had passed. Time was very different in the fortress of the Basilisks than in Jamaa.

"And now, the fox was afraid. He mourned the likely loss of his family and friends. He sulked his way to his old den, and found no one there.

"He was on the verge of giving up. But then, to his very pleasant surprise, he was powerfully embraced by both of his mothers, who were both well and overjoyed to see him!

"Since that day, the fox was the key to defeating the Basilisks. He kept his promise to stay safe, though: He always came back to his family with a smile, and his wonderful mothers would always insist on a celebration.

"The young fox grew to be a hero, but not just any hero, a happy one with a very happy family."

And that was where the story ended.

Not a soul was there to hear it.

No audience applauded.

But the young fox had felt free while he told his story. 

And so, he spent the rest of the night telling more. 

&lt;nowiki&gt;*****&lt;/nowiki&gt;

A tall, smiling snow leopard entered the Pillow Room. It was morning by then, and she had just arrived from her den in Jamaa Township. As she opened the old oak doors, a gust of wind burst into the room, bringing in loose petals of bright hues.

Sunlight dappled the room, warming the snow leopard's fur. As she strolled further across the room, she noticed a small fox that had fallen asleep on a large mat. Not wanting to disturb the little fellow, she paused and sat down as quietly as she could.

It was a strange silence, unlike any other she had previously experienced. She was desperate to fill it. Had her daughter been by her side, there would have been no doubt that the room would've been ''far'' too loud. 

The thought only amplified her anxiety, and she felt she was about to implode from the quiet when suddenly, the fox rolled to its side, yawning and stretching its legs.

As soon as she realized she was now standing and had been pacing around the room, she was embarrassed. She regretted the action, not having meant to disturbed the child in the room.

Wait... A child! Alone! He was shivering, clearly unhappy and in pain. He looked like he hadn't eaten in weeks, based on his ever-so-thin limbs.  This quickly captured the snow leopard. She would not let a child suffer like this!

She inhaled sharply and stepped forward. She feared that she would scare the little boy, as her appearance made many believe that she was a phantiminal, with her midnight purple spots and dark gray overcoat. 

She began to mutter words under her breath, trying to encourage herself. She was not a monster, and certainly not half-phantom. She was a kind, caring, snow leopard, who had never hurt a fly. 

But the voice in her head was too powerful: She had hurt someone. She had failed someone. Her own daughter, of all people.

Beads of sweat formed on her forehead, dripping down slowly. She began to shake her head, in a bewildered attempt to reclaim herself. She had done all she could that day. It was not her fault, no, it was fate, out of her control, unable to be altered.

Yet why, then? How could fate be so cruel? What purpose, what right did it have to take the life of a beautiful, clever, girl, one so filled with passion and love? 

Her daughter had meant so much to her: the falling stars she wished on as a child, the majestic mountains she had hiked in her more adventurous years, the thousands of diamonds she had made from her verse novels, the stunning view of the open blue ocean she had given up so they could move to a safer place, the sunshine that used to greet her every morning, the moon that lit up her midnight walks, and so much more.

Tears streamed from her eyes as she swallowed her confidence. Enough is enough: she had to be brave for this child.

"Hello there," she whispered hopefully as the fox, startled, jumped up in surprise.

"Oh! Ma'am! Er- Miss. I- I'm so sorry. I didn't mean to fall asleep. I was so tired. I'll- I'll leave now if I must," the fox replied nervously.

"Leave? Oh, oh no. But where are your parents? Shouldn't you be here with someone else? You're far too young to be wandering around alone,"  the snow leopard responded insistently. "Truly, it isn't safe!"

"Oh," the fox muttered, face turning grim. "Do you mean to take me away, then? To prison again?"

For a moment, the snow leopard stood there, shocked. She wiped the tears from her eyes. This couldn't be true. The child was ''imprisoned''?

"No! Absolutely not! Anyone your age shouldn't be out here all alone, much less imprisoned! And, well, you really don't look to be all that healthy. It's urgent that I get you back to your family as soon as possible. You'll need medical attention," answered the snow leopard.

"...Oh, yes. My family. I have two mothers, you know. One is a fox named Ember, the other is an arctic wolf. Have you seen either of them? Ember is bright orange and dark gray. She's a fox, just like me. And the arctic wolf, I can't seem to remember her name, but--"

"You... you don't remember?" the snow leopard interrupted, rather concerned.

"It doesn't matter," protested the fox. "I ''know'' I have a family. They're out there somewhere. And they love me very much."

"...You don't have a family," the snow leopard murmured softly.

The fox grumbled in response. Shortly after, though, he replied genuinely.

"No, but I had a dream that I did. It was quite pleasant, really. And in the dream, I had two mothers, an arctic wolf and a fox, and I was happy. And I fought Basilisks and I was a hero! Well, no, I made that part up. But it made me happy," the fox answered, a faint cheer in his voice.

"You're a storyteller?" the snow leopard asked wistfully.

"I would say so," the fox replied after a brief hesitation.

"You know," she added, "I used to write poetry."

"Poetry?! Oh, that's incredible! Show me, show me!" By then, the fox was jumping up and down, giddy with excitement.

"I wish I could," she sighed, "I haven't written anything in a very long time."

"Oh," the fox muttered, disappointed. 

But, he still had hope: the gleam returned to his eyes, and he sat up once more. "Maybe you could still try to teach me? Or, if not, we could learn together!"

However, the snow leopard changed the subject.

"Well, you should learn about grammar and writing essays first. Have you ever gone to school?"

"I don't think so," the fox responded, "I've heard of it, though. It's a big, tall, building, with lots of children and lots of books."

"Yes, it is indeed," smiled the snow leopard, "it's where all the children go to learn, so that when they're older, they can go to college or get jobs and live a life of their own."

"It's very important, too. Someone your age should definitely be attending school," she added firmly.

"Do you have any shelter? Anywhere to turn to?" The snow leopard questioned, eyes widening with worry.

"...Not really. I have some gems saved up, though," the fox murmured, suddenly ashamed of himself. 

He sniffed, and his eyes began to wet.

"No, no, please don't cry... You didn't do anything wrong. You just need someone to look after you," the snow leopard offered warmly. 

She took a deep breath, and steadied herself as best as she could.

"Would you like to come home with me? I can buy you some new clothes. I have a spare bedroom for you to sleep in. I can take you to school. I have a fire that will warm you and toys for you to play with. 

"And plenty of stories, too! I have seven books of bedtime stories that I can read to you at night. And I'll cook you meals, too, and give you presents for your birthday and the holidays. I'll always take care of you, and I'll do my best to keep you safe," the snow leopard finished passionately.

And the fox, for a moment, was quiet. And then, a single tear rolled down his snout. And then his eyes gleamed once again. And he began to jump for joy once more, screaming ''yes, yes, yes!'' so many times that it made his throat sore, but now, he would finally have someone to take care of him.

Though they hadn't made it official on that day, in their own way, they had. The loving snow leopard and curious fox became mother and son.

The fox had been found.

&lt;nowiki&gt;*****&lt;/nowiki&gt;

''Two Weeks Later''

The snow leopard grinned from ear to ear, finding herself to be much happier while taking care of the fox. She had buried her sorrows for years, only to let them all out in tears the night before she had found him, a beacon of hope, a sign from Mira and Zios that not all was lost. In fact, she was so filled with glee and anticipation that she had woken up at three in the morning to do something very special for the little boy.

She did her best to be quiet, and frankly, it ''was'' a strength of hers; her daughter had always been the one to fill the silence. Still, though, she was at the very least patient, and tried to turn her timid tendencies into a gift: That was what she had done with her poetry.

And after two weeks of taking care of the young fox, she was determined to show him that she could be a good mother, that she ''was'' a good mother. She thought of how excited he had been when she brought up having written poems in the past. And so she inferred that he would be ''overwhelmed'' with joy if she presented him with not just any poem, but a poem depicting how much he meant to her, how deeply she cared for him.

As she sat at her desk at the very break of dawn, she struggled to find those words, though. She barely knew this child yet. But she hated to see an innocent kid without any support, without any love. She found it heartbreaking that he had ''dreamed'' of his parents, ''pretended'' he had a family like having a family was the same thing as having a pet dragon. 

Impossible. 

Yet as a writer, she had to consider that impossible things were just a prompt. "What if" was a simple, two-word phrase that could change the world in a matter of seconds. But as a person, she couldn't live with her head in the clouds. As a person, she was meant to fit in, she was meant to be average, she was meant to normal.

How was she meant to teach a child all of those things? Those unspoken rules of society that she personally accursed, but knew that so many followed like a religion? 

But she didn't want such a creative boy to be restricted so early on. She knew that limiting someone could do more harm than good. 

But what would happen when she let the boy believe in superheroes and Basilisks and unicorns and dragons? What would happen when someone squashed those beliefs, those ''dreams'' of his?

How could she handle the misery of someone so young, so vulnerable, so dangerously curious, when she couldn't sort out her own grief?

She had always known that love was a sacrifice, that loving someone meant being hurt when they were,  that loving someone meant always wanting to be closer to them, that the stronger such a desire was the more it stung when all of it, so close, so possible, so ''almost there'', so close to once-upon-a-time, be ripped out from right underneath you.

The smooth, carpeted floor you had slept on, read on, written on, played on, smiled on, laughed on, dreamed on-- replaced with infinite nothing. Every memory of it stained with darkness. 

She remembered the feeling so vividly.

The days when she wouldn't get out of bed. When she felt too numb to even cry. And when at long last she had pushed everyone in the world who had loved her away, when she believed that her presence ailed them, when she felt a burning pressure that she could remove such pain by removing herself, by ending the cycle of loss she had unintentionally triggered.

And yet, in one of her first novels, a memoir of her middle school and high school years that she had hidden so far away, she had questioned whether one's intention mattered at all.

And that was what had ultimately broken her. 

Herself.

How was she meant to protect a child from such invisible demons? How was she meant to cradle him, to lie and say that all would be well soon, when she knew that the opposite was the truth? How could she keep him from doing the same awful things she had, and keep him from thinking those terrible, terrible thoughts?

No, she could not write a poem about love, not when she still struggled to find it for herself.

&lt;nowiki&gt;***&lt;/nowiki&gt;

The young fox woke up very early, though for him, it was the regular time. By 4:00 AM, he had changed out of his pajamas, made his bed, brushed his teeth, and bathed. Excited for his first day of school, he took little care in the tying of his shoes, sloppily shoving his paws into them then rushing down the hall to find his new mother.

To his shock, she was asleep in her own room, clearly not even noticing his presence. He decided that it would be impolite to awaken her (even though he believed it was an appropriate time to), so he trotted off to the kitchen, leaving the door open in the hopes of her waking up and making breakfast for him.

Upon his arriving at the kitchen, he realized that he had no idea what to eat or how to cook. He had never seen a refrigerator or an oven in his life, and was extremely confused.

''What are all of these machines?'' He thought to himself uncertainly.

Nervously, the fox approached the stovetop, accidentally bumping into one of its knobs- and lighting a burner. ''Flash!'' The fox jumped back, stammering in fear.

His immediate instinct was to call for help, but he bit his tongue in reluctance, worrying that he would bother his mother or be seen as weak and cast away. So the innocent kit searched the kitchen, desperate for something to douse the fire: A spatula, a teapot, a seder plate, a peeler, a wooden spoon, a frying pan, a colander, a bread knife...

No, no, no. None of them would work. The fox began pacing, his anxiety increasing-- the fire didn't appear to be growing, but what if it started to do so suddenly, and the entirety of the kitchen was burnt to the ground all because of his indecisiveness? Flustered, he growled, walking even faster, batting at the cabinets, hopping up and down to the reach the shelves, only to find himself more and more frustrated.

The wood floor of the hallway began to creak, and a shadow cast overhead. Had someone broken in? Was he about to be killed? The fox staggered backwards, whimpering in fear, and pushed back a cabinet that he had opened.

"What's all of this ruckus?" the shadow asked drowsily, shifting in the darkness.

"I- Please don't hurt me! I'm- I'm trying to douse the fire!" The fox exclaimed, jabbing a claw at the stovetop.

Then, the shadow stepped into the light. It was no thief. It was the snow leopard. His mother.

"I'm not going to hurt you," she said softly, walking slowly towards him. "Are you alright?"

"I- I- the- the fire. It just- it came out of nowhere! I'm s- sorry, I didn't know what to do-" He started anxiously.

For a moment, the snow leopard turned towards the stovetop in confusion- then, she saw that the burner was on, and laughed to herself. "That's nothing. It's just the oven. See the silvery knob? If you turn it or bump into it, it will tell the stovetop- with these burners- to light a fire."

"...Oh," he murmured embarrassedly, "Whoops."

She proceeded to show him how to turn the stove off, smiling politely all the while. A part of her, though, was scared- How could a child be so fearful and know so little? 

The snow leopard leaned closer, her vision blurring as she crossed her eyes- she blinked several times, still appearing slightly confused. "...You've nothing to apologize for. You just haven't used an oven before. Although... Why are you all dressed up?"

"School," he answered, his voice a whisper, "Was I not supposed to?"

"Oh! Well, school isn't on weekends. Only during the weekdays. Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. Today is Sunday, so there's no need to get up..." she paused, glancing at the clock, her mouth widening before she continued- "''This'' early."

"S- Sunday? But I don't see any sunlight," the boy replied questioningly. "That can't be right."

"You don't know your days of the week?" she inquired, a bit surprised. 

"I've never even heard of Sunday," he responded honestly. 

"My," the snow leopard muttered, "Well, I... I suppose I ought to teach you then."

"Yes," the boy nodded eagerly, "Please! I'd love to start school early. That way, I'll be smarter than all the other kids."

She swallowed, trying to stop herself from saying ''I'm not so sure about that,'' and ended up not replying at all. She plopped down in a chair, wincing at the realization of her aching back, and somewhat hesitantly patted the stool next to her, motioning for the little kit to sit besides her.

Shortly after, the kit leaped up onto the stool and sat down too. He wagged his tail energetically, looking up at the snow leopard with big, starry eyes that reminded her of the moon, which had just recently faded away. 

"Alright," she started with a sigh, "There are seven days in each week..."</text>

  <page>
    <title>Tears</title>
    <ns>0</ns>
    <id>162996</id>
    <revision>
      <id>259460</id>
      <parentid>259456</parentid>
      <timestamp>2024-01-10T01:17:32Z</timestamp>
      <contributor>
        <username>Puppygrl</username>
        <id>46410937</id>
      </contributor>
      <comment>Adding categories</comment>
      <origin>259460</origin>
      <model>wikitext</model>
      <format>text/x-wiki</format>
      <text bytes="3461" sha1="dsdkdlqqnxbi6p5n43y9btomcay6cj9" xml:space="preserve">My take on the original origin story for phantoms.

== Tears ==
It was destined for Mira to fall in love with Zios. She had no choice. From the moment he breathed life into her form and very soul, she was his, like the grass, and the trees, and the sunlight whose rays graced every corner of Jamaa, no matter how deep or hidden. He was the center of the world, the source of all of her wonder. Perhaps she loved him because he was her creator, and he had willed it so. Or because she had truly gained an attachment to him, the only other being whose mind was remotely in likeness to hers.

He taught her everything. Once, they landed in a forest of his. The trees were packed together so closely that their branches were hugging and overlapping with one another, creating a blanket of leaves that shadowed the ground beneath. It was dark, and strange, to not feel the sun. But Zios comforted her with the glow of his presence and showed her how to grow the trees, from seed to sapling to a behemoth reaching for the sky. It was his gift to her: an aptitude for growth, for life, for healing. It was her purpose. She was to be the gardener of Jamaa.

Seasons passed, and all was well, for Zios was with her. He was kind, patient, and loving. He shared all that he was and all that he had with Mira, and she did the same. There were no reservations or secrets between them. They simply were. It was a pure and sweet love, a true, unbreaking one. Or so Mira had thought.

There came a day that she awoke in her garden, absent of Zios' presence. His aura, normally calming and warm, was not there. She spread her great wings and leapt into the air, soaring over the lands he had spent so long molding and cultivating into perfection, but she could not find him. She flew and flew, and even dived into his rivers and seas, but he had not gone for a swim. When night fell, Mira had resigned herself to the truth. Zios had left her.

She laid alone in the forest where he first showed her how to grow. He had not said a word about leaving. She did not understand why he left her. Her soul ached, longing for its other half. There were the animals that she loved dearly, but none of them could understand her half as well as Zios did. Why would he create her with a mind so distant, so imperceivable to anyone but him, only to leave her alone? Even with all of the intelligence Zios had given her, she could not find the answer.

Mira was utterly alone. And for the first time, she wept.

Her tears collected in pearlescent drops in the corners of her eyes. They surprised her - she had never experienced them before. What strange wetness, she thought, running down her cheeks.

And the more she turned over Zios' departure in her mind, the less sad she became. She felt something else for the first time - anger!

What right did he have, to leave her behind? How crude and egotistical! How crass!

The tears that fell from her eyes were laden with her potent mixture of grief and anger. As they fell, they grew heavier, until they landed on the ground as clumps of oil-slick bile. And as more tears came, they dropped into the clumps, until they grew, and gained a conscience. A conscience of fear, anger, and betrayal. The first phantoms rose from Mira's tears. And when she finally stopped her crying, they had already left, gone into the shadowy depths of the forest where they hid easily.

A godless age had begun...
[[Category:Jamaa history]]
[[Category:Fantasy]]</text>

      <format>text/x-wiki</format>
      <text bytes="3022" sha1="0l76qc3wcepmps42av0vqdutovu6vsb" xml:space="preserve">In the dimly lit world of Animal Jam, there lurked a mysterious figure known only as EntityReturns. His presence was unnerving, for he communicated solely in Morse code, his cryptic messages haunting the game's chatrooms. His wolf, a sinister creature, bore a jet-black coat with a blood-red swirl, its eyes piercing white beacons in the darkness.

Equipped with a chilling ensemble, EntityReturns wielded a spectral blue sword, donned a spectral police hat, and adorned diamond-encrusted gauntlets and tail armor, marking his ominous aura.

Whispers spread that EntityReturns had hacked two unfortunate users, Arcticskys and Wingedfire, who had vanished from the game without a trace, their absence stretching beyond 30 ominous days. The community shuddered as they wondered what sinister fate had befallen them.

But EntityReturns was not finished. His eerie focus turned to a new victim, the unsuspecting Sassy2092. The air grew heavy with apprehension as players caught glimpses of his shadowy figure stalking the virtual realms, his intentions shrouded in malevolence.

Rumors circulated of bizarre sightings, of a ghostly wolf with eyes like stars and a figure draped in diamond-encrusted darkness. Whispers of Morse code messages that seemed to beckon, promising secrets or foretelling doom.

As Sassy2092 logged into the game, an unsettling sensation crept over her. Strange occurrences plagued her every step, the once bright and cheerful world now tainted by an unshakable sense of dread. EntityReturns had woven his web of fear, ensnaring her in a nightmare from which she could not awaken.

The legend of EntityReturns grew, a specter haunting Animal Jam, a tale of hacked accounts, vanished players, and a looming threat that lingered in the digital shadows. And amidst the game's innocent facade, the unsettling question remained: who would be next to fall under the chilling influence of EntityReturns?

In the heart of Jamaa Township, nestled within the cozy confines of the pillow room, whispers circulated of a shadowy figure, a presence that seemed out of place amidst the whimsical comfort of the space. Witnesses spoke of glimpses, fleeting and eerie, of a spectral wolf with eyes like stars, and a player draped in diamond-encrusted darkness.

Some claimed to have spotted EntityReturns, his Morse code messages echoing through the room, weaving an unsettling tapestry of cryptic warnings and chilling prophecies. Others dismissed these accounts as mere fabrications, yet a lingering unease settled over the once cheerful gathering place.

Players hesitated to linger too long in the pillow room, a sense of foreboding tainting the air, as if the very fabric of the game had been tainted by EntityReturns' ominous presence. The legend of the enigmatic figure grew, his influence casting a pall over the once joyous space, leaving players to wonder if they were truly alone in the room or if something sinister lurked just beyond their field of vision.

  <page>
    <title>Letters of The Komodo Brothers</title>
    <ns>0</ns>
    <id>163002</id>
    <revision>
      <id>259754</id>
      <parentid>259540</parentid>
      <timestamp>2024-03-27T04:43:07Z</timestamp>
      <contributor>
        <username>SuperTapirWoman</username>
        <id>51711888</id>
      </contributor>
      <origin>259754</origin>
      <model>wikitext</model>
      <format>text/x-wiki</format>
      <text bytes="5853" sha1="2pjjk4wjsysgir4cxu21fqqp3e9mhva" xml:space="preserve">'''''Warning: This page belongs to SuperTapirWoman and &lt;u&gt;her only.&lt;/u&gt;  Any vandalism will not be tolerated.'''''

'''Page under construction!''' 
[[File:Letters of the Komodo Brothers-Volume 1.jpg|center|thumb|Elm is the green one, and Admiral is the orange one]]
''The tale of two brothers about relationships, danger, and chickens.'' 

'''Letters of the Komodo Brothers''' is a series of posts that line up to create a story of two Komodo dragon brothers named Admiral and Elm. Admiral is a brave, nerdy, and playful Komodo brother with a  goal to help find the Komodo dragon heartstone and Elm is his rude, arrogant, yet fatherly and hard-working older brother. There is one volume so far, which focuses on the start of Admiral’s journey and Elm’s farm.

== Plot overview ==
Links to chapters are under construction. Please go to AJPW wiki, go to search and search up “Letters of the Komodo Brothers”, click posts, and you should be able to view them! 

=== Volume One ===
Admiral has began his great journey to explore Jamaa and uncover its secrets. His brother, Elm, wants to pursue a career in farming, but since his sister who he cannot live with due to family issues already claimed the original Orangeclaws farm, he relocates to Canyons Pathway and marries Dove Daisyflower. On the northwestern side of Jamaa, Admiral explores and eventually takes his round back to Coral Canyons, where he gets into a bar fight with a  rugged camel. Elm is utterly annoyed by the mass majority of his discoveries in his letters, so he sends back oranges and family photos back to bribe him to stop writing down his discoveries.

However, trouble strikes Elm’s farm and also, when a maniac customer asks for some things, he accidentally locks himself in the closet, along with the crazy man. Suffering from little food, he demands Admiral’s help, but it seems Admiral’s response came off more careless than it was supposed to be. Elm begins his memoir, and although the broken family ties, he plans to forgive Admiral for both their actions.

== Characters ==

* '''Admiral Orangeclaws:''' A eight-year-old (24 years in human years) Komodo dragon explorer who had his venom glands removed when he was young for surgery. Admiral has a nerdy yet brave personality with a playful tone of voice. He isn’t afraid of bar fights or battling phantom bears, making him a born leader. The lizard helped discover the corvace fox heartstone.
* '''Elm Orangeclaws:''' A eight-year and two months old Komodo Dragon and the brother of Admiral. Despite his rude and aggressive attitude, he is kind and protective to his brother. As the husband of a nervous farmer, he has to do tons of farm work, but he doesn’t mind so. Contrary to belief, Elm is not an expert at marketing, nor does he know how to deliver mammal offspring like stereotypical farmers.
* '''Dove:''' The caring wife of Elm. She is described as fidgety, worried, and nervous, but determined and intelligent. 
* '''Juniper Frillyruler:''' Admiral’s travel partner. Although she is fidgety and slow, she can help others due to her knowledge of the medical field.
* '''Avalon:''' The owl alpha. They are brave, knowledgeable, and willing like an alpha can be.
* '''”Horse Dude”:''' A nonsense horse with a barking voice who doesn’t know simple things like ukuleles (consuming one), paper (swordfighting a jar with a sheet), and spiders (thinking three were Barbie dolls). 
* '''Bear:''' A fast and loyal yet paranoid grizzly who speaks fluent Spanish. He understands English perfectly, but usually speaks Spanish under choice. 
* '''Duchess Orangeclaws:''' The fussy nine-year-old (28 in human years) older sister of Admiral and Elm. She and Elm always squabbled, leading to separation for good in their adult years. However, Duchess is quite helpful when packages are mixed up.
* '''Cowboy Camel:''' A drunk and violent camel who shot Admiral once in a bar fight. 
* '''Poshmoon Jr. Greenivy:''' A kind-hearted, friendly yet combative crocodile who rediscovered the Komodo dragon heartstone. He is excellent at explaining things, but has a terrible childhood. From bullies to his father overworking to the war happening within Reptile Forge, the explorer has some trauma. 
* '''Baroness Bluecloud:''' A jammer who Admiral once had a crush on. They have yet to make an appearance.
* '''The Orangeclaws:''' 25 children who are the offspring of ‘Father’ and ‘Mom’ excluding Admiral, Duchess, and Elm. Only Elm and Admiral’s batch has known names. 
* '''‘Father’:''' The presumably deceased father of the Orangeclaws children who was/is generous and helped save Admiral’s life in some dangerous situations. Since Duchess “claimed the farm”, it is a possible hint that she earned inheritance from her parents who are either deceased or retired.
* '''‘Mom/Mother’:''' The presumably deceased mother of the Orangeclaws children who was/is an intelligent, cautious, and satire woman with a career of a farmer. Since Duchess “Claimed the farm”, it is a possible hint that she earned inheritance from her parents who are either deceased or retired.

== Trivia ==

* Most of the names are AJ animal names.
* The story’s rising action is heavily inspired by Carl Hiassen books, and the story is sort of based off Super’s own experience, while mixing a bit of her friend’s in.
* Super has joked that Admiral’s theme is “I Won’t Back Down” by Tom Petty because of his personality and a sort-of version of herself.

== Reception ==
The series was claimed by users for “rising the triumph of action into the calm, serene side plot of brotherhood and family history”, but also sometimes criticized for censored language.
